d.crumb: 50. The Ritual of the Controlling Burned Offering and Teaching on the Abodes of the Grounds and So Forth

f.d: 50. The Ritual of the Controlling Burned Offering and Teaching on the Abodes of the Grounds and So Forth
de nas sbyin sreg cho ga ni/ / nges par dbang du byed 'gyur ba/ / yang dag cho ga gang gis ni/ / myur du dngos grub thob 'gyur bshad/ /
Next, through the ritual of the burned offering You will definitely accomplish control. And it is taught that if the ritual is done correctly Realization will quickly be accomplished.
go mAng sa ni myos byed bsre/ / lag pa g.yon pas sbyin sreg byas/ / sangs rgyas kyang ni dbang 'gyur na/ / phran tshegs mi ni smos ci dgos/ /
If you mix beef with intoxicants And perform the burned offering with the left hand, The buddhas will definitely be subjugated; [therefore,] What need is there to mention an insignificant person?
kha chu so shing dag dang ni/ / de bzhin rang gi lus mnyes pa/ / myos byed ming dang bcas pa yis/ / khams gsum dag ni dbang du 'gyur/ /
The three realms will be subjugated With saliva, tree splinters, and Likewise what is pleasing to one’s own body as well as Intoxicants together with the name of the [victim].
zla mtshan gyi ni khrag dang ni/ / zos nas rlon pa'i zas dag dang / / mi yi skra dang ldan pa yis/ / mod la 'gugs par 'gyur ba yin/ /
In an instant they will be summoned with Blood from the sign of the moon[102] and Food moistened by eating Together with human hair.
rang gi lus las skyugs pa 'am/ / mkhas pas rang skras sbyin sreg bya/ / nim pa'i shing la rab sbyar na/ / mod la dbye bar 'gyur ba yin/ /

In an instant they will be separated by The adept performing a burned offering with Vomit from his own body And his own hair and through Performing the burned offering With the burning wood from a nimba tree.
mnyam par bzhag pas d+ha dur me/ / yungs mar tshan der bsgres pa yi/ / bya rog gshog pas sbyin sreg byas/ / 'phral du 'chi ba'am skrod par 'gyur/ /
[He] will immediately be killed or expelled With meditative stabilizations. In a fire [made from] datura, Mustard seed oil, and a wing of an aged crow, Perform the burned offering.
nyal dang ma nyal 'dug pa'am/ / zas dang sbyor ba sogs rnams la'ang / / mkhas pas rtag tu zlo byed na/ / de la bgegs ni yod ma yin/ /
If the adept always recites the mantra, Obstructions will not exist for that one While sleeping, not sleeping, Eating, [engaged] in union, and so forth.
wa yi sha yis bsregs blugs brgyas/ / yang dag bsregs blugs byed pa'i mi/ / de ni zla ba gsum rjes la/ / rigs kyi dbul ba 'jig par 'gyur/ /
After three months The poverty of his lineage will be destroyed By one hundred sacrificial offerings of fox meat, And by the one who performs the sacrificial offerings properly.

sha chen dag gis la la zhig / myos byed ldan pas sbyin sreg byed/ / brgya rtsa brgyad kyi bar du ni/ / sgrub pa po ni thun gsum byed/ / ma lus sa rnams spyod pa dang / / zla ba drug gis dbang du 'gyur/ / tshim 'gyur mkha' 'gro ma de la/ / rgyal srid ster bar gdon mi za/ /

In all places where one performs the burned offering With the great meats and intoxicants Up to one hundred and eight [times], All those places where the practitioner has performed [That burned offering] during the three periods For six months, will be subdued. That will satiate the dakinis, who will Undoubtedly give him a kingdom.

lha rnams thams cad bsgoms nas ni/ / thun gnyis bar du sbyin sreg byas/ / rang gi lus ni de nyid kyis/ / mkha' la 'gro ba nyid thob 'gyur/ / go mA yu dang sha chang gis/ / phyi dang nang gi sbyin sreg bya/ /

By meditating on all deities while Performing the burned offering during the two parts of the day, You will obtain [the ability] to travel in the sky With your own body. With jackal meat and wine Perform the outer and inner burned offering.
myur du de yi lag tu 'gyur/ / dngos grub thams cad rab tu 'jug /
This will quickly bring to hand An engagement with the best attainments.

sngags kyi bzlas brjod mtshan mo bzlas/ / yul 'khor yang ni 'gugs par byed/ / de ltar nyin re byas na ni/ / rgyal po nyid du de byed 'gyur/ / 'di las rab mchog gzhan dag ni/ / 'jig rten gsum na yod ma yin/ / rnal 'byor chen po rang dgas 'chi/ / sna tshogs gzugs ni 'dzin cing rol/ /

By reciting the mantra at night The surrounding area will be summoned. If you do this everyday You will also become a king. There is nothing more supreme than this in the three worlds. The great yogi’s own death will be as he pleases And will manifest in a variety of forms.
bil ba de bzhin pa la sha/ / u dum bA ra nyid dag ni/ / sbyin sreg 'bum byas myur du ni/ / nor gyi bdag po chen por 'gyur/ /
If one performs one hundred thousand Burned offerings with wood-apple (bilva), a palasha tree, And udubvara, one will Quickly become a lord of great wealth.[103]
go mAng sa dang myos byed bsre/ / rgyal srid 'dod pas sbyin sreg bya/ / rnal 'byor dbang phyug mnyes byas na/ / dbul po nyid du ga la 'gyur/ /
With mixed beef and intoxicants, The burned offering should be done by one who desires a kingdom. If pleasing the powerful yogi How could one become poor?

go mA yu ni bsreg byas pas/ / ci bde bar ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / go mA yu yi sbyin sreg gis/ / myur du nor bdag mnyam par 'gyur/ / brtul zhugs gtsang sbra med na yang / / bstan pa'i dngos grub thob par 'gyur/ /

By burning jackal [flesh] What [you desire] is easily obtained. By offering jackal [flesh] You will quickly become a lord of wealth. Even if you don’t observe the conducts purely, You quickly obtain the realizations of [this] teaching.

lhag pa'i tshe dang kuSh+maN+DaM/ / mut+ga mA Sha tsa na ka / sbrang rtsi gtsigs ma ske tshe dang / / khyim gyi ta ma la 'dab blangs/ / kha bcing bar ni 'gyur ba yin/ / ci rung spyod pa'i rnal 'byor pa/ / gang du dga' ba der gnas so/ /

To extend one’s life take Wax gourd,[104] chickpea, Honey, husks, mustard grain, And the limbs of a tamala tree, And bind one’s mouth. The yogi will enjoy one’s desires And abide on the Joyous [ground].[105]
OM VAJRA BEROTZANIYE HUM HUM PHAT SÖHA[106]

de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ / rnal 'byor ma yi sa dang gnas/ / he ru ka dpal rgyu yan lag / thams cad brtan g.yo'i bdag nyid can/ / gnas ni rab tu dga' ba'i sa/ / de bzhin nye gnas dri ma med/ / zhing 'dir 'od byed shes par bya/ / nye ba'i zhing ni 'od 'phro ba/ / ts+tshan+do ha ni mngon 'gyur nyid/ / nye ba'i ts+tshan+do sbyang dka' ba/ / 'dus pa ring du song ba yin/ / nye bar 'dus pa mi g.yo ba/ / dur khrod legs pa'i blo gros nyid/ / nye ba'i dur khrod chos kyi sprin/ / shrI he ru ka gzhung spyod pa'i/ / 'di ni nang gi bdag nyid sa/ / pha rol phyin bcu sa rnams ni/ / rnal 'byor ma yi brda yi skad/ / mtho ris sa steng sa 'og tu/ / dpa' bo'i yan lag brtan g.yo'i bdag / pul+lIr la sogs gang bstan pa/ / phyi nang bdag nyid can du gnas/ / dpal ldan khrag 'thung rgyal po che/ / 'dod pa kun gyi dbang phyug gtso/ / kun tu phyag dang zhabs ldan zhing / / thams cad du ni spyan zhal dbu/ / kun tu thos ldan 'jig rten na/ / thams cad g.yogs te rnam par bzhugs/ / de nas dngos grub bsgrub bya ba/ / bsam gtan ldan pa'i sems kyis te/ / sgrub pa po la phan pa'i phyir/ / gsang ba'i de nyid gsungs pa yin/ /

And then, further explanation of The grounds and abodes of the yoginis: The limbs of Heruka’s body are The nature of all things stable and moving. The seat is the Very Joyous ground, Likewise the adjacent seat is the Stainless, This field is the Illuminating, The close-place is the Radiant, The tsandoha[107] is the Manifest, The close tsandoha is the Difficult to Overcome, The gathering place is the Gone Afar, The close gathering is the Unshakeable, The charnel ground is the Good Intelligence, and The close charnel ground is the Cloud of Dharma.[108] Through the teaching and practice of Shri Heruka The grounds abide within oneself. The grounds of the ten perfections are in The symbolic language of the yoginis. In the heavens above, on the earth, and below, The limbs of the hero are the nature Of all things stable and moving; Revealed as Pulliramalaya and so forth, They are [both] the inner and outer abode of oneself. The great king, the Glorious Drinker of Blood, The principal lord of all desires, [He] is everywhere, in the hands and feet, In every eye, face, and hand, Every hearer in the world. His abode covers all things. You will accomplish all the attainments With the mind endowed with concentration. For the sake of benefiting the practitioner I have taught this secret.
dpal he ru ka'i nges par brjod pa las dbang gi sbyin sreg dang gnas la sogs pa'i sa bstan pa'i cho ga'i le'u ste lnga bcu pa'o// //
FROM THE SPEECH OF GLORIOUS HERUKA, “THE RITUAL OF THE CONTROLLING BURNED OFFERING AND TEACHING ON THE ABODES OF THE GROUNDS AND SO FORTH” IS THE FIFTIETH CHAPTER.

d.crumb: 51. [Untitled Final Chapter]

f.d: 51. [Untitled Final Chapter]

de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ / man ngag shin tu rnyed dka' ste/ / dpa' bo'i brda yi skad du ni/ / nga yis rgyud du sbas pa yin/ / gos dang phyag rgya lnga la sogs/ / shes rab yan lag phur bu dra/ / A li kA li zhes brjod pa/ / rgyu la sogs stong sngon 'gro ba/ / 'jug pa sgra la sogs pa nas/ / ji srid bsdus pa'i sbyor ldan pa/ / bdud rtsi tshim byed mya ngan 'das/ / lag pa'i mchod pa'i dbang bskur ba/ / go cha chen pos yang dag srung / / sngags rnams kun gyis mchod par bya/ / de ltar de nyid bcu bzhi ni/ / mdor bsdus nas ni bshad pa yin/ / mi mchog gang zhig kun spyod pa/ / sdig pa thams cad rnam dag bdag / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sa 'thob cing / / skye dang skye bar bde gshegs kyi/ / rigs skyes rgyal po chos ldan 'gyur/ / ji ltar sngon bsags sdig pa yi/ / mtshan nyid thams cad dman pa ste/ / gang zhig 'di ni rtag sgom pa/ / sa la 'dod pa kun dbang phyug / dper na mar gyis gang ba'i snod/ / me yi dbus su bzhag na ni/ / mar sar steng du zhu 'gyur zhing / / snod kyi dri ma 'jig par 'gyur/ / de bzhin shrI he ru ka yi/ / mtshan gyis sdig pa 'jig par 'gyur/ / bsam gtan sems pa tsam gyis sam/ / klog cing kha ton bris pa yis/ / mtho ris longs spyod thob 'gyur ba'am/ / yang na 'khor los sgyur ba 'thob/ / rnal 'byor pa rnams 'pho ba'i tshe/ khrag 'thung dpal sogs rnal 'byor ma/ / lag na me tog sna tshogs thogs/ / rgyal mtshan ba dan sna tshogs dang / / rol mo'i sgra ni sna tshogs dang / / sna tshogs glu yi mchod pa yis/ / 'chi ba zhes bya rnam rtog 'di/ / mkha' spyod gnas su 'khrid par byed/ / de 'dra'i dpa' chen rnal 'byor ma/ / sa stengs na ni rnyed par dka'/ / dpal ldan he ru ka'i rgyud chen/ /

And then the supreme explanation of that[109] The oral instructions are very difficult to find, The symbolic language of the hero I have hidden in the Tantra. The garments, five mudras, and so forth, Branches of wisdom, the tent and dagger. Through reciting the Ali-Kali[110] The cause and so forth, are preceded by emptiness. By the nada entering and so forth,[111] Until the yoga of absorption, Nectar that satisfies and brings liberation, Bestowing initiation, and the hand offering. Also, by the great armor of perfect protection, And making offerings with all the mantras, In that way, these are the fourteen essential topics I have briefly explained.[112] Those supreme people who perform every action, Completely purifying all negativities of the self, Will attain the ground of a tathagata, and Life after life will be born into the lineage of the Buddha And become a king endowed with faith. The characteristics of all the previously Accumulated negative karma will lessen. For those who continuously meditate All of your wishes will be accomplished. For example, if a container filled with butter Is placed in the middle of a fire, The fresh butter on top will melt and Destroy the impurities of that container. In the same way Shri Heruka Will destroy the signs of nonvirtue. By merely remembering, concentrating, Reading, reciting, or writing, You will attain the enjoyments of the pure lands Or the state of a chakravartin king. The yogi will be transferred [to the pure land] with The Drinker of Blood as well as the yogini, With a variety of flowers held in their hands, Possessing a variety of victory banners and pendants, With the sound of a variety of music, And offering various sounds, [they] Will lead you to the pure land of the dakinis. In this way death will be a [mere] conceptualization. On this earth it is difficult to find This great tantra of the most glorious Heruka.

gang zhig shes nas ma dad pa/ / dbul po sdug bsngal gyis gdungs par/ / de la rtag tu 'byung bar 'gyur/ / mgul rgyan gdu bu dpung rgyan dang / / rna rgyan tshangs pa'i skud pa dang / / do shal mgo bo'i phreng ba dang / / ske rags sil sil sgra sgrogs pa/ / ri stengs sna tshogs pad+ma yi/ / lte bar A li kA li skyes/ / dkar mo bdag po rnam gnon cing / / rdo rje dril bus sku la 'khyud/ / nyi shu rtsa bzhi'i phyed ldan pa'i/ / dpa' bo rnal 'byor ma tshogs dang / / he ru ka dpal rgyal po che'i/ / go 'phang mchog ni bsgom par bya/ / dpa' bo kun dang rnal 'byor ma'i/ / 'khor bcas dbus su sbyor ldan pa/ / thams cad dgyes shing gnyis med 'gyur/ / 'byin dang sdud par mdzad pa yin/ / mos pa du ma'i sems can la/ / spyod pa sna tshogs ston mdzad de/ / sna tshogs tshul gyis gdul bya ba/ / thabs ni sna tshogs ston pa yin/ / zab mo'i chos ni ston pa la/ / gal te mos par ma gyur kyang / / smod pa dag tu mi bya ste/ / chos nyid bsam mi khyab dran bya/ / gang gis 'dir bdag yul min pa/ / gang gis chos nyid mi shes yin/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas dang de'i sras ni/ / bdag nyid chen po rnams kyis mkhyen/ / sangs rgyas rnams ni byung gyur tam/ / ma byung na yang rnam kun tu/ / bsam mi khyab pa'i chos nyid ni/ / 'phel 'grib spangs pas gnas pa yin/ / de ltar rnam par bzhag nas kyang / / 'jig rten pa kun yong mi smad/ / de yi bgrod pa bsam yas shing / / sangs rgyas rol pa bsam mi khyab/ / mdo sde bya ba spyod pa rnams/ / rnal 'byor gsang mtha'i dbye ba nyid/ / sems can mos pas 'jug pa rnams/ / de dang de la dga' ba bzhin/ /

For those who know of this yet lack faith, Those poor beings will be tormented. For them suffering will always arise. A necklace, bracelets, armlets, Earrings, and a brahmin’s thread, A noose, trident, and a rosary of human heads, A girdle and small bells creating sounds. On a lotus of various colors atop Mount [Meru] In the center of which the Ali-Kali are generated, Assuming the aspect of subduing Gauri’s Lord,[113] Embracing [Vajravarahi] and holding a vajra and bell. Meditate on the supreme state of The great king, glorious Heruka Endowed with twelve limbs[114] And the twenty-four heroes and yoginis. All the heroes and yoginis, The retinue unified in the center, Joyfully become nondual, Sending out and collecting, [Fulfilling] the many wishes of sentient beings, Teaching with various activities, Subduing in a variety of ways, And displaying a variety of methods. Even though one may have no devotion for The explanation of this profound Dharma, They should not criticize it [But should] contemplate this inconceivable Dharma. For the person [for whom] self is not an object, For him reality is not known, but It is known by the complete Buddha and his spiritual sons. Have the buddhas arisen Or did they all never arise? The sphere of reality is inconceivable; Abandon dwelling in either increasing or diminishing. Even though we establish [reality] in that way, Do not completely diminish worldly [views]. The transcendent method is beyond thought; The play of the buddhas inconceivable. The divisions of the sutra class, action, performance, and Yoga and highest yoga tantra: Those sentient beings that enter [this path] with devotion Bring happiness according to their wishes.

This is the definitive expression of glorious Heruka, the great king of tantra, that was extracted from the One Hundred Thousand [Verse Tantra] that establishes that which is the most amazing and wonderful; and it is the king of all discourses read by the great hero, glorious Heruka. It is not accomplished by the omniscience of other practitioners and is the unsurpassed attainment from the beginning.

THIS CONCLUDES THE FIFTY-FIRST CHAPTER OF THE DEFINITIVE EXPRESSION OF GLORIOUS HERUKA, THE GREAT KING OF YOGINI TANTRAS.

d.crumb: i. the body of hevajra

f.d: CHAPTER I. THE BODY OF HEVAJRA[1]
a.
'di skad bdag gis thos pa dus gcig na/ bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi sku dang gsung dang thugs kyi snying po/ rdo rje btsun mo'i b+ha ga rnams la bzhugs so/ /
(1) Thus have I heard—at one time the Lord dwelt in bliss with the Vajrayoginī who is the Body, Speech, and Mind of all the Buddhas.

de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi sku dang gsung dang thugs kyi snying po rje btsun gsang ba las shin tu ches gsang ba'ang de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ e ma'o byang chub sems dpa' chen po rdo rje snying po snying rje chen po legs so/ / rdo rje sems dpa' dang / sems dpa' chen po dang / dam tshig sems dpa' chen po dang snying po kye'i rdo rje zhes bya ba nyon cig /

(2) There the Lord pronounced these words: ‘Greatly to be revered is this most secret of all secret things, this essence which is the Body, Speech, and Mind of all the Buddhas. O Vajragarbha, good, good indeed, thou Great Bodhisattva of great compassion. Do thou listen to this which is named Hevajra, the essence of Vajrasattva, Mahāsattva, and Mahāsamayasattva.’
rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ gang phyir rdo rje sems dpa' lags/ / ji ltar sems dpa' chen po lags/ / gang gis dam tshig sems dpa' lags/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bdag la gsungs/ /
(3) Vajragarbha replied: ‘Why Vajrasattva, how so Mahāsattva and wherefore Samayasattva? May the Lord please explain.’

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / rdo rje mi phyed ces byar brjod/ / sems dpa' srid pa gsum gcig pa/ / 'dis ni shes rab rigs pa yis/ / rdo rje sems dpa' zhes byar brjod/ / ye shes chen po'i ros gang ba/ / sems dpa' chen por brjod par bya/ / rtag tu dam tshig la spyod phyir/ / dam tshig sems dpar brjod par bya/ /

(4) The Lord replied: ‘It is indivisible and so known as Vajra. A Being which is unity of three;[2] Because of this device[3] he’s known as Vajrasattva (Adamantine Being). (5) He is full of the flavours of great knowledge, and so he is called Mahāsattva (Great Being); From his continual creation of conventional forms, as Samayasattva (Convention Being) he’s named.’
b.
rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ ming bsdus pa ni ji lta bu/ / gang zhig kye yi rdo rje lags/ / he yi rnam pas ci zhig bshad/ / badzra yis kyang de bzhin ci/ /
(6) Vajragarbha said: ‘What is meant by this composite name of hevajra? What is proclaimed by the sound he, and likewise what by VAJRA?’

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / he ni snying rje chen po nyid/ / badzra'ang shes rab brjod par bya/ / thabs dang shes rab bdag nyid rgyud/ / de ni nga yis bshad kyis nyon/ / lta stangs dgug dang brda chen dang / / don byed rnam mang brjod pa dang / / rengs par byed dang skrod pa nyid/ / sde rengs byed dang mngon spyod dang / / ji ltar rigs pa rnal 'byor ma'i/ / bskyed dang gnas dang byed rgyu dang / / don byed ye shes rnam shes dang / / lha rnams ji ltar 'byung ba'o/ /

(7) The Lord replied: ‘By he is proclaimed great compassion, and wisdom by vajra. Do thou listen to this tantra, the essence of Wisdom and Means, which now is proclaimed by me. (8) Its proficiency is known to be manifold; it teaches the gazes,[1] how to conjure forth and the language of secret signs, how to petrify, how to drive away, how to bewitch an army into rigidity. (9) It is the means of producing and maintaining the yoginīs in accordance with right method; it is proficient in knowledge, both absolute and relative[2] in the matter of the due order of appearance of the divinities.

he ru ka ni bskyed pa'i rgyu/ / dang por gcig ni bsgom par bya/ / rdo rje snying po snying rje che/ / dngos po nyid kyis rnam grol zhing / / dngos po'i 'ching bas 'ching bar 'gyur/ / de yongs shes pas grol ba yin/ / dngos po med par yongs shes pas/ / dngos po bsgom 'gyur shes rab can/ / dngos po med pa yongs shes pas/ / de ltar he ru ka bsgom bya/ / lus la ye shes chen po gnas/ / rtog pa thams cad yang dag spangs/ / dngos po kun la khyab pa po/ / lus gnas lus las ma skyes pa'o/ /

(10) But in the first place it is the one means of producing Heruka, and it is by such production[3] that men are released, O Vajragarbha of great compassion. (11) They are bound by the bonds of existence and released by knowledge of them. O wise one, you should conceive of existence in knowledge of its non-existence, and likewise you should conceive of Heruka in knowledge of his non-existence. (12) Great knowledge abides in the body, free of all falsification, but although it pervades all things and exists in the body, it is not in the body that it arises.’
c.

rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ kye bcom ldan 'das rdo rje'i lus la rtsa du lags/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rtsa rnams ni sum cu rtsa gnyis te/ byang chub kyi sems sum cu rtsa gnyis 'bab pa bde ba chen po'i gnas su 'dzag pa'o/ / de rnams kyi nang nas rtsa rnam pa gsum ni gtso mo ste/ brkyang ma dang / ro ma dang / kun 'dar ma'o/ / brkyang ma shes rab rang bzhin gyis/ / thabs kyis ro ma yang dag gnas/ / kun 'dar ma ni dbus gnas su/ / gzung dang 'dzin pa rnam par spangs/ /

(13) Then Vajragarbha said: ‘How many veins are there, Lord, in the vajra-body?’ ‘There are thirty-two veins’, he replied, ‘thirty-two that bear bodhicitta, and flow into the place of great bliss. Among these three veins are the chief, Lalanā, Rasanā, and Avadhūtī. (14) Lalanā has the nature of Wisdom and Rasanā consists in the Means, and Avadhūti is in the middle, free from the notions of subject and object.
brkyang ma mi bskyod 'bab pa ste/ / ro ma de bzhin khrag 'bab cing / / shes rab zla ba 'bab bshad pa/ / de ni kun 'dar mar rab grags/ /
(15) Lalanā is the bearer of Akṣobhya and Rasanā the bearer of blood, and she who is known as the bearer of both[1] is famed as Avadhūtī.’

mi phyed ma dang / phra gzugs ma dang / rtse ba ma dang / g.yon pa ma dang / thung ngu ma dang / rus sbal skyes ma dang / sgom pa ma dang / dbang ma dang / skyon ma dang / 'jug ma dang / ma mo dang / mtshan mo dang / bsil sbyin ma dang / tsha ba ma dang / brkyang ma dang / kun 'dar ma dang / ro ma dang / gzhol ma dang / rangs ma dang / shin tu gzugs can ma dang / spyi ma dang / rgyu sbyin ma dang / sbyor bral ma dang / sdug gu ma dang / grub ma dang / 'tshe ma dang / de bzhin du yid bzangs ma dang / sum skor ma dang / 'dod ma dang / khyim ma dang / gtum mo dang / bdud dral ma'o/ /

(16-19) Their names are: Indivisible, Subtly-formed, Divine, Lefthanded, Dwarfish, Tortoise-born, Anchoress, Consecration, Fault, Pervader, Mother, Savage, Freshener, Heat, Lalanā, Avadhūtī, Rasanā, Bent, Black, Beautiful, Common, Producer of the Cause, Unattached, Affectionate, Perfected, Purifying, High-minded, Threefold, Lustful, Homely, Impetuous, Daughter of Death.
rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ kye bcom ldan 'das sum cu rtsa gnyis po 'di rnams ji ltar lags/
(19) Vajragarbha again asked: ‘Of what kind, Lord, are these thirty-two veins?’

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / srid gsum yongs gyur thams cad ni/ / gzung dang 'dzin pa rnam par spangs/ / yang na thabs ni thams cad kyis/ / dngos po'i mtshan nyid du ni brtag / sdom pa'i dbye ba'ang bshad par bya ste/

(20) The Lord replied: ‘They are all a permutation of the triple nature and essentially free of the notions of subject and object, but on the other hand when they are used as means, they are conceived as possessing the characteristics of phenomenal things.’ (21) Now are listed the components of the internal maṇḍala:[2]
A li dang kA li ni zla ba dang / nyi ma dang / shes rab dang / thabs so/ /
ĀLI—sun—wisdom (which represent the left vein); KĀLI—moon—means (which represent the right vein);

chos dang / longs spyod rdzogs pa dang / sprul pa ni sku dang / gsung dang / thugs so/ / e ba~M ma yA ni/ e yi rnam pas lha mo spyan/ /ba~M gi rnam pas bdag mar brjod/ /ma ni lha mo gos dkar mo/ /ya rnam pas sgrol mar brjod/ /
Navel — Heart — Throat — Head (22) E — VAM — MA — YĀ Locanā — Mamakī — Pāṇḍuradevī — Tārā (4 goddesses)

(23) nirmāṇa — dharma — sambhoga — mahāsukha (4 cakras) (body) — (mind) — (speech) — (unity of body, speech, and mind) lotus of: 64 petals — 8 petals — 16 petals — 32 petals

(24) variety — development — consummation — blank (4 moments)
(25) worship — adoration — propitiation — fulfilment (4 requisites)

(30) Then there are ĀLI, KĀLI, sun, and moon,[3] the 16 phases, the 64 periods, the 32 hours and the 4 watches. So everything goes in fours.

a.
sngags kyi le'u bshad par bya'o/ /
We shall expound the chapter on mantras.
oM a kA ro mu khaM sar+b+ba d+har+m+mA NA~M Ad+ya nut+pan+na twAta oM AH hU~M phaT swA hA/ 'byung po thams cad kyi gtor ma'i sngags so/ /
(1) the mantra that accompanies offerings to all the spirits: OṂ A—origin of all things for they are essentially non-arisen—OṂ ĀḤ HŪṂ PHAṬ SVĀHĀ.
bU~M A~M dzri~M kha~M hU~M/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis bon no/ /
(2) the seed of the buddhas: BUṂ AṂ JRĪṂ KHAṂ HŪṂ.[2]
oM de ba pi tsu badzra hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/ kye'i rdo rje'i snying po'o/ /

oM a ka tsa Ta ta pa ya sha swA hA/ grong khyer dkrug pa'i sngags so/ /

oM dz+wa la dz+wa la b+h+yo hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/ phyag bzhi pa'i'o/ /

oM AHhU~M/ sku dang gsung dang thugs byin gyis brlab pa'i sngags so/ /

oM ra k+Sha ra k+Sha hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/ sa sbyang ba'i sngags so/ /

oM hUM swA hA/ rengs par byed pa'o/ /

oM a~M swA hA/ dbang du byed pa'o/ /

oM g+huHswA hA/ gsod par byed pa'i'o/ /

oM ku ru kul+le hrIHswA hA/ ku ru kul+le'i sngags so/ /
(19) OṂ KURU KULLE HRĪ SVĀHĀ.[1]

AHphuH'i rnam pas mtha' yas kyi gzugs brnyan byas la bdud rtsi lngas ni blugs/ me tog nag pos ni mchod/ klu 'dul bar byed pa'i khu bas ni byugs/ glang po che'i chang gis ni mgo bo byugs/ kham phor kha sbyor du ni bzhag / ba nag mo'i 'o mas ni dgang / gzhon nu ma nag mos bkal ba'i skud pas ni dkri/ / rlung gi phyogs su rdzing bu byas te mtha' yas der bzhag go/ / de'i 'gram du dkyil 'khor bzhengs par bya ste/ dur khrod kyi sol bas ni rdul tshon nag po/ skyes pa'i rus pa'i phye mas ni rdul tshon dkar po/ ldong ros kyis ni rdul tshon ser po/ dur khrod kyi so phag gis ni rdul tshon dmar po/ rkun ma'i lo ma dang / skyes pa'i rus pa'i bye ma dag gis ni rdul tshon ljang gu ste/ rdul tshon 'di rnams kyis dkyil 'khor bzhengs so/ / dur khrod kyi srad bus thig gdab cing dkyil 'khor khru gsum pa bya ste/ de'i dbus su mtha' yas mnan pa'i kye'i rdo rje zhal brgyad pa/ zhabs bzhi pa/ phyag bcu drug gis brgyan pa/ spyan nyi shu rtsa bzhis phye pa/ 'jigs pa'ang 'jigs par mdzad pa bri'o/ /

(20) Rain-producing ritual: OṂ ĀḤ PHUḤ. Intoning these syllables, make an image of a snake, wash it with the five ambrosias,[2] honour it with blue lotuses,[3] smear it with nāga-subduing juice,[4] smear its head with ichor, and having made a pot by placing two dishes together, lay the snake inside. Then fill the pot with milk from a black cow and wrap it in a woven cloth that has been cut by a dark-skinned girl. Then in the north-west make a small pool, and place the snake in it. At its edge lay out the maṇḍala. Black colouring is obtained from charcoal of the cemetery, white from ground human bones, yellow from green lac, red from cemetery-bricks, green from caurya leaves and ground human bones, and dark blue from ground human bones and cemetery charcoal. With these colours lay out the maṇḍala, measuring it with a cemetery thread[5] three cubits, three inches in size. In the centre draw Hevajra in the act of trampling on a snake; he has eight faces, four feet, sixteen arms, and twenty-four eyes.
de nas slob dpon gyis nang gi ma rungs pa'i sems kyis dben pa'i gnas su sngags bzla ste/
Then the master, his mind resolved in inmost wrath, should utter this mantra in that lonely spot:

oM g+hu ru g+hu ru g+hu Tu g+hu Tu/ ma sa ma sa g+ha Ta g+ha Ta/ g+ho Ta ya g+ho Ta ya/ a nan ta k+Sho b+ha ka rA ye nA gA d+hi pa ta ye he he ru ru kaM sab+ta pA tA la/ ga tA na nA ga A kar Sha ya/ bar Sha ya/ gar+dz+dza ya/ tar+dz+dza ya/ phuHphuHphuHphuHphuHphuHphuHphuHhU~M hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/ gal te char mi 'bab na de'i tshe sngags 'di bzlog la bzlas te char 'bab bo/ /

OṂ GHURU GHURU GHUḌU GHUḌU GHAṬA GHAṬA GHOṬAYA GHOṬAYA[1] O Lord of the nāgas who causes the snakes to tremble, He-he Ru-ru Ka—those nāgas who have gone to the seven lower realms, drag them forth, drag them forth, rain, rain, thunder, thunder—PHUḤ PHUḤ PHUḤ PHUḤ PHUḤ PHUḤ PHUḤ PHUḤ HŪṂ HŪṂ HŪṂ PHAṬ SVĀHĀ.
gal te mi 'bab na/ de'i mgo ardza ka'i dog pa ltar 'gas so/ / char 'bab pa zhes bya ba'i cho ga'o/ /
If it does not rain now, one should recite this mantra backwards. If then they do not produce rain, their heads will burst like bunches of bread-fruit.[2]
sprin dral ba bshad de dur khrod kyi ras la nye bar 'dug nas sngags bzlas shing dral te/
(21) The cloud-rending ritual:[3] Taking one’s seat on a cemetery-shroud, one rends them by reciting this mantra:
oM Ar+yA sh+ma shA na pri yA ya hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/ sprin dral ba'i cho ga'o/ /
OṂ noble one to whom the cemetery is dear—HŪṂ HŪṂ HŪṂ PHAṬ SVĀHĀ.
pha rol gyi sde rnam par gzhig par bya ba'i phyir kha Ti kA'i bsgrub pa bshad de/ kha Ti kA dang bdud rtsi lnga dang / ku ThA rats+tshani na dang lhan cig btags la ril bu bya ste/ sngags ni/

(22) The ritual of the vajra-knife: I tell of the chalk-ritual for destroying an enemy army. Having pounded the chalk, mix it with the five ambrosias and kuṭhārachinna[4] and make a small ball. The mantra is:

oM badzra karta ri he badzrA ya hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/ dngos grub kyi don du bye ba bzlas shing sngon du bsnyen pa 'bum byas te/ de bsgrubs la ril ba spyi blugs kyi mgrin par bskor zhing bskor nas bcag na dgra thams cad kyi mgo med par 'gyur ro/ / rdo rje gri gug gi cho ga'o/ /

OṂ vajra-knife—o Hevajra HŪṂ HŪṂ HŪṂ pHaṬ. For the gaining of siddhi he should recite it ten million times, and for the above-mentioned practice a hundred thousand times. He should then wrap round the neck of the jar upon which the ritual is being practised, and having wrapped it round, he should break it off. All the enemies will become headless.[5]

lha rnams dgas par 'dod pas thig le bsgrub ste tshangs pa'i sa bon rgyal la bsgrubs nas/ ku ThA rats+tshi nan dang bsres la nyi ma gzas zin pa na mi bskyod pa dang btag cing btags nas dgra sta bya ste/ de rkang pas mnan nas sngags bzlas te/

(23) The ritual for the destruction of gods;[1] One who wishes to destroy the gods must perform the ritual upon an axe-shaped mark (tilaka). A palāśa seed,[2] plucked under Puṣya[3] and mixed with kuṭhārachinna, he should pound together with śukra under a solar eclipse. Having pounded it, he should form it into an axe. Trampling it beneath the feet he should recite the mantra:
oM badzra ku ThAr pA Ta ya pA Ta ya hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/
OṂ vajra-axe—cleave cleave HŪṂ HŪṂ HŪṂ PHAṬ SVĀHĀ.
bye ba bzlas la thig le byas te gang la phyag byas pa de 'gas so/ / lha dgas pa'i cho ga'o/ /
Reciting it ten million times, he should make homage to the tilaka, and the one to whom it clings will burst.[4]
tsha bas gdung bar bya bar 'dod pas ar+k+ka'i lo ma la dug dang ske tshe dang tsi tra ka'i khu bas dgra bo'i ming phri zhing 'bras phub kyi me la gdungs te sngags khri bzlas so/ /

(24) The burning ritual: One should write the name of an enemy on an arka-leaf with the juice of poisonous mustard and burning citraka, and throwing it in a fire chaff, recite this mantra ten thousand times:
oM he badzra dz+wA ra dz+wA ra sha tI+u b+h+ru~M hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/ tsha ba'i cho ga'o/ / khri bzlas pas 'grub bo/ /
OṂ Hevajra—burn burn this enemy BHRUṂ HŪṂ HŪṂ HŪṂ PHAṬ SVĀHĀ. By reciting it ten thousand times one succeeds.
chang skyug par bya bar 'dod pas bsgrub bya'i lte bar yaM gi rnam par bsgom zhing maM gi rnam par gyur pa las chang lto bar rnam par bsgoms te skyugs par byed par bltas na chang skyug go/ /

(25) The vomiting ritual: If one wishes to cause the vomiting forth of intoxicants, one should imagine the syllable mam on the navel of the patient. One imagines the syllable mam becoming a belly full of wine. He is seen as vomiting, and he vomits the wine.

rab tu myos ma dbang du bya bar 'dod pas mya ngan med pa'i brgyad la mya ngan med pa'i 'og tu song ste gos dmar po bgos nas myos byed kyi 'bras bu bza' zhing / kA kA ma tsi kA'i khu bas thig le byas nas sngags bzlas te/ oM a mu kI me hrIH/ ba sI b+ha ba tu swA hA/ khri yis 'ong bar 'gyur ro/ /

(26) The ritual for gaining mastery of a young woman: One who wishes to quell a young woman should go on the eighth day of aśoka to the foot of an aśoka-tree, and donning a red garment, he should cat madana-fruit. Then making a tilaka with kāmācika-juice, he should recite this mantra: OṂ HRĪ may she come into my power SVĀHĀ.[1] By reciting it ten thousand times one gets her to come.

zla ba dang nyi ma dbang du bya bar 'dod pas sA lu btags pa'i 'gyur ba la zla ba dang nyi ma byas nas rdo rje'i chu la gzhug cing sngags bzlas te/ oM badzra arkaka mA tsa la mA tsa la tiSh+Tha tiSh+Tha he badzrA ya hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT swA hA/ bye ba phrag bdun bzlas te nyi ma dang zla ba dag yang dag par gnas shing nyin mtshan bye brag med par 'gyur ro/ / zla ba dang nyi ma rnam par 'dzin pa zhes bya ba'i cho ga'o/ /

(27) The ritual for holding sun and moon: One who wishes to have power over sun and moon, should make a sun and moon of ground-rice, throw them into vajra-water, and recite this mantra: OṂ sun and moon, move not, move not; stay, stay—o Hevajra HŪṂ HŪṂ HŪṂ PHAṬ SVĀHĀ. One should recite it seventy million times and they will stand still so that sun and moon will be indistinguishable day and night.

oM na grA na grA zhes bya ba'i sngags 'dis dus ma yin pa'i dus su don bsgrub pa'i phyir gzhon nu ma'i mig dag la brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags nas me tog la sogs pa'i mchod pa rnam pa lngas yang dag par mchod cing snyan gsan dbab bo/ / bcu bzhi pa'am brgyad pa'i snga ba'i dus su bum pa la sogs pa gzhag cing 'bru mar dang a lak+ta'i khu ba la sngags 'di nyid kyis lan brgya rtsa brgyad mngon par bsngags so/ / de nas mngon par bsngags pa'i a lak+ta'i khu bas sngags pa'i mthe bong rgan po la bskus nas 'bru mar gyis kyang blugs la gzhon nu ma la bstan te nga'i rdzas sus khyer smos de la des smras pa/ che ge mo zhes bya bas khyer ro/ / rdo rje skar ma'o/ /

(28) The ritual for seeking a thing which is lost: In order to gain success in this one should enchant at night time the eye of a maiden with this formula, repeating it 108 times: OṂ NAGRĀ NAGRĀ, honouring her with the five kinds of offerings, flowers, incense, lamps and so on. Then at night on the eighth or fourteenth day having put ready jars containing sesame oil and lac,[2] one should enchant them with this formula repeated 108 times. Next smearing his big toe with the enchanted lac, and washing it with the sesame oil, he should show it to the girl, saying: Speak! Who has removed this thing of mine?’ Then she will reply: ‘Such or such a one.’ This is Vajra-astrology.
be Tu yA be Tu yA zhes brjod na glang po che 'bros par 'gyur ro/ /
(29) OṂ VEḌUYĀ VEḌUYĀ—pronounce this and an elephant flees.
mam+mA mam+mA zhes brjod na stag 'bros par 'gyur ro/ /
(30) OṂ MARMMĀ MARMMĀ—pronounce this and a tiger flees.
te l+li yA te l+li yA zhes brjod na bse 'bros par 'gyur ro/ /
(31) OṂ TELIYĀ TELIYĀ—pronounce this and a rhinoceros flees.
i li mi li phuHphuHzhes brjod na sbrul 'bros par 'gyur ro/ /
(32) ILI MILI PHUḤ PHUḤ—pronounce this and a serpent flees.
nor skyong 'dul ba'i phyag gis lag pa rab tu bstan na khyi 'bros par 'gyur ro/ /
(33) Show your hand with a gesture which indicates protection of wealth and power of subduing, and a dog will flee.
b.

rdo rje ma dang / dkar mo dang / chu ma dang / rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dang / bdag med ma dang / sa spyod ma dang / mkha' spyod ma'i rnal 'byor las rengs par byed pa la sogs pa brtul zhugs can gyis byed do/ /
(34) It is in association with Vajrā, Gaurī, Vārī, Vajraḍākinī, Nairātmikā, Bhūcari, and Khecarī, that the yogin practises the rites of petrifying and so on.[1]
sngags kyi le'u ste gnyis pa'o// //
[lha]

d.crumb: iii. hevajra and his troupe

f.d: CHAPTER III. HEVAJRA AND HIS TROUPE
de nas lha'i le'u bshad par bya'o/ /
dang por byams pa bsgom par bya/ / gnyis par snying rje rnam bsgom zhing / / gsum par dga' ba bsgom pa dang / / kun gyi mthar ni btang snyoms so/ /
(1) We shall expound the chapter on the divinities. First[1] one should produce thought of love, secondly that of compassion, thirdly that of joy, and last of all that of impassibility.
yang ni stong pa'i byang chub ste/ / gnyis pa la ni sa bon bsdu/ / gsum pa la ni gzugs brnyan rdzogs/ / bzhi pa la ni yig 'bru dgod/ /
(2) Then again: first the realization of the void, secondly the seed in which all is concentrated, thirdly the physical manifestation, and fourthly one should implant the syllable.[2]
re phas nyi ma sngon du rnam bsgoms nas/ / nyi der hU~M byung sna tshogs rdo rje ste/ / rdo rje de nyid kyis ni ra ba dang / / gur bcing ba yang rnam par bsgom pa nyid/ /

(3) One should imagine before one a solar disk arising from the syllable ram and at its centre a crossed-vajra which has emerged from the syllable HŪṂ. As produced from this vajra one should imagine a balustrade and canopy.[1]

dang por ro ni rnam bsgoms pa/ / chos kyi dbyings kyi bdag nyid brjod/ / de stengs rnal 'byor pa gnas nas/ / he ru ka nyid rnam par bsgom/ / rang gi snying gar re ba bsgom/ / de las byung ba'i nyi dkyil 'khor/ / der ni hU~M gi rnam pa nyid/ / thabs dang shes rab rang bzhin can/ / hU~M las byung ba'i rdo rje ni/ / kha dog nag po 'jigs chen po/ / rdo rje lte ba'i dbus gnas par/ / yang ni hU~M gi de nyid bsgom/ / hU~M gi rnam pa gyur bltas nas/ / zhe sdang bdag nyid rnam par bsgom/ / rdo rje skye ba nag po che/ / 'dam skyes sngon po 'dra ba'i mdog / yang na sngo dang nyi ma'i mdog / dad pas nges par rnam par bsgom/ /

(4) (Then within the balustrade) one should first imagine a corpse which represents the whole of existence, and the yogin, seated thereupon, should conceive himself of the nature of Heruka (5). In his own heart he imagines the syllable ram and a solar disk arising from it, and then upon that the syllable HŪṂ, the nature of which is Wisdom and Means. (6) It is dark in colour and exceedingly fearful this syllable HŪṂ which has emerged from a vajra, and one should conceive of the essence of this HŪṂ as abiding in the heart of the vajra. (7) Then he should envisage the syllable HŪṂ as transformed into (Heruka) whose nature is wrath. This Vajra-Born is exceedingly dark like a blue lotus in colour, or one may conceive of him as dark blue and red—as one pleases.[1]

nam mkhar rje btsun bltas nas ni/ / rdo rje skye ba snying rje che/ / rgyan rnams thams cad 'dzin pa yi/ / lha mo brgyad po rnams kyis mchod/ / dkar mo ri dgas mtshan ma 'dzin/ / chom rkun bdud las rgyal ba'i snod/ / ro langs ma ni chu lag ma/ / g+hasma rI ni sman 'dzin cing / / puk+ka sI ni rdo rje'i lag / de bzhin ri khrod ma ro 'dzin/ / gdol pa mo ni cang te'u rdung / / 'di rnams kyis ni gtso bo mchod/ / 'dod chags chen po rjes chags pas/ / g.yung mos sku la 'khyud pa nyid/ /

(8) Envisaging in the sky that Lord, who is vajra-born and of great compassion, one should worship him in the company of eight goddesses who are wearing all their adornments. (9) Gaurī holds the moon, Caurī the sun-vessel, Vetālī holds water, Ghasmarī medicament, (10) Pukkasī holds a vajra, Śavarī the ambrosia, and Caṇḍālī sounds a drum. By these the Lord is worshipped, with Ḍombī clinging to his neck and impassioned by great passion.

A li zla ba kA li nyi/ / sa bon nang du son gyur pa/ / de nyid sems dpa' zhes byar brjod/ / mchog tu dga' ba'i rang bzhin can/ / nam mkha'i dkyil 'khor khyab pa yi/ / rang gi lus mtshungs rnam par spro/ / bsdus nas snying gar dgug pa na/ / yo gi zhe sdang bdag nyid 'gyur/ /

(11) There is Moon and Sun and betwixt them the Seed. This last is that Being, ’tis taught, whose nature is Joy Supreme. (12) Forms like to his in brilliance shoot forth and cover the expanse of the sky. Drawing them together he induces them into his own heart, and the yogin becomes the Wrathful One himself.[2]

sngo dang nyi ma mtshungs pa'i mdog / ban+d+hu dmar po'i spyan dang ldan/ / skra ser gyen du 'khyil ba dang / / phyag rgya lngas ni rnam par brgyan/ / 'khor lo rna cha nor bu dang / / lag gdub dang ni ska rags nyid/ / sangs rgyas lnga ni rnam dag pa/ / 'di rnams phyag rgyar rab tu grags/ / sdang mig brgyad gnyis lo yi tshul/ / g.yon na rdo rje thod pa dang / / g.yon pa nas kyang kha T+wAM ga/ / g.yas na rdo rje nag po nyid/ / hU~M gi yi ge 'don pa'i bdag /

(13) Dark blue and like the sun in colour with reddened and extended eyes,[3] his yellow hair twisted upwards, and adorned with the five symbolic adornments, (14) the circlet, the ear-rings and necklace, the bracelets and belt. These five symbols are well known for the purificatory power[4] of the Five Buddhas. (15) He has the form of a sixteen-year-old youth and is clad in a tiger-skin. His gaze is wrathful. In his left hand he holds a vajra-skull, and a khaṭvāṅga likewise in his left, while in his right is a vajra of dark hue. In his essence he is the enunciation of the sound HŪṂ.
rnal 'byor ma brgyad yongs bskor nas/ / dur khrod du ni mgon po rol/ / dbugs rgyu zhes bya'i rigs pa 'dis/ / dur khrod ces ni mngon par brjod/ /

(16) This Lord plays in the cemetery surrounded by his eight yoginīs. ‘In the cemetery’, we say, because here we have a play on words, for śvasiti means ‘he breathes’ and śavavasati means ‘resting-place of corpses’.

phyag bzhi ni bdud bzhi las rnam par rgyal ba rnam par dag pa ste/ gong du brjod pa'i gzugs dang / sku mdog dag hU~M las byung ba'o/ / phyag g.yon gyi dang po na skyes pa'i thod pa lha dang lha ma yin gyi khrag gis bkang ba/ de bzhin du g.yas kyi phyag na rdo rje/ phyag lhag ma dag gis shes rab la 'khyud pa/ shes rab rdo rje phag mo ni bcom ldan 'das kyi gzugs can no/ /

(17) The four-armed form symbolizes the destruction of the four Maras. He is born of the syllable HŪṂ and his form and colour are as previously described. In the first left-hand he holds a human skull filled with the blood of gods and titans; in the first right hand he holds a vajra; with the remaining two hands he embraces Prajñā. She is Vajravārāhī and is similar in form to her lord.

phyag drug pa/ zhal gsum pa/ g.yon dmar ba/ g.yas zla ba dang nyi ma lta bu dang po sngon po/ gcer bu gong du brjod pa'i sku mdog dang gzugs can/ phyag rnams ni pha rol tu phyin pa drug rnam par dag pa'o/ / phyag g.yon gyi dang po na rtse gsum pa/ phyag g.yas kyi dang po na rdo rje/ phyag g.yon gyi gnyis pa na dril bu/ phyag g.yas kyi gnyis pa na gri gug / phyag lhag ma dag gis rdo rje lu gu rgyud ma la snyoms par 'jug pa/ bcom ldan 'das ji lta ba de ltar shes rab ste/ g.yas pa dang g.yon pa na gri gug dang thod pa/ khams gsum gyi bdag nyid can gyi ro mnan pa'o/ /

(18) The six-armed form has three faces, the left red, the right the colour of the rising moon, and the foremost one dark blue. The six arms symbolize the six Perfections; in the first left hand he holds a trident, in the first right hand a vajra, in the second left hand a bell and in the second right hand a knife. With his remaining two hands he clasps Vajraśṛṅkhalā. She too is like her lord. In her right and left hands she holds knife and skull. He treads upon a corpse who represents the threefold world.
lha'i le'u ste gsum pa'o// //

d.crumb: lha dbang bskur ba

f.d: [lha dbang bskur ba]

d.crumb: iv. self-consecration

f.d: CHAPTER IV. SELF-CONSECRATION
de nas lha dbang bskur ba'i le'u bshad par bya'o/ /
(1) We shall expound the chapter on divine consecration.

rang gi snying gar sa bon bsam mo/ / sa bon las 'od zer nag po lcags kyu'i rnam pa'i gzugs kyis phyung nas/ des khams gsum du bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas thams cad spyan drangs la ma mo brgyad kyis yang dag par mchod nas gsol ba gdab par bya'o/ / oM a b+hi Shiny+tsa tu mAM sar+b+ba ta thA ga ta zhes sangs rgyas de rnams he ru ka'i rnam pa'i gzugs kyis de bzhin gshegs pa lnga'i bdag nyid kyi bdud rtsi lngas gang ba'i bum pas dbang bskur bar bya'o/ / dbang bskur ba na me tog gi char 'bab par 'gyur ro/ / rnga'i sgra 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / gur gum gyi char 'bab par 'gyur ro/ /

Imagine that from the seed[1] in your own heart you lead forth a ray, which is shining black in colour and of the form of a hook, and by means of this you draw in the buddhas who are stationed throughout the threefold world. Having worshipped them with the eight goddesses,[2] you should beseech them saying: ‘OṂ may all the buddhas consecrate me’. (2) Then you will be consecrated by those buddhas who have all assumed the form of Heruka, with the five vessels which symbolize the Five Tathā-gatas and which contain the five ambrosias.[3] At the time of consecration there will be a shower of flowers and one of saffron; drums will sound;

gzugs kyi rdo rje ma la sogs pa rnams kyis mchod par bya'o/ / rdo rje'i glu spyan ma la sogs pa rnams kyis blang par bya'o/ / dbang bskur nas spyi bor rang gi rigs kyi bdag por 'gyur ro/ / 'dis ni he ru ka rdzogs pa nyid do/ / thun gsum du byin gyis brlabs pa'i bsgom pa rnam par bsgoms nas langs te lha'i gzugs su gzhag go/ /

(3) you will be worshipped by Rūpavajrā and her companions[4] and Locanā and the others[1] will sing vajra-songs.[2] When you have been thus consecrated, the Lord of your Family[3] will appear on your head, and Heruka will be revealed in you. Performing morning, noon and night this meditation which bestows such power, you should arise, and at all times remain consubstantiated with the divinity.[4]
dbang gi le'u ste bzhi pa'o// //

d.crumb: de kho na nyid

f.d: [de kho na nyid]

d.crumb: v. reality

f.d: CHAPTER V. REALITY
de nas de kho na nyid kyi le'u bshad par bya'o/ /
(1) Now we shall expound the chapter on reality.
ngo bos gzugs med mthong ba po/ / sgra med thos pa po yang med/ / dri med snom pa po yang med/ / ro med myong ba po yang med/ / reg med reg pa po yang med/ / sems med sems las byung ba'ang med/ /

In reality there is neither form nor seer, neither sound nor hearer, There is neither smell nor one who smells, neither taste nor taster, Neither touch nor one who touches, neither thought nor thinker.[5]
skyed byed ma dang sring mo nyid/ / rnal 'byor rig pas rtag tu mchod/ / gar ma tshos ma rdo rje ma/ / gdol ma de bzhin bram ze mo/ / thabs dang shes rab cho ga yis/ / de nyid rig pas rtag tu mchod/ /

(2) He who is well versed in this yoga gives honour always to the Mother and the Sister. Likewise he to whom this truth is dear, pays honour to Nartī, Rajakī, and Ḍombī,[6] to Caṇḍālī and to Brāhmaṇī, combining Means and Wisdom in the rite.[7]
ji ltar bye bar mi 'gyur bar/ / rab tu 'bad pas bsten pa nyid/ / ma gsang sprul dang chom rkun dang / / sa spyod me yis sdug bsngal byed/ /
(3) They must be served with circumspection that no disclosure come about. Through lack of secrecy misfortune will befall you, from snake or thief or fire or sprite.[1]
rigs lnga'i phyag rgya zhes bya ba/ / thar pa'i rgyur ni brjod par bya/ / rdo rje 'dis ni gdab pa nyid/ / des na phyag rgyar brjod par bya/ /
(4) In order that one may gain release, these Mudrā are identified with the Five Families. She is called Mudrā or Sign, because she is signed with the Vajra.
rdo rje pad+ma de bzhin las/ / de bzhin gshegs dang rin chen nyid/ / snying rje chen po dam pa yi/ / rigs ni rnam pa lnga ru brjod/ /
(5) Vajra, Padma, Karma, Tathāgata, Ratna; these are known as the Five Families supreme, O thou of great compassion.

rdo rje'i phyag rgya g.yung mo nyid/ / de bzhin pad+ma'i gar ma nyid/ / las ni tshos mar rab tu bshad/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i bram ze mo/ / rin chen gdol mar shes par bya/ / phyag rgya lngar ni rnam par nges/ / 'di rnams de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs/ / mdor bsdus pas ni brjod par bya/ /

(6 and 7) These then are their five Mudrā: Ḍombī for Vajra, Nartī for Padma, Rajakī for Karma, Brāhmaṇī for Tathāgata, and Caṇḍālinī for Ratna. For shortness they are called the families of the tathāgatas.
dpal ldan de bzhin nyid gshegs shing / / de bzhin slar yang gshegs pa nyid/ / 'dis ni shes rab rigs pa yis/ / de bzhin gshegs zhes brjod par bya/ /
(8) He enters supreme reality, he the Blessed One, and comes just as he went, and so on account of this play on words, it’s as Tathāgata he’s known.
rigs ni rnam pa drug brjod cing / / mdor bsdus pas ni rnam pa lnga/ / sku gsung thugs kyi dbye ba yis/ / phyi nas rnam pa gsum du 'gyur/ /
(9) These families are of six kinds, it’s taught, but abbreviated they are five. Then they may become three with the distinction of Body, Speech, and Mind.[2]
rigs dang 'byung ba lha rnams dang / / phung po lnga yi rang bzhin gyi/ / rigs dang bgrang bya 'di yis ni/ / rigs zhes mngon par brjod par bya/ /
(10) These families correspond with the five elements and are identified with the five skandkas.[3] It is because they can be reckoned (kul) or counted that they are therefore known as hula.
sgom pa po med bsgom pa'ang med/ / lha med sngags kyang yod ma yin/ / smos pa med pa'i rang bzhin las/ / sngags dang lha ni yang dag gnas/ /
(11) There is neither meditator, nor whatso’er to meditate; there is neither god nor mantra. It is as (aspects of) the undifferentiated unity that god and mantra have their existence.
rnam snang mi bskyod don yod dang / / rin chen dpag med sems dpa' bo/ / tshangs pa khyab 'jug zhi ba dang / / thams cad sangs rgyas de nyi brjod/ /
(12) This unity is known as Vairocana, Akṣobhya, Amogha, Ratna, Ārolika,[4] and Sātvika, as Brahmā, Viṣṇu, Śiva, Sarva, Vibuddha, and Tattva.[5]

tshangs pa sgrib bral sangs rgyas nyid/ / 'jug phyir khyab 'jug brjod par bya/ / rtag tu dge bas zhi ba nyid/ / thams cad kun gyi bdag nyid gnas/ / dam pa'i bde bas de nyid de/ / bde ba rtogs phyir rnam sangs rgyas/ / gang phyir lus las byung ba nyid/ / lha zhes mngon par brjod par bya/ /

(13) He is called Brahmā because he has gained nirvāṇa and enlightenment. Viṣṇu because he is all-pervading, Śiva because he is propitious, Sarva because he abides in all things, (14) Tattva because he experiences real bliss, and Vibuddha because he is aware of this happiness. He becomes manifest in the body (deha) and he is therefore called the divinity (devatā).

sangs rgyas 'di la b+ha ga mnga'/ / bcom ldan 'das zhes brjod par bya/ / b+ha ga rnam pa drug tu brjod/ / dbang phyug la sogs yon tan kun/ / yang na nyon mongs la sogs bdud/ / bcom phyir bcom ldan 'das zhes brjod/ /

(15) Because he, as Buddha, possesses many blessings (bhaga), he is called most blessed (bhagavat). These blessings are six: lordliness, beauty, fame, wealth, wisdom, and great energy.[1] Or he may be called Bhagavat because he destroys (bhañjanāt) Kleśamāra and the others.
gang phyir skye 'gro skyed pa yis/ / shes rab ma zhes brjod par bya/ / gang phyir skal ba ston pa yis/ / shes rab sring mo zhes bya nyid/ /
(16) Prajñā is called the Mother, because she gives birth to the world; and likewise the Sister (bhaginī) because she shows the apportionment (vibhāga).[2]

btso blag ma dang bu mo dang / / gar mkhan mar yang brjod par bya/ / sems can thams cad 'tshod pa'i phyir/ / btso blag ma zhes de bzhin brjod/ / yon tan 'jo phyir shes rab ni/ / bu mo zhes ni brjod par bya/ /
(17) She is called Washerwoman or Daughter or Dancer: Washerwoman (rajakī)[3] because she tinges all beings (rañjanāt); Daughter (duhitā) because she yields good qualities (duhanāt);
snying rje chen po g.yo ba'i phyir/ / shes rab gar mar brjod par bya/ / gang phyir bcom ldan mi reg pa/ / de phyir g.yung mor brjod par bya/ /
(18) Dancer because of her tremulous nature. She is called Ḍombī (outcast) because she is untouchable.
A li kA li rab brtags pas/ / brjod pa bzlas par yang dag bshad/ / rkang pa'i rjes ni dkyil 'khor nyid/ / nyid phyir dkyil 'khor brjod par bya/ /

(19) Our speech is called uttering (japa) because it is the enunciation (prajalpana) of āli and kāli.[4] A maṇḍala is a foot-mark, and it is called maṇḍala because it arises from pressure (malanāt).[1]
lag pa sgyur ba phyag rgya yin/ / sor mo nyed pa'ang de bzhin no/ / gang phyir rnam sems bsam gtan ni/ / gang bsams de ni bsam gtan no/ /
(20) A gesture (mudrā) is an opening of the hand and the pressure of one finger upon another. Our thought is our meditation, since meditation consists in thought.[2]
ji ltar pha las bde thob pa/ / de yi bde ba Rang gis bza'/ / bde ba gang gis 'chi ba 'di/ / de yi bde ba bsam gtan brjod/ /
(21) The bliss that is found in the Father,[3] that bliss is enjoyed of oneself, and that bliss by which occurs the Slaying,[4] such bliss is said to be dhyāna.
de kho na nyid kyi le'u ste lnga pa'o// //

d.crumb: spyod pa

f.d: [spyod pa]

d.crumb: vi. the performance

f.d: CHAPTER VI. THE PERFORMANCE
a.
de nas gzhan yang rab bshad bya/ / spyod pa pha rol phyin mchog nyid/ / gang gis dngos grub mthar 'gro ba/ / kye yi rdo rjes dngos grub rgyus/ /
(1) Now we shall further tell of the practice so excellent and supreme, the cause of perfection by means of which one gains the finality of this perfection in Hevajra.

sgom pa po yis rnam 'dzin pa/ / rna ba dag la rna cha bzas/ / spyi bor 'khor lo rnam par 'dzin/ / lag pa dag la lag gdub gnyis/ / rked pa la yang ska rags nyid/ / rkang par de bzhin rkang gdub bo/ / lag pa'i rtsa bar dpung rgyan nyid/ / mgrin par rus pa'i phreng ba ste/ /

(2-3) The yogin must wear the sacred ear-rings, and the circlet on his head; on his wrists the bracelets, and the girdle round his waist, rings around his ankles, bangles round his arms; he wears the bone-necklace
bgo ba stag gi pags pa nyid/ / bza' ba mi 'chi'i bcu phyed de/ / he ru ka sbyor skyes bu ste/ / kha dog lnga la rnam par gnas/ /
(4) and for his dress a tiger-skin, and his food must be the five ambrosias. He who practises the yoga of Heruka should frequent the five classes.[5]
rigs lnga dag dang mnyam ldan pa/ / rigs ni gcig tu rnam par brtag / kha dog du ma nyid kyis ni/ / gang phyir dbye ba mtshon mi bya/ /
(5) These five classes that are associated together, he conceives of as one, for by him no distinction is made as between one class or many.
shing gcig dang ni dur khrod dang / / ma mo'i khyim dang mtshan mo dang / / yang na dben pa'am bas mtha' ru/ / bsgom pa bzang por brjod par bya/ /
(6) Meditation is good if performed at night beneath a lonely tree or in a cemetery, or in the mother’s house,[6] or in some unfrequented spot.
cung zad drod ni thob pa na/ / gal te spyod pa byed 'dod pas/ / gal te 'grub 'gyur 'dod yod na/ / 'dis ni spyod pa spyad pa nyid/ /
(7) When some heat has been developed,[1] if one wishes to perform this practice and to gain perfection, then upon this course one should proceed.

shin tu bzhin bzangs mig yangs ma/ / rang gis dbang bskur snying rje can/ / rdo rje'i bu mo 'di khyer nas/ / spyod pa bya bar rtogs par bya/ / rdo rje rigs kyi dngos med na/ / rang 'dod lha yi rigs kyis bya/ / yang na gzhan gyi rigs byung ba/ / byang chub sa bon gdab pa dang / / sbyang ba yis ni gzung bar bya/ /

(8-9) Take a girl of the Vajra-family, fair-featured and large-eyed and endowed with youth and beauty, who has been consecrated by oneself[2] and is possessed of a compassionate disposition, and with her the practice should be performed. In the absence of one from the Vajra-family, it should be performed with a girl from the family of one’s special divinity, or (if this fails) from some other. Take her then who is now consecrated with the depositing of the seed of enlightenment.
gal te dga' bas glu blang ste/ / de tshe rdo rje mchog ldan no/ / gal te dga' ba skyes pa na/ / thar pa'i rgyur ni gar bya ste/ / de tshe rdo rje rkang pas gar/ / yo gis mnyam par bzhag pas byed/ /

(10) If in joy songs are sung, then let them be the excellent Vajra-songs,[3] and if one dances when joy has arisen, let it be done with release as its object. Then the yogin, self-collected, performs the dance in the place of Hevajra.[4]
'khor lo'i gzugs kyis mi bskyod pa/ / rna cha'i bdag nyid 'od dpag med/ / mgul gyi phreng ba rin chen bdag / lag gdub rnam par snang mdzad brjod/ /
(11) Akṣobhya is symbolized by the circlet, Amitābha by the ear-rings, Ratneśa by the necklace, and Vairocana (by the rings) upon the wrists.
ska rags la ni don yod gnas/ / kha T+wA~M ga gzugs shes rab ste/ / thabs kyi gzugs kyis cang te'u nyid/ / zhe sdang rnam dag rnal 'byor pa/ /
(12) Amogha is symbolized by the girdle, Wisdom by the khaṭvāṅga and Means by the drum, while the yogin represents the Wrathful One himself.

glu ni rnam dag sdugs su gnas/ / gar ni bsgom pa byas pa nyid/ / de yi phyir na glu dang gar/ / yo gis rtag tu rtag tu byed/ / sman ni rnam par bza' ba ste/ / chu ni rtag par btung ba nyid/ / rga shis zil gyis mi non cing / / rtag tu bsrung bar 'gyur ba yin/ /

(13) Song symbolizes mantra, dance symbolizes meditation, and so singing and dancing the yogin always acts. (14) He should always eat herbs and drink water, then old age and death will not harm him and he will always be protected.

rkun ma'i skra las cod pan byas/ / de la hU~M byung sbyar bar bya/ / sangs rgyas lnga yi thod pa rnams/ / rnal 'byor spyod pas rnam par 'dzin/ / thod pa sor lnga pa yi tshad/ / byas pas cod pan 'dzin par byed/ / thabs dang shes rab rang bzhin las/ / skra yi ska rags nyis skor nyid/ / thal ba skra yi mchod phyir thogs/ / rnal 'byor pa yi spyod pas 'dzin/ / cang te'u sgra ni bzlas pa ste/ / kha T+wA~M ga sgom shes rab nyid/ / rdo rje thod pa'i sbyor ba yis/ / 'di dag bzlas dang sgom pa yin/ /

(15) Now he, whose nature is HŪṂ (viz. Hevajra), should arrange his piled-up hair[1] as a crest and for the performance of the yoga he should wear the skull-tiara, representing the five buddhas.[2] (16) Making pieces of skull five inches long, he should secure them to the crest. He should wear the two-stranded cord of hair, that symbolizes Wisdom and Means, the ashes and the sacred thread of hair; (17) the sound of the drum is his invocation, and the khaṭvāṅga of Wisdom is his meditation.[3] It is this that is intoned and meditated in the practice of Vajra and Skull.
b.

brkam dang rmongs dang 'jigs dang khro/ / ngo tsha'i 'bras bu rnam par spang / / bdag nyid kyis ni gnyid spangs nas/ / the tshom med par spyod pa bya/ / lus kyi sbyin pa byin nas ni/ / phyi nas spyod pa yang dag spyad/ / skal dang skal min rnam dpyad pas/ / de phyir sbyin pa sbyin mi bya/ / bza' bca' de bzhin btung ba nyid/ / ji ltar rnyed pa rab tu bza'/ / yid 'ong mi 'ong rnam rtog phyir/ / zhen pa tsam du mi bya'o/ / bza' dang bza' min spyod pa dang / / de bzhin btung dang btung min nyid/ / bgrod dang bgrod min sngags pa yis/ / rnam rtog nyid du mi bya'o/ /

(18) He should abandon desire and folly, fear and anger, and any sense of shame. He should forgo sleep and uproot the notion of a self, and then the practice may be performed, there is no doubt. (19) Only when he has made an offering of his own body,[4] should he commence the practice. Nor should he make this gift with the consideration of who is worthy and who is not. (20-21) Enjoying food and drink he should take it as it comes, making no distinction between that which is liked or disliked, eatable or uneatable, drinkable or undrinkable. Nor should he ever wonder whether a thing is suitable or unsuitable.
dngos grub rnyed pa'i slob ma gang / / yang dag ye shes snang ba po/ / mnar med spang ba'i rgyu yi phyir/ / grub pas bla ma mngon phyag 'tshal/ /
(22) Even when he has attained to siddhi and is resplendent in his perfect knowledge, a disciple respectfully greets his master, if he wishes to avoid the Avici Hell.

bslab dang dbang las rnam par grol/ / de bzhin ngo tsha'i 'bras bu nyid/ / dngos po kun gyi rang bzhin gyi/ / yo gis rnam dpyad snying rje che/ / sbyin sreg mchod sbyin dka' thub 'das/ / sngags dang bsam gtan rnam par spangs/ / dam tshig sdom las rnam par grol/ / rnal 'byor ldan pas spyod pa byed/ /

(23) Free from learning and ceremony and any cause of shame, the yogin wanders, filled with great compassion in his possession of a nature that is common to all beings. (24) He has passed beyond oblations, renunciation, and austerities, and is freed from mantra and meditation. Released from all the conventions of meditation,[3] the yogin performs the practice.
nges par sngon du lha min gang / / brgya byin ltu bu yin na yang / / de la 'jigs par mi bya ste/ / seng ge'i gzugs kyis rnam par rgyu/ /
(25) Whatever demon should appear before him, even though it be the peer of Indra, he would have no fear, for he wanders like a lion.
sems can kun gyi don gyi phyir/ / rtag tu snying rjes btung bar bya/ / rnal 'byor btung dga' rnal 'byor ba/ / gzhan gyi btung bas bzi ba med/ /
(26) For the good of all beings, his drink is always compassion, for the yogin who delights in the drink of yoga, becomes drunk with no other drink.
spyod pa'i le'u ste drug pa'o// //

d.crumb: brda dang gnas

f.d: [brda dang gnas]

d.crumb: vii. secret signs

f.d: CHAPTER VII. SECRET SIGNS
a.
de nas ts+tsho m+mA'i le'u bshad par bya'o/ / gang gis spun dang sring mor yang / / the tshom med par shes par bya/ /
(1) Now we shall expound the chapter on secret signs,[1] by which the (right) yogin and yoginī may be recognized with certainty.
gang zhig sor mo gcig ston dang / / gnyis kyis legs par 'ongs pa yin/ / g.yon pa'i mthe bong bcangs pa las/ / bsnyun gyi phyag rgyar rnam par shes/ /
(2) Whoever shows one finger, implies: Am I welcome?[2] The showing of two implies he is welcome. The sign of well-being may be known from pressure with the left thumb.
gang zhig srin lag ston pa la/ / de yi mthe'u chung rnam par sbyin/ / gang zhig gung mo ston pa la/ / de yi mdzub mo rnam par sbyin/ /
(3) If he presents the fourth finger, he should be shown the little finger. If he presents the middle finger, he should be shown the second finger.
gang zhig srin lag ston pa la/ / de yi mgrin pa rab tu bstan/ / gang zhig gos ni ston pa la/ / de yi rtse gsum rab tu bstan/ /
(4) If he shows the fourth finger, one should indicate to him the neck. If he shows a painting, one should show him a trident.
gang zhig nu ma ston pa la/ / de yi mtshams ni rab tu bstan/ / gang zhig so ni ston pa la/ / de yi kha ni rab tu bstan/ /
(5) If he indicates the breasts, one should indicate the parting of the hair. If he indicates the earth, one should indicate the mouth.
gang zhig khro gnyer ston pa la/ / gtsug phud dgrol bar brjod par bya/ / gang zhig dpral ba ston pa la/ / de yi rgyab ni rab tu bstan/ /
(6) If he indicates the eyebrow, one should indicate the loosening of one’s crest of hair. If he indicates the forehead, one should indicate the back.
gang zhig rkang mthil ston pa la/ / lto yis rnam par rtse bar bya/ / phyag rgya phyag rgya'i lan gyis ni/ / dam tshig gis ni rnam par bye/ /
(7) If he indicates the sole of the foot, one should dance with joy. So one explains things conventionally by means of sign and countersign.

de la rnal 'byor mas smras pa/ / e ma bu ni snying rje che/ / gal te phreng ba lag ston na/ / 'du bar bya zhes smra ba yin/ / phreng ba mngon par gtad byas na/ / dam tshig la mnos brtul zhugs bzang / / de la phyi rol zhes 'du ba/ / bzang po'i spyod yul la gnas pa/ / de la 'du bar rnal 'byor mas/ / gang smras de ltar thams cad bya/ /

(8) Then the yoginīs say: ‘Well done, O Son, thou of great compassion.’ If they show wreaths in their hands, they are signifying that you should come together in that place; (9) motioning forward with their wreaths' (they mean to say) ‘O True One, stay at this ceremony and take part’. So there at that meeting-place, abiding within that sacred orbit, he should do whatever the yoginīs say.
b.

kye bcom ldan 'das 'du ba'i gnas lags/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / gnas dang nye ba'i gnas dang ni/ / zhing dang nye ba'i zhing nyid dang / / ts+tshan do nye ba'i ts+tshan do dang / / de bzhin 'du ba nye 'du ba/ / 'thung gcod nye ba'i 'thung gcod nyid/ / dur khrod nye ba'i dur khrod nyid/ / 'di rnams sa ni bcu gnyis te/ / sa bcu'i dbang phyug mgon po nyid/ / 'dis ni gzhan gyis brjod mi bya/ /

(10) Vajragarbha said: ‘What, O Lord, are these places of meeting?’ The Lord replied: ‘They are the pīṭha and the upapīṭha, the kṣetra and the upakṣetra, the chandoha and the upachandoha, the melāpaka and the upamelāpaka, the pīlava and the upapīlava, the śmaśāna and the upaśma-śāna.[1] (11) These correspond with the twelve stages of a Bodhisattva. It is because of these that he receives the title of Lord of the Ten Stages and as Guardian Lord.’[1]
kye bcom ldan 'das gnas la sogs pa gang lags/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ /
(12) Vajragarbha said: ‘What are these pīṭhas and the rest?’[2] The Lord replied:
gnas ni dzA lan d+ha rar bshad/ / de bzhin du ni au T+yan nyid/ / gnas ni ko la la gi ri nyid/ / de bzhin du ni kA ma rU nyid/ /
‘The pīṭhas are Jālandhara, Oḍḍiyāna, Paurṇagiri, and Kāmarūpa;
nye gnas mA la wa zhes brjod/ / si na d+hu na gar nyid do/ / zhing ni mum+mu nir bshad de/ / zhing ni byed pa'i brang nyid do/ / de wI ko Ti de bzhin zhing / / zhing ni lcags pa'i brang nyid do/ /
(13) The upapīṭhas are Mālava, Sindhu, and Nagara. The kṣetras are Munmuni, Kāruṇyapāṭaka, Devīkoṭa, and Karmāra-pāṭaka.
nye zhing gu la ta zhes brjod/ / de bzhin a rbud nyid dang / / ba yi mchog sbyin kha ba'i ri/ / nye ba'i zhing ni mdor bsdus pa'o/ /
(14) The upakṣetras are Kulatā, Arbuda, Godāvarī, and Himādri.
ts+tshan do ha ri ke la dag / / lan tshwa rgya mtsho'i nang skyes dang / la ma ba kA dang kAny+tsi nyid/ / de bzhin saurASh+Sha nyid do/ /
(15) The chandohas are Harikela, arising in the salt-ocean, Lampāka, Kāñcika, and Saurāṣṭra.
nye ba'i ts+tshan do ka ling ka / gser dang ldan pa'i gling dang ni/ / kong ka Na yang nye tsan dor/ / mdor bsdus pas ni brjod par bya/ /
(16) The upachandohas are Kaliṅga, the Isle of Gold and Kokaṇa which is called upachandoha for short.
'thung gcod grong khyer gyi dang yang / / 'thung gcod grong gi mthar gnas pa/ / tsa ri tra dang ko sa la/ / bin d+h+ya gzhon nu'i grong khyer ro/ /
(17) The pīlavas comprise that which lies on the village boundary, and that belonging to the city, Caritra, Kośala, and Vindhyākau-mārapaurikā.
rdo rje snying po snying rje che/ / nye ba'i 'thung gcod de nye ba'o/ /
The upapīlava is nearby to that, O Vajragarbha of great compassion.
dur khrod rab son dge 'dun dang / / dur khrod rgya mtsho'i 'gram nyid do/ / skyed tshal ra ba rdzing bu'i 'gram/ / nye ba'i dur khrod brjod par bya/ /
(18) The śmaśānas are where the pretas meet and the ocean’s shore. The upaśmaśānas are the garden and the shore of the lotus-pool.
c.
sems can kun gyi don gyi phyir/ / rnal 'byor ma rgyud kye'i rdo rje/ / rnal 'byor ma yi legs 'du ba/ / nyin bar nyid kyang rab bshad bya/ /
(19) The day too I will tell you when the yoginīs meet together, for the purpose of the welfare of all beings in the Yoginī-tantra of Hevajra.’
kye bcom ldan 'das nyi ma gang lags/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / yi dgas zla phyed bcu bzhi dang / / de bzhin du yang brgyad pa nyid/ /
(20) Vajragarbha said: ‘Lord, which are those days?’ The Lord replied: ‘The fourteenth and the eighth days in the dark fortnight.
d.
rgyal mtshan dang ni mtshon bsnun nyid/ / lan bdun pa yang bza' bar bya/ /
(21) A man who has been hanged, a warrior killed on the field of battle, and a man of irreproachable conduct who has returned seven times to human state, of the flesh of these one should partake.[1]
e.

'bad pas snying rje bskyed pa yis/ / gsad par bya bar brjod pa nyid/ / snying rje med na mi 'grub pas/ / de phyir snying rje bskyed pa nyid/ / thams cad gdug pa gzhug pa ste/ / cho ga'i gtso bos dgag par bya/ /

The act of slaying[1] is performed, accompanied by the strenuous arousing of compassion. (22) Without compassion one cannot succeed, and so one should arouse compassion. By this best of methods the activity of evil is stopped.[2]
f.
de la 'di ltar blta ba nyid/ / nyin mo bcom ldan rdo rje can/ / mtshan mo shes rab brtag par bya/ /
(23) In this manner one should regard things: The day is the Adamantine Lord, and Prajñā is the night.
mi bya cung zad yod ma yin/ / rtag tu mi bza' yod ma yin/ / 'di la mi bsam yod ma yin/ / bzang ngan mi smra gang yang med/ /
(24) There exists nothing one may not do and nothing one may not eat. There is nothing one may not think or say, either pleasant or unpleasant.
ji ltar bdag nyid de ltar gzhan/ / de bzhin bdag ni nga mchog nyid/ / 'di ltar sems pa'i rnal 'byor bdag / bza' dang btung ba la sogs spyad/ /
(25) The Supreme Self (ahaṃ) exists in oneself just as in other beings and (as in other beings) so in oneself.[3] Conceiving thus, the yogin should approach food and drink and other things.
yan lag ji snyed bsgyur ba dang / / tshig rnams rab tu rgyas pa nyid/ / he ru ka dpal gnas bzhugs pas/ / de snyed sngags dang phyag rgya yin/ /
(26) Whatever movement of his limbs, whatever pouring forth of words, these are as mantra and mudrā for him who holds the place of Śrī Heruka.
shrI ni gnyis med ye shes te/ / he ni rgyu sogs stong pa nyid/ / ru ni tshogs dang bral ba nyid/ / ka ni gang du'ang mi gnas pa'o/ /
(27) ŚRĪ implies monistic knowledge, HE the voidness of causality, RU the end of discriminating thought, KA its indeterminability.
rdo rje thod pa'i sbyor ba yis/ / skye bo gang dang gang rnams kyi/ / sha ni mkhas pas bza' bar bya/ / sems can de de'i dbang du 'gyur/ /
(28) Those beings, whose flesh is eaten by knowing yogins, are subdued to their power by the yoga of vajra and skull.[4]
brda dang gnas gtan la phab pa'i le'u ste bdun pa'o/ /

d.crumb: rnal 'byor ma'i 'khor lo zhes bya ba 'du ba

f.d: [rnal 'byor ma'i 'khor lo zhes bya ba 'du ba]

d.crumb: viii. the troupe of yoginīs

f.d: CHAPTER VIII. THE TROUPE OF YOGINĪS
a.
de nas rnal 'byor ma'i 'khor lo bshad par bya'o/ / nam mkha'i khams su b+ha ga bsam/ / dbus su rnam par bsgom pa ni/ / 'khor lo sngon du ci rigs par/ / lha rnams ji ltar 'byung ba nyid/ /

(1) Now I shall explain the circle of the yoginīs. Concentrate upon the triangle of origination[1] in the midst of space, and then perform this meditation at its centre, first the figurative representations[2] of the four elements in their right order—in the due order of appearance of the divinities.[3]
'khor lo sa dang chu ni sngo/ / ji ltar rigs par byin za dang / / lha rnams kyis ni rlung chen dang / / ji ltar sgom po 'byung ba yang / /
(2) First earth and water, then fire and wind, which correspond with the appearance of the goddesses, and with the meditator himself.[4]

chos 'byung las skyes 'khor lo nyid/ / 'phar ma gnyis dag skyon med pa/ / ze'u 'bru las ni gcig 'gyur te/ / gru gsum gyis ni phyi mar brjod/ / de dbus shi ba bcwa lnga yi/ / gdan gyi bdag nyid rnam par bsam/ / de yi steng du zla ba yin/ / zla ba'i steng du sa bon nyid/ / phyi nas bdud las rgyal bas mnan/ /

(3) The maṇḍala which now arises pure and unblemished from the triangle, consists of two concentric parts, one formed by the eight central petals of the lotus, and the other by the triangle. (4) At their centre one should imagine a corpse,[5] which is in effect the seat of the fifteen yoginīs. Resting on that there should be a lunar disk, upon that the seed-syllable and upon that a solar disk.[6]
gnyis 'dus pa las bde chen po/ / A li zla ba'i gzugs kyis gnas/ / kA li'i gzugs kyis snang byed do/ / zla ba nyi ma 'dus pa las/ / dkar mo la sogs rab tu grags/ /

(5) The conjunction of these two, lunar disk and solar disk, is the great bliss, Āli has become the moon, and the sun has resolved into kĀli,[7] (6) and from this mingling of sun and moon Gaurī and her companions are proclaimed to be.
zla ba me long ye shes ldan/ / bdun gyi bdun pa mnyam nyid ldan/ /
The Moon is Mirror-like Wisdom,[1] The Sun is the Wisdom of Sameness,
rang lha'i sa bon phyag mtshan ni/ / so sor rtog par brjod par bya/ / thams cad gcig gyur nan tan nyid/ / rdzogs pa chos dbyings dag pa ste/ /
(7) The seed-syllables and symbols of the chosen divinity are Discriminating Wisdom. The merging of all into one is Active Wisdom, The manifestation is the Wisdom of the Pure Absolute.
mkhas pas cho ga gsungs pa yis/ / rnam pa lnga bo bsgom pa nyid/ /
(8) The sage should conceive of phenomenal forms in terms of these five modes here listed.

A li kA li mnyam sbyor bas/ / rdo rje sems dpa' nyid kyi gdan/ / yi ge las byung gong bu la/ / hU~M phaT rnam pa'ang 'dod mi bya/ / sems dpa'i gzugs brnyan las byung ba'i/ / dkyil 'khor bdag po rnam par bsgom/ /

The meeting-place of ĀLI and KĀLI is the seat of Vajrasattva. (9) For the embryo that arises from the seed-syllable the sound of HŪṂ and PHAṬ is not required.[2] One should envisage the chief divinity of the maṇḍala arising as a manifestation of that Being.

phyag mtshan zhal sogs gong ma bzhin/ / zla ba chu shel nor bu'i 'od/ / thabs dang shes rab rab bzhin las/ / 'di ltar thams cad rdzogs pa nyid/ / zla ba nyi ma'i rab dbye bas/ / A li shes rab kA li thabs/ / 'di las dkar mo la sogs pa/ / kha dog dbye bas so so yin/ / re zhig nang gi 'phar ma la/ / rnal 'byor ma lnga ngas gnas pa/ / phung po lnga yi rang bzhin gyis/ / rnal 'byor rig pas rtag tu bsgom/ / dbang por rdo rje gshin rjer dkar/ / chu bdag chu yi rnal 'byor ma/ / lus ngan rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma/ / dbus su bdag med rnal 'byor ma/ / phyi rol gyi ni 'phar ma la/ / dkar mo chom rkun ro langs ma/ / g+hasma rI dang puk+ka sI/ / ri khrod ma dang gdol ba ma/ / brgyad pa Do m+bi nI ru brjod/ / 'og ldan ma dang steng ldan nyid/ / mkha' spyod ma dang sa spyod brjod/ / srid dang zhi ba'i rang bzhin gyis/ / snying rje chen po 'di dag gnas/ /

(10) With features and symbolic implements as before,[3] and brilliant as the magic moon-stone, so they all become manifest with the self-nature of Wisdom and Means. (11) From the separating of Sun and Moon, Āli and KĀLI, Wisdom and Means, Gaurī and her companions arise each from a separate letter.[4] (12) Now in the inner circle there are five yoginīs, whom the knowing yogin always regards as representing the five skandhas. (13) In the east is Vajrā, and Gaurī to the south, Vāriyoginī in the west, Vajra-ḍākinī to the north, and Nairātmyā at the centre. (14) In the outer circle there are Gaurī II, Caurī, Vetālī, Ghasmarī and Pukkasī, Śavarī and Caṇḍālī, and Ḍombinī as the eighth. (15) At the zenith is Khecarī and at the nadir Bhūcarī, O thou of great compassion, and these two stand to represent saṃsāra and nirvāṇa.

lha mo thams cad kha dog gnag / drag chen phyag rgya lnga yis brgyan/ / zhal gcig spyan ni dmar ba rnams/ / lag par gri gug thod pas khyab/ / 'khor lo rna cha mgul rgyan dang / / lag par lag gdub ska rags nyid/ / sangs rgyas lnga ni rnam dag pas/ / 'di lnga phyag rgya dag pa'o/ / ji ltar bdag med rnal 'byor ma/ / de ltar thams cad rnam par bshad/ / lag pa gcig ni thod pas brel/ / g.yas pa na ni gri gug 'dzin/ / g.yon pas kha T+wA~M ga nyid do/ / stag gi pags pas rnam dkris shing / / rol zhon zhing gzi brjid 'bar/ / phyag gnyis gyen du dbu skyes ser/ /

(16) All these goddesses are black in colour and exceedingly fearful and decked with the five symbolic adornments. They have one face and inflamed eyes and clasp in their hands the knife and the skull. (17) The circlet, the ear-rings and the necklace, the bracelets and the girdle, such are the five symbolic adornments that symbolize the Buddhas Five. (18) Just as is Nairātmyā, so are they all proclaimed to be. One hand holds the skull, in the right hand is the knife (19) and in the left hand the khaṭvāṅga; around her thighs is a tiger-skin; she stands upon a corpse and is burning bright, with two arms and with yellow hair.
b.

nga rgyal la sogs skyon drug rnams/ / gcod phyir gri gug rnam par gnas/ / dngos dang dngos med rnam rtog gi/ / mgo bo'i pad+ma'i snod du ni/ / bdud rnams rnam pa bzhi yi khrag / dngos grub phyir ni btung bar bya/ / stong pa'i rnam pas kha T+wAM ga/ / thabs kyis ro ni rnam par brtag / 'dis ni 'khor lo rnam bsgoms na/ / dngos grub myur du thob par 'gyur/ /

(20) The knife is there to cut off the six defects of pride and so on,[1] and the skull for bringing to an end discriminating thought which would regard existence and non-existence as essentially different.[2] (21) From it one drinks the blood of the Four Maras. The khaṭvāṅga represents the Void and the corpse is understood as Means. (22) If he conceives of the troupe in this way, the yogin will very soon gain perfection.
c.

dang por nag po rab tu bsgom/ / gnyis par dmar po rnam par bsgom/ / gsum pa la ni ser po bsgom/ / bzhi par ljang gu de bzhin no/ / lnga par kha dog sngon po dang / / drug par dkar po'i lus can te/ / yan lag drug bsgom rnal 'byor pas/ / dga' bral mthar yang de bzhin no/ /

He should imagine the Innate under six aspects, first as black, secondly as red, (23) thirdly as yellow, fourthly as green, fifthly as indigo, and sixthly as white. (24) Then he conceives of it as the End of Cessation.[3]
bskyed pa'i rim pa nyid dang ni/ / rdzogs pa'i yang ni rim pa nyid/ / rim gnyis mnyam par gnas nas ni/ / rdo rje can gyis chos 'chad do/ / bskyed pa yi ni cha bshad do/ /

There is the Process of Emanation and the Process of Realization,[4] (25) and relying upon these two processes the Adamantine One teaches the doctrine. The Process of Emanation has been told, and now I will tell of the Process of Realization.
d.
nam mkha'i khams ni pad+ma la/ / b+ha ga zhes bya ye shes brjod/ / bsgom pa zhes bya snyoms 'jug nyid/ / de yi bde ba 'khor lor brjod/ /
(26) In space — In the lotus[5] is the triangle; — lies knowledge; here meditate. — here is union. Thence the circles — Thence bliss
sngon du byung ba zhu ba nyid/ / rim pa ji bzhin rang rig nyid/ / lha zhes bya ba byang chub sems/ / ji ltar 'byung ba khu ba yin/ /
(27) in right order, — self-experiencing, and the divine forms — which is bodhicitta appearing in due order. — and is śukra.

lhan cig skyes pa rnam pa gnyis/ / re zhig btsun mo shes rab yin/ / skyes bu thabs su brjod pa nyid/ / kun rdzob don dam dbye ba las/ / phyi nas de yi rnam pa gnyis/ / re zhig skyes bu rnam pa gnyis/ / de yi khu ba'ang bde ba nyid/ / skyes bu ji bzhin shes rab la'ang / / de yi khu ba'ang bde ba nyid/ /

Therefore twofold is the Innate, (28) for Wisdom is the woman and Means is the man. Thereafter these both become twofold, distinguished as absolute (vivṛti) and relative (saṃvṛti). (29) In man there is this twofold nature, śukra (relative) and the bliss arising from it (absolute); in woman too it is the same, śukra and the bliss arising from it.
e.

de nyid phyir na dga' ba nyid/ / bzhi yi rab tu dbye ba yis/ / skye med rim pa'i phyogs las ni/ / 'di ltar lhan cig skyes rnam bzhi/ / dga' ba dang po dpa' bo nyid/ / mchog tu dga' ba rnal 'byor ma/ / shin tu bde dga' thams cad nges/ / de bde'i thabs las thams cad rig /

(30) It is here that we have the distinction of the four kinds of Joy, since the Innate is fourfold in the Process of Realization.[1] (31) The first Joy is the yogin, perfect joy is the yoginī, extreme joy is all-embracing unity, and by means of that bliss one is omniscient.
dga' ba'i bde ba cung zad de/ / mchog tu dga' ba de las lhag / dga' bral dga' bas chags bral yin/ / lhag ma lhan cig skyes dga' nyid/ /
(32) From Joy there is some bliss, from Perfect Joy yet more, From the Joy of Cessation comes a passionless state. The Joy of the Innate is finality.
dang po reg par 'dod pa dang / / gnyis pa bde bar 'dod pa nyid/ / gsum pa 'dod chags 'jig pa nyid/ / des na bzhi pa bsgom par bya/ /
(33) The first comes by desire for contact, the second by desire for bliss, the third from the passing of passion, and by this means the fourth is realized.
mchog tu dga' ba srid par brjod/ / dga' bral las ni mya ngan 'das/ / dbu ma dga' ba tsam nyid de/ / 'dis ni lhan cig skyes pa spangs/ /
(34) Perfect Joy may be called saṃsāra, and nirvāṇa the Joy of Cessation, with plain Joy as a middle state. But the Innate is free of all three;
'dod chags med cing chags bral med/ / dbu mar dmigs par mi 'gyur ro/ /
(35) for there is found neither passion nor absence of passion, nor yet a middle state.
f.
'di la thabs dang shes rab med/ / yang dag de nyid snang ba'o/ /
