In that realization of the perfect truth there is neither Wisdom nor Means.
gzhan gyis brjod min lhan cig skyes/ / gang du yang ni mi rnyed de/ / bla ma'i dus thabs bsten pa yis/ / bdag gis bsod nams las shes bya/ /
(36) By no other may it be told, and from no one may it be received. It is known intuitively as a result of merit and of honouring one’s guru and the set observances.
dman pa 'bring dang mchog rnams dang / / gzhan rnams gang rnams de rnams kyang / / ro mnyam de nyid bsgoms pa yis/ / 'di kun mnyam pa nyid du blta/ /
(37) Small and middling and great and whatever other things there are, all these are regarded as equal by those who have realized the truth.
dman pa'i gnas ni phra ba'i don/ / mchog ni dngos por brjod par bya/ / dbu ma gnyis kyis spangs pa nyid/ / gzhan rnams zhes bya dbang po drug /
(38) (Small means the subtle concept of a thing, and great refers to the thing as existing; middling is neither the one nor the other, and other things refers to the six faculties of sense.)[2]

gang rnams de rnams brtan dang g.yo/ / 'di kun zhes bya nga nyid de/ / mnyam nyid mtshungs par 'dod pa nyid/ / ro mnyam de nyid bsgoms pas ni/ / mnyam zhes bya ba mtshungs par brjod/ / de yi 'khor lor zhas brjod/ / bsgom pa ro gcig mnyam pa nyid/ / 'dis ni don gyis brjod par bya/ /

(39) Whatever things there are, moving and motionless, all these things am I. They are accepted as being equal and the same by those who have realized the truth and find everywhere the same flavour. (40) To be equal is to be the same, and of this the manifestation[1] is the flavour. There is a single substance of the one same flavour,[2] and in this sense it is said:
nga las 'gro ba thams cad 'byung / / nga las gnas gsum po yang 'byung / / nga yis 'di kun khyab pa ste/ / 'gro ba'i rang bzhin gzhan ma mthong / /
(41) The whole of existence arises in me, In me arises the threefold world, By me pervaded is this all, Of nought else does this world consist.

de ltar rnal 'byor pas shes na/ / shin tu mnyam gzhag gang goms pa/ / bsod nams chung ba'i mi yis kyang / / de ni grub par the tshom med/ / bza' dang btung dang blugs pa dang / / nyal dang log dang sems pa na/ / phyag rgya chen po mngon 'dod pas/ / de nas sngon du 'gro bar 'gyur/ /

(42) Whatever yogin, thinking thus, should perform the practice in complete self-control, he will succeed, there is no doubt, even though he be a man of little merit. (43) Eating, drinking, performing ablutions, awake, asleep, it is thus he should think, and so seeking after the Great Symbol, he will gain thereby that eternal state.
gang phyir yid kyis mi bsgom par/ / 'gro ba thams cad bsgom par bya/ / thams cad chos ni yongs shes na/ / bsgom pa nyid ni bsgom pa min/ /
(44) One conceives of the whole of existence in that the mind does not conceive of it, and in this perfect knowledge, the conceiving is a nonconceiving.[3]
brtan dang g.yo ba'i dngos po gang / / rtswa lcug 'khri shing la sogs pa/ / bdag gi dngos po'i rang bzhin las/ / dam pa'i de nyid nges bsgom bya/ /

(45) Whatsoever things there are, whether moving or motionless, grass and shrubs and creeping-plants, they are conceived of as the supreme essence and possessing the nature that one possesses oneself.
de rnams dam pa gcig yod min/ / rang rig bde ba chen po nyid/ / rang rig nas ni byang chub 'gyur/ / rang rig phyir na bsgom pa nyid/ /
(46) In them there is just one without a second, great bliss which is self-experiencing. It is from this self-experiencing that perfection comes, and in self-experiencing consists thought-creation.
rang gis rig pa'i 'gyur ba las/ / dman pa las ni las skyes te/ / rang gis 'phrog cing rang gis byed/ / rang rig rgyal po rang gtso bo/ /
(47) Karma consists of this same self-experiencing, for karma arises when it is thwarted.[4] One is oneself the Destroyer, the Creator, the King, the Lord.
'dod chags zhe sdang phrag dog dang / / de bzhin gti mug nga rgyal nyid/ / de kun de gnas nyams dga' bar/ / bcu drug chaRa yang mi phod do/ /
(48) Passion and wrath, envy, delusion, and pride, none of these can prevail one sixteenth part against this delightful spot.[1]
chos 'byung las skyes ye shes ni/ / mkha' mnyam lhan cig thabs dang bcas/ / thabs dang shes rab rang bzhin las/ / 'jig rten gsum po de las skyes/ /
(49) It is the origin of all that is; it is knowledge; it is like space and it comprises Means. It is there that the threefold world arises of the nature of Wisdom and Means.
khu ba'i rnam pa bcom ldan nyid/ / de yi bde ba 'dod mar brjod/ / gcig dang du ma bral ba ste/ / skad cig gcig las mchog dga' ba/ /

(50) The Lord (Means) has the form of śukra, and the Lady (Wisdom) is the bliss that arises from it. He is free of the notions of unity and plurality, and she who is born of a moment, is the one supreme delight.
rang gis rig pa'i ye shes 'di/ / ngag gi lam 'das spyod yul te/ / 'di ni byin rlabs rim pa'i phyir/ / kun mkhyen ye shes de lta bu/ /
(51) Self-realizing is this knowledge which surpasses the scope of words. It is a process of empowering, for it consists of the knowledge that pertains to the Omniscient Ones.[2]
sa dang chu dang rlung dang ni/ / me dang nam mkha' nyid dag ni/ / rang gzhan rig pa'i tshor ba yis/ / kun gyis skad cig mi gnod de/ /
(52) Earth, water, wind, fire, and space; none may obstruct at that moment the knowledge that knows self and other.[3]
mtho ris mi yul rkang 'og gi/ / skad cig las ni gzugs gcig 'gyur/ / rang gzhan cha yi rnam rtog gis/ / gnod pa nyid ni nus pa min/ /
(53) At that moment it assumes one form together with the heavens, hells and abodes of men. Thus obstruction becomes impossible from that thought which distinguishes self and other.
thams cad rig byed grub mtha' dang / / de bzhin las rgyas la sogs pas/ / srid pa dag 'gyur dngos grub min/ / yang ni srid mthar skye bar 'gyur/ /
(54) Perfection is not achieved by all the vedas and siddhāntas, and by purification there is another birth in another existence.
'jig rten 'di dang pha rol du/ / de med pas kyang dngos grub med/ / gang gis mi shes kye'i rdo rje/ / de yi ngal ba don med 'gyur/ /
(55) Vain is the striving of him who does not know Hevajra, for without him there can be no perfection in this world or the next.
chu bo'i rgyun ni rab 'bab dang / / mar me'i rtse mo rab bcings ltar/ / rtag tu de nyid rnal 'byor gyis/ / nyin dang mtshan du rnam par gzhag /
(56) So always, all day and night, one should abide in union with this one essential, like the flowing of the river’s stream and the steadiness of the lantern’s light.
rnal 'byor ma'i 'khor lo zhes bya ba 'du ba'i le'u ste brgyad pa'o// //

d.crumb: rnam par dag pa

f.d: [rnam par dag pa]

d.crumb: ix. the spheres of purification

f.d: CHAPTER IX. THE SPHERES OF PURIFICATION
a.
de nas mchog tu rnam par dag pa'i le'u bshad par bya'o/ / nges par dngos po thams cad kyi/ / dag pa de bzhin nyid du brjod/ / phyi nas re re'i dbye ba yis/ / lha rnams kyi ni brjod par bya/ /

(1) Now I shall further expound the chapter on purification.[4] The purified condition of all things whatsoever is known[5] as the very truth itself. Proceeding from this we now speak of the purificatory power of the divinities, taking one by one.
phung po lnga dang dbang po drug / skye mched drug dang 'byung chen lnga/ / rang bzhin gyis ni rnam par dag / nyon mongs shes bya'i sgrib sbyang bya/ /
(2) The six faculties of sense, their six spheres of operation,[6] the five skandhas and the five elements are pure in essence, but they are obscured by the molestations of ignorance.

rang rig bdag nyid dag pa nyid/ / dag pa gzhan gyis rnam grol min/ / yul gyi dngos po dag pa'i phyir/ / rang gis rig pa'i bde ba mchog / gzugs la sogs pa'i yul rnams dang / / gzhan yang rnal 'byor pas mthong ba/ / dngos po de kun dag pa ste/ / 'di ltar 'gro ba sangs rgyas bdag /

(3) Their purification consists in self-experience, and by no other means of purification may one be released. This self-experiencing, this bliss supreme, arises from the pure condition of the spheres of sense. (4) Form and so on and whatever other spheres of sense there are, for the yogin all these appear in their purified condition, for of Buddha-nature[1] is this world.

kye bcom ldan 'das rnam par ma dag pa gang lags/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ gzugs la sogs pa'o/ /de ci'i slad du zhe na/ gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i dngos po'i phyir ro/ / rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ kye bcom ldan 'das gzung ba dang 'dzin pa yang gang lags/

(5) Vajragarbha said: ‘O Lord, what are these things unpurified?’ The Lord replied: ‘They are form and so on. And how so? Because of their nature as subject and object.’ Vajragarbha said: ‘What are these subjects and objects? ’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal ba/ / mig gis gzugs ni gzung bar bya/ / sgra ni rna bas mnyan par bya/ / dri ni sna yis tshor bar bya/ / lce yis ro ni myang bar bya/ /
(6) The Lord replied: ‘Form is perceived by the eye, sound is heard by the ear, smell is perceived by the nose, and taste by the tongue, ’tis sure;
dngos po lus kyis reg par bya/ / yid kyis bde sogs thob pa ni/ / dag pas dug med byas nas ni/ / bsten bya 'di dag bsten pa nyid/ /
(7) things are sensed by the body and feelings of pleasure and so on are received by the mind. These are worthy of indulgence and should be indulged, when once rendered innocuous by purification.
gzugs phung rdo rje ma yin te/ / tshor ba la yang dkar mor brjod/ / 'du shes chu yi rnal 'byor ma/ / 'du byed rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma/ /
(8) So there is Vajra for the rūpa-skandha (bodily form), Gaurī for the vedanā-skandha (feeling), Vāriyoginī for the saṃjñā-skandha (perception), Vajraḍākinī for the saṃskāra-skandha (impulses),
rnam shes phung po'i tshul gyis ni/ / bdag med rnal 'byor ma gnas so/ /
(9) Nairātmyā for the vijñāna-skandha (consciousness).
rtag tu 'di dag rnam dag pas/ / de nyid rnal 'byor pas 'grub 'gyur/ / nang gi 'phar ma la'o/ /
Such is the inner circle, and by the purificatory power of these, yogins who seek this truth will always gain their end.
de nas phyi yi 'phar ma bshad/ / dbang ldan du ni puk+ka sI/ / mer ni de bzhin ri khrod ma/ / bden bral gdol pa mo bzhag cing / / rlung du g.yung mo rnam par bzhag /
(10) As for the outer circle: in the north-east there is Pukkasī in the south-east there is Śavarī in the south-west there is Caṇḍālī in the north-west there is Ḍombinī
phyi nas lha mo dkar mo sogs/ / dbang dkar gshin rjer chom rkun ma/ / chu bdag phyogs su ro langs ma/ / lus ngan por ni g+hasma rI/ / 'og tu sa spyod ma zhes brjod/ /
(11) in the east is Gaurī II[2] in the south is Caurī in the west is Vetālī in the north is Ghasmarī at the nadir is Bhūcarī who represents saṃsāra
steng du mkha' spyod ma zhes bshad/ / bskyed pa'i rim pa nyid kyi phyogs/ / srid dang zhi ba'i rang bzhin gyis/ / lha mo 'di gnyis rnam par gnas/ /
(12) at the zenith is Khecarī who represents nirvāṇa. Such they are in the Process of Emanation.
gzugs la dkar mo rtag tu bshad/ / sgra la chom rkun ma rab grags/ / dri yi cha la ro langs ma/ / ro la g+hasma rI rab grags/ /
(13) Gaurī is for form, Caurī is for sound, Vetālī is for smell, Ghasmarī is for taste,
reg la sa spyod ma zhes bshad/ / chos kyi dbyings la mkha' spyod ma/ / rtag tu 'di dag rnam dag pas/ / de nyid rnal 'byor pas 'grub 'gyur/ /
(14) Bhūcarī is for touch, Khecarī is for thought. By the purificatory power of these, yogins who seek this truth will gain their end.
b.
phyag gi dag pa stong pa nyid/ / bdud dag pa las zhabs rnams nyid/ / rnam thar brgyad kyis zhal rnams nyid/ / rdo rje gsum gyis dag pa'i spyan/ /

(15) The purificatory significance of the sixteen arms is the sixteen kinds of voidness.[1] The four legs signify the crushing of the four Māras,[2] The faces the eight releases,[3] The eyes the three adamantine ones,[4]
sa ni buk+ka sI zhes bshad/ / chu khams rngon pa mo zhes brjod/ / me ni gtum mor shes par bya/ / rlung ni g.yung mor rab tu grags/ /
(16) Pukkasī is for earth, Śavarī is for water, Caṇḍālinī is for fire, Ḍombī is for wind.
zhe sdang zhes bshad rdo rje ma/ / 'dod chags chu yi rnal 'byor ma/ / phrag dog rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma/ / ser sna gsang ba'i dkar mo nyid/ /
(17) Nairātmyā[5] is pervaded by wrath, Vāriyoginī by passion, Vajraḍākinī by envy, The hidden Gaurī[6] by malignity,
gti mug de bzhin rdo rjer bshad/ / zhe sdang la sogs rnam spyod pa/ / bskyed pa'i rim pa'i phyogs las ni/ / 'dis ni phung po sbyang bar bya/ /
(18) Vajrā by delusion. By these the skandhas are purified in the Process of Emanation.
gang dang gang gis 'jig rten 'ching 'gyur ba/ / de dang des ni 'ching ba las grol te/ / de nyid mi shes 'jig rten mi grol zhing / / de nyid rnam spangs dngos grub rnyed mi 'gyur/ /
(19) That by which the world is bound, by that same its bonds are released, but the world is deluded and knows not this truth, and he who is deprived of this truth will not gain perfection.
de phyir dri med sgra med gzugs nyid med/ / ro dang sems kyi rnam par dag pa med/ / reg med chos med thams cad rnam par dag / rang bzhin dag pa'i 'gro la 'gro bar shes/ /

(20) So it is said: “No smell, no sound, no form, no taste, and no purification of thought, no touch, no substance, for the world is essentially pure by a universal purification. Ah, I know the world.”[1]
rnam par dag pa'i le'u ste dgu ba'o// //
[dbang]

d.crumb: x. consecration

f.d: CHAPTER X. CONSECRATION
a.
de nas ji ltar dkyil 'khor gyi/ / rim pa yang dag rab tu bshad/ / gang gis slob ma dbang bskur ba'i/ / cho ga'ang rab tu bshad par bya/ /
(1) Now I shall expound the ordering of the maṇḍala, by means of which a pupil is consecrated, and of the rite too I shall speak.
dang por lha yi bdag nyid kyi/ / rnal 'byor pas ni nor 'dzin sbyang / / 'bad pas hU~M las rdo rje can/ / byas te phyi nas dkyil 'khor pri/ /
(2) First the yogin, himself the essence of the god, should purify the site, and having zealously prepared the requisite protection,[2] he should then inscribe the maṇḍala.

tshal dang skye bo med gnas dang / / byang chub sems dpa'i khyim dang ni/ / dkyil 'khor khang pa'i nang du yang / / dkyil 'khor dam pa rab tu bzhengs/ / rdul tshon dam pa'i tshon dang ni/ / yang na 'bring po nyid kyis te/ / rin chen lnga yi phye ma'am/ / yang na 'bras la sogs pas so/ /

(3) In a garden or in a lonely spot or in a bodhisattva’s house[3] or in the centre of the maṇḍala-hall[4] one should lay out the maṇḍala supreme, (4) using the sacred writing-colours,[5] or secondly powder made from the five gems, or else the grains of rice and so on.

de nas dkyil 'khor khru gsum dang / / mthe bong gsum ni lhag par bya/ / der ni rigs lnga las byung ba'i/ / rig ma bzang mo rnam par gzhug / yang na ji ltar gang rnyed de/ / de ltar bcu drug lon pa nyid/ / ji srid khu ba ldan gyur pa/ / de srid phyag rgya bsten par bya/ /

(5) With these the maṇḍala should be made, in size three cubits plus three inches. The celestial spell who comes of the Five Families, should be placed there, (6) or whatsoever sixteen-year-old girl is found.[5] A yoginī is resorted to, so long as she possesses śukra.

phyag rgya'i gdong ni bcing ba dang / / thabs kyi gdong yang de bzhin no/ / bsten pa de las gang byung ba/ / slob ma'i khar ni btung bar bya/ / ro mnyam slob ma'i spyod yul nyid/ / de nyid la yang bya bar bya/ /

(7) One binds the face of the pràjñā and likewise of the upāya, and the product of the service rendered one drops into the pupil’s mouth. (8) In that very act the Flavour of Sameness should be placed within the pupil’s range.
b.

rang rig ye shes nyid du 'gyur/ / rang gzhan yang dag rig pa spangs/ / mkha' mnyam rdul bral stong pa nyid/ / dngos dang dngos med bdag nyid mchog / thabs dang shes rab shin tu 'dres/ / chags dang chags bral rnam par 'dres/ /

From self-experiencing comes this knowledge, which is free from ideas of self and other; (9) like the sky it is pure and void, the essence supreme of non-existence and existence, a mingling of Wisdom and Means, a mingling of passion and absence of passion.
de nyid srog chags rnams kyi srog / de nyid yi ge dam pa nyid/ / de nyid 'gro ba'i bdag nyid de/ / de nyid thams cad khyab pa po/ / thams cad lus la rnam par gnas/ /
(10) It is the life of living things, it is the Unchanging One Supreme; it is all-pervading, abiding in all embodied things.
dngos dang dngos med de las byung / /
(11) It is the stuff the world is made of, and in it existence and nonexistence have their origin.

gzhan rnams gang rnams de rnams dang / / rnam par shes pa kun gyi tshul/ / skyes bu sngon rabs dbang phyug dang / / bdag dang gso ba sems can dang / / dus dang gang zag nyid dang ni/ / dngos po kun gyi rang bzhin 'di/ / sgyu ma'i gzugs kyis yang dag gnas/ /

(12) It is all other things that there are: the universal consciousness, the primeval man, Īśvara, ātman, jīva, sattva, kāla, pudgala. It is the essential nature of all existing things and illusory-in its forms.
dang po dga' ba tsam nyid de/ / gnyis pa'i grangs las mchog dga' nyid/ / gsum pa las ni dga' bral bshad/ / bzhi pa lhan cig skyes par brjod/ /
(13) First is just Joy, Secondly is Joy Supreme, Thirdly is the Joy of Cessation, Fourth is the Joy Innate.
de bzhin gshegs pa rnams dang ni/ / rdo rje snying po la sogs kun/ / mkhas pas de skad nges thos nas/ / mchog tu ngo mtshar gyur nas ni/ / brgyal zhing sa la 'gyel bar 'gyur/ /
(14)[1] Hearing this, all the buddhas, Vajragarbha and the rest, were seized with the greatest astonishment and fell senseless to the ground.
dang po dga' ba 'gro ba'i gzugs/ / de bzhin mchog dga' 'gro ba nyid/ / dga' bral dga' ba'ang 'gro ba nyid/ / gsum pa lhan cig skyes pa med/ /
(15) The first Joy is of this world, the second Joy is of this world, the third Joy is of this world, but the Innate exists not in these three.’
bcom ldan bka' stsal kye'i rdo rje/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi sku gcig pa/ / rdo rje snying pos rtogs bya'i phyir/ / the tshom legs par sel ba ni/ /
(16) Then the Lord Hevajra whose form comprises all the Buddhas, said these words for the arousing of Vajragarbha, and which were a wondrous cure for their astonishment.
'dod chags med cing chags bral med/ / dbu mar dmigs par mi 'gyur ro/ / gsum po spangs pa nyid kyi phyir/ / lhan cig skyes pa byang chub brjod/ /
(17) ‘Neither passion nor absence of passion is found there, nor yet a middle state. Because of its freedom from all three the Innate is called perfect enlightenment.
yang na de nyid thams cad bdag / yang na kun gyis rnam par spangs/ / de yang dga' bral dang por mtshon/ / dga' ba gsum po rnam par spangs/ /
(18) The essence of all things and yet free of all things, one may mark it at the beginning of Cessation,[2] but from those other three Joys it is free.
dang po sprin dang 'dra ba yin/ / grub pa sgyu ma lta bur 'gyur/ / gnyid log sad par mi byed par/ / nyal dang log pa'i khyad par las/ / rtag tu rmi lam 'dra bar 'gyur/ /
(19) At first it appears as cloud, but with realization arisen it appears as māyā; then it suddenly appears as sleep with no distinction between sleep and the waking state.
dngos grub mtshan nyid mi phyed pa'i/ / phyag rgya rnal 'byor pa yis 'grub/ /
(20) The yogin of the Great Symbol gains fulfilment in that which is no fulfilment, for its characteristic is the very absence of any characteristic.’
c.

ston pas dkyil 'khor 'di skad gsungs/ / gru bzhi yang dag 'bar ba nyid/ / sgo bzhi gzi brjid chen po ste/ / do shal do shal phyed pas brgyan/ / phreng ba sna tshogs rnga yab ldan/ / ka ba brgyad kyis nye bar brgyan/ / rdo rje srad bu mnyam par ldan/ / me tog sna tshogs nye bar brgyan/ / bdug pa mar me de bzhin dri/ / bum pa brgyad la sogs pa ldan/ /

Then the Master spoke of the maṇḍala, blazing (21) and brilliant, square with four portals, adorned with garlands and chains and variously coloured streamers, equipped with eight columns (22) and vajra-threads, decorated with flowers of different hues, with incense, lamps, and scents, and provided with the eight vessels.
de yang yal ga la sogs brgyan/ / mgrin pa gos kyis dgab pa dang / / rin chen lnga ni yongs su gzhug / rnam par rgyal ba shar du sbyin/ /
(23) These last have branches in them, and their necks are covered with cloth and encircled with the five kinds of gem. To the east one should place the Vessel of Victory.
rang 'dod lha yi gzugs kyis ni/ / sar pa legs par bkal ba dang / / shin tu tshad ma mdzes pa yi/ / sra dbus shes rab can gyis gdab/ /
(24) With a fair new thread, well-fastened and of right measurement, the master should bind it round, for it represents the chosen divinity.

'khor lo'i bdag po'i bzlas pa 'bum/ / dkyil 'khor can gyi de bzhin khri/ / gong du gsungs pa'i sngags nyid kyis/ / mkhas pas nor 'dzin rnam par sbyang / / gong gi a sogs sngags kyis ni/ / de la gtor ma rnam par sbyin/ / ji ltar bsam gtan de bzhin 'dir/ / bsrung ba ji ltar gsungs pa nyid/ /

(25) He should repeat one hundred thousand times the mantra of the central divinity, and ten thousand times that of the other components. With the mantra quoted above he should purify the site, (26) but first he should present an offering accompanied by the mantra: OṂ A-kāro, and c.[3] He should perform the rite of protection just as prescribed, for as for meditation so it is here.
gang zhig dbang ni rab phye ba/ / rang gi dkyil 'khor cho gas sbyin/ / mchod dang gsol ba gdab pa nyid/ / ji ltar bshad pa de bzhin 'dir/ /
(27) The consecrations which are taught, he should give correctly in his maṇḍala, and worship and supplication should be made as ordained.

'phar ma gnyis bzang rnam bris nas/ / myur du dkar mo la sogs bri/ / shar du gri gug rnam par bri/ / lho dang nub tu'ang de bzhin no/ / byang dang me yi mtshams dang ni/ / bden bral rlung du'ang de bzhin no/ / dbang ldan du ni ci gsungs pa/ / da lta de ltar 'og dang steng / /

(28) He should draw the unblemished twofold circle of Gaurī and her companions. In the east he should draw a knife,[1] and continue likewise to the south and west (29) and north, to south-east, south-west, north-west, north-east, even as it is prescribed, and likewise to nadir and zenith.
rdo rje sems dpa'i snyems byas nas/ / rkang pa g.yas pa brkyang byas te/ / phyag gnyis kye rdo rje sbyor bas/ / slob dpon dkyil 'khor 'jug pa nyid/ /
(30) Then the master should enter the maṇḍala as two-armed Hevajra, and assuming the majestic bearing of Vajrasattva, he should adopt the ālīḍha[2] posture.
khrus dang gtsang sbra dri zhim lus/ / sna tshogs rgyan gyis rnam par brgyan/ / hU~M hU~M snyems pa byas nas ni/ / hI hI rnam pas 'jigs byed bdag /
(31) He is washed and purified and perfumed, and adorned with the various adornments. HŪṂ HŪṂ he cries majestically, HI HI he cries to terrify.
d.
phyi nas de nyid yang dag bshad/ / rnam dag ye shes gzugs can dang / / 'khor ba dang ni mya ngan 'das/ / khyad par cung zad yod ma yin/ /
(32) Then the essence is declared, pure and consisting in knowledge, where there is not the slightest difference between saṃsāra and nirvāṇa.

mchog dgar bsgom pa med cing sgom pa po yang med/ / lus kyang med cing gzung ba med dang 'dzin pa'ang med/ / sha dang khrag kyang med cing bshang dang gci ba'ang med/ / skyug bro rmongs med gtsang sbra mchod phyir thogs med dang / /

(33) Nothing is mentally produced in the highest bliss, and no one produces it, There is no bodily form, neither object nor subject, Neither flesh nor blood, neither dung nor urine, No sickness, no delusion, no purification,

chags med sdang ba med dang rmongs med phrag dog med/ / ser sna med dang nga rgyal med cing mthong bya med/ / bsgom dang sgom pa po med bshes dang dgra med cing / / rlom sems med pa'i lhan cig skyes pa'i sna tshogs nyid/ /

(34) No passion, no wrath, no delusion, no envy, No malignity, no conceit of self, no visible object, Nothing mentally produced and no producer, No friend is there, no enemy, Calm is the Innate and undifferentiated.
e.
rdo rje snying pos 'di skad gsol/ / gzod nas rang bzhin med pa yi/ / lus kyi rang bzhin dag pa ni/ / ci slad 'byung ba'i bdag nyid lags/ /
(35) Then Vajragarbha said: ‘How does bodily form consisting of the five elements come about, for in the beginning it is essentially pure and lacks any proper nature? ’
de nas bcom ldan rdo rje can/ / mkha' 'gro bde ba sbyin pas gsungs/ / rlom sems med pa'i rang bzhin bdag / thams cad lus la rnam par gnas/ /
(36) Then said the Adamantine Lord, rejoicer of the ḍākinīs: ‘Calm it is in its proper nature and abiding in all bodily form.’
kye bcom ldan 'das ci'i slad du 'byung ba chen po las gyur pa'i phung po lags/
(37) Vajragarbha then said: ‘But how, Lord, should the group of skandkas come about?’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / po la kak+kol sbyor bas/ / reg pa sra ba'i chos kyis ni/ / sa ni de las skye bar 'gyur/ /
(38) The Lord replied: ‘At the union of vajra and lotus, earth arises there from that contact with the quality of hardness.

byang sems khu ba'i rnam pa las/ / chu yi khams ni 'byung bar 'gyur/ / bskyod pa las ni drod skye ste/ / 'gro bas rlung du rab tu grags/ / bde ba nam mkha' nyid kyi khams/ / lnga bo rnams kyis yongs su bskor/ / gang phyir 'byung ba che bde ba/ / de phyir bde ba de nyid min/ /

(39) From the flow of śukra water arises, and fire from the friction. Wind comes from the motion, (40) and space corresponds to the bliss. Because it is involved with these five, bliss is not the final essence, for bliss consists in the elements.
lhan cig skyes pas gang skyes pa/ / lhan cig skyes par de brjod bya/ / rang bzhin lhan cig skyes zhes brjod/ / rnam pa thams cad sdom pa gcig /
(41) The Innate is proclaimed as that which arises in spontaneity. The Innate is called self-nature, the single unity of all phenomenal forms.
phyag rgya rgyu dang bral ba las/ / yo gi snying rje thabs su 'gyur/ / stong nyid snying rje dbyer med pa/ / byang chub sems zhes rab tu brjod/ /
(42) The yogin is Means and Compassion, and the yoginī Wisdom and Voidness for she is deprived of causation.[1] The thought of enlightenment is the undivided unity of Compassion and Voidness.
sngags kyi bzlas med dka' thub med dang sbyin sreg med/ / dkyil 'khor can yang med cing dkyil 'khor yang ni med/ /
(43) There is no recitation of mantras, no austerities, no oblations, no maṇḍala, and none of its components.
de ni sngags bzlas de dka' thub dang de sbyin sreg / de ni dkyil 'khor can dang de ni dkyil 'khor nyid/ /
This is the recitation of mantras, the austerities and oblations, this is the maṇḍala and its components.
mdor bsdus nas ni sems ni 'dus pa'i gzugs can no/ /
This in short consists of unity of thought.
dbang gi le'u zhes bya ba ste bcu pa'o// //

d.crumb: lta stangs

f.d: [lta stangs]

d.crumb: xi. the four gazes

f.d: CHAPTER XI. THE FOUR GAZES[2]
a.
mnyam par ma rangs dbral ba can/ / rtag tu ltung bar byed par brjod/ / dbang gi lta stangs g.yon na gnas/ / g.yon pa nas ni gzugs brnyan gnyis/ /
(1) For Overthrowing the eyes are level with the gaze directed upwards towards the forehead. For Subduing the gaze is directed towards the left and the two eyes towards the left.
g.yas pa'i cha la dgug pa nyid/ / steng nas kyang ni gzugs brnyan gnyis/ / dbu ma rengs pa'i lta stangs nyid/ / sna yi rtse mo'i dbus su gnyis/ /
(2) For Conjuring forth one directs the two eyes towards the right and upwards. For Petrifying the gaze is central with the eyes looking towards the end of the tip of the nose.[3]
'byung ba nyid kyis ltung bar byed/ / rngub pa yis ni dbang du byed/ / dgang ba yis ni dgug pa nyid/ / gzhil ba yis ni rengs par byed/ /
(3) Overthrowing is accompanied by exhaling, Subduing by inhaling, Conjuring forth by holding the breath, and Petrifying by the tranquillized pose.[1]
rlon pa'i shing la ltung byed nyid/ / dbang ni me tog rab tu grags/ / rdo rje'i shing la dkug pa nyid/ / g.yo bcas rtsa la rengs byed nyid/ /
(4) Overthrowing must take place amidst succulent trees, Subduing is associated with flowers, Conjuring forth must take place amidst vajra-trees, and Petrifying in moving grass.[2]
zla drug goms pa'i sbyor ba yis/ / 'grub 'gyur 'dri la the tshom med/ / 'di la 'khrul ba mi bya ste/ / sangs rgyas rdzu 'phrul bsam mi khyab/ /
(5) With six months’ application to the practice one will succeed, there is no doubt. Let no mistakes be made about it, unthinkable are a buddha’s powers.
lta stangs bzhi po bsgrubs nas ni/ / mkhas pas sems can gzhug par bya/ / gsad par 'di la bya ma yin/ / dam tshig nges par nyams par 'gyur/ /
(6) Having perfected the four gazes, the yogin should bring about the salvation of all beings. Actual slaying should not be done as that would be indeed a breach of the convention.[1]
sems can slu ba spangs nas ni/ / bya ba ma yin thams cad bya/ / sems can gnod pa tsam gyis ni/ / phyag rgya'i dngos grub rnyed mi 'gyur/ /
(7) All things not done may here be done except for misleading living-beings. One does not obtain the perfection of the sign by simply harming living-beings.
b.
de la dam tshig bza' bya ba/ / na dang ga ha dang po dang / / mtha' yi shwa dang dang po'i shwa/ / kye'i rdo rje yi dngos grub phyir/ / bdud rtsi lnga yang de bzhin bza'/ /

(8) For the sake of perfection in Hevajra he should consume the fivefold sacrament of initial na, initial ga, initial ha, final Śva and initial Śva. (9) So five ambrosias one should consume for the sake of perfection in Hevajra.[2]

kye yi rdo rjes gsungs mtshan nyid/ / skye ba bdun pa'ang de nas mtshon/ / dga' bral dga' ba la smod pa/ / lan bdun pas ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / skad snyan mig dang ldan pa dang / / dri lus gzi brjid chen po dang / / de yi grib ma bdun du 'gyur/ / mthong nas rnal 'byor pa yis mtshon/ / de ni zos pa tsam gyis ni/ / skad cig las ni mkha' spyod 'gyur/ /

Then one should mark out a ‘seven-timer’[3] with the characteristics recounted in Hevajra. (10) In the seventh birth there comes about that perfection, making of no account the Joy of Cessation (which precedes it). He has a fair-sounding voice, beauteous eyes and a sweet-smelling body of great splendour, (11) and he possesses seven shadows.[1] When he sees such a one the yogin should mark him out. By the mere eating of his flesh one will gain at that moment the powers of an aerial being.[2]
c.
ku ru kul+le'i sgrub thabs bshad par bya ste/ gong du brtag pa bcu gnyis par/ / rgyas par gsungs pa mdo ru bsdu/ /
(12) Now I shall give the sādhana of Kurukullā, by means of which all beings are brought into subjection. It has been mentioned before in brief, and is told in full in twelve parts.[3]
hrIHlas byung ba'i lha mo ni/ / kha dog dmar zhing phyag bzhi ma/ / mda' dang gzhu yi lag pa ma/ / ut+pa la dang lcags kyu 'dzin/ /
(13) This goddess arises from the syllable HRĪḤ, is red in colour with four arms, and in her hands she holds a bow, an arrow, a blue lotus, and a hook.

'di ni bsgoms pa tsam gyis ni/ / 'jig rten gsum po dbang du byed/ / 'bum phrag gcig gis rgyal po rnams/ / khri yis 'jig rten phal ba nyid/ / bye bas phyugs dang gnod sbyin sogs/ / 'bum phrag bdun gyis lha ma yin/ / 'bum phrag gnyis kyis lha rnams nyid/ / brgya phrag gcig gis sngags pa nyid/ /

(14) By merely meditating upon her one brings the threefold world to subjection. By 100,000 recitations of her mantra one reduces kings, by 10,000 the people, (15) by 10 million cattle and yakṣas, by 700,000 the titans, by 200,000 the gods, and yogins by 100.
kye'i rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dra ba'i sdom pa las rdo rje snying po mngon par byang chub pa zhes bya ba brtag pa'i rgyal po rdzogs so// //

f.d: PART II

d.crumb: rab gnas

f.d: [rab gnas]

d.crumb: i. consecrations and oblations

f.d: CHAPTER I. CONSECRATIONS AND OBLATIONS
a.
rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ bcom ldan rdo rje snying po bdag / sangs rgyas thams cad gcig bsdus pa/ / rab gnas mtshan nyid bzang po nyid/ / rim pa ji bzhin bshad du gsol/ /
(1) Then Vajragarbha said: ‘May the Adamantine Lord, whose form comprises all the Buddhas, tell us about the consecration of books and images and so on, just as it should be.’[1]
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / ci gsungs sbyin sreg byas nas ni/ / dkyil 'khor dam pa bzhengs pa dang / / snga bar sku gzugs sbyang ba dang / / sta gon la sogs byas nas ni/ /
(2) The Lord replied: ‘Having made the correct oblation and laid out the maṇḍala, at night-fall one should prepare the image, the requisite arrangements being made.
nam mkhar bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas kun/ / sku gzugs snying gar rab tu gzhug / rang 'dod lha mnyam rnal 'byor pa/ / rab mthong sngags kyi pha rol son/ /
(3) Then into its heart one should cause to enter the buddhas of all the directions, remaining united with one’s chosen divinity and with full and intuitive knowledge of the mantras.
oM badzra puSh+pe AHhUM swA hA/ oM badzra d+hu pe AHhUM swA hA/ oM badzra dI pe AHhUM swA hA/ oM badzra gan+d+he AHhUM swA hA/ / oM badzra nai we d+ye AHhUM swA hA/
(4) ‘OṂ Vajra-flower ĀḤ HŪṂ SVĀHĀ’ ‘OṂ Vajra-incense „ „ ’ ‘OṂ Vajra-lamp ,, „ ’ ‘OṂ Vajra-perfume „ „ ’ ‘OṂ Vajra-offering „ „ ’
sna tshogs hUM ni rdzogs pa dang / / me tog la sogs dbul ba nyid/ / gong ma'i rgyud kyi chog rim pas/ / mchod yon zhabs bsil gong ma bzhin/ /
(5) So one should present flowers and so on, produced variously from the syllable HŪṂ, offerings of water for the feet and so on, all as before in accordance with the way of former tantras.’[2]
b. The oblations:[3]
zhi ba'i thab khung zlum po nyid/ / rgyas pa nyid kyi gru bzhi pa/ / gsad pa la ni gru gsum brjod/ / 'di nyid la ni lhag ma bsgrub/ /
(6) For Propitiation the place for the fire should be round, for the Bestowing of Prosperity it should be square, for Slaying it should be triangular, and here too one should perform the others.
khru gang dang ni khru phyed nyid/ / zhi ba'i steng dang 'og tu yin/ / khru do dang ni khru gang nyid/ / rgyas pa'i steng dang 'og tu brjod/ /
(7) For Propitiation it should be one cubit across and half a cubit deep, For the Bestowing of Prosperity two cubits across and one deep,

sor mo nyi shu'am de yi phyed/ / gsad pa'i steng dang 'og tu yang / / zhi bar kha dog dkar por 'gyur/ / rgyas par ser po de bzhin no/ / gsad pa la ni kha dog gnag / dbang la dmar por rab tu grags/ / dbang la ji bzhin de ltar dgug / gsad la ji ltar zhe sdang sogs/ /

(8) For Slaying twenty aṅgulas across and ten deep.[4] For Propitiation it is white, for the Bestowing of Prosperity it is yellow, (9) for Slaying black, and for Subduing red. Conjuring forth is as for Subduing, and causing Hatred is as for Slaying.
zhi la til dang rgyas la zho/ / gsad la tsher ma de bzhin no/ / sdang la sogs pa'ang tsher mar brjod/ / dbang dang dgug la ut+pa la/

(10) As for the actual oblations, for Propitiation one uses sesame oil, for Bestowing Prosperity curds, for Slaying, causing Hatred and other harmful rites one uses thorns, and a blue lotus for Subduing and Conjuring forth.
oM a sne ma hA te dzA/ sar+b+ba karma pa sA d+hu kaH kA ru N+yA kr-i ta sa twa ar+tha a smin san+ni hi to b+ha ba/ me dgug pa'o/ /
(11) The mantra for invoking Fire: OṂ Agni of mighty energy, fulfiller of all desires, who in compassion serves all beings, be thou present here.
ma ma rin chen sna tshogs 'dzin/ / kye yi rdo rje khros mchod pa'i/ / lha mo khyod ni dbang du gyur/ / che ge bdag ni dkyil 'khor 'dri/ /

(12) The invocation of the Earth-Goddess: Thou Goddess, honoured by Hevajra’s wrath, Mother of the Earth, and bearer of many kinds of gems, Thou art witness here, for I, so and so, would lay out the maṇḍala.
swAr+thany+tsai ba ba rAr+thany+tsa sA d+hi taM gats+tsha ha bya b+hu ka / A ga mi Sh+ya si ya thA kA le sar+b+ba sid+d+hiM ku ru Sh+wa me/ me dga' ba'i sngags so/ /
(13) The mantra for gratifying Fire: Go thou, O Consumer of the Offering, to prosper the affairs of yourself and of others. At the right time you will approach. Grant me complete success.
oM dzaHhUM baM hoH khaM raM mchod yon gyi sngags so/ / oM ni ri ti hUM khaMHzhabs bsil gyi sngags so/ / oM d+h+wa~M d+h+wa~M lha bshos kyi sngags so/ /
(14) Mantra of the offerings: OṂ JAḤ HŪṂ VAṂ HĀḤ KHAṂ RAṂ Mantra of the water for the feet: OṂ NĪ RĪ HŪṂ KHAḤ Mantra of the food-offering: OṂ DHVAṂ DHVAṂ DHVAṂ
kye'i rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dra ba'i sdom pa las brtag pa gnyis pa rab gnas kyi le'u ste dang po'o// //

d.crumb: dngos grub gtan la phab pa

f.d: [dngos grub gtan la phab pa]

d.crumb: ii. the certainty of success

f.d: CHAPTER II. THE CERTAINTY OF SUCCESS
a.
rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ nam mkha' lta bu'i chos kun la/ / rgya mtshor ku ba ji lta bar/ / rang 'dod lha yi gzugs las ni/ / sems can ji ltar 'grub par 'gyur/ /

(1) Vajragarbha said: ‘But how should beings reach perfection by means of their chosen divinity, when they find themselves amidst all the elements of existence as extensive as space, (lost) like a goad in the ocean?’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / bdag med rnal 'byor ldan pa'am/ / yang na he ru ka dpal brtson/ / gzhan pa'i sems kyis skad cig kyang / / dngos grub 'dod pas mi gnas so/ /
(2) The Lord replied: ‘One who desires perfection should keep his inner self in union with Nairātmyā or Śrī Heruka, and not even for a moment should his thought be deflected elsewhere.
dang po goms par byed dus kyi/ / gnas ni gang du bsngags pa'i sems/ / gcig tu mnyam gzhag 'grub 'gyur ba'i/ / gnas ni bzang po nges par brtag /
(3) For one who is persevering for the first time, that place is considered propitious, where singleminded and self-collected a yogin may gain success.
rang gi khyim du mtshan dus su/ / bdag nyid 'grub pa'i sems kyis ni/ / rnal 'byor ma bsgom shes rab can/ / yang na he ru ka dpal gzugs/ /
(4) At night in his own house, confident of gaining perfection, the wise man should meditate upon the Yoginī or upon Śrī Heruka in his manifested form.

rkang pa 'khrud dang za ba dang / / 'thor 'thung so rtsi za ba dang / / tsan+dan gyis ni lag nyed dang / / smad g.yogs kyis ni rkang 'gebs dang / / 'byung dang smra dang 'gro ba dang / / 'dug dang khro dang rgod pa dang / / bcom ldan 'das ma bsten pa dang / / shes rab brtul zhugs can nyid kyis/ / rnal 'byor ma ni rnam par bsgom/ /

(5) (Moreover at all times) whether washing the feet or eating, rinsing the mouth or chewing betel-nut, rubbing the hands with sandal-wood, or girding the hips with the loin-cloth, (6) going-out, making conversation, walking, standing, in wrath, in laughter, the wise man should honour the Lady, strong in his vows, he should meditate upon the Yoginī.[1]
gzhan gyi tshul gyis skad cig kyang / / gdug pa'i sems ni mi rigs pas/ / dngos grub 'dod pas dngos grub phyir/ / mkhas pas 'bad pas mi gnas so/ /
(7) Seekers of perfection with perfection as their goal strive never for one moment to have their thought deflected elsewhere with the mind defiled by ignorance.

bsam gtan nyon mongs 'jig byed pa/ / rdo rje snying po nga yis bshad/ / brtse bas dngos grub don du yang / / zla ba phyed du yongs su rtogs/ / bsam pa thams cad yongs spangs nas/ / lha yi gzugs su sems pa yis/ / nyi ma gcig tu ma chad par/ / bsgom pas yongs su brtag par gyis/ /

(8) O Vajragarbha, I call meditation the destroyer of evil. Try it one fortnight with zeal, making perfection your goal, (9) abandoning all discursive thought, your mind set on the form of the divinity. Try it one day, meditating uninterruptedly.
rang gzhan don ni rab bsgrub phyir/ / 'khor bar thabs gzhan yod ma yin/ / rig ma lhan cig goms byas pas/ / 'phral du mngon du byed pa nyid/
(10) There are no other means in the saṃsāra for gaining the end of yourself and others, for a spell, once acquired, brings about immediate realization.[1]
b.
'jigs smyo de bzhin sdug bsngal dang / / mya ngan gdung ba 'tshe ba dang / / 'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug ches/ / sgrub pa po ni nyon mi mongs/ /
(11) By fears and passions and sorrows, by griefs and torments and such calamities, by passion, wrath, and delusion, the yogin is not disturbed.
phan dang gnod pa'i 'bras 'byung bar/ / de ltar nges par shes nas ni/ / ji ltar de ni skad cig kyang / / rnal 'byor ma rnams du 'bod gnas/ /
(12) Thus understanding the ripening of the fruit of good and evil acts, how should yogins stay one moment in the Raurava Hell?

mtshams med lnga ni byed pa dang / / srog chags gsod la dga' ba dang / / gzhan yang skye ba dman gang dang / / rmongs dang ma rungs las byed dang / / gzugs ngan yan lag mtshang ba'ang / / bsams pas de rnams 'grub par 'gyur/ / dge ba bcu la goms pa dang / / bla ma la gus dbang po dul/ / nga rgyal khro las rnam par gol/ /

(13) Perpetrators of the five great evil acts and those who delight in taking life, also those of wretched birth, and fools who are wicked in their conduct, (14) and ugly brutes with distorted limbs, these gain perfection by the right use of thought. So certainly will he succeed who practises the ten virtues, is devoted to his master with his senses well controlled, (15) and is free from pride and wrath.
c.

des ni re zhig nges 'grub 'gyur/ / rtag tu goms pa'i rnal 'byor gyis/ / mnyam par bzhag pas dngos grub 'thob/ / zla ba gcig tu gsang la spyad/ / ji srid phyag rgya ma rnyed par/ / gnang ba rnyed gyur sngags pa la/ / rnal 'byor ma yis bstan par bya/ / phyag rgya che ge mo khyer la/ / sems can don gyis rdo rje 'dzin/ / rnyed pa de yang mig yangs ma/ / gzugs dang lang tshos rnam par brgyan/ / si h+la ga bur yang dag ldan/ / byang chub sems kyis rnam par sbyang / / dge ba bcu las brtsams nas ni/ / de la chos ni rab tu dbye/ / lha yi gzugs kyi sems dang ni/ / dam tshig sems dang gcig pa nyid/ / zla ba gcig gis skal ldan par/ / 'gyur bar 'di la the tshom med/ /

Keeping continuously to the practice, perfected in the siddhi and selfcollected, (16) for one month one should privately continue, while one awaits the acquiring of a mudrā. The yogin then receives instructions. He is instructed by the yoginīs: (17) “Take such and such a Mudrā, O Vajradhṛk, and serve the cause of living-beings.” Taking this girl, who has wide-open eyes and is of age[2] and endowed with youth and beauty, (18) he should consecrate her with the seed of enlightenment. Beginning with the ten rules of virtuous conduct, he should expound to her the Dharma, (19) how the mind is fixed on the divine form, on the meaning of symbolic forms and concerning one-pointedness of mind, and in one month she will be fit, of that there is no doubt.

mchog thob pa yi bud med gang / / rtog pa thams cad yang dag spangs/ / yang na bdag gi nus pa yis/ / lha dang lha min mi rnams dang / / gnod sbyin mi'am ci las kyang / / phyag rgya bkug la rab tu brtag / de yang khyer la spyod pa spyad/ / bdag nyid la ba mngon du'i phyir/ /

(20) And so the girl is there, now freed from all false notions, and received as though she were a boon. Or else he should produce a Mudrā by conjuring her forth by his own power (21) from amongst the gods or titans or men, or the yakṣas or kinnaras. Then taking her, one should perform the practice with the realization of one’s own composure.
gang bshad 'jigs pa'i gzugs can gyi/ / spyod pa longs spyod phyir ma gsungs/ / yid ni brtan nam g.yo'am ci/ / rang gi sems ni so sor brtag /
(22) For this practice, which is called terrifying in appearance,[1] is not taught for the sake of enjoyment, but for the examination of one’s own thought, whether the mind is steady or waving.’
d.
rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ / bdag med rnal 'byor ldan pa yis/ / phyag rgya nyid ces ji ltar brjod/ / phyag rgya phyag rgya nyid dag gis/ / phyag rgya'i dngos grub ji ltar 'gyur/ /

(23) Vajragarbha said: ‘By one who is joined in union with Nairātmyā how can any distinction be made in the meaning of mudrā? And with this Mudrā and that Mudrā, with two Mudrās in fact, how should the perfection of the Great Mudrā come about?’[2]

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / bud med gzugs ni spangs nas ni/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi gzugs su bya/ / nu ma spangs pa po lar 'gyur/ / kak+ko la dbus yang dag gnas/ / 'gram gnyis dril bu nyid du 'gyur/ / ze'u 'bru bo la can du 'gyur/ /
(24) The Lord replied: ‘Relinquishing her form as a woman, she would assume that of her Lord. Gone are her breasts, and his vajra is manifest with a bell on each side, where the lotus had been.

lhag ma bdag nyid chen po nyid/ / dpa' chen he ru ka yi gzugs/ / he ru ka sbyor skyes bu nyid/ / 'bad pa med par skyes bur 'gyur/ / gsal bar nus pa'i rnal 'byor pas/ / de phyir phyag rgya'i dngos grub 'gyur/ /

(25) The rest of the form of the mighty and blissful Heruka (26) easily assumes the masculine condition of the man who is in union with Heruka, and from this the perfection of the Great Symbol would come about for the yogin of such manifest power.
chags dang 'jig pa dag gis kyang / / thabs dang shes rab gnod mi 'gyur/ / gang phyir thabs ni 'byung ba nyid/ / 'jig pa shes rab srid mthar byed/ /
(27) This identity of Wisdom and Means remains unharmed by the twofold process of origination and dissolution, for Means is the origination and Wisdom the dissolution and end of existence.
des na rab 'jig yod ma yin/ / de nyid la ni chags pa med/ / la la 'jig pas 'jig par 'gyur/ / 'jig pa'i dngos med zad pa med/ /
(28) So in truth there is neither destruction nor origination. Having dissolved away, it has come to its end, and since there can now be no dissolution, neither is there destruction.
bskyed pa'i rim pa'i rnal 'byor gyis/ / brtul zhugs can gyis spros pa bsgom/ / spros pa rmi lam ltar byas nas/ / spros pa nyid ni spros med byed/ /
(29) The yogin conceives of the diversity of existence as the Process of Emanation, and realizing the dream-like nature of this diversity, he renders it undiversified by means of its diversity.
ji ltar sgyu ma rmi lam dang / / ji ltar bar ma'i srid yin pa/ / rtag tu goms par sbyor ba las/ / dkyil 'khor nyid ni de bzhin 'dod/ /
(30) Like a dream, like a mirage, like the “intermediate state”, so the maṇḍala appears from continuous application to the practice.
phyag rgya chen po'i dbang bskur ba/ / ji ltar shes pa'i bde chen po/ / 'di ni de yi byin brlabs yin/ / gzhan las dkyil 'khor 'byung ba med/ /
(31) The great bliss, such as one knows it in the consecrations of the Great Symbol, of that the maṇḍala is the full and efficacious expression, for nowhere else does it have its origin.
bde ba gnag cing bde bser/ / bde ba dmar po bde ba dkar/ / bde ba ljang gu bde ba sngo/ / bde ba rgyu dang mi rgyu kun/ /
(32) This bliss is black and yellow, red and white, dark green, dark blue, all things moving and unmoving.
bde ba shes rab bde ba thabs/ / de bzhin kun tu ru skyes bde/ / bde ba dngos dang dngos med bde/ / rdo rje sems dpa' bde bar brjod/ /
(33) This bliss is Wisdom, this bliss is Means, and likewise it is their union. It is existence, it is non-existence, and it is Vajrasattva.’[3]
rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ rdzogs pa'i rim pa'i rnal 'byor 'di/ / de yi bde ba bde chen brjod/ / rdzogs pa bsgom pa med pa ste/ / bskyed pa yis ni ci zhig 'tshal/ /

(34) Vajragarbha said: ‘This state of unity achieved in the Process of Realization is deemed as Excellent Bliss, as Great Bliss, so what is the use of the Process of Emanation except for conceiving it as Realization?’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / e ma'o byang chub sems dpa' che/ / dad pa'i shugs kyis rab tu nyams/ /
(35) The Lord replied: ‘Oho, Great Bodhisattva, by dint of faith it is destroyed, they say.[1]
e.
lus kyi dngos med gang las bde/ / bde ba smra bar mi nus so/ / khyab dang khyab byed tshul gyis ni/ / bde bas 'gro ba khyab pa nyid/ /
Without bodily form how should there be bliss? Of bliss one could not speak. The world is pervaded by bliss, which pervades and is itself pervaded.
ji ltar me tog la gnas dri/ / me tog dngos med shes mi 'gyur/ / de bzhin gzugs sogs dngos med pas/ / bde ba nyid kyang dmigs med 'gyur/ /
(36) Just as the perfume of a flower depends upon the flower, and without the flower becomes impossible, likewise without form and so on, bliss would not be perceived.
dngos nga dngos po med pa nga / / dngos po rtogs phyir sangs rgyas nga / / gang zhig le los bsnun pa dang / / rmongs pa gang gis nga mi shes/ /
(37) I am existence, I am not existence, I am the Enlightened One for I am enlightened concerning what things are. But me they do not know, those fools, afflicted by indolence.
rdo rje btsun mo'i b+ha ga ni/ / e yi rnam pa'i cha byad gzugs/ / sangs rgyas rin chen za ma tog / bde ba can du rtag tu bzhugs/ /
(38) I dwell in Sukhāvatī in bliss with the Vajrayoginī, in that place which is symbolized by the syllable e,[2] in that casket of buddha-gems.
'chad pa po nga chos kyang nga / / rang gi tshogs ldan nyan pa nga / / 'jig rten ston pa bsgrub bya nga / / 'jig rten 'jig rten 'das pa nga / /
(39) I am the teacher, and I am the doctrine, I am the disciple endowed with good qualities. I am the goal, and I am the trainer. I am the world and worldly things.
lhan cig skyes dga'i rang bzhin nga / / mchog mtha' dga' bral dang por ni/ / mun pa la ni mar me ltar/ / de bzhin bus kyang yid ches kyis/ /
(40) My nature is that of Innate Joy and I come at the end of the Joy that is Perfect and at the beginning of the Joy of Cessation.[3] So be assured, my son, it is like a lamp in darkness.
btsun mo'i b+ha ga bde chen du/ / ston pa sum cu rtsa gnyis mtshan/ / gtso bo dpe byad brgyad cur ldan/ / khu ba zhes bya'i rnam par gnas/ /
(41) I am the Master with the thirty-two marks, the Lord with the eighty characteristics and I dwell in bliss in Sukhāvatī and my name is śukra.
de med pas ni bde med 'gyur/ / bde ba med na de med 'gyur/ / nus pa med phyir ltos dang bcas/ / lha yi rnal 'byor las bde ba/ /
(42) Without this there would be no bliss, and without bliss this would not be. Since they are ineffective one without the other, bliss is found in union with the divinity.
de phyir sangs rgyas dngos po min/ / de nyid dngos med tshul yang min/ / zhal phyag rnam pa'i gzugs can nyid/ / mchog tu bde bas gzugs med pa/ /
(43) So the Enlightened One is neither existence nor non-existence; he has a form with arms and faces and yet in highest bliss is formless.
de phyir 'gro kun lhan cig skyes/ / rang bzhin lhan cig skyes par brjod/ / rnam dag rnam pa'i sems kyis ni/ / rang bzhin mya ngan 'das pa nyid/ /
(44) So the whole world is the Innate, for the Innate is its essence. Its essence too is nirvāṇa when the mind is in a purified state.
lha yi rnam pa'i gzugs kyis ni/ / bzhin lag kha dog gnas pa ni/ / skyes pa tsam gyis rnam par gnas/ / 'on kyang bag chags phal pas so/ /
(45) The divine form consists of just something born, for it is a repository of arms and face and colours, and moreover arises by the normal influence of past actions.[4]
f.
dug gi dum bu gang nyid kyis/ / skye bo thams cad 'chi bar 'gyur/ / dug gi de nyid shes pa des/ / dug gis dug ni 'bigs par byed/ /
(46) With the very poison, a little of which would kill any other being, a man who understands poison would dispel another poison.

ji ltar rlung gis zin pa la/ / mon sran sde'u yi bza' ba sbyin/ / bzlog pa'i sman ni brtags pa yis/ / rlung gis rlung la snun par byed/ / rnam rtog las ni rnam rtog dang / / srid pa nyid kyis srid pa dag /

(47) Just as a man who suffers with flatulence is given beans to eat, so that wind may overcome wind in the way of a homoeopathic cure, so existence is purified by existence in the countering of discursive thought by its own kind.
ji ltar rna bar chu zhugs pa/ / chu gzhan dag gis 'gugs par byed/ / de bzhin dngos po'i rnam rtog kyang / / rnam par nges pas sbyang bar bya/ /
(48) Just as water entered in the ear is drawn out again by water, so also the notion of existing things is purified by appearances.
ji ltar 'tshed pas tshig pa yang / / me yis kyang ni gdung bar bya/ / de bzhin 'dod chags mes tshig pa/ / 'dod chags me yis gdung bar bya/ /
(49) Just as those who have been burned by fire must suffer again by fire,[1] so those who have been burned by the fire of passion must suffer the fire of passion.
skye bo mi bzad pa yi las/ / gang dang gang gis 'ching 'gyur ba/ / thabs dang bcas na de nyid kyis/ / srid pa'i 'ching ba las grol 'gyur/ /
(50) Those things by which men of evil conduct are bound, others turn into means and gain thereby release from the bonds of existence.
chags pas 'jig rten 'ching 'gyur ba/ / 'dod chags nyid kyis rnam grol 'gyur/ / bzlog pa'i bsgom pa 'di nyid ni/ / sangs rgyas mu stegs kyis mi shes/ /
(51) By passion the world is bound, by passion too it is released, but by the heretical buddhists this practice of reversals is not known.
g.
'byung ba lnga yi rang bzhin la/ / kun tu ru las lnga ru 'gyur/ / dga' ba chen po gcig nyid las/ / dbye bas lnga ru 'gro bar 'gyur/ /
(52) In the one essential unity a fivefold aspect subsists expressed in the set of five elements, and the Joy Supreme which is essentially one becomes five through their distinctions.
bo la kak+ko la sbyor bas/ / reg pa sra ba'i bag chags kyis/ / sra ba gti mug chos kyi phyir/ / gti mug rnam par snang mdzad brjod/ /
(53) From the contact that comes of the union of vajra and lotus, there arises the effect of hardness. The nature of hardness is delusion, and Vairocana is deemed to be delusion.
gang phyir byang sems gsher ba nyid/ / gsher ba chu yi khams su brjod/ / chu ni mi bskyod gzugs kyi phyir/ / zhe sdang 'dren pa mi bskyod pa/ /
(54) The bodhicitta is a flow and this flow is deemed as water. The nature of water is wrath and this wrath is Akṣobhya.
gnyis kyis bskyod pa'i sbyor ba las/ / drod ni rtag tu skye bar 'gyur/ / 'dod chags dpag med rdo rje yin/ / 'dod chags drod las 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
(55) From the rubbing together of two things fire always arises. From heat arises passion and this passion is Amitābha.
kak+ko lar ni gang zhig sems/ / de ni rlung gi rang bzhin can/ / phrag dog don yod grub pa yin/ / don yod rlung las 'byung ba nyid/ /
(56) The bodhicitta in the lotus has the nature of air. From air arises envy, and envy is Amoghasiddhi.
bde ba 'dod chags khrag tu 'gyur/ / dga' ba nam mkha'i mtshan nyid de/ / nam mkha' ser sna rdo rjer 'gyur/ / ser sna nam mkha' las byung nyid/ /
(57) The blood is bliss and passion and the nature of bliss is space. From space arises malignity and malignity is Ratnasambhava.[2]
sems ni chen po gcig nyid la/ / lnga yi gzugs kyis rnam par mtshon/ / rigs ni lnga po de nyid las/ / stong phrag du ma skyes pa nyid/ /
(58) Thought is one but consists in this fivefold form. This develops into the five families, and then there develop many thousands.
de phyir 'di dag rang bzhin gcig / bde chen mchog tu rtag pa nyid/ / 'dod chags la sogs sems lnga yi/ / dbye bas lnga ru 'gro bar 'gyur/ /
(59) So this is the single self-existent, it is the great bliss, perfect and eternal, but it becomes five by the fivefold distinction of thought as passion and the other four.
gang gA'i klung ni bcu yi bye snyed kyis/ / rigs gcig la ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i tshogs/ / rigs kyi tshogs la rigs ni du ma rnams/ / de rnams rigs ni rnam pa brgya/ /
(60) As numerous as the sands of ten River Ganges are the companies of the tathāgatas in these single families. In these companies there are numerous clans, and in these clans yet hundreds of clans.
de rnams la yang 'bum phrag rigs chen rnams/ / bye ba'i rigs la grangs ni med par 'gyur/ / de la rigs la grangs med rigs rnams ni/ / mchog tu dga' ba'i rigs las byung ba rnams/ /
(61) These many thousands of clans become many millions of clans, and in these clans there are still innumerable clans. Yet they all arise from the one clan of perfect joy.’
kye'i rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dra ba'i sdom pa las dngos grub gtan la phab pa zhes bya ba'i le'u ste gnyis pa'o// //

d.crumb: rgyud thams cad kyi gleng gzhi dang gsang ba'i skad

f.d: [rgyud thams cad kyi gleng gzhi dang gsang ba'i skad]

d.crumb: iii. the basis of all tantras

f.d: CHAPTER III. THE BASIS OF ALL TANTRAS

de nas rdo rje can gyi rnal 'byor ma rnams la rgyud thams cad kyi gleng gzhi zhes bya ba'i thabs bka' stsal pa/ sdom pa dang ni dbang dang yang / / de bzhin dgongs pa'i skad nyid dang / / dga' dang skad cig dbye ba dang / / gzhan yang bza' ba la sogs pa/ / de la sdom pa bka' stsal pa/ /

(1) Then the Adamantine Lord spoke to the yoginīs of the Means, which are the basis of all tantras, of the Union,[1] of consecrations and of secret language, of the different Joys and Moments, of feasting and the rest.
a.
sangs rgyas kun gyi sdom pa ni/ / e ba~M rnam par reb tu gnas/ / e ba~M rnam pa'i bde chen po/ / dbang las yang dag shes par bya/ /
(2) ‘Now the union of all buddhas consists in the sound EVAṂ.[2] This sound evaṂ, the great bliss itself, is known from the process of consecration.’

de nas rnal 'byor ma rnams kyis bcom ldan 'das rdo rje sems dpa' la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan ston pa 'gro ba'i bla/ / mkha' 'gro ma yi sdom pa nyid/ / e ba~M rnam pas ci zhes brjod/ / rim pa ji bzhin bshad du gsol/ /
(3) Then the yoginīs said to the Lord Vajrasattva: ‘Is the sound EVAṂ then called the union of the ḍākinīs?[3] May the Lord, the Teacher, the Master of the World please expound the matter as it is.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / e yi cha byad bzang po gang / / dbus su ba~M gyis rnam par brgyan/ / bde ba thams cad kyi ni gnas/ / sangs rgyas rin chen za ma tog /
(4) The Lord replied: ‘The sacred syllable e, adorned at its centre by the syllable VAṂ, is the abode of all delights, the casket of buddha-gems.
skad cig dbye bas phye ba nyid/ / dga' ba de las skye bar 'gyur/ / skad cig shes nas bde shes pa/ / e ba~M rnam par rab tu gnas/ /
(5) It is there that the four Joys arise, distinguished by the Moments, and from knowledge of these Moments the knowledge of Bliss is consummated in that sound EVAṂ.
sna tshogs dang ni rnam smin dang / / rnam nyed de bzhin mtshan nyid bral/ / skad cig bzhi ni rab shes pa/ / de ltar rnal 'byor pas shes 'gyur/ /
(6) So yogins know that the sound evaṂ is attainable through the four Moments: Variety, Development, Consummation, and Blank.[4]
'khyud dang 'o byed la sogs pa/ / sna tshogs rnam pa sna tshogs bshad/ / rnam par smin pa de las bzlog / bde ba'i ye shes za ba nyid/ /
(7) It is called Variety, because it involves different things, the embrace, the kiss and so forth. Development is the reverse of this, for it is the experiencing of blissful knowledge.
bdag gis bde ba zos pa yi/ / gros ni rnam par nyed par brjod/ / mtshan nyid bral ba gsum las gzhan/ / chags dang chags bral rnam par spangs/ /
(8) Consummation is defined as the reflection that this bliss has been experienced by oneself. Blank is quite other than these three, and knows neither passion nor the absence of passion.
sna tshogs dang po'i dga' ba nyid/ / rnam smin la ni mchog dga' nyid/ / rnam nyed dga' bral dga' ba nyid/ / mtshan bral lhan cig skyes dga' nyid/ /
(9) The first Joy is found in Variety, Perfect Joy in Development, the Joy of Cessation in Consummation and the Joy of the Innate in Blank.
slob dpon gsang ba shes rab dang / / bzhi bde yang de bzhin no/ / dbang ni bzhi yi grangs kyis ni/ / dga' ba la sogs rim zhes bya/ /
(10) These four Joys are to be experienced in due order in accordance with the list of the four consecrations, that of the Master, that of the Secret, that of the Prajñā and the Fourth.[1]
dgod pa dag pa slob dpon nyid/ / lta ba gsang ba de bzhin no/ / lag bcangs las ni shes rab nyid/ / gnyis gnyis 'khyud pa de yang nyid/ /
(11) The first is represented by a smile, the second by a gaze, the third in an embrace, and the fourth in union.
sems can rnams kyi dngos grub phyir/ / dbang ni rnam pa bzhi ru bshad/ / gtoRa dang blugs pa zhes bya 'dis/ / des na dbang zhes brjod par bya/ /
(12) This fourfold set of consecrations is for the purpose of perfecting living-beings. The word consecration or sprinkling is used because one is sprinkled or cleansed.
b.
shes rab bcu drug lon pa la/ / lag pa dag gis yang dag 'khyud/ / rdo rje dril bu mnyam sbyor bas/ / slob dpon dbang du rab tu brjod/ /
(13) The Prajñā of sixteen years he clasps within his arms, and from the union of the vajra and bell the Master’s consecration comes about.
shin tu bzhin bzang mig yangs ma/ / gzugs dang lang tshos rnam par brgyan/ / mthe bong srin lag dag gis ni/ / slob ma'i kha ru ltung bar bya/ /
(14) She is fair-featured, wide-eyed, and endowed with youth and beauty. Then with thumb and fourth finger he drops the bindu in the pupil’s mouth.

de nyid du ni mnyam pa'i ro/ / slob ma'i spyod yul dag tu bya/ / ston pas shes rab rab tu mchod/ / rjed par byas nas gtad par bya/ / ston pas smras pa sems dpa' che/ / phyag rgya bde ba ldan pa khyer/ / phrag dog khro ba rnam spangs pa'i/ / slob ma cher gyur shes nas ni/ / ston pas de la gnang ba sbyin/ / kun tu ru gyis rdo rje 'dzin/ /

(15) In that very act the flavour of sameness should be placed within the pupil’s range.[1] Then having honoured and worshipped the Prajñā, he should consign her to the pupil, (16) saying: “O Great Being, take thou the Mudrā who will bring you bliss”, and knowing his pupil to be worthy, free of envy and wrath, (17) he then further commands him: “Be ye one, O Vajradhṛk.”
ji ltar dbang bskur gsol btab pa'i/ / slob ma'i bya ba bshad par bya/ / bla ma phyag rgya ldan mthong nas/ / bstod dang mchod pa ji bzhin bya/ /
Now I shall tell you of the pupil’s part and how he begs for consecration, (18) how he pronounces words of praise and worship when he beholds his master with the mudrā.

bcom ldan zhi ba chen po kye/ / rdo rje rnal 'byor gcig bzhed pa/ / mi phyed phyag rgya sgrub pa po/ / rdo rje rnal 'byor las byung ba/ / ji ltar khyod ni bdag nyid che/ / mnga' bdag bdag la'ang de ltar mdzod/ /

“O great tranquil Lord, intent on the vajra-practice, (19) Thou perfecter of the Symbol, that hast thine origin in the oneness of the indestructible vajra, As you now do for yourself, may you also do for me.
'khor ba 'dam gyi tshogs nad du/ / bying ba skyabs med bdag la skyobs/ /
(20) I am sunk in the thick mud of the saṃsāra. Save me who am without a helper.”[2]

zhim pa'i bza' ba btung ba dag / pa la che mchog ma da na/ / bdug pa lha bshos phreng ba dang / / dril bu rgyal mtshan byug pa yis/ / 'di rnams mchod pa rnams kyis ni/ / slob mas rdo rje 'dzin pa mchod/ /
(21) Then with pleasing food and drink, with wine and meat of good quality, with incense, oblations, and garlands, with bells and banners and ointments, with all these he should honour his lord.
mchog tu dga' ba yang dag thob/ / sna tshogs spangs pa'i skad cig la/ / ston pas smras pa sems dpa' che/ / bde ba chen po rnam par gzung / /
(22) When the pupil has now reached the moment of Perfect Joy which is free from all notions of diversity, the master should say: “O Great Being, hold thou to the great bliss.
ji srid byang chub bar du ni/ / sems can don gyis rdo rje 'dzin/ / slob ma snying rje can mthong nas/ / rdo rje can gyis 'di skad smras/ /
(23) Until the time of enlightenment, O Vajradhṛk, serve thou the cause of beings.” Thus should speak the Adamantine Lord as he sees his pupil overwhelmed in compassion.
c.
'di ni ye shes chen po nyid/ / thams cad lus la rnam par gnas/ / gnyis dang gnyis su med pa'i tshul/ / dngos dang dngos med bdag nyid gtso/ /
(24) This is the great knowledge that exists in all phenomenal forms, dual by nature and yet free of duality, the Lord whose essence is both existence and non-existence.
brtan dang g.yo ba khyab nas gnas/ / sgyu ma'i gzugs can nyid du 'dod/ / dkyil 'khor 'khor lo'i thabs kyis ni/ / rtag tu nges par 'gro bar 'gyur/ /
(25) He abides pervading all things, moving or motionless, for he manifests himself in these illusive forms. But by means of the maṇḍala and so on, he goes with certainty to his eternal condition.’
d.

de nas rdo rje snying pos rnal 'byor ma rnams la bzod par gsol nas/ bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / dkyil 'khor 'khor lo ci zhes brjod/ / sangs rgyas kun bdag grong khyer la/ / bcom ldan bdag ni 'khrul gyur pas/ / rim pa ji ltar bshad du gsol/ /

(26) Then Vajragarbha, begging all the yoginīs to have patience, addressed the Lord: ‘May the maṇḍala be called a stronghold, which is the essence of all buddhas? Tell me Lord, just how things are, for doubt assails me.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / dkyil ni snying po zhes brjod de/ / byang chub sems ni bde chen po/ / len par byed pas dkyil 'khor nyid/ /

(27) The Lord replied: ‘The maṇḍala is the very essence, we say; it is bodhicitta and the great bliss itself. This it takes to itself,[1] and so in this sense maṇḍala is said to be malana, “the act of taking”.
'dus pa dkyil 'khor nyid du brjod/ / 'khor lo zhes bya nam mkha'i khams/ / yul la sogs pa rnam par sbyang / / bo la kak+ko la sbyor bas/ / de yi bde ba shes par 'gyur/ /
(28) Cakra is an assembly (of divinities) which purifies the spheres of sense and so on, and thus it is as void as space. By the union of vajra and lotus its bliss is experienced.’
e.

rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ sdom pa zhes bya gang gis dang / / dam tshig gang gis gnas par bgyi/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / khyod kyis srog chags bsad pa dang / / brdzun gyi tshig kyang smra ba dang / / khyod kyis ma byin par yang long / / pha rol bud med bsten par gyis/ /

(29) Vajragarbha said: ‘What usage and observance should one follow?’ The Lord replied: ‘You should slay living-beings. You should speak lying words. You should take what is not given. You should frequent others’ wives.

sems gcig srog chags gsod pa nyid/ / gang phyir srog ni sems su brjod/ / 'jig rten bsgral ba zhes bya ba/ / brdzun gyi tshig tu rab tu bsgrags/ / btsun mo'i khu ba ma byin par/ / gzhan gyi bud med rang mtshungs mdzes/ /

(30) Now to practise singleness of thought is the taking of life, for the thought is the life. To vow to save all men is interpreted as lying-speech. That which is not given is the bliss of woman, and she is your own Nairātmyā who is the wife of all others.’[2]
f.

de nas rnal 'byor ma thams cad kyis bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / yul de rnams kyang ci lags/ dbang po rnams ni gang lags/ skye mchid ni ci lags/ phung po rnams ni gang lags/ khams rnams de yang ci lags/ 'di rnams kyi rang bzhin ni ci lags/

(31) Then all the yoginīs addressed the Lord: ‘What are the spheres and faculties of sense? What are the bases of consciousness and how many are the component groups of personality? What are the spheres of consciousness and what is their true nature? ’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ yul drug ni/ gzugs sgra de bzhin dri dang ni/ / ro dang de bzhin reg bya dang / / chos kyi khams kyi rang bzhin nyid/ / 'di rnams yul ni drug tu brjod/
(32) The Lord replied: ‘There are six spheres of sense: form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and thought.
dbang po rnams ni drug ste/ mig dang rna ba sna dang ni/ / lce dang lus dang de bzhin yid/ /
(33) Likewise there are six faculties of sense: the eye, the ear, the nose, the tongue, the body, and the mind.
'di rnams dbang po drug po ni/ / gti mug rdo rje la sogs ldan/ / yul dang yul can dag gis ni/ / skye mched pa nu gnyis dag tu 'gyur/ /
(34) From spheres and faculties together we then have the twelve bases of consciousness.
phung po lnga ni gzugs la sogs/ / mthar ni rnam shes snying rje che/ /
The five skandhas are bodily form, feeling, impulses, power of perception and consciousness.
dbang po dang ni yul nyid dang / / dbang po'i rnam par shes pa nyid/ / rnal 'byor ma rnams go bya'i phyir/ / khams ni bcwa brgyad rnams su bshad/ /
(35) The eighteen spheres of consciousness are the six faculties and six spheres of sense together with the six kinds of consciousness belonging to each pair.
rang bzhin gdod nas ma skyes pa/ / brdzun min bden min de bzhin du/ / thams cad chu yi zla ba ltar/ / 'dod pas rnal 'byor mas shes kyis/ /
(36) Their nature is that of the essentially non-arisen and is neither true nor false, for all is like the reflection of the moon in water. O yoginīs, understand it as you will.

'di lta ste/ gtsub shing dang gtsub stan dang skyes bu'i lag pa'i rtsol ba las glo bur du me skye bar 'gyur ro/ / me 'di ni gtsub shing la yang mi gnas/ gtsub stan la yang mi gnas/ skyes bu'i lag pa dag la yang ma yin te/ rnam pa thams cad du yongs su btsal na gcig na'ang yod pa ma yin pas me de yang bden pa yang ma yin zhing brdzun pa yang ma yin no/ / de ltar chos thams cad rnal 'byor mas yid la gyis shig /

(37) For just as fire suddenly arises from the two fire-sticks and the action of a man’s hand, and cannot be located in either of the sticks nor in the hand’s action, and although sought everywhere, is not to be found anywhere, and is therefore neither a true thing nor a false thing, even thus, O yoginīs, should you conceive of all the elements.’
g.

de nas rnal 'byor ma bdag med ma la sogs pa rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma thams cad kyis bdud rtsi lnga thogs shing dam tshig gi rdzas thogs pas bcom ldan 'das rdo rje sems dpa' la mchod par byed/ kun tu ru'i sbyor bas rjes su chags par byed/ bdud rtsi lnga'i ro yang 'thung bar byed do/ /

(38) Then all the vajra-ḍākinīs with Nairātmyā to the fore, took up the five ambrosias and the ingredients of the sacrament, and honouring the Lord Vajrasattva, they drank the vajra-elixir of immortality.[1]

de nas bcom ldan 'das dgyes nas rang byin gyis brlabs pa bstan pa/ kye kye rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma/ / sangs rgyas kun gyis phyag mdzad pa'i/ / de nyid bdag gis gsang mdzad pa/ / rdo rje mchod pa'i byin brlabs kyis/ / bshad kyis 'dod pas rab tu nyon/ /

(39) At that the Lord was greatly pleased and told them of effective power. ‘Good, good O vajra-ḍākinīs, that truth which I keep secret and is honoured by all buddhas, of that I now tell you, for I am compelled thereto by the power of your vajra-praise, so listen if you will.’
lha mo thams cad dga' bar 'gyur/ / rangs par gyur te pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga sa la btsugs nas/ bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der thal mo sbyar ba btud nas bcom ldan 'das kyi gsung nyan to/ /
(40) Then all the goddesses became very zealous, and touching the ground with one knee, they stretched forth their hands in worship to where the Lord stood, and listened to that which he said.
h.
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / bza' btung ji ltar rnyed pa dang / / bgrod dang bgrod min mi spang zhing / / khrus dang gtsang sbra mi bya ste/ / grong gi chos ni rab tu spangs/ /

(41) The Lord said: ‘Food and drink must be just as it comes. One should not avoid things, wondering whether they are suitable or unsuitable. One should not perform special ablutions or purifications, nor avoid the affairs of the town.
blo ldan sngags nyid mi bzla zhing / / bsam gtan nyid ni dmigs mi bya/ / gnyid ni spang bar mi bya ste/ / dbang po rnams ni mi dgag go/ /
(42) The wise man does not mutter mantras, nor devote himself to meditation; he does not abandon sleep, nor restrain his senses.
ba la thams cad bza' bar bya/ / kha dog lnga la mnyam par spyad/ / dogs pa med pa'i sems kyis ni/ / btsun mo thams cad dga' bar bya/ /
(43) He should eat all meat and associate with all manner of men. He keeps the company of all women, his mind quite free of trepidation.
mdza' bo sdug par mi bya zhing / / de bzhin gdug la zhe sdang nyid/ / rdo shing 'jim pa'i bdag nyid kyi/ / lha 'di rnams la phyag mi bya/ /

(44) He should have no love for friend, nor hatred for any enemy. Those gods he should not honour, which are made of wood and stone and clay. For the yogin should always be consubstantiated with the form of his own divinity.
g.yung mo gdol ba ko lpags mkhan/ / phyag dar mkhan sogs reg ring dang / / bram ze rgyal rigs rje'u dmangs rnams/ / bdag gi lus ltar reg pa nyid/ /
(45) Men of all castes he may touch as readily as his own body, ḍombas, caṇḍālas, carmāras, haḍḍikas and the rest, brahmans and kṣatriyas, vaiśyas, and śūdras.

bdud rtsi lnga dang bu ram chang / / dug dang nim pa bu btsas skyes/ / skyur dang mngar dang bska la sogs/ / kha ba lan tshwa tsha ba dang / / dri nga dri zhim mchil snabs rnams/ / byang chub sems bsres rab tu bza'/ / gnyis med ye shes sems kyis ni/ / mi bza' cung zad yod ma yin/ / rang byung me tog rnyed nas ni/ / pad+ma'i snod du bzhag pa dang / / lud pa dang ni snabs dag gis/ / bsres nas brtul zhugs can gyis btung / /
(46-48) Nor is there anything he may not consume,[2] for his mind conceives no distinctions.
smad g.yogs kha dog sna tshogs dang / / ro bsregs thal bas de bzhin brgyan/ / me tog ra ba song gnas rnyed pas/ / mgo skyes legs par bcing bar bya/ /
(49) His loin-cloth is many-coloured and he adorns himself with clay-markings of different colours. Finding a flower in a cemetery he should bind it in his hair.’
i.
de nas rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ thams cad yul gyi rnam dag pa/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis sngar gsungs na/ / nges par dbang po drug gi grangs/ / rnam par dag par ma mdzad pa/ /
(50) Then Vajragarbha said: ‘The unpurified faculties of sense have not been listed as a set of six. Of the purification of their respective spheres the Lord has already spoken.’[1]
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / mig la gti mug rdo rje ma/ / rna bar zhe sdang rdo rje ma/ / sna la ser sna ma zhes bshad/ / kha la 'dod chags rdo rje ma/ /
(51) The Lord replied: ‘For the eyes is Mohavajrā, For the ears Dveṣavajrā, For the nose Mātsaryavajrā, For the mouth Rāgavajrā,
lus la phrag dog rdo rje ma/ / yid la bdag med rnal 'byor ma/ / dbang po rnams ni dag bya'i phyir/ / 'dis ni go cha sems dpa' che/ /
(52) For the touch is Īrṣyāvajrā, And for the mind Nairātmyayoginī.[2] By these protection is given for the purification of the faculties of sense.’
j.
rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ dgongs pa'i skad ni ci zhes bgyi/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis nges par gsungs/ / rnal 'byor ma yi dam tshig che/ / nyan thos la sogs mi shes pa/ /
(53) Vajragarbha said: ‘What may be said of secret language, that great convention of the yoginīs, which the śrāvakas and others cannot unriddle. May the Lord please tell us decisively.

dgod dang lta ba dag gis dang / / 'khyud dang de bzhin gnyis gnyis kyi/ / rgyud kyang rnam pa bzhi rnams kyis/ / dgongs pa'i skad ni ma bsgrags pa/ /
bcom ldan nges par gsung du gsol/ /
(54) As for the smile, the gaze, the embrace and the union, even by the tantras the secret language of these four is not mentioned.’[3]
dgongs pa yi ni skad chen po/ / dam tshig brda ni rgyas pa ru/ / rdo rje snying po ngas bshad kyis/ / khyod ni rtse gcig sems kyis nyon/ /
(55) The Lord replied: ‘I shall explain, O Vajragarbha, do thou listen with singleness of mind. This is that secret language, that great language, the conventional signs told in full.
ma da na chang ba la sha/ / 'du ba ma la ya dzar brjod/ / 'gro ba khe Ta ro ni shrA pa/ / rus pa'i rgyan ni ni ra~M shu/ /

(56) madhya (wine) is madana (passion) māṃsa (flesh) is bala (strength) malayaja (sandal-wood) is milana (meeting) kheṭa (hide? ) is gati (going) śava (corpse) is śrāya (resort) asthyābharaṇa (bone-ornament) is niraṃśuka (naked)
'ong ba phra~M kha Na ru brjod/ / cang te'u kr-i pI Ta ru brjod/ / skal med du d+hu ra zhes brjod/ / skal ldan kA liny+dza ra~M brjod/ /
(57) preṅkhana (wandering) is āgati (coming) kṛpīṭa (? belly) is ḍamaruka (drum) dundura (emission) is abhavya (unworthy) Kāliñjara (n.pr.) is bhavya (worthy)
reg min Di Na Di ma zhes brjod/ / thod pa pad+ma b+ha dza na~M/ / bza' ba tr-ip+ti ka zhes bya/ / tshod ma mA la hAn d+ha na~M/ /
(58) ḍiṇḍima (small drum) is asparśa (untouchable) padmabhājana (lotus-vessel) is kapāla (skull) tṛptikara (satisfying) is bhakṣya (food) mālatīndhana (jasmine wood) is vyañjana (herbs)
bshang ba tsa tuHsa ma~M brjod/ / gci ba ka stu ri zhes brjod/ / rang byung si grar shes par bya/ / khu ba karu ra zhes brjod/ /
(59) catuḥsama (a potion of four ingredients) is gūtha (dung) kasturikā (musk) is mūtra (urine) sihlaka (frankincense) is svayaṃbhu (blood) karpūra (camphor) is śukra (semen)
sha chen sha li ra~M zhes brjod/ / dbang po gnyis sbyor kun tu ru/ / rdo rje bo la zhas brjod de/ / pad+ma kak+ko la zhes zer/ /
(60) sālija (rice product) is mahāmāṃsa (human-flesh) kunduru is the union of two bold is vajra kakkola is lotus
k.
kha dog dbye bas phye ba la/ / rigs ni rnam pa lnga ru bshad/ / 'di ni gsang ba'i skad yin no/ / phyag rgya lnga ni bsdus pa nyid/ /
(61) Likewise the buddhas of the five families may be referred to by means of hidden speech:

g.yung mo rdo rje'i rigs su bshad/ / gar ma de bzhin pad+ma'i rigs/ / rang 'tshed ma ni rin chen rigs/ / skye gnyis de bzhin gshegs par brjod/ / tshos ma las kyi rigs nyid de/ / phyag rgya 'di rnams dngos grub sbyin/ / 'di rnams khu ba rdo rjer 'gyur/ / brtul zhugs can gyis mchod nas btung / /

(62) Ḍombī for the Vajra-family, Nartī for the Lotus-family, Caṇḍālī for the Gem-family, Brahmaṇī for the Tathāgata-family (63) and Rajakī for the Karma-family. These are the Mudrās, bestowers of siddhi; adamantine is their śukra, so honouring them, the yogin drinks it.
rdo rje snying po sems dpa' che/ / gsang ba'i skad ni mtshar che ba/ / nga yis khyod la gang bshad pa/ / de rnams thams cad gus pas zung / /
(64) O Vajragarbha, thou Great Being, you must receive with respect all that I have told you of this wondrous secret language.
kye rdo rje 'dir dbang bskur gang / / gsang ba'i skad kyis mi smra ba/ / de yi dam tshig nyams par ni/ / 'gyur bar 'di la the tshom med/ /
(65) He who has been consecrated in Hevajra and does not use this hidden language, will lose the sacramental power, of that there is no doubt.
'tshe ba dang ni rkun ma dang / / gdon dang rims dang dug gis kyang / / gal te sangs rgyas gsang ba'i skad/ / mi gsung na yang 'grongs par 'gyur/ /
(66) From calamities or thieves, demons, fevers, poisons, he will die, even though he be a buddha, if he does not speak with this secret language.
rang gi dam tshig rigs rnyed nas/ / gal te tshig 'di mi smra na/ / gnas bzhi las skyes rnal 'byor ma/ / de yi tshe na khro bar byed/ /
(67) Having gained this knowledge of his own sacramental nature, if he does not use this speech, then the yoginīs who spring from the four pīṭhas[1] will show forth their wrath.’
kye'i rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dra ba'i sdom pa las rgyud thams cad kyi gleng gzhi dang gsang ba'i skad ces bya ba'i le'u ste gsum pa'o// //

d.crumb: rgyud thams cad kyi phyag rgya bsdus pa'i don

f.d: [rgyud thams cad kyi phyag rgya bsdus pa'i don]

d.crumb: iv. answers to various questions

f.d: CHAPTER IV. ANSWERS TO VARIOUS QUESTIONS

de nas rdo rje snying po la sogs pa'i rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma thams cad the tshom du gyur/ yid gnyis su gyur te/ bcom ldan 'das rdo rje sems dpa' la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan the tshom bsal du gsol/ /
(1) Then all those divine beings with Vajragarbha at their head, were filled with wonderment and consternation and addressed the Lord Vajrasattva thus: ‘O may the Lord remove our doubts.
a.
spyod pa'i le'u las gang bshad pa/ / glu dang gar ni dngos grub sbyin/ / de la bdag ni the tshom mchis/ / glu ni ci lags gar kyang ci/ /
(2) (Firstly) as for what is said in the Chapter on Performance about singing and dancing as bestowing perfection, concerning this I have doubts. What is this singing and dancing?
b.
lha yi le'u las gang gsungs pa/ zhe sdang la sogs phyag rgya rnams/ / de la bdag ni the tshom mchis/ / gang gi phyag rgya phyag rgya ci/ /

(3) (Secondly) as for what is said in the Chapter on Consecration about receiving the sign of the Wrathful One or of some other family-head, concerning this I have doubts. What is the sign and of whom is the sign?
c.
sngags btu ba las gang gsungs pa/ / bdag med la sogs sa bon nyid/ / de la bdag ni 'khrul par gyur/ / gang gi sa bon sa bon gang / /
(4) (Thirdly) as for what is said in the Chapter on Matras about the seed-syllables of Nairātmyā and so on, concerning this I have doubt. Which is the syllable of whom?
d.
rigs kyi le'u las gang bshad pa/ / bcu drug gnyis kyi bdag nyid rtsa/ / bcom ldan bdag ni 'khrul gyur pas/ / de rnams rnam dag bshad du gsol/ /
(5) (Fourthly) in the Chapter on Hevajra’s Body thirty-two veins were mentioned. May the Lord please tell me their purificatory significance, for I am confused about them.’[1]
a.
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ /
(6) The Lord replied (in answer to the first question):
