kol+la i ri T+Thi a bo lA/ mum+mu Ni re kak+ko lA/ g+ha Na kiM pi Ta ho badz+dza i/ ku ru Ni ki a i Na ro lA/ ta hiM ba la khadz+dza i/ gaD+heM ma a NA pi dz+dza a i/ ha le kA li ny+dza ra pa Ni a i/ dun \u0fa1ru pA dz+dzi a i/ tsa us ma kats+tshur sih+lA kap+pu ra lA i a i/ mA la i in+d+ha Na sA liny+dza ta hi~M b+ha ru kha i a e/ phe~M kha Na khe Ta ka ran+te shud+d+hA shud+d+hA na mu Ni a i/ ni rang shu a~M ge tsa DA wi ta hi dzi sa rA ba pa Ni a i/ ma la ya dze kun+du ru bA Ta i/ DiN+Di ma ta hiN+Na badz+dzi a i/

‘The yogin stays at Kollagiri, the yoginī at Mummuṇī. Loudly the drum sounds forth. Love is our business and not dissension. (7) There we eat meat and drink wine in great quantity. Hey there, the true followers are come together, but the frauds are kept far away. We take the fourfold preparation and musk and frankincense and camphor, Herbs and special meat we eat with relish. (8) Going this way and that in the dance, we give no thought to what is chaste or unchaste, Adorning our limbs with bone-ornaments, we place the corpse in position. Union takes place at that meeting, for Ḍombī is not there rejected.[2]
dran pa mi 'phrog rnal 'byor bas/ / he ru ka yi gzugs kyis gar/ / chags bral mi goms sems kyis ni/ / 'dod chags sems kyis bsgoms pa nyid/ /
(9) Dancing as Śrī Heruka[1] with mindful application, undistracted, Meditating with thought impassioned,[2] the mind uninterrupted in its concentration,
rdo rje chos dang sangs rgyas dang / / rnal 'byor ma dang ma ma yas/ / glu dang gar ni 'di dag gis/ / legs par glu blang gar kyang bya/ /
(10) Buddhas and Masters in the Vajra-doctrine,[3] goddesses and yoginīs, Sing and dance to their utmost in this song and dance.
'di nyid kyis ni tshogs bsrung zhing / / de bzhin bdag kyang bsrung ba nyid/ / 'dis ni 'jig rten dbang du byed/ / 'dis ni sngags kyi bzlas pa nyid/ /
(11) There comes thereby protection for the troupe and protection for oneself. Thereby the world is reduced to subjection, and all reciting of mantras (is perfected) by it.

gang du gus pas glu len dang / / gang du gus bcas gar byed pa/ / tshogs kyi bdag pos sngar byas nas/ / de la dri ni mtshon par bya/ / sgog pa'i dri ni dang po nyid/ / de nas yang ni bya rgod dri/ / ga bur ma la ya dza~M nyid/ /

(12) Decorously one sings there; decorously one dances there. The leader is first appointed, and then he should note the scent, (13) first of garlic, next of vultures, and then of camphor and sandal-wood. Afterwards he should note the effective power of the song.
ngang pa dang ni bung ba'i sgra/ / glu yi mtha' nas mnyan par bya/ / ba lang tshe yi sgra yang ni/ / phyi rol tshal du mtshon bya dang / / gru yi byin brlabs mtshan nyid do/ /
(14) The sound of a goose and a bee is heard at the end of the song, and of a jackal too he should note the sound in the garden without.[1]
b.
phyag rgya rtags dang mtshan ma ste/ / 'dis ni rigs ni mtshon par bya/ / rigs 'tshol bsgom pa'i sbyor ba las/ / dngos grub med cing sgrub po'ang med/ /

(Answer to the second question.) (15) The mudrā is a sign or mark, and by this mark the particular family is indicated. If one practises meditation within the wrong family you will gain no perfection for there will be no perfection to gain.

zhe sdang phyag rgyas bdag med ma/ / gti mug phyag rgyas rdo rje ma/ / ser sna'i phyag rgyas dkar mo nyid/ / chags pas chu ma phyag rgyas gdab/ / phrag dog phyag rgyas mkha' 'gro ma/ / zhe sdang phyag rgyas puk+ka sI/ / gti mug phyag rgyas ri khrod ma/ / ser sna'i phyag rgyas gdol ba mo/ / 'dod chags phyag rgyas g.yung mo nyid/ / yang ni dkar mo zhe sdang las/ / gti mug phyag rgyas chom rkun ma/ / ser sna'i phyag rgyas ro langs ma/ / 'dod chags phyag rgyas g+hasma rI/ / gti mug phyag rgyas sa spyod ma/ / 'dod chags phyag rgyas mkha' spyod ma/ / 'dod pas phyag rgyar shes par bya/ /

(These are the families:) (16-19) Dveṣa — Moha — Piśuna — Rāga — Īrṣyā Nairātmyā — Vajrā — Gaurī — Vārī — Vajraḍākinī Pukkasī — Śavarī — Caṇḍālī — Ḍombī — Ghasmarī Gaurī II — Caurī — Vetālī — … … — Bhūcarī — … — Khecarī — … Understand this if you will.
c.

A li dang po bdag med ma/ / A li gnyis pa rdo rje ma/ / A li gsum pa dkar mo nyid/ / bzhi pa chu yi rnal 'byor ma/ / lnga pa rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma/ / drug pa puk+ka sI zhes brjod/ / bdun pa nyid ni ri khrod ma/ / brgyad pa sme sha can du brjod/ / dgu pa yang ni g.yung mo nyid/ / yang ni lnga gnyis dkar mo nyid/ / bcu gcig chom rkun ma zhes bshad/ / bcu gnyis ro langs ma zhes brjod/ / bcu gsum pa ni g+hasma rI/ / bcu bzhi pa ni sa spyod ma/ / bcwa lnga pa ni mkha' spyod ma/ / rnal 'byor ma yi sa bon nyid/ /

(Answer to the third question.) (20-23) A — Nairātmyā — Ṛ — Śavarī Ā — Vajrā — Ṝ — Caṇḍālī I — Gaurī — Ḷ — Ḍombī Ī — Vāriyoginī — Ḹ — Gaurī II U — Vajraḍākinī — E — Caurī Ū — Pukkasī — AI — Vetālī O — Ghasmarī AU — Bhūcarī AṂ — Khecarī These are the seed-syllables of the yoginīs.
d.

rigs kyi le'u las rtsa rnams gang / / bcu drug gnyis kyi bdag nyid gsungs/ / rtsa ni gnyis gnyis rnal 'byor ma/ / re re rnam pa gsum du brjod/ / brkyang ma ro ma kun 'dar ma/ / bdag med rnal 'byor ma zhes brjod/ / gang phyir bcu drug cha med pas/ / 'bad pas kun gyi lhag ma spangs/ /

(Answer to the fourth question.) (24) The thirty-two veins which are mentioned in the Chapter on Hevajra’s Body, are equated with the yoginīs, two to each, (25) except for Nairātmyā who is equated with three, Lalanā, Rasanā, and Avadhūtī. The last one of all[1] must be firmly rejected, for there is no sixteenth phase.
ci'i slad du zhe na/ don gyi bya ba mi byed phyir/ / bcwa lnga'i cha yi bdag nyid kyi/ / zla ba byang chub sems su 'gyur/ / bde ba chen po A li'i gzugs/ / rnal 'byor ma rnams de yi cha/ /

(26) And why is that? Because it is non-productive of an effect. The moon with its fifteen phases represents the Thought of Enlightenment. It is the great bliss symbolized by the fifteen vowels and the yoginīs are its phases.’
e.
rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ rnal 'byor ma kun las byung ba/ / lhan cig skyes dga'i rang bzhin nyid/ / 'grib med btung mchog nam mkha' nyid/ / ga bur nges par cis mi spang / /

(27) Vajragarbha said: ‘So one should not eject this‘camphor’. It is there that all the yoginīs have their origin, and its nature is the Joy Innate. It is indestructible and luscious, as pervasive as the sky.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ ji skad smras pa de bzhin no/ / rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ thabs gang gis byang chub kyi sems bskyed pa lags/
(28) The Lord replied: ‘It is even as you say.’ Vajragarbha asked: ‘By what means should one arouse the Thought of Enlightenment? ’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / dkyil 'khor 'khor lo'i thabs dang ni/ / rang byin rlabs pa'i rim pas kyang / / kun rdzob don dam gzugs can gyi/ / byang chub sems ni rab tu bskyed/ /
(29) The Lord replied: ‘By such means as that of the maṇḍala or the process of the self-bestowing of power, by these one arouses the Thought of Enlightenment, both in its absolute and relative form.
kun rdzob kun da lta bu nyid/ / don dam bde ba'i gzugs can no/ / bud med kak+ko la bde ba can/ / e ba~M rnam pa'i rang bzhin du/ /
(30) As relative, white as white jasmine, as absolute essentially blissful, it arises in the lotus-paradise, which is symbolized by the word EVAṂ.
bde ba bsrung ba nyid kyi phyir/ / bde ba can zhes rab tu bsgrags/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' dang / / rdo rje 'dzin pa rnams kyi gnas/ /
(31) We call it paradise or land of bliss (sukhāvatī) because of this bliss it is the keeper, for it is the home of all buddhas, bodhisattvas and vajra-holders.
f.
'di nyid 'khor ba zhes bya ste/ / 'di nyid mya ngan 'das pa nyid/ / 'khor ba spangs nas gzhan du ni/ / mya ngan 'das pa rtogs mi 'gyur/ /
(32) Such as is saṃsāra, such is nirvāṇa. There is no nirvāṇa other than saṃsāra, we say.
'khor ba gzugs dang sgra la sogs/ / 'khor ba tshor ba la sogs pa/ / 'khor ba dbang po rnam nyid do/ / 'khor ba zhe sdang la sogs pa/ /
(33) Saṃsāra consists in form and sound and so on, in feeling and the other four skandhas, in the faculties of sense, in wrath and illusion and the other three.
'di rnams chos ni mya ngan 'das/ / rmongs phyir 'khor ba'i gzugs can nyid/ / rmongs med 'khor ba dag pas ni/ / 'khor ba mya ngan 'das par 'gyur/ /

(34) But all these elements are really sunk in nirvāṇa, and it is only from delusion that they appear as saṃsāra. The wise man continues in saṃsāra, but this saṃsāra is recognized as nirvāṇa, for he has brought this about by the process of purification.
byang chub sems ni mya ngan 'das/ / kun rdzob don dam tshul can no/ /
(35) This nirvāṇa, being the Thought of Enlightenment, is both absolute and relative in form.[2]

shin tu bzhin bzangs mig yangs ma/ / gzugs dang lang tshos rnam par brgyan/ / sngo bsangs dal ma rigs bzang ma/ / si h+la ga pur 'byung ba'i gnas/ / rang gis dbang bskur kye'i rdo rje/ / skra bzang sgrub pa po la dga'/ / der ni chang yang btung bar bya/ / de nas rang yang btung ba nyid/ / rang bzhin don ni rab bsgrub phyir/ / phyi nas phyag rgya rjes chags bya/ / bo la kak+ko lar bcug nas/ / kun tu ru byed brtul zhugs can/ / der ni sbyor ba las byung ba'i/ / ga bur mkhas pas mi spang ste/ /
She is fair-featured, wide-eyed, and endowed with youth and beauty.… *
de ni lag tu mi blang zhing / / nya phyis dung chos nyid du min/ / nges par blo dang stobs kyi phyir/ / mi 'chi lce yis blang ba nyid/ /
He should not receive it in his hand, neither on mother-of-pearl nor in a conch-shell. With his tongue he must receive the ambrosia for the increasing of his strength.
g.
ga bur nyid ni bdag med ma/ / bde ba bdag med tshul can nyid/ / de yi bde ba phyag rgya che/ / lte ba'i dkyil 'khor nyid du gnas/ /
(40) For Nairātmyā is the camphor and Nairātmyā is the bliss. The realization of this bliss which is the Great Symbol itself is to be found in the lower cakra.

dang po'i dbyangs yig rang bzhin te/ / blo zhes sangs rgyas rnams kyis brtags/ / rdzogs pa'i rim pa'i rnal 'byor las/ / de nyid bcom ldan shes rab ma/ / de ni ring min thung ba min/ / gru bzhi ma yin zlum po min/ / dri dang ro dang myang las 'das/ / lhan cig skyes dga' byed pa can/ /

(41) She is symbolized by the letter A, and it is as Wisdom that the enlightened conceive of her. In the Process of Realization she is the Lady Prajñā. (42) (No form may one apply to her) neither tall nor short, neither square nor round. She transcends all taste and smell and flavour, and it is she who brings the Joy Innate.
de las skyes pa'i rnal 'byor pas/ / de yi bde ba za ba nyid/ / de dang lhan cig phyag rgya che/ / bde ba sbyin pa'i dngos grub 'gyur/ /
(43) In her the yogin is con-substantiated, for it is her bliss that he enjoys. With her that perfection is found that bestows the bliss of the Great Symbol.
gzugs sgra de bzhin dri dang ni/ / ro dang de bzhin reg bya nyid/ / chos kyi dbyings kyi rang bzhin yang / / shes rab nyid kyis dpyad par bya/ /
(44) Form and sound, smell, taste, touch, and sphere of thought, are all enjoyed in this Prajñā.

de nyid lhan cig skyes pa'i gzugs/ / bde chen bzang po'i rnal 'byor ma/ / de nyid dkyil 'khor 'khor lo dang / / ye shes lnga yi rang bzhin can/ / de ni me long ye shes gzugs/ / mnyam nyid ye shes dngos po can/ / yang dag gyur pa so sor rtog / de nyid bya ba nan tan te/ /
(45-46) She is the Innate itself, the divine yoginī of great bliss. She is the whole maṇḍala and comprehends the Five Wisdoms.
chos dbyings shin tu rnam dag ma/ / de nyid dkyil 'khor bdag po nga / / de nyid bdag med rnal 'byor ma'o/ / chos kyi dbyings kyi rang bzhin can/ /
(47) She is the “I”, the Lord of the maṇḍala. She is Nairātmyāyoginī, the sphere of thought in essence.’
h.
rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ 'khor lo bsgom pa'i lam dang ni/ / lha rnams ji ltar 'byung ba nyid/ / thams cad bcom ldan 'das gsungs na/ / sdom pa'ang bdag la bshad du gsol/ /
(48) Vajragarbha said: ‘The Lord has already explained how the divinities arise in the process of meditating upon the maṇḍala. May he please tell me about the maṇḍala within.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / rnal 'byor ma lus dbus gnas su/ / a yi rnam pa sdom pa'i gnas/ / ji ltar phyi rol de bzhin nang / / sdom pa de nyid rab tu phye/ /

(49) The Lord replied: ‘We explain the internal maṇḍala as being comprised in the unity of the sound a which exists at the centre of the yoginī’s body, and just as the external maṇḍala (evolves from the seed-syllable), so also does the internal.[1]
bo la'i bde ba phyag rgya che/ / rdo rje skye mched thabs chen nyid/ / 'dis ni gsang ba'i snyoms 'jug pas/ / phyi rol gnyis gnyis bstan pa med/ /
(50) The bliss that the vajra experiences here is the Great Symbol, and as coefficient the vajra is Means. The internal mingling that comes about, is figured in the external union of two.[2]
sku gsum lus kyi nang du ni/ / 'khor lo'i gzugs ni brjod par bya/ / sku gsum yongs su shes pa ni/ / bde ba chen po'i 'khor lor brjod/ /
(51) The three kāyas are found within the body in the form of the cakras, and the perfect knowledge of these three kāyas is the cakra of Great Bliss.
chos dang longs spyod sprul pa dang / / de bzhin du yang bde chen nyid/ / skye gnas snying mgrin mgo bor yang / / sku gsum po ni rnam par gnas/ /
(52) (Therefore there are four in all:) the nirmāṇakāya, the dharmakāya, the sambhogakāya and the mahāsukhakāya. These are situated at the navel, at the heart, at the throat and in the head.
ma lus pa yi sems can gyi/ / skye ba gang la brjod bya ba/ / gang phyir sprul pa gnas brtan phyir/ / de las sprul pa'i sku nyid yin/ /
(53) The nirmāṇakāya is in the place where the birth of all beings comes about.[3] One is born or fashioned (nirmīyate) and therefore it is called nirmāṇa.
gang gis skyed dang sprul byed pa'i/ / sku ni sprul pa can zhes brjod/ / sems ni chos kyi rang bzhin te/ / chos kyi sku yang snying gar 'gyur/ /
(54) Dharma consists of thought and the dharmakāya is at the heart.
ro rnam drug gi gzugs can gyi/ / bza' ba nges par longs spyod brjod/ / mgrin par longs spyod 'khor lo dang / / spyi bor bde ba chen po gnas/ /
(55) Sambhoga is enjoyment which consists in the six kinds of flavour, and so the sambhogakāya is at the throat. The mahāsukhacakra is in the head.

e ba~M rnam par rgyu mthun nyid/ / rnam smin chos kyi 'khor lo las/ / longs spyod skyes bu byed pa nyid/ / bde ba'i 'khor lo dri med nyid/ / rgyu mthun sogs pas rab phye ba'i/ / 'bras bu rnam pa bzhi zhes brjod/ / las kyi rlung gis bskul ba yis/ / las la bcom ldan shes rab spyod/ /

(56-57) (The Four Fruits[4] are situated thus:) The fruit which corresponds (niṣyandaphala) is at the navel. The fruit of retribution (vipākaphala) is at the heart. The fruit of manly activity is in the throat (puruṣakāraphala). The pure fruit is in the head (vimalaphala). The Lady Prajñā, impelled by the winds of karma, is herself the enjoyer of karma.

ji ltar byas pa de bzhin spyod/ / rgyu mthun zhes ni rab tu bsgrags/ / las chung 'bras bu che ba'i phyir/ / rnam par smin pa de las bzlog / rnal 'byor dag phyir dri med nyid/ / skyed pa skyes bu'i byed pa nyid/ /

(58) A corresponding fruit is that which is enjoyed in correspondence with what has been done. A fruit of retribution is the reverse of this, where the activity is small and the fruit is great. A fruit of manly activity is that which is gained by effort. A pure fruit is that which arises from the purificatory process of yoga.
gang phyir sprul pa gnas brtan phyir/ / sprul pa'i 'khor lor gnas brtan nyid/ / chos ni smra ba 'byung ba'i phyir/ / chos kyi 'khor lor thams cad yod/ /

(59) The Sthāvara School is allocated to the nirmāṇacakra, since the act of creation (nirmāṇa) has continued long; The Sarvāstivāda to the dharmacakra, for it is there that the theory of dharma originates;
gang phyir mgrin par kun bkur phyir/ / longs spyod 'khor lor kun bkur nyid/ / gang phyir bde chen mgor gnas pas/ / bde ba'i 'khor lor dge 'dun che/ /
i.
sde pa zhes bya sku ru brjod/ / lto ba gnas su brjod par bya/ / skye gnas 'dod chags bral bar 'gyur/ / mngal gyi phru ma chos gos nyid/ /
(61) The School, we say, is the body. The monastery is the womb. By freedom from passion one is in the womb. The yellow robe is the covering of the embryo.
de bzhin ma ni mkhan po nyid/ / mgo bor thal mo sbyar ba phyag / 'gro ba'i bya ba khrims kyi gnas/ / sngags kyi bzlas pa a dang ha~M/ /

(62) One’s preceptor is one’s mother. The salutation is the coming head-foremost. The course of instruction is one’s worldly experience (from former lives). The reciting of mantras is the notion of self (AHAṂ).
skye gnas 'khor lo'i rnam pa a/ / bde chen gyi yeng rnam pa ha~M/ / gcer bu skra dang kha spu bregs/ / sngags 'don skyes pa dge slong nyid/ /
(63) The sound A is found in the lower cakra, and the sound ha in the head. So one is born as a bhikṣu, reciting mantras, naked and free from hair on head and face.
'di dag rkyen gyis sems can rnams/ / sangs rgyas nyid du the tshom med/ / zla ba bcu yangs rnams yin/ / sems can sa bcu'i dbang phyug go/ /
(64) By means of such effects all beings are buddhas, there is no doubt. The bhūmis are the ten months (in the womb), so all beings are already lords of the ten bhūmis.’

de nas rnal 'byor ma bdag med ma la sogs pa'i lha mo thams cad la 'di lta ste/ spyan ma dang / mA ma kI dang / gos dkar mo dang / sgrol ma dang / khro gnyer can dang / tsun dA dang / par+N+Na ri khrod ma dang / 'og zhal ma dang / de dag la sogs pa ri rab kyi rdul phra rab dang mnyam pa'i rnal 'byor ma rnams kyis tshig 'di dag thos nas mchog tu ngo mtshar bar gyur cing brgyal ba dang / skrag pa dang / sa la 'gyel ba dang / 'dar bar 'gyur ro/ / yang rdo rje can gyis lha mo de rnams thams cad la gzigs nas/ bslang ba'i phyir yang dag par bstod pa/

(65) Then all those goddesses, led by Nairātmyā, with Locanā, Māmakī, Pāṇḍurā and Tārā, Bhṛkuṭī, Cundā, Parṇaśavarī, Ahomukhā and the rest, as numerous as the atoms in Mount Meru, were seized with great wonderment, (66) and hearing those words, they fell senseless and terrified to the ground. Seeing them all thus afflicted, the Lord uttered these words of encouragement to arouse them:
sa dang chu dang rlung byin za'i/ / lha mo snod can khyed nyid la/ / gang zhig sus kyang mi shes pa/ / de nyid nga yis spro yi nyon/ /
(67) ‘O you who are Earth and Water and Fire and Air, O worthy Goddesses, do you listen, for I shall discourse to you on the truth which no one else knows.’
bcom ldan 'das kyi gsung rmi lam lta bu nye bar thos nas de rnams thams cad srog rnyed par gyur to/ /
(68) Then hearing his words as though in a dream, they all regained their senses.
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / sems can rnams ni sangs rgyas nyid/ / 'on kyang glo bur dri mas bsgribs/ / de nyid bsal na sangs rgyas nyid/ /
(69) The Lord said: ‘All beings are buddhas, but this is obscured by accidental defilement. When this is removed, they are buddhas at once, of this there is no doubt.’
lha mos gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das de de bzhin te/ bden yang ma mchis zhing brdzun yang ma mchis so/ /
(70) The goddesses said: ‘It is even so, Lord, this is true and not false.’[1]
j.
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / gang gis mi shes 'jig rten pa/ / btsan dug zos pas brgyal bar 'gyur/ / rmongs spangs de nyid yid kyis ni/ / de yis de nyid yongs su gcod/ /

(71) The Lord said: ‘If he drinks strong poison, the simple man who does not understand it, falls senseless. But he who is free from delusion with his mind intent on the truth destroys it altogether.[3]
de bzhin zhi ba'i thabs shes shing / / kye yi rdo rjer ngal bsos na/ / ma rig la sogs mi 'dzin cing / / gti mug la sogs 'ching bas min/ /
(72) So those who know the means for release and make effort in Hevajra, are not held by the bonds of delusion and so on, by ignorance and the rest.
k.

rang dang rang gis rtogs pa las/ / sangs rgyas ma yin sems can ni/ / gcig kyang yod pa ma yin no/ / dmyal ba yi dgas byol song dang / / lha dang lha min mi rnams dang / / bshang ba'i srin bu la sogs pa/ lha dang lha ma yin gyi yang / / bde ba gang phyir mi shes pas/ / rtag tu rang bzhin bde ba can/ /

(73) There is no being that is not enlightened, if it but knows its own true nature. The denizens of hell, the pretas and the animals, gods and men and titans, (74) even the worms upon the dung-heap, are eternally blissful in their true nature, and they do not know the transitory bliss of gods and titans.[3]
'jig rten khams ni gang du yang / / sangs rgyas gzhan du rnyed mi 'gyur/ / sems ni rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas nyid/ / sangs rgyas gzhan du bstan du med/ /
(75) No buddha is found elsewhere in any of the spheres of existence. The mind itself is the perfect buddha, and no buddha is seen elsewhere.
gdol ba smyig mkhan la sogs pa/ / gsod don don du sems pa po/ / de rnams kye rdo rjer shes na/ / 'grub 'gyur 'di la the tsom med/ /
(76) Even Caṇḍālas[4] and other low-caste wretches and those whose minds are set on slaughter, if they will betake themselves to Hevajra, they will gain siddhi, there is no doubt.
byis pa mi shes pas bsgribs pa/ / 'di yi 'gro ba mi shes pa/ / 'gro ba drug gi srid pa'i mthar/ / gang zhig rmongs pa 'khor bar 'gyur/ /
(77) But those fools who are obscured in ignorance and do not know this way, continue to transmigrate through the six realms of existence.
rdo rje snying po snying rje che/ / kye yi rdo rje'i thabs rnyed pas/ / gang zhig yul rnams rnam sbyong ba/ / de ni bla med rnyed par 'gyur/ /
(78) But when one has found Hevajra, who is the Means, O Vajragarbha of great compassion, one purifies the spheres of sense, and gains the highest state.’
l.
rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ sa ni puk+ka sIr bshad pa/ / gang phyir gti mug sra ba nyid/ / sku ni rnam snang nyid gsungs pa/ / ji ltar mi bskyod phyag rgya lags/ /

(79) Then Vajragarbha asked: ‘Pukkasī is said to be Earth, so why should Akṣobhya (dveṣa) be her sign? [5] Since hardness corresponds to delusion (moha) and this is Vairocana, then Vairocana (moha) would be suitable as the sign of Pukkasī.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / sems spangs nas ni lus kyis ni/ / mdzes pa gzhan du mi 'gyur ro/ / de phyir rnam par snang mdzad sems/ / sku la thugs kyi phyag rgyas gdab/ /

(80) The Lord replied: ‘Apart from the body, there is no means of activity for the mind, and therefore Vairocana becomes Mind and the Body (= Vairocana = Earth = Pukkasī) is marked with the sign of Mind (= Akṣobhya).’
rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ / chu khams ri khrod mar bshad pa/ / mi bskyod khu ba'i gzugs can nyid/ / gtso bo mi bskyod phyag rgyas ni/ / ri khrod ma la phyag rgyar rigs/ /
(81) Vajragarbha said: ‘Śavarī is said to be water, and Akṣobhya has the nature of fluid. Therefore it would be suitable for Śavarī to be signed with the sign of Akṣobhya.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / lus spangs nas ni sems kyis ni/ / gnas pa gzhan du mthong mi 'gyur/ / de phyir sems ni gti mug 'gyur/ / thugs la gti mug phyag rgyas gdab/ /

(82) The Lord replied: ‘Apart from the Mind (= Akṣobhya = water = Śavarī) there would be no stability for the Body (= Vairocana = Moha), and so Mind becomes delusion, and Mind (= Śavarī as above) is marked with the sign of Delusion.’
rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ me ni gdol ba mor bshad pa/ / 'dod chags phyag rgyas gdol ba mo/ / rigs te phyag rgya gzhan min na/ / ji ltar rin chen phyag rgya lags/ /

(83) Vajragarbha said: ‘Caṇḍālinī is said to be fire, so why is she signed with the Gem (Paiśunya, family of Ratnasambhava)? It would be suitable with the sign of Passion (rāga); for Caṇḍālī we want no other sign.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / gang phyir 'dod chags khrag bshad pa/ / khrag ni rin chen 'byung ldan nyid/ / drod ni khrag gi rang bzhin phyir/ / 'dod chags ser sna'i phyag rgyas gdab/ /

(84) The Lord replied: ‘Since Passion (rāga = Amitābha = fire = Caṇḍāli) is red, and Ratnasambhava is red,[1] therefore since fire is red, Passion (= Caṇḍālī as above) is signed with the sign of Envy (Ratnasambhava).’
rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ gang phyir g.yung mo rlung nyid de/ / don yod rlung gi gzugs can nyid/ / don yod phyag rgyas g.yung mo la/ / gtso bo phyag rgyar rigs par 'gyur/ /
(85) Vajragarbha said: ‘Since Ḍombinī is air, and Amoghasiddhi has the nature of air, it would be suitable for Ḍombinī to be signed with the sign of Amogha, O Lord.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / 'dod chags ma gtogs phrag dog ni/ / gzhan du 'byung ba ma yin te/ / de phyir 'dod chags phyag rgya yis/ / mkhas pas gsung mo phyag rgyas gdab/ /
(86) The Lord said: ‘Apart from Passion (rāga) there would be no other source of origin for Envy (īrṣyā), and therefore he who understands, signs Ḍombinī with the sign of Passion.
gang phyir gzugs ni sra ba nyid/ / dkar mo snang mdzad gsungs pa nyid/ / sngar gsungs nyid kyi rim pa yis/ / sems kyi bdag pos phyag rgyas gdab/ /
(87) Since form is hardness, for Gaurī Vairocana would be prescribed, but in the manner already stated, she is signed with the Lord of Mind (= Akṣobhya).
de nyid rigs pas chom rkun ma/ / de bzhin ro langs ma nyid dang / / de yi rigs pas g+hasma rI/ / ma log pa las phyag rgya'o/ /
(88) In that same manner Caurī, Vetālī and Ghasmarī all have their signs free of contradiction.’[2]
m.

kye yi rdo rje rdo rje 'dzin/ / snyoms 'jug gnas pa'i lha nyid la/ / sems can don phyir gtor ma che/ / de la bdag med mas zhus pa/ / e ba~M rnam par bzhugs nas ni/ / bgegs dang log par 'dren pa las/ / sems can rnams kyi srog bsrung phyir/ / rdo rje sems dpas gtor ma bstan/ /

(89) Then Nairātmyā for the benefit of living beings questioned Hevajra concerning the offerings,[3] (90) and he spoke about them that the life of beings might be protected from obstacles and troubles.
oM in+da dza ma dza la dza kla/ b+hu ta ba h+ni bA u rak+kha tsan+da sudz+dza mAd bap+ba ta la pA tA le aT+Tha sa p+ba swA hA/
(91) ‘OṂ Indra, Yama, Jala, Yakṣa, Bhūta, Vahni, Vāyu, Rakṣa.[4] O Sun and Moon, O Mother Goddess of the Earth, O Father Brahmā. O ye eight serpents of the lower realms, SVĀHĀ.
i dam ba ling b+huny+dza dzi g+ha phul+la d+hup+pa mAM sa biM g+ha/ am+b+ha sab+ba kadz+dza sA d+ha khan+ti khu Ni pe Da gA de/
(92) Taste and smell these offerings. There are flowers and incense and meat. May ye prosper all our affairs and remove from our limbs our wounds and bruises.[1]
oM a kA ro mu khaM sar+b+ba d+har+m+mA NAM Ang+ya nut+pan+natwA ta/ oM AHhU~M phaT swA hA/
(93) OṂ A—the source of all things for they are unmanifest from the beginning.

gal te 'di'i gtor mas 'byung po thams cad mchod par byed na rnal 'byor pa rnams legs par 'gyur te/ de rnams la bde ba dri ma med pa dang / lha mo rnams dang / 'gro ba rab tu 'byor pa rnams dga' bar 'gyur ro/ /

(94) If yogins for their welfare make this invocation together with the offering, then there will be for them unalloyed happiness and the gods will be contented, possessed of all the good things of the world.

gal te 'dis 'byung po'i tshogs kyi phyir rtag tu gtor ma phyin na dbang dang / mngon spyod dang / dgra'i sde 'jig pa dang / bskrad pa dang / bsad pa dang / dgug pa dang / zhi ba dang / rgyas par yang 'gyur ro/ /

(95) Moreover the rites of subduing, bewitching, destroying enemy armies, driving away, slaying, conjuring forth, propitiating and bringing happiness and prosperity, all will succeed, if one always makes this offering here to the company of these spirits.’
n.
rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ phyag rgya gang gis mkha' spyod ma/ / gang gis phyag rgyas sa spyod ma/ / gtso bo bdag gis sngar ma 'tshal/ / bcom ldan ji ltar phyag rgya bgyi/ /
(96) Vajragarbha asked: ‘With which sign should Khecarī and Bhūcarī be signed, O Lord? I have never known before.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / gsang gsum 'khor lo'i dbus su ni/ / sku gsung thugs su phye pa las/ / steng dang 'og dang dbus gnas pa'i/ / 'khor lo'i dbus su rnam par gnas/ /
(97) The Lord replied: ‘The threefold mystery is at the centre of the maṇḍala, and differentiated as Body, Speech, and Mind. These occupy a middle position, situated at nadir, zenith, and centre.
sa spyod sku yi phyag rgya can/ / steng zhal sku yi rdo rje ma/ / mkha' spyod 'dod chags phyag rgya can/ / 'og zhal gsung gi rdo rje ma/ /

(98) At the nadir is Bhūcarī, the adamantine representative of Body, and she has Body (Vairo-cana) as her sign. At the zenith is Khecarī, the adamantine representative of Speech, and she has Passion (Amitābha) as her sign.
thugs kyi rdo rje bdag med ma/ / sems ni bdag med tshul can nyid/ / sems ni dbus kyi gnas su ste/ / des na bdag med ma dbus skye/ /
(99) The adamantine representative of Mind is Nairātmyā, for mind is the essential nature of Nairātmyā. Mind has the central position and so Nairātmyā arises in the centre.
rgyas par rab tu phye ba las/ / rigs ni rnam pa drug tu brjod/ / rnam gsum rnam pa lnga nyid kyang / / bshad kyis rnal 'byor ma nyid nyon/ /
(100) In full the families are six, but they are also five and three. Just listen, Yoginī.
mi bskyod rnam snang rin chen 'byung / / dpag med don grub rdo rje sems/ / zhe sdang gti mug ser sna dang / / 'dod chags phrag dog bde ba dag /
(101) Akṣobhya — Vairocana — Ratnasambhava — Amitābha —Amoghasiddhi dveṣa — moha — piśuna — rāga —īrṣyā Vajrasattva saukhya
'dis ni rim pas bsgom pa nyid/ / rdo rje sems dpa' spangs nas ni/ / phyi nas rigs ni rnam pa lnga/ / 'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug gis/ / de rjes rnam pa gsum du 'gyur/ /

(102) They should be conceived in this order with these spheres of purification. By omitting Vajrasattva, we have a fivefold set of families. Then they become three by (retaining just) dveṣa, moha, and rāga.
mi bskyod zhe sdang gzugs can gyi/ / thugs kyi bdag po rigs gcig nyid/ / zhe sdang rdo rje'i byin rlabs 'di/ / rigs ni drug dang lnga ru brjod/ /
(103) But these six or five families are comprised in one, that one family which has mind as its Lord and consists in the wrath of Akṣobhya. Such is the adamantine power of wrath.
kye'i rdo rje las rgyud thams cad kyi phyag rgya bsdus pa'i don zhes bya ba'i le'u ste bzhi pa'o// //

d.crumb: kye rdo rje mngon par 'byung ba

f.d: [kye rdo rje mngon par 'byung ba]

d.crumb: v. the manifestation of hevajra

f.d: CHAPTER V. THE MANIFESTATION OF HEVAJRA
a.
de nas rgyal po rdo rje 'dzin/ / gtso bo kye rdor kun sbyin pas/ / rnam kun rang bzhin bdag nyid kyi/ / dkyil 'khor dag ni yang dag gsungs/ /
(1) And now the Adamantine One, the mighty King and Lord Hevajra, the giver of all things and the substance of all forms, discourses on the maṇḍala.
rnam pa thams cad rang bzhin gyis/ / bde ba can na yang dag bzhugs/ / thugs kyi rdo rje'i sa bon gyis/ / rang gi dkyil 'khor bskyed pa ste/ /
(2) He reposes there in bliss as the essence of all forms, for he is Lord of the Maṇḍala and has emanated from the seed of the Vajra of Mind.
phyag ni bcu drug zhal brgyad pa/ / zhabs bzhi pa la 'jigs pa po/ / dpa' bo thod pa'i phreng ba can/ / bdag med mas ni mgul nas 'khyud/ /

(3) He has sixteen arms and eight faces and four legs, and is terrible in appearance with his garland of skulls and he wears the five symbolic adornments. Nairātmyā, clinging round the neck of this hero and god, addresses him thus:
phyag rgya lnga ni 'dzin lha la/ / bdag med ma ni nyid kyis zhus/ / bcwa lngas yongs su bskor ba yi/ / bdag gi 'khor lo khyod bshad na/ / khyod kyi dkyil 'khor ji ltar lags/ /
(4) ‘You have spoken of our circle with its troupe of fifteen.[1] But what is your own maṇḍala like, O Lord? Of this I have so far known nothing.’

gtso bo bdag gis sngar ma 'tshal/ / bdag med ma la 'o mdzad nas/ / rdo rje thod par stsal nas ni/ / lha yi nu ma mnye mdzad de/ / dkyil 'khor yang dag rab tu dbye/ / 'khor lo ji ltar sngar gsungs pa/ / do shal do shal phyed pas brgyan/ / mtshams bzhi pa la sgo bzhi ba/ / rdo rje srad bus yang dag brgyan/ /
(5-6) He replied: ‘The circle is the same as described before, square and with four portals, and adorned with garlands and chains and vajra-threads.
'dod chags chen po'i rjes chags pas/ / lhan cig skyes dga'i rang bzhin las/ / khyod dang lhan cig bzhin bzangs ma/ / de la dbus su nga yod de/ /
(7) There at its centre am I, O Fair One, together with you. The Joy Innate I am in essence, and impassioned with great passion.

zhal brgyad pa la zhabs bzhi pa/ / phyag ni bcu drug gis brgyan pa/ / bdud bzhi mnyam par mnan pa nyid/ / 'jigs pa yang ni 'jigs pa'o/ / mgo bo'i phreng bas do shal mdzad/ / nyi mar bzhugs shing rol mor bcas/ / kha dog nag po 'jigs pa po/ / sna tshogs rdo rje spyi bor 'dzin/ /

(8) I have eight faces, four legs, and sixteen arms, and trample the four Maras under foot. Fearful am I to fear itself, (9) with my necklace made of a string of heads, and dancing furiously on a solar disk. Black am I and terrible with a crossed vajra on my head,

nyid kyi zhal nas hU~M spro zhing / / thal bas lus la byugs pa nyid/ / bdag med lhan cig mnyam sbyor zhing / / dga' ba gnyis gnyis snyoms 'jug pas/ / dpa' rlabs med pa'i bde ba po/ / rlom sems med pa'i rang bzhin can/ / rtsa ba'i zhal ni nag po che/ / g.yas pa la ni kun da mtshungs/ /

(10-11) my body smeared with ashes, and my mouths sending forth the sound HŪṂ. But my inner nature is tranquil, and holding Nairātmyā in loving embrace, I am possessed of tranquil bliss. My front face is black, the one to the right is like white jasmine,
g.yon pa dmar zhing cher 'jigs pa/ / spyi bo'i zhal ni gtsigs pa can/ / spyan ni nyi shu rtsa bzhis che/ / lhag ma'i zhal ni bung ba bzhin/ /
(12) the one to the left is red and fearful, and the one to the rear is distorted. The remaining faces are like those of bees, and there are twenty-four eyes and so on.
grong khyer nyams dgar khyod dang nga / / dga' bas shin tu rol ba las/ / dkar mo dbang po'i phyogs phyung nas/ / shar gyi sgo ru yang dag gnas/ /
(13) In that fair citadel we play together with much delight, and thence Gaurī emerges and takes her position at the eastern portal.
srub dang bsrub pa'i sbyor ba las/ / chom rkun ma yang phyung nas ni/ / phyung nas lho yi sgo ru ni/ / chom rkun ma ni sgo srungs ma/ /
(14) Next from our union there emerges Caurī who appears to the south as keeper of that portal.
bo la kak+ko la sbyor bas/ / ro langs ma yang phyung nas ni/ / phyung nas nub kyi sgo ru ni/ / bdud 'joms ma ni rnam par gnas/ /
(15) Then Vetālī, that destroyer of Māra, appears in the west,
dga' ba chen po'i snyoms 'jug las/ / g+hA sma rI yang phyung nas ni/ / phyung nas byang gi sgo la ni/ / 'jigs pa'i gzugs can ma nyid gnas/ /
(16) and Ghasmarī of fearful appearance, in the north.
gnyis kyis bskyod pa'i sbyor ba las/ / puk+ka sI yang phyung nas ni/ / phyung nas dbang ldan mtshams su ni/ / drag po'i gzugs can ma nyid gnas/ /
(17) Likewise there appear Pukkasī in the north-east,
yang ni srub pa'i sbyor ba yis/ / 'tshed pa'i mtshams su ri khrod ma/ / srin po'i mtshams su gdol pa mo/ / rlung gi mtshams su g.yung mo nyid/ /
(18) Śavarī in the south-east, Caṇḍālī in the south-west, and Ḍombinī in the north-west.
de nas rdo rje chags chen las/ / rig mar bcas pa khu bar gyur/ / sna tshogs glu yi mchod pa las/ / de nas lha mo rnams kyis bskul/ /
(19) Then the Adamantine Lord sinks with his Spell into the condition of bliss,[2] and the goddesses with the offering of various songs urge him to arise.
rje btsun snying rje'i yid bzhengs shig / buk+ka sI ni bdag la skyobs/ / stong ba'i rang bzhin nyid spongs la/ / bdag la bde chen sbyor bzhed mdzod/ /
(20) “Arise, O Lord, thou whose mind is compassion, and save me, Pukkasī. Embrace me in the union of great bliss, and abandon the condition of voidness.”
khyod med na ni bdag 'gums pas/ / kye yi rdo rje khyod bzhengs shig / stong pa'i rang bzhin nyid spongs la/ / ri khrod ma 'bras grub par mdzod/ /
(21) “Without you I die. Arise, O Hevajra. Leave this condition of voidness, and prosper the doings of Śavarī.”
dga' gtso 'jig rten mgron gnyer ba/ / stong pa nyid la bzhugs sam ci/ / khyod med phyogs ni mi 'tshal bas/ / gdol pa mo bdag du ba bgyid/ /
(22) “O Lord of Bliss, who speak your words of power for the benefit of the world, why do you remain in the void? I Caṇḍālī entreat you, for without you I cannot consume the four quarters.”
bdag gis khyod kyi thugs 'tshal gyis/ / mig 'phrul mnga' ba khyod bzhengs shig / g.yung mo bdag nyid dran mnyam pas/ / snying rje rgyun chad ma mdzad cig /
(23) “O Wonder-worker, arise, for I know your thought. I, Ḍombī, am Weak in mind. Do not interrupt your compassion.”[1]
glang po rta bong glang rnga mo/ / mi dang sha ra b+ha byi la/ / g.yas pa'i thod pa brgyad rnams la/ / gnyis 'thung la sogs rim shes bya/ /
(27) Then from the sounds of am and HŪṂ the Lord arises from his trance, spreading his feet upon the ground, and threatening gods and titans.
sa dang chu dang rlung dang ni/ / me dang zla ba nyi ma nyid/ / mthar byed dang ni nor sbyin nyid/ / g.yon pa'i thod pa brgyad na'o/ /
(24) The skulls in his right hands contain these things in this order: an elephant, a horse, an ass, an ox, a camel, a man, a lion, and a cat.
sgeg cing dpa' bo mi sdug pa/ / rgod cing drag shul 'jigs rung ba/ / snying rje rngam dang zhi ba yis/ / gar dgu'i ro dang ldan pa nyid/ /
(25) Those in the left are: Earth, Water, Air, Fire, Moon, Sun, Yama, and Vaiśrāvana.[2]
oM dang hU~M gis rdo rje che/ / khu ba'i gzugs las bzhengs nas ni/ / zhabs rnams sa la brdebs pa dang / / lha dang lha min bsdigs par mdzad/ /
(26) He is possessed of the nine emotions of dancing: passion, heroism, loathsomeness, horror, mirth, frightfulness, compassion, wonderment, and tranquillity.
ga~M tsa~M ba~M g+ha~M/ sha~M tsa~M la~M Da~M/ 'di yis sa bon phyung ba las/ / bdag po'i sa bon dag gis ni/ / oM hU~M sngon po 'bar 'jigs pas/ /

(28) GAṂ CAṂ VAṂ GHAṂ PAṂ SAṂ LAṂ DAṂ—thus does he produce their seed-syllables from HŪṂ and AṂ which are blazing and terrible and black in appearance, the seed-syllables of the Lord himself and his consort.
ma mo'i 'khor lo grong nyams dgar/ / kha dog nag po 'jigs chen po/ / bdag med bde ba sbyin pa po/ / gtso bo 'di ltar bsgom pa nyid/ /
(29) In this manner one should conceive the Lord in that fair citadel, that circle of goddesses, where, black in colour and exceedingly fearful, he bestows such bliss upon Nairātmyā.
(These are the implements of the goddesses:)
dkar mo'i g.yas na gri gug ste/ / de bzhin g.yon na ro hi ta/ / chom rkun ma g.yas cang te'u ste/ / g.yon pa'i phyag na phag pa nyid/ /
(30) Gaurī holds in her right hand a knife and in her left a fish Caurī „ „ drum „ „ wild boar
ro langs ma g.yas rus sbal te/ / g.yon pa yis ni pad+ma'i snod/ / g+hasma rI yi g.yas na sprul/ / g.yon pas rnal 'byor lhung bzed nyid/ /
(31) Vetālī „ „ tortoise „ „ skull Ghasmarī „ „ snake „ „ bowl
puk+ka sI g.yas seng+ge ste/ / g.yon pas dgra sta de bzhin no/ / ri khrod ma g.yas dge slong ste/ / g.yon pas bsil byed de bzhin no/ /
(32) Pukkasī „ „ lion „ „ axe Śavarī „ „ monk „ „ fan
gdol pa mo g.yas 'khor lo ste/ / g.yon pas thod pa de bzhin no/ / g.yung mo g.yas na rdo rje nyid/ / g.yon na sdigs mdzub de bzhin no/ /
(33) Caṇḍālī holds in the right a wheel and in the left a plough. Ḍombī has in the right a vajra and with the left she points one finger.[1]
skyil krung phyed pa'i gar gyis gnas/ / dkar mo la sogs phyag gnyis brjod/ / spyan gsum skra ni gyen du ste/ / phyag rgya lnga yis rnam par brgyan/ /
(34) They are all two-armed and in a dancing-stance in the semi-paryaṅka position. They have three eyes, their hair twists upwards, and they wear the five symbolic adornments.

gau rI kha dog nag por 'gyur/ / chom rkun ma ni bcod dang mtshungs/ / ro langs ma ni gser btsos bzhin/ / g+ha sma rI ni ma rgad mtshungs/ / puk+ka sI ni dbang sngon mtshungs/ / ri khrod ma ni zla nor 'od/ / gtum mo nam mkha'i sngo sangs ma/ / g.yung mo sna tshogs pa zhes brjod/ /

(35) Gaurī is black; Caurī is like the sun; Vetālī is like burnished gold; Ghasmarī is like emerald; (36) Pukkasī is like sapphire; Śavarī is like moonstone; Caṇḍālī is dark like cloud and Ḍombinī is golden.
tshangs pa dbang po nye dbang drag/ / gshin rje dang ni nor bdag dang / / bden bral dang ni thags bzangs ris/ / gau rI la sogs pa yi gdan/ /
(37) Their seats are: Brahmā, Indra, Viṣṇu, Śiva, Yama, Kubera, Nairṛti, and Vemacitrin.’
b.
bo la gzhib par mdzad nas ni/ / dam du 'khyud cing 'o mdzad pas/ / bcom ldan gus pas mchod nas ni/ / bdag med ma yis sngags zhus so/ /
(38) Then Nairātmyā asked about mantras,

bud med rnams kyi dbang byed sngags/ / de bzhin gdug pa sdigs pa dang / / klu rnams sdigs par byed pa nyid/ / lha dang lha min rnam nyed pa/ / de ni nga yis bshad bya yis/ / lha mo bde ba sbyin ma nyon/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' la/ / bdag gis gzhan du ma bstan to/ / 'di yi sngags kyis gang byung zhing / / rdo rje sems dpas gang mdzad pa/ / lha mo shin tu 'jigs pa ste/ / ngo mi chog pas khyod la bshad/ /

and the Lord replied: (39-41) ‘I will tell you of that mantra which is effective in subduing women and in threatening the wicked, which overthrows the serpents and destroys gods and titans, so do thou listen, O Goddess, thou giver of bliss. I have told none but buddhas and bodhisattvas of what is done by Vajra-sattva and what comes of this mantra. I am greatly afraid, O Goddess; for your protection it is told to you.[2]
'bar ba'i phreng ba 'khrug pa yi/ / dkyil 'khor rab tu bzhengs nas ni/ / rdo rje snying po dbang sbyin phyir/ / thig le mchog ni bkug pa nyid/ /
'Having laid out the mandala, terrible with its ring of flames, one should draw forth the excellent bindu for the consecration of Vajragarbha.'
bzlas pa khri yis gsal ba dang / / sgra ring ba dang bzang ba yis/ / kye yi rdo rje sbyor ldan pas/ / btsun mo thams cad dgug par bya/ /
(43-44) By 10,000 recitations in a clear, pleasant and sonorous tone, one who has applied himself to practice in Hevajra, may draw to himself all women.
bzlas pa 'bum gyis rnal 'byor bdag / kye yi rdo rje'i rnal 'byor gyis/ / dogs pa med pa'i sems kyis ni/ / 'di yis las rnams thams cad byed/ /
By 100,000 recitations he may perform any rite.
rig byed rnams kyi dang po sbyin/ / zla phyed thig les rnam par brgyan/ /
de nas

aSh+TA na nA ya/ piM ga ur+d+ha ke sha brtam ne/ tsa turba sha ti ni tA ya/ de'i rjes su/ Sho Da shwab+hu dzA ya/ kr-iSh+NA dzI mU ta wa pu She ka bA la mA lA nai ka d+hA ri Ne/ A d+ha mA taH/ krUr tsit+tA ya ar d+he na du daMSh+Ti Ne/ oM mA ra ya mA ra ya/ ka ra ya kA ra ya/ gar+dz+dza ya gar+dz+dza ya/ tar+dz+dza ya tar+dz+da ya/ shoSho ya sho Sha ya/ sab+ta sA ga rA ni/ ban+d+ha ban+d+ha nA gASh+Ta kA~M gr-ih+na gr-ih+na sha trU~M/

to the eight-faced one with yellow hair twisting upwards, (46) who has twenty-four eyes and sixteen arms, whose body is like a black thunder-cloud and bears numerous skulls and garlands, and whose mind is extremely ferocious and whose teeth are like half-moons: (47) Slay! Slay! Have done! Have done! Roar! Roar! Threaten! Threaten! Consume! consume the seven seas! Bind! bind the eight serpents! Seize! seize our enemies!
ha hA hi hI hu hU he haM ho hau haM haHphaT swA hA/
HA HĀ HI HĪ HU HŪ HE HAI HO HAU HAṂ HAḤ PHAṬ SVĀHĀ
c.

de nas lha mo de dgyes nas/ / srub dang bsrub pa'i sbyor ba las/ / dam du 'khyud dang 'o byed pas/ / dkyil 'khor yid du 'ong ba zhus/ / de la ston pa ye shes che/ / rdo rje pad+ma mnyam sbyar nas/ / dgyes pa'i thugs kyis mnyam gzhag pas/ / nyid kyi dkyil 'khor bri bar mdzad/ /
(48) Then the Goddess asks about the maṇḍala, (49) and the Master of Mighty Knowledge, blissful and self-collected, draws it there himself.
'phar ma gA cig dang sgo bzhi pa/ / sna tshogs 'od kyis yang dag 'khrugs/ / rta babs bzhi dang yang dag ldan/ / rdo rje srud bus rnam par brgyan/ / re khA lnga dang yang dag ldan/ /
(50) There is one circle, surrounded by flames of different hues, with four doors and four portals, adorned with vajra-threads and the series of five colours.
de nas bum pa brgyad po bri/ / rin chen lnga yi phye ma'am/ / yang na 'bras la sogs pa yi/ / dur khrod kyi ni so phag gam/ / de bzhin dur khrod sol ba yis/ /
(51) He draws then the eight vessels, all done with powder made from the five kinds of gem or from rice and so on, or else from cemetery bricks or the charcoal from the funeral pyre.
de dbus pad+mA 'dab ma ni/ / brgyad pa ze bar bcas pa bri/ / snying por skyes pa'i thod pa nyid/ / mdog dkar cha ni gsum pa bri/ /
(52) In the centre he draws a lotus with its pericarp and eight petals. At the centre of this he draws a skull, white and in three sections.
dbang ldan du ni shar b+ha/ / me yi mtshams su dge slong bri/ / bden bral du ni 'khor lo bri/ / rlung du rigs kyi bdag po bri/ /
(53) Then on the north-east petal he draws a lion, on the south-east a monk, on the south-west a wheel and on the north-west a vajra,
shar sgor de bzhin gri gug nyid/ / lho ru cang te'u bri ba nyid/ nub tu rus sbal bri ba nyid/ / lto 'phye byang du de bzhin no/ /
(54) on the eastern a knife, on the southern a drum, on the western a tortoise, and on the northern a serpent.
lha mo'i kha dog dbye ba yis/ / phyag mtshan brgyad du rab tu grags/ / dbus su thod pa dkar po yang / / sna tshogs rdo rjes mtshan pa bri/ /
(55) These are the eight symbols of the goddesses in accordance with their different categories. In the centre he draws a white skull, signed with a crossed-vajra,
de nas rnam rgyal bum pa nyid/ / yal ga'i rtse mo gos bzang can/ / lto ba rin chen lngas gang ba/ / sA lu skyes pas yongs bkang bzhag /
(56) and (to the east) he places the sacred Vessel of Victory with branches in it and enwrapped with cloth, the five gems inside and filled with śālija.[1]
mang du rab tu brjod pas ci/ / ji ltar de nyid bsdus pa yi/ / dkyil 'khor cho ga de bzhin bya/ /
(57) But why say more? The maṇḍala-ritual should be performed as it is given in the Tattvasaṃgraha.[2]
bcu gnyis brgyad gnyis lon pa yi/ / rig ma bde chen brgyad po nyid/ / do shal rkang gdub kyis brgyan nas/ / dkyil 'khor du ni rab tu gzhug /
(58) Into the maṇḍala one should cause to enter the eight blissful Spells, twelve or sixteen years of age, and adorned with necklaces and bangles.

ma dang sring mo nyid dang yang / / bu mo sring mo tsha mo dang / / de bzhin zhang po'i chung ma dang / / ma yi spun dang sgyug mo dang / / de bzhin pha yi sring mo nyid/ / rig ma brgyad du rab tu grags/ /
(59) They are called wife, sister, daughter, niece, maternal uncle’s wife, maternal aunt, mother-in-law, and paternal aunt.
dam du 'khyud dang 'o byed pas/ / 'di rnams rnal 'byor pa yis mchod/ / de las ga bur btung ba nyid/ / des ni dkyil 'khor bsang gtor bya/ /
(60) These the yogin should honour with deep embraces and kisses. Then he should drink camphor and sprinkle the maṇḍala with it.
de rnams rnal 'byor bas btung bya/ / dngos grub myur du thob par 'gyur/ / de la chang yang btung ba dang / / sha dang sA lu skyes pa bza'/ /
(61) He should cause them to drink it and he should quickly gain siddhi. Wine is drunk and meat and herbs are eaten.
de yang gos dang bral byas nas/ / b+ha gar 'o ni yang dag bya/ / des kyang bol+la gzhib par bya/ / gar bya glu yang blang bar bya/ /
(62) Next he removes their garments and kisses them again and again. They honour him in return and sing and dance to their best,
bol+la kak+ko la sbyar nas/ / de la rtsed mo rtse bar bya/ /
(63) and they play there together in the union of vajra and lotus.
de nas thun tshod gnyis pa la/ /
Then at the second stage he should cause the pupil to enter,
gos kyis mig ni bkab nas su/ / der ni slob ma gzhug pa nyid/ / phyi nas dkyil 'khor rab tu bstan/ / mtshan mo skye bo med khyim du/ /
(64) and having covered his eyes with a cloth, he should afterwards display to him the maṇḍala.[3] Consecration is given there in that lonely place at night.
slob dpon la sogs rab phye nas/ / dbang ni ji ltar gsungs pa nyid/ / de la dbang bskur sbyin par bya/ / ji ltar mchod dang bstod bshad pa/ / slob ma bzang pos sngar shes bya/ /
(65) The consecrations are as ordained, distinguished as that of the Master and so on. Good pupils should first pronounce words of praise and worship.[4]
de la de nyid bstan pa ni/ / dga' bral dang po mchog mtha' can/ / thams cad rgyud du sbas pa ste/ / mtha' yi mtha' ru phye ba nyid/ /

(66) Then he initiates him in the truth itself, which is experienced at the beginning of the Joy of Cessation, and at the end of the Joy Perfect. That which is concealed in all the tantras, is here finally made manifest.’[1]
d.
rdo rje mchod pa rab sbyar nas/ / de la lha mo des zhus pa/ / lha de'i skad cig ji ltar lags/ / gtso bo chen pos bshad du gsol/ /
(67) Then the Goddess asked: ‘What is that moment like? May the Great Lord please tell me.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / der ni thog ma dbus mtha' med/ / srid med mya ngan 'das pa med/ / 'di ni mchog tu bde chen nyid/ / bdag med gzhan yang med pa nyid/ /
(68) The Lord replied: ‘There there is no beginning, no end, no middle; there is neither saṃsāra nor nirvāṇa. It is the great and perfect bliss, where there is neither self nor other.
longs spyod kyi ni rlabs gnyis la/ / rang gi g.yas dang lag gzhan gyi/ / mthe bong dang ni srin lag gis/ / de ni rnal 'byor pa yis btsir/ /
(69) The thumb of one’s own right hand and the fourth finger of the other hand, with these the yogin should press the two waves at the sambhogacakra (the throat),[2]
de nas ye shes skye bar 'gyur/ / de las ci zhig skye zhe na/ / gzhon nu'i dga' ba ji lta'am/ / lkugs pa'i rmi lam ji lta'o/ / mchog gi mtha' dang dga' bral dbus/ / stong dang stong min he ru ka/ /

(70) and from this what happens, you ask. Then there arises knowledge blissful like that of union with a maiden or like the dream of a fool. This is the end of the Joy Perfect and the beginning of the Joy of Cessation,[3] Void and non-Void, the state of Heruka.’
kye rdo rje las kye rdo rje mngon par 'byung ba zhes bya ba'i le'u ste lnga pa'o// //

d.crumb: bris sku'i cho ga

f.d: [bris sku'i cho ga]

d.crumb: vi. the making of a painting

f.d: CHAPTER VI. THE MAKING OF A PAINTING
a.

lha mo la ni dam 'khyud cing / / bol+la thod par bcug nas ni/ / dam du nu ma bzung mdzad nas/ / skyes pa'i sna ni gzhibs nas kyang / / tshems kyis ma mchu btsir nas ni/ / mchan khung sen mos rma mdzad de/ / mnyam sbyor bde ba myong mdzad nas/ / phyag rgya lnga ni rab phye ba/ /
(1-2) Then the Lord discoursed upon the five symbolic adornments.[4]

bla ma slob dpon 'dod lha la/ / phyag 'tshal don du 'khor lo 'dzin/ / bla ma rdo rje 'dzin pa la/ / smod tshig mi nyan pa yi phyir/ / rna ba dag tu rna cha 'dzin/ / sngags kyi bzlas pa mgul rgyan nyid/ /
(3) The crown is worn for the adoration of one’s guru and master and chosen divinity. Earrings are worn to indicate one’s deafness to evil words spoken against one’s guru and “vajra-holder”.
gdu bu srog chags gsod pa spangs/ / phyag rgya bsten pa ska rags nyid/ / sangs rgyas lnga yi phyag rgyas ni/ / rtag tu lus la phyag rgyas gdab/ /

(4) The necklace suggests the mantras intoned, the bracelets one’s renunciation of harming living-beings, the girdle one’s service of the Mudrā. The body should always be signed with these signs of the Five Buddhas.’
b.

de nas rab tu bzhad mdzad nas/ / tshems kyis ma mchu btsir nas ni/ / kye yi rdo rje zhes bya ba/ / lhan cig skyes pa'i gzugs can nyid/ / de la lha mo des zhus pa/ / gtso bo cho ga gang gis dang / / de bzhin bya ba gang gis ni/ / kye rdo rje yi bris sku ni/ / byed pa bde ba chen pos gsungs/ /
(5-6) Then the Goddess asked Hevajra: ‘In accordance with what precept and what ritual should one make a painting of Hevajra? May the Lord of Great Bliss please tell me.’

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / 'dir ni 'dri mkhan dam tshig can/ / sgrub po'ang dam tshig can gyis ni/ / bris sku 'jigs pa bri ba nyid/ / skyes pa'i thod gnas kha dog lnga/ / ro yi skra yi pir nyid kyis/ / byis sku bla ma bri ba nyid/ /

(7) He replied: ‘By a painter who belongs to our tradition, by a yogin of our tradition, this fearful painting should be done, and it should be painted with the five colours reposing in a human skull and with a brush made from the hair of a corpse.
gang gang skud pa 'khal ba dang / / gang gang ras yug 'thag pa yang / / de yang dam tshig can nges pas/ / dam tshig byin rlabs rnal 'byor pas/ /
(8) She who is to spin the thread and weave the canvas should also be of our tradition and united in its sacramental power.
zla ba zla ba'i mar ngo yi/ / bcu bzhi pa la khyim dben par/ / phyed nam rungs sems kyis ni/ / chang gi btung ba cung zad las/ /
(9) (It should be painted under these circumstances:) in a lonely spot at noon on the fourteenth day of the dark fortnight, in a ferocious state of mind from the drinking of some wine,
lus la ni ra~M shu bsams nas/ / de bzhin gcer bur gyur pas kyang / / 'bags pa dang ni ma dag pas/ / de nas dam tshig rab tu bza'/ /
(10) with the body naked and adorned with the bone accoutrements; one should eat the sacrament in its foul and impure form,[1]
bzhin bzangs snying rje ldan pa dang / / gzugs dang lang tsho skal bzang ma/ / me tog bcas shing sgrub por dga'/ / rang gi phyag rgya g.yon du gzhag /
(11) having placed one’s own mudrā at one’s left side, she who is beautiful, compassionate, well endowed with youth and beauty, adorned with flowers and beloved of her master.’
kye'i rdo rje las bris sku'i cho ga'i le'u ste drug pa'o// //

d.crumb: bza' ba

f.d: [bza' ba]

d.crumb: vii. books and feasting

f.d: CHAPTER VII. BOOKS AND FEASTING
a.
de nas de la lha mos zhus/ / bol+la kak+ko la sbyar nas/ / tshems kyis ma mchu btsir nas ni/ / glegs bam yang ni ji ltar 'gyur/ /
(1) Then the Goddess asked about books and he replied:

rdo rje pad+ma mnyam sbyar nas/ / dgyes pas lha yis rab phye ba/ / glegs bam nga yis bshad bya yis/ / lha mo skal ba chen mo nyon/ / sbrang chen snag tsha byas nas ni/ / mi yi rus pa'i smyu gus ni/ / glegs bam sor ni bcu gnyis pa/ / gro gar dam tshig can gyis bri/ / glegs bam dang ni bris sku nyid/ /

(2) ‘O listen, Goddess, greatly blessed, and I will speak on the subject of books. The book should be written by one of our tradition on leaves of birch-bark twelve aṅgula long, with collyrium for ink and with a human bone as a pen.
gal te skal med mthong na ni/ / skye ba 'dir ni dngos grub med/ / 'jig rten pha rol spyod yul med/ /
(3) But if someone unworthy should see either book or painting, one will fail to gain perfection either in this world or the next.
yang dag rab sbyin ldan pa la/ / res 'ga' tsam zhig bstan pa nyid/ / glegs bam lam gyi spyod yul du/ / skra dang mchan khung nyid du sba/ /
(4) To one of our tradition it may be shown at any time. Then on a journey the book should be hidden in the hair or under the arm.
b.
b+ha gar ling ga rab bzhag nas/ / yang dang yang du 'o mdzad nas/ / bde chen mnyam par myong mdzad de/ / rdo rje can gyis bza' ba bstan/ /
tshogs kyi dkyil 'khor bzo' ba ni/ / nyon cig lha mo mig yangs ma/ / gang du zos pas 'dod don kun/ / sgrub pa can gyi dngos grub 'gyur/ /
(6) Now listen Goddess of wide-open eyes, to the matter of feasting in the company-circle, where if one feasts, that siddhi is gained that fulfils the substance of all one’s desires.
dur khrod ri yi bya skyibs dang / / de bzhin mi med grong khyer dang / / yang na dben pa'am rgya mtsho'i mthar/ / bza' ba 'di ni rab tu bza'/ /
(7) One should set about this feasting in a cemetery or mountain-cave, in a deserted town or in some lonely place.
de la gdan du brtag pa ni/ / ro yi gzugs can dgu dang ni/ / yang na stag gi pags pa dang / / dur khrod ras ni de bzhin no/ /
(8) One should arrange seats there, reckoned as nine, in the form of corpses, or tiger-skins, or rags from a cemetery.
dbus su kye rdo rje yi gzugs/ / ji ltar sngar bzhin gnas shes nas/ / phyogs dang phyogs bral dag tu yang / / de nas rnal 'byor ma rnams dgod/ /
(9) In the centre is he who embodies Hevajra, and with previous knowledge of their right positions one should place the yoginīs in the eight directions.
dam tshig mA la tin+dA naM/ / stag gi pags pa'i steng du bza'/ / 'bad pas rgyal po sA lu yi/ / bza' ba der ni bza' ba nyid/ / der ni zos nas zos nas kyang / / der ni ma mo mchod par bya/ /

(10) Then seated upon one’s tiger-skin one should eat the food with eagerness, the sacramental herbs and the special flesh.[3] Having eaten and eaten again, one should worship the mother-goddesses there,
sring mo bu mo sgyug mo dang / / gal te ma sring yin na yang / / de rnams rtag tu legs mchod na/ / tshogs kyi dkyil 'khor 'grub par gyur/ /
(11) and perhaps the mother may be sister or niece or mother-in-law.[4] One should honour them to a high degree and gain siddhi in their company.
skyes pa'i thod chen cha gcig par/ / chang ni bzang pos yongs bkang ste/ / bla ma la dbul skal chen ma/ / phyag 'tshal nas ni rang yang btung / /
(12) The meritorious (pupil) should present to his master a sacred skull-cup in one piece which is filled with wine, and then having made obeisance to him, he himself should drink.
pad+ma'i lag pas blangs pa dang / / de nyid kyi ni lag pas dbul/ / yang nas yang du rab 'dud pa/ / de ltar sgrub pa po yis bya/ /
(13) He should hold it with his hands in the lotus-gesture and present it with his hands in the same position. Again and again the yogins make obeisance there.’
kye'i rdo rje las bza' ba'i le'u ste bdun pa'o// //

d.crumb: 'dul ba

f.d: ['dul ba]

d.crumb: viii. subjugating

f.d: CHAPTER VIII. SUBJUGATING
a.
de nas rnal 'byor mas zhus pa/ / phyag rgya chen po ji lta bu/ / kun rdzob rnam pa'i gzugs kyis ni/ / bde ba sbyin pas bshad du gsol/ /
(1) Then the yoginīs asked: ‘What is the Great Symbol like in relative form? May thou, the giver of bliss, please tell us.’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / shin tu ring min thung ba min/ / gnag pha ma yin dkar ba min/ / pad+ma'i 'dab ma'i rnam pa 'dra/ /
(2) The Lord replied: ‘She is neither too tall, nor too short, neither quite black nor quite white, but dark like a lotus-leaf.[1]

de yi dbugs ni dri zhim ldan/ / rdul kyang dri zhim ldan 'gyur te/ / ri dgas lte ba'i dri dang mtshungs/ / pad+ma la yang dbang mchog dri/ / skad cig pad+ma lta bu 'byung / / de yi ga pur sih+la dag / mkhas pas dri bzang mtshon par bya/ / ut+pa la yi drir 'gyur zhing / / a ka ru ni nag po mtshungs/ /
(3-4) Her breath is sweet, and her sweat has a pleasant smell like that of musk. Her pudenda give forth a scent from moment to moment like different kinds of lotuses[2] or like sweet aloe wood.

dal zhing mi g.yo ba nyid dang / / snyan par smra zhing yid 'ong ma/ / skra bzang dbus su gnyer ma gsum/ / phal pas pad+ma can du brjod/ / lhan cig skyes pa'i gzugs can ma/ / de rnyed nas ni dngos grub 'gyur/ /

(5) She is calm and resolute, pleasant in speech and altogether delightful, with beauteous hair and three wrinkles in the middle of her body. By vulgar men, in fact, she would be classed as first-rank. Having gained her, one gains that siddhi, the nature of which is the Joy Innate.’
b.
de nas rnal 'byor ma bdag med mas gsol ba/ bcom ldan 'das smon lam ji ltar gdab par bgyi/
(6) Then Nairātmyā said: ‘Lord, what kind of vow should be made?’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / rigs su skye dang dam tshig can/ / smyo med kye yi rdo rje ston/ / bla ma la gus snying rjer ldan/ / skye zhing skye bar 'gyur bar shog /
He replied: ‘May I be born from birth to birth as a member of this family, free from mania, compassionate, devoted to my guru, abiding by our conventions and an expounder of Hevajra.
lag pas rdo rje dril bu 'khrol/ / zab mo'i chos ni klog pa dang / / btsun mo'i khu ba mnyam bzas can/ / skye zhing skye bar 'gyur bar shog /
(7) May I be born from birth to birth, proclaiming this doctrine profound and ringing the vajra-bell, concentrating in myself the essence of woman.’
c.
de nas lha mo de dgyes nas/ / tshig ni 'di nyid yang zhus pa/ / skal med sems can gdul dka' ba/ / gang gis 'dul bar 'gyur ba lags/ /
(8) Then pleased at this the Goddess asked: ‘Those unworthy beings who are hard to tame, how are they brought to subjugation?’
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / dang por gso sbyong sbyin par bya/ / de rjes bslab pa'i gnas bcu nyid/ / de la bye brag smra ba bstan/ / mdo sde pa yang de bzhin no/ /
(9) The Lord replied: ‘First there should be the public confession (poṣadha), then they should be taught the ten rules of virtuous conduct, then the Vaibhāṣya teachings and then the Sautrāntika,

de nas rnal 'byor spyod pa nyid/ / de yi rjes la dbu ma bstan/ / sngags kyi rim pa kun shes nas/ / de rjes kye yi rdo rje brtsam/ / slob mas gus par blangs nas ni/ / 'grub 'gyur 'di la the tshom med/ /
(10) after that the Yogācāra and then the Mādhyamika. Then when they know all mantra-method, they should start upon Hevajra. The pupil who lays hold with zeal, should succeed, there is no doubt.
kye'i rdo rje las 'dul ba'i le'u ste brgyad pa'o// //

d.crumb: sngags btu ba

f.d: [sngags btu ba]

d.crumb: ix. mantras

f.d: CHAPTER IX. MANTRAS
a.

de nas kha sbyar 'byed pa yi/ / mtshan nyid yang dag rab tu bshad/ / gang gis rnam par shes tsam gyis/ / sgrub pos dngos grub thob 'gyur ba/ / bsgrub bya'i lte ba'i rtsa ba la/ / brtul zhugs can gyi lag pas gdon/ /

(1) Now I shall speak of the splitting of the human-complex,[3] how by the mere knowledge of which the yogin gains the end he seeks, and causes his victim to split open at the navel for one cubit’s length.
he ru ka mnyam rnal 'byor gyis/ / nang gi ma rungs sems kyis ni/ / 'di ni bsgoms pa tsam gyis ni/ / sangs rgyas kyang ni nges par 'jig /
(2) When one’s mind is resolved in inmost wrath in counterpart of Heruka, even a buddha may be destroyed by means of meditation only.
bstan la gnod pa byed pa dang / / bla ma sangs rgyas 'jig pa ni/ / bla ma thub pa la zhus nas/ / snying rjes gsad par bya ba nyid/ /
(3) Such slaying is done from compassion, after one has supplicated one’s guru and master (and is directed against) those who bring harm to the doctrine or injure one’s guru or other buddhas.
ji ltar phyugs kyi gzugs mthong nas/ / khrag ni skyugs pa nyid dang yang / / 'dar zhing mgo skyes grol ba dang / / kha ni 'og tu rnam par sgom/ /
(4) One should imagine such a one as a victim face-downwards, vomiting blood and trembling with his hair unloosed.
de yi lam du khab ni me'i/ / gzugs can 'jug par bsam pa ste/ / snying gar byin za'i sa bon nyid/ / dmigs nas skad cig gsod par byed/ /
(5) One should then imagine a needle of fire as entering his rear, and the seed-syllable of fire in his heart. By envisaging him thus, one slays him in that instant,
rgyud 'di la ni sreg blugs med/ / phyag rgya bcing dang bya ba'ang med/ / rgyud chen bklags pas 'grub pa nyid/ / bsam gtan tsam gyis 'grub par 'gyur/ /
(6) for in this rite there is no need of oblations or a performance of a sequence of gestures; this great rite succeeds just by meditation, and is brought to success by the recitation of formulas.
b.
rtog med dngos grub sbyin pa po/ / srid pasbyong ba nyams dga' bar/ / gsang ba mchog ni bshad bya yis/ / nyon cig lha mo bzhin bzangs ma/ /
(7) Now listen, fair-faced Goddess, and I will tell you the profoundest secret of the beauteous purifier of existence, who bestows that perfection that is free from all relative thought.
rin chen gzi brjid 'bar ba yi/ / phreng ba 'khrugs pa lha mo ltos/ / ma phug pas ni sbyor bral 'gyur/ / phug pas dga' ba sbyin pa'o/ /
(8) Behold, O Goddess, this great gem, this body in a darting ring of flames. Useless is a gem uncut, but once cut, it gives forth its brilliance.
de ltar 'khor bar 'dod pa yi/ / yon tan lnga ldan rin chen nyid/ / ma dag pas ni dug tu 'gro/ / dag pas bdud rtsi lta bur 'gyur/ /
(9) Likewise this gem of the saṃsāra, possessed of the properties of the five desires, becomes like poison in its unpurified state, but when purified, it becomes ambrosia.
c.
'khor ba'i rnam pa he ru ka/ / 'gro ba sgrol ba'i gtso bo nyid/ / gang gi gzugs kyis 'gyur ba nyid/ / de ni nga yis smra yis nyon/ /
(10) The saṃsāra is Heruka’s phenomenal aspect, and he is the Lord, the saviour of the world. The form in which he becomes manifest, that I will tell, so now listen.
snying rje'i spyan ni dmar po la/ / byams pa'i thugs la yan lag gnag / bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhi yis ni/ / zhabs ni rnam pa bzhi zhes brjod/ /
(11) His eyes are red from compassion; his body is black to indicate his sentiments of friendliness; his four legs symbolize the four means of conversion,[1]
zhal brgyad rnam par thar pa brgyad/ / phyag ni stong pa bcu drug nyid/ / gug skyed kyis ni sangs rgyas lnga/ / gdug pa 'dul phyir khro bo nyid/ /
(12) his eight faces the eight releases and his sixteen arms the sixteen voids. The Five Buddhas are represented by the symbolic adornments, and he is wrathful for the subduing of the evil-disposed.
sha ni puk+ka sI ru brjod/ / de bzhin khrag ni ri khrod me/ / gdol ba mo ni khu bar brjod/ / g.yung mo rkang dang tshil bu dag / pags pa byang chub yan lag bdun/ / rus pa bden pa bzhi po nyid/ /

(13) His flesh represents Pukkasī (earth), his blood Śavarī (water), his semen Caṇḍālī (fire), and his fat and marrow Ḍombī (air), his skin the seven factors of enlightenment, and his bones the four truths.’
d.
bdag med mas gsol ba/ sngags btu ba ni ji ltar 'gyur/ / gang gi sngags kyis skye bo yi/ / las kyi dngos grub 'gyur ba nyid/ / bde ba chen pos bshad du gsol/ /

(14) The Goddess said: ‘What is that collection of mantras like, by which the activities of men reach a successful conclusion? May the Giver of Great Bliss please tell me.’ He then explained the mantras.[2]

bcom ldan 'das rdo rje can chen po/ rdo rje snying po gzi brjid chen pos bka' stsal pa/ sngags ni khyod la ngas bshad kyis/ / lha mo shes rab chen mo nyon/ / dang por rnam par snang mdzad sbyin/ / uSh+mA rnams kyi da ki pa la/ / puk+ka sIs brgyan stong pas mnan/ / mdog dkar mthar ni swA hA sbyar/ /
'dis ni bzlas pa 'bum gyis ni/ / 'gro ba rtag tu rengs par byed/ / dang por yi ge'i bdag po bzhag / de rjes mkha' spyod ma de nas/ / mthar ni swA hA sbyar byas nas/ /
sangs rgyas rnams kyang dbang du byed/ / rig byed rnams kyi dang po sbyin/ / dang po yi ni gnyis pa la/ / stong bcas mtha' ni swA hA sbyar/ /

sangs rgyas kyang skrod shes rab can/ / dang por rnam par snang mdzad sbyin/ / gnyis pa yi ni gsum pa la/ / rwa dang ldan zhing chu mas brgyan/ / stong bcas swA hA yang dag ldan/ / mi rnams thams cad sdang bar byed/ / dang po yi ge'i dbang phyug bzhag / lnga pa nyid kyi gsum pa la/ / stong pa mkha' 'gro ma dang ldan/ / mthar ni swA hA mngon spyod che/ / yang ni yi ge'i thu bo sbyin/ / hU~M ni khrag dang 'dra ba yi/ / mthar ni swA hA thig le mchog /

dga' bzang ma sogs rtag tu 'gugs/ / gti mug rigs ni dang por sbyin/ / g+hu ni yang dag rab tu sbyar/ / mthar ni swA hA yang byas na/ / lha dang mi rnams gsod par byed/ / dang por rnam par snang mdzad bzhag / dang po nyid kyi dang po la/ / rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dang sbyar/ / mthar gnas pa yi gnyis pa la/ / rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dang ldan/ / yang na dang po'i rtse mo la/ / rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dang ldan/ / mthar gnas pa yi gsum pa la/ / yang ni de nyid yang dag ldan/ / steng du chom rkun ma yis brgyan/ / de rjes hrIHyis rnam par sbyar/ / mthang yang swA hA spyod pa nyid/ / ku ru kul+le'i sngags so/ /

oM ni dang po bzhi pa yi/ / gsum pa chom rkun ma yis brgyan/ / mthar gzhas pa yi bzhi pa la/ / pi tsu badzra sbyar pa dang / / uSh+mA rnams kyi bzhi pa la/ / puk+ka sI yis rnam par brgyan/ / stong pas mnan cing sum 'gyur nyid/ / lnga pa yi ni gnyis pa dang / / gsum pa'i dang po mthar swA hA/ /

kye'i rdo rje'i snying po'o/ / snang mdzad dang por dz+wa la gnyis/ / sbyar nas lnga ba'i bzhi pa la/ / mthar gnas rnams kyi dang po ldan/ / g+hasma rIs ni rnam par brgyan/ / uSh+mA rnams kyi bzhi pa la/ / rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma yis brgyan/ / stong pas mnan cing sum 'gyur nyid/ / lnga pa yi ni gnyis pa dang / / gsum pa'i dang po mthar swA hA/

phyag bzhi pa'i sngags so/ / dang por rnam snang dang po yi/ / dang po nang gi dkar mos brgyan/ / gsum pa nyid kyi dang po la/ / nang gi dkar mos rnam par brgyan/ / nyis 'gyur lnga pa'i gsum pa dang / / gnyis pa'i gsum pa me yis brgyan/ / hU~M gi rnam pa gsum sbyar nas/ / lnga pa nyid kyi gnyis pa dang / / gsum pa'i dang po mthar swA hA/ /

phyag drug pa'i sngags so/ / dang po rnam snang bzhi pa yi/ / dang po byin za yang dag ldan/ / ro langs ma yis rnam par brgyan/ / mthar gnas pa yi gsum pa la/ / g+hasma rI yis rnam par brgyan/ / dang po yi dang po la/ / mthar gnas pa yi dang po dang / / rdo rje ma yis rnam par brgyan/ / k+Sha ni chom rkun ma yis brgyan/ / lnga pa nyid kyi dang po dang / / uSh+mA rnams kyi bzhi pa la/ / rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma yis brgyan/ / stong pas mnan cing sum 'gyur te/ / phaT dang mthar ni swA hA nyid/ / phyag gnyis pa'i sngags so/ /

bdag med dang po'i dang po dang / / gnyis pa nyid kyi dang po dang / / gsum pa nyid kyi dang po dang / / bzhi ba yi ni dang po dang / / lnga pa yi ni dang po dang / / mthar gnas rnams kyi dang po dang / / uSh+mU rnams kyi dang po nyid/ / dang por rnam snang mthar swA hA/ /

grong khyer dkrug pa'i sngags kyi bzlas pa ni 'bum mo/ / mthar gnas rnams kyi gnyis pa dang / / k+Sha yi rnam pa nyis 'gyur nyid/ / hUM gi rnam pa gsum dang ldan/ / dang por rnam snang phaT nyid kyi/ / rnam pa nang bcug mthar swA hA/ / sa sbyangs pa'i sngags so/ / dang por rnam snang de rjes su/ / rdo rje ma yi mtha' ru hUM/ / bza' ba dang btung ba byin gyis brlab pa'o/ / dang por rnam par snang mdzad nyid/ / de rjes a ka ro mu kha~M/ / uSh+mA rnams kyi gsum pa dang / / mthar gnas pa yi bzhi pa ni/ / steng du me yis rnam par brgyan/ / d+harmA NA~M de rjes rdo rje ma/ / byin la dra nu t+pan+na twA ta/ / oM AHhU~M phaT swA hA/ / 'byung po thams cad kyi gtor ma'i sngags so/ / kye'i rdo rje las sngags btu ba'i le'u ste dgu pa'o// //

d.crumb: bzlas pa

f.d: [bzlas pa]

d.crumb: x. on reciting mantras

f.d: CHAPTER X. ON RECITING MANTRAS
a.
de nas chos kun sdom gcig pa'i/ / rdo rje sems dpa' zhes byas gsungs/ / bdag med ma la 'o mdzad nas/ / bzlas pa'i yul ni rab tu dbye/ /
(1) Then the Lord Vajrasattva, the one unity of all that is, explained to Nairātmyā the different (means used in the) reciting of mantras.
shel gyis rengs pa'i bzlas pa nyid/ / dbang la tsan+dan dmar po nyid/ / lung tang gis ni mngon spyod nyid/ / ni raM shus ni sdang ba la/ /
rta yi rus pas skrod baM nyid/ / bram ze'i rus pas 'gugs pa nyid/ / glang po'i rus pas char pa la/ / ma he yis kyang gsad pa la/ /
b.
rengs pa 'o ma'i btung ba nyid/ / dbang la rang gi 'dun pas spyad/ / gsad pa la ni sih+la nyid/ / dgug pa la ni bzhi mnyam nyid/ /
sdang la sA lu skyes pa brjod/ / bskrad pa nyid la gla rtsir brjod/ / yang na mtha'i shwa dang / dang po'i shwa dang / na dang po dang / ga dang po dang / ha dang po nyid kyang de bzhin no/ /
kye'i rdo rje las bzlas pa'i le'u ste bcu pa'o// //

d.crumb: xi. the five families

f.d: CHAPTER XI. THE FIVE FAMILIES
a.
kye'i rdo rje la dam 'khyud cing / / tshems kyis ma mchu btsin nas ni/ / lus can rnams kyi rigs kyi gzugs/ / de la bdag med mas zhus pa/ /
(1) Then Nairātmyā asked about the families of human beings,
b+ha gar ling ga gzhag nas ni/ / 'khor lo'i 'dren pas 'di skad gsungs/ / lus can rang gi rigs bshad kyis/ / shes rab pha rol phyin ma nyon/ /
(2) and the Lord of the maṇḍala replied: ‘O listen, thou Perfection of Wisdom, and I will speak of the several families of human beings.[3]
bud med dam ni skyes pa yi/ / gang gi srin lag rtsa ba la/ / rdo rje rtse dgu par gyur pa/ / mi bskyod pa yi rigs mchog nyid/ /
(3) Whatever man or woman has a nine-pointed vajra on the lower joint of the fourth finger, belongs to Akṣobhya’s family, which is the highest.
rnam snang mdzad kyi 'khor lor 'gyur/ / dpag med mgon gyi 'dam skyes nyid/ / rin chen 'byung ba'i rin chen nyid/ / las kyi rigs kyi ral gri nyid/ /
(4) For Vairocana’s there would be a wheel, for Amitābha’s a lotus, for Ratnasambhava’s a gem and for Amoghasiddhi’s a sword.
rnal 'byor pa gang nag po che/ / de yi lha ni mi bskyod pa/ / rnal 'byor pa gang dkar po che/ / de yi lha ni rnam snang mdzad/ /
(5) The yogin whose colour is black has Akṣobhya as his divinity. The yogin whose colour is white has Vairocana.
rnal 'byor pa gang sngo bsangs che/ / de yi lha ni don yod nyid/ / rnal 'byor pa gang ser po che/ / rin chen bdag po rigs kyi lha/ /
(6) The yogin whose colour is dark green has Amoghasiddhi. The yogin whose colour is yellow has Ratnasambhava.
rnal 'byor pa gang dkar dmar nyid/ / 'od dpag med pa rigs kyi lha/ / rnal 'byor pa gang dkar dang ser/ / de ni sems dpa'i rigs su 'gyur/ /
(7) The yogin whose colour is red has Amitābha. The yogin whose colour is white is of Vajrasattva’s family.
skye bo rnal 'byor mthar phyin pas/ / nga rgyal mi bcag tho mi btsam/ / kun rdzob gzugs su gnas nas ni/ / de rnams bde gshegs rigs su 'gyur/ /
(8) Yogins who have reached perfection should have no special liking or contempt for people. These families of the Five Buddhas should exist from a relative point of view.
bud med rnams kyi mtshan nyid ni/ / ji ltar skyes pa der bzhin no/ / kun rdzob tha snyad tshul las ni/ / de yi rigs su'ang de 'gyur ro/ /
(9) The signs for women are the same as those for men, for they also belong to these families under a relative aspect.’
b.
b+ha gar ling ga'i 'o mdzad nas/ / de la rdo rje che mnyes nas/ / bdag med ma yis go mdzad pa/ / lha mo rab tu mchod pa nyon/ /
(10) Then the Adamantine Lord bade Nairātmyā be attentive and said: ‘Listen, Goddess, how the Prajñā should be honoured.

tshal dang skye bo med gnas dang / / bdag gi khyim gyi nang du yang / / gcer bu phyag rgya cher byas nas/ / rnal 'byor rig pas rtag tu mchod/ / 'o dang 'khyud pa byas nas ni/ / de bzhin b+ha gar reg pa nyid/ / skyes pa'i sna ni gzhib pa nyid/ / ma mchu'i sbrang rtsi btung ba nyid/ / rtag tu myos pa'i mtshan ma las/ / bo la ldan pas lag pas bya/ / khyogs dang brla zhes bya ba dang / / de bzhin shin tu bkal ba yi/ / yang yang rdo rjes 'dod pa bya/ / steng dang 'og tu lta ba nyid/ / dngos grub rgyas pa thob pa ste/ / sangs rgyas kun dang mnyam par 'gyu+ur/ / de la ga bur btung bar bya/ / de la ga bur rgyu yi phyir/ / sha ni bza' ba nyid du bya/ / khyad par du ni chang nyid do/ /
(11) In a garden, in a lonely place, or in one’s inner apartment, ...’ (there follows an account similar to that already given on p. 113, embellished only by the listing of various postures).
kye'i rdo rje las lhan cig skyes pa'i sbyor ba don gyi le'u zhes bya ba ste bcu gcig pa'o// //

f.d: CHAPTER XII. THE FOUR CONSECRATIONS

de nas rdo rje can gyis dbang / / bzhi pa'i tshigs bcad bka' stsal pa/ / rdo rje rab gnas rdo rje nyid/ / che dang dril bu chen po bzung / / de ring rdo rje slob dpon 'gyur/ / slob ma bsdu ba nyid du gyis/ /

(1) Then the Adamantine Lord spoke concerning the four consecrations. ‘O thou who art already consubstantiated with the Vajra, take up the great vajra and the great bell, and perform even today for your pupil the beneficent act[1] of a vajra-guru.
ji ltar 'das pa'i sangs rgyas kyis/ / byang chub sras rnams dbang bskur ba/ / bdag gis gsang ba'i dbang gis ni/ / sems kyi rgyun gyis dbang bskur ro/ /
(2) Even as the bodhisattvas are consecrated by past buddhas, so in this Secret Consecration you are consecrated by me with the flow of bodhicitta.
lha mo dga' sbyin gnas sbyin me/ / sna tshogs gzugs can yid 'ong ma/ / khyer cig khyer cig sems dpa' che/ / khyer la mchod pa dag tu gyis/ /
(3) O Great One, take, take to yourself this beauteous and delightful goddess, bestower of bliss, bestower of siddhi, and having taken her, pay her due honour.
ye shes 'di ni ches phra zhing / / rdo rje nam mkha'i dkyil lta bu/ / rdul bral thar sbyin zhi ba nyid/ / khyod rang yang ni de yi pha/ /
(4) This knowledge is the great bliss, the adamantine essence, and like space, bestowing salvation, pure and tranquil. You are yourself the Father.’
rdo rje dang pad+ma byin gyis brlab pa'i sngags ni/
(5) And now the empowering mantra of vajra and lotus:
oM pat+mu su khAd+hA ra ma hA rA ga su khaM dad tsatwA rA nan+da b+hA ga pi shwa hU~M hU~M hU~M kAr+YaM ku ru Sh+wa me/
OṂ Lotus, receptacle of bliss, bestowing the bliss of great passion. Many are the blessings of your four joys, HŪṂ HŪṂ HŪṂ Prosper my affairs!
oM badzra ma hA dwe Sha tsa turA nan+da dA ya kaHkha ga mu khai ka ra so nA tha hU~M hU~M hU~M kAR+yaM ku ru Sh+wa me/
(6) OṂ Vajra, greatly wrathful, bestower of the four joys. Source of all things, of single savour, pervading space, HŪṂ HŪṂ HŪṂ Lord, prosper my affairs!
spyi bor ni oM gyi rnam pa/ snying gar ni hU~M gi rnam pa/ ze 'bru la ni AH'i rnam pa'o/ /
In the head OṂ In the heart HŪṂ In the lotus A

rgyud kyi rgyal po chen po sgyu ma'i brtag pa zhes bya ba brtag pa sum cu rtsa gnyis las phyung ba brtag pa gnyis kyi bdag nyid kye'i rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dra ba'i sdom pa'i rgyud kyi rgyal po rdzogs so// //

f.d: CHAPTER 1. Vajra Family
oṃ namaḥ śrīhevajrāya ||
kye'i rdo rje la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Oṃ Obeisance to the Divine Hevajra
evaṃ mayā śrutam ekasmin samaye bhagavān sarvatathāgatakāyavākcittahṛdayavajrayoṣidbhageṣu vijahāra / (1)
'di skad bdag gis thos pa dus gcig na/ bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi sku dang gsung dang thugs kyi snying po/ rdo rje btsun mo'i b+ha ga rnams la bzhugs so/ /
Thus have I heard: At one time Bhagavān dwelt in the wombs of the Vajra Lady which are the Body, Speech and Mind of all the Buddhas.
@##/ /rgya gar skad du/ yo ga rat+na mA la nA ma he badzra pany+tsi kA/ bod skad du/ dgyes pa rdo rje'i dka' 'grel rnal 'byor rin po che'i phreng ba zhes bya ba/
YOGARATNAMĀLĀ
dpal dgyes pa'i rdo rje la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Obeisance to Hevajra
'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
mchog tu dga' ba'i gzugs can gyis/ / dgyes pa'i rdo rjer phyag 'tshal nas/ / sngon grub rim pa'i lugs bzhin du/ / dgyes pa'i rdo rje bdag gis bri/ /
After bowing to the divine Hevajra, the essence of supreme joy, I comment upon the Hevajra Tantra following the sacred view of the lineage masters.

'di skad bdag gis zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ 'di ni gleng gzhi'i tshig yin te/ / mdo dang rgyud du rab tu bstan/ / rgyud 'di ru ni snying po'i don/ / gzhan dag gis ni gzhan dag bstan/ / de yang bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong dag 'di skad bdag gis zhes bya bas nga'i chos rnams bsdu bar bya'o zhes gsungs pa'i phyir sdud pa pos 'di skad bdag gis thos pa zhes bya ba smras pa yin no/ /

evaṃ mayā ityādi (Thus have I etc.): It is said: “In truth, it is this Fundamental Statement (nidānavākyaṃ) which is revealed in the Sutra and Tantra. In the tantric tradition the Fundamental Statement indicates the essence of tantra. Others say it refers to other things.” Therefore, it has been said by Bhagavān: “O monks, my doctrine is to be known by the proper consideration of evaṃ mayā (Thus have I).” For this reason the writer of this tantra begins with ‘Thus have I heard’.

'dir kha cig ni thos pa zhes bya bas ni sdud pa po ston pa yin te/ bdag nyid kyis shes pa dang brgyud nas thos pa ni sdud pa po tshad ma ma yin par 'gyur bas skyon 'di gnyis spang pa'i phyir 'di skad bdag gis zhes bya ba smos te/ bdag gis zhes bya ba ni bdag nyid kyis thos kyi/ gcig nas gcig tu brgyud nas thos pa ni ma yin no/ / 'di skad ces bya ba ni ji skad bsdus pa bzhin du'o/ /

śrutaṃ (heard): Here the fact that it was heard by somebody refers to the devotees who heard the proclamation of the doctrine in Bhagavān’s assembly. On the other hand, if the proclamation of the doctrine was heard through some other orally transmitted tradition, it would not be considered authoritative. ‘Thus have I’ has been used in order to exclude this possibility. Here, the use of the first person pronoun, I, emphasizes the fact that the writer of this treatise has himself heard this proclamation of the doctrine in the assembly of devotees and that it was not heard from a handed-down tradition. I will amplify evaṃ in due course.
dus gcig na zhes bya ba ni dus gcig kho nar te/ thams cad kyi thams cad du ma yin pa'o zhes bya ba'i bar du'o/ /
ekasmin samaye (at one time): Means once, not at all times and everywhere.

bcom ldan 'das zhes bya ba ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i gzugs kyi rdo rje 'chang ste/ gang la dbang phyug la sogs pa'i skal pa rnams mnga' ba de ni bcom ldan 'das te/ de yang ji skad du/ dbang phyug dang ni gzugs bzang dang / / dpal dang grags dang ye shes dang / / brtson 'grus phun sum tshogs pa dang / / drug po de la ldan zhes bya/ / zhes bstan pa yin no/ /
