Kula, family is so called because of reckoning (kulyate), that is, grouping the families of the five elements and the five components of phenomenal awareness.
nāsti bhāvako na bhāvo 'sti mantran nāsti na devatā || saṃsthitau mantradevau ca niḥprapañcasvabhāvataḥ || (11)
sgom pa po med bsgom pa'ang med/ / lha med sngags kyang yod ma yin/ / smos pa med pa'i rang bzhin las/ / sngags dang lha ni yang dag gnas/ /
There is neither emanator nor the emanated, neither mantra nor deity. Mantra and deity exist as aspects of the undifferentiated nature.
sgom pa po med ces bya ba la sogs pa la chos thams cad de bzhin nyid kyi rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir sgom pa po dang / bsgoms pa dang / bsgom par bya ba gsum don dam par dmigs par mi 'gyur ro/ /

nāsti bhāvako ityādi (there is neither emanator etc.): Since all things are characterised by Thusness, the three, the emanated, the emanator and the act of emanating, are indistinguishable in absolute terms.

de ltar na ji ltar 'jig rten gyis mthong bar 'gyur zhe na/ spros pa med pa'i rang bzhin las/ /zhes bya ba gsungs te/ spros pa ni sna tshogs kyi mtshan nyid can no/ / de'i gcig dang du ma'i rang bzhin dang bral ba nyid kyi de dag gi skye ba med pa'i mtshan nyid ni de bzhin nyid do/ / rnam pa de lta bur yod do zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ /

Then how are they perceived in the world? To that it is said: niḥprapañcasvabhāvataḥ (as aspects of the undifferentiated nature): The differentiated (prapañca) is characterised by plurality. When devoid of the differentiated nature of one and many, they exist as aspects of the Thusness which is characterised as the non-arising nature of the differentiated.

Vairocanākṣobhyāmoghaś ca Ratnārolic ca Sātvikaḥ || Brahmā Viṣṇuḥ Śivaḥ Sarvo Vibuddhas tattvam ucyate || (12) Brahmā nirvṛtito buddhaḥ viṣanād Viṣṇur ucyate || Śivaḥ sadā sukalyāṇāt Sarvaḥ sarvātmani sthitaḥ || (13) satsukhatvena tattvaṃ ca vibuddho bodhanāt rateḥ || dehe saṃbhavatīty asmād devateti nigadyate || (14)

rnam snang mi bskyod don yod dang / / rin chen dpag med sems dpa' bo/ / tshangs pa khyab 'jug zhi ba dang / / thams cad sangs rgyas de nyi brjod/ / tshangs pa sgrib bral sangs rgyas nyid/ / 'jug phyir khyab 'jug brjod par bya/ / rtag tu dge bas zhi ba nyid/ / thams cad kun gyi bdag nyid gnas/ / dam pa'i bde bas de nyid de/ / bde ba rtogs phyir rnam sangs rgyas/ / gang phyir lus las byung ba nyid/ / lha zhes mngon par brjod par bya/ /

The deities [which are aspects of the undifferentiated] are known as Vairocana, Akṣobhya, Amogha, Ratna, Ārolika, Sāttvika, Brahmā, Viṣṇu, Śiva, Sarva, Vibuddha and Tattva. From being the release, Brahma is the enlightened one (buddhah).Viṣṇu is so called because of entering. Siva is so called because of always being auspicious; Sarva, All, because of abiding in all things; Tattva, the True Principle, because of being true bliss; Vibuddha, the Awakened, because of the awareness of erotic bliss. The deity originates in the body (dehe saṃbhavati) and so it is called devatā.

rnam snang zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ 'od gsal ba de nyid ni rnam par snang mdzad kyi rang bzhin nyid do/ / de nyid ni mi bskyod pa ste/ nyon mongs pa las bskyod par mi nus pa'i phyir ro/ / de nyid ni don yod de/ rnam pa thams cad kyis 'gro ba rnams kyi don mdzad pa'i phyir ro/ / de nyid ni rin chen te/ sangs rgyas kyi chos rin po che thams cad kyi rten du gyur pa'i phyir ro/ / de nyid ni 'khor 'das te/ de dag rnam pa thams cad yongs su spyod pa'i phyir ro/ / de nyid ni sems dpa' ste/ ye shes lnga'i rang bzhin gyi phyir ro/ / tshangs pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ de nyid ni tshangs pa la sogs pa yin par brjod par bya'o/ / ji ltar byas nas she na/ sgrib bral zhes bya ba gsungs te/ nyon mongs pa rnams lhag ma ma lus par bral ba ni thar pa ste/ ye shes kyi gzugs can yin pa'i phyir ro/ / sangs rgyas kyi de kho na nyid ni sangs rgyas te/ de lta bas na de nyid ni sangs rgyas so/ /

vairocana ityādi (Vairocana etc.): Vairocana, the Radiant One, is so called because of being full of the Innate Radiance. Akṣobhya, the Imperturbable One, is so called because of not being perturbed by distresses (kleśāḥ). Amogha, the Beneficial One, is so called because of performing all kinds of beneficial activities for the benefit of the world. Ratneśa, the Lord of Jewels, is so called because of being the receptacle of the treasures of all the Buddhas. Ārolika, the Impartial One, is so called because of not discriminating between anything at all. Sāttvika, the Pure One, is so called because of being full of the five-fold knowledge. brahmā ityādi (Brahmā etc.): They are known as Brahma etc. How so? It is said: nirvṛtitaḥ (from being the release): The release from all kinds of distresses is the liberating knowledge and because Brahma is of that nature, it is a principle of the Enlightened One. Therefore Brahma is an aspect of the enlightened nature.

'jug phyir zhes bya ba la/ de nyid du de'i bdag nyid kyi 'jug pa'o/ / rtag tu dge ba zhes bya ba ni de nyid ni mchog tu dge ba'i de bzhin nyid yin pa'i phyir zhi ba nyid do/ / thams cad kun gyi zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ ji ltar na de thams cad yin zhe na/ gang gi phyir 'dis rgyu ba dang mi rgyu ba thams cad la mngon par khyab pa de'i phyir de thams cad ces bya'o/ / dam pa'i bde ba zhes bya ba ni zag pa med pa'i bde ba'i ngo bo nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de nyid ni de kho na nyid ces bya ba'o/ / rnam sangs rgyas zhes bya ba ni de nyid bla na med pa'i dga' ba'i tshor ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / tshangs pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa mdor bstan pa'i rgyas par bstan pa yin no/ / gal te 'dis dngos po thams cad la khyab par gyur pa zhig yin na/ 'di ji ltar goms par bya bar nus/ / gang du ni goms par bya zhes som nyi za na de'i phyir/ gang phyir lus las byung ba nyid/ /ces bya ba gsungs te/ de ni lus nyid las byung ba'i phyir de lus nyid la goms par bya ba yin no/ / de lta bas na/ lha zhes mngon par brjod par bya/ /zhes bya ba ste dgyes pa'i rdo rje dang rdo rje rnal 'byor ma la sogs pa'i lha rnams te/ de dag nyid bde ba chen po'i rang bzhin can kyi gnyis su med pa'i ye shes so/ / de nyid ni lus la gnas pa nyid yin no/ / de nyid ni don dam par na sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das zhes bya'o/ /

viṣaṇād (because of entering): ‘ Viṣṇu’ because of entering (viṣaṇād) into unity with the enlightened nature. sadā sukalyāṇāt (because of being always auspicious): ‘Śiva’ because of being full of the most auspicious. sarvaḥ (All): How is it ‘All’? Because of pervading all things, satsukhatvena (because of being the true bliss): ‘True Principle’ because it is of the nature of pure bliss. vibuddhaḥ (the Awakened): ‘Awakened’ because of the experience of bliss which is the supreme delight. So far, what was said regarding Brahma and the others has been explained. If this enlightened nature pervades all natures, then what method must be applied and where must it be applied? In answer to such a question it is said: dehe saṃbhavatīti ityādi (since... originates in the body etc.): Since the deity arises in the body (deha), the deity practice must be performed in the body. For this reason it is called deity (devatā). The deities are Hevajra and the Vajrayoginīs. The non-dual knowledge arising from the Great Bliss resides in the body. In supreme truth that non-dual knowledge is the Enlightened One (buddha), Bhagavān.
ji ltar na bcom ldan 'das zhes brjod par bya zhe na/ bcom pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /
Why is Bhagavān so called? It is said:
bhago 'syāstīti buddhasya Bhagavān iti kathyate || bhagāni ṣaḍvidhāny āhur aiśvaryādiguṇākhilāḥ || athavā kleśādimārāṇāṃ bhañjanād Bhagavān iti || (15)

sangs rgyas 'di la b+ha ga mnga'/ / bcom ldan 'das zhes brjod par bya/ / b+ha ga rnam pa drug tu brjod/ / dbang phyug la sogs yon tan kun/ / yang na nyon mongs la sogs bdud/ / bcom phyir bcom ldan 'das zhes brjod/ /

The Enlightened One who has the auspicious qualities (bhagāni) is known as Bhagavān. The auspicious qualities are said to be six, lordliness and the other qualities. In another sense Bhagavān is so called because he destroys (bhañjanāt) Kleśa and the other Māras.
Jananī bhaṇyate prajñā janayati yasmāj jagat || Bhaginīti tathā prajñā vibhāgaṃ darśayed yathā || (16)
gang phyir skye 'gro skyed pa yis/ / shes rab ma zhes brjod par bya/ / gang phyir skal ba ston pa yis/ / shes rab sring mo zhes bya nyid/ /
Wisdom is called Mother because she gives birth to the universe. Wisdom is called Sister because she reveals the diverse distinctions.

de ni skyed byed ces bya ba la sogs pa'i sgras bla na med pa'i shes rab brjod par bya ba yin pas phyi dang nang gi bdag nyid can las khyad par du bstan par bya ba'i phyir/ ma zhes brjod ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ bde ba chen po'i rnam pa sna tshogs pa 'di dag skyed par byed pas ma zhes brjod do/ / kun rdzob dang don dam pa'i bden pa dag rnam par 'byed par byed pa'i phyir sring mo'o/ /

It is the Supreme Wisdom which is referred to by the terms ‘Mother’ and so on. They neither specify an external nor an internal distinction. Now instruction is given on this: jananī (Mother): She is known as Mother because she gives birth (janayati) to the universe by means of Great Bliss. bhaginī (Sister): She is Sister because she indicates the distinction (vibhagaṃ) between the relative and the absolute.

Rajakīti Duhitā ca Nartakī ca prakathyate || rañjanāt sarvasattvānāṃ Rajakīti tathā smṛtā || (17) guṇasya duhanāt prajñā Duhitā ca nigadyate || Nartakī bhaṇyate prajñā cañcalatvān mahākṛpa || asparśā Bhagavatī yasmāt tasmād Ḍombī prakathyate || (18)

btso blag ma dang bu mo dang / / gar mkhan mar yang brjod par bya/ / sems can thams cad 'tshod pa'i phyir/ / btso blag ma zhes de bzhin brjod/ / yon tan 'jo phyir shes rab ni/ / bu mo zhes ni brjod par bya/ / snying rje chen po g.yo ba'i phyir/ / shes rab gar mar brjod par bya/ / gang phyir bcom ldan mi reg pa/ / de phyir g.yung mor brjod par bya/ /

Wisdom is famed as the Washerwoman, the Daughter and the Dancer. She is called Washerwoman because she delights all beings. Since this Wisdom gives good qualities she is known as Daughter. She is known as Dancer, O Being of great mercy, because she is very fickle. Since the Goddess is untouchable she is known as the Outcaste Woman.

btso blag ma zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ bla na med pa'i bde bas sems can thams cad la chags par 'gyur ba'i phyir btso blag ma'o/ / bla na med pa'i sangs rgyas kyi yon tan rnams kyis yongs su 'gengs par byed pa'i phyir bu mo'o/ / las dang po'i sems can rnams kyis brtan par bya bar mi nus pa'i phyir gar ma'o/ / dbang po rnams kyi yul ma yin pa'i phyir g.yung mo zhes bya ba'i sgras brjod par bya'o/ /

rajakī (Washerwoman): She is ‘Washerwoman’because she delights [all beings] with the Supreme Bliss. duhitā (Daughter): She is known as ‘Daughter’ because she is full of the Supreme Enlightened qualities. naitakī (Dancer): She is known as ‘Dancer’ because the novices are unable to stabilize her. ḍombī (Outcaste Woman): She is known as ‘Outcaste Woman’ because she is outside the realm of the experience of the senses.

gal te thams cad rdzogs pa'i rim pa'i nang du 'dus par 'gyur na/ bzlas pa dang bsam gtan dang phyag rgya dkyil 'khor la sogs pa gang dag gsungs pa de dag ci thams cad du med pa zhig yin nam/ 'on te yod pa zhig yin zhe na/ des 'dul ba'i las dang po pa rnams la de yod pa nyid du bstan pas de dag yongs su gzung bar bya ba yin no/ / de nyid kyi phyir spros pa med pa'i rang bzhin las/ sngags dang lha ni yang dag gnas/ /zhes gsungs pa yin no/ /

If everything is encompassed within the stabilised meditative state of the Process of Perfection, then what regarding the instruction on mantra recitation, concentration, mudrās and maṇḍalas! Do they under all conditions exist or not? For those novices who are being disciplined, as a blessing of Bhagavān, they exist as instructions upon the basic principles Thus it is said: “Mantra and deity exist as aspects of the undifferentiated nature.”
gal te de ltar na rdzogs pa'i rim pa'i phyogs la bzlas pa dang / bsam gtan la sogs pa rnams ji ltar bya ba yin zhe na/ de'i phyir/
Nevertheless, from the view-point of the undifferentiated process how are mantra recitation, concentration and so on to be performed? That is explained by:

jalpanaṃ japam ākhyātam ālikālyoḥ prajalpanāt || maṇḍalaṃ pādalekhaḥ syān malanād maṇḍalam ucyate || (19) karasphoṭo bhaven mudrā • aṅgulyāmoṭanaṃ tathā || tad dhyeyaṃ cintitaṃ yac ca dhyeyaṃ yasmād vicintanaṃ || (20)

A li kA li rab brtags pas/ / brjod pa bzlas par yang dag bshad/ / rkang pa'i rjes ni dkyil 'khor nyid/ / nyid phyir dkyil 'khor brjod par bya/ / lag pa sgyur ba phyag rgya yin/ / sor mo nyed pa'ang de bzhin no/ / gang phyir rnam sems bsam gtan ni/ / gang bsams de ni bsam gtan no/ /

Speech is mantra recitation because it is the uttering of the vowels, Āli and the consonants, Kāli. Maṇḍala is the impression of the feet, and it is so called because it bears. Mudrā is the hand gesture and the snapping of the fingers. Concentrate on that which is thought because concentration is thought.

brjod pa bzlas par yang dag bshad/ /ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ brjod pa ni mngon par rtogs pa dang rnam par gzung bar bya'o/ / gang gi zhe na/ A li zhes bya ba ste/ g.yas pa dang g.yon pa'i sna'i sbubs kyi rlung du rtogs pa la nges par rtogs pa'o/ / de yang bla ma'i man ngag las nges par gzung bar bya'o/ / bzlas pa ni de nyid las rdo rje bzlas pa zhes bya ba'i sgras brjod par bya'o/ / dkyil 'khor yin zhes bya ba la sogs pa la dkyil ni snying po ste/ bde ba chen po'i ye shes so/ / de len par byed pa ni 'khor te dkyil 'khor zhes bya'o/ / de ci zhig ce na/ rkang pa'i rjes zhes bya ba gsungs te/ rkang pa'i mthe bong dag dam du bskums pa'o/ / nyed phyir dkyil 'khor brjod par bya/ /zhes bya ba ni nyed cing 'dzin pa zhes bya ba'i skad kyi dbyings kyis bde ba chen po 'dzin par byed pa la dkyil 'khor zhes bya'o/ / man ngag 'di ni bde ba chen po'i rnam par 'dzin par byed pa'i thabs yin no/ /

jalpanaṃ (Speech): Means the observation and the regulation. The observation and the regulation of what! ālikālyoḥ (of the vowels, Āli and the consonants, Kāli): The observation of Ali and Kali, that is, the air moving in and out through the left and right nāḍī and the regulation, according to the guru’s instructions, of Ali and Kali, is known as mantra-recitation. Such a mantra-recitation is known as the Adamantine Mantra Recitation (vajrajapa). maṇḍalam ityādi (Maṇḍala etc.): [The composite word maṇḍala is composed of] maṇḍaṃ which means essence, that is, the Great Blissful Knowledge, and lāti which means to possess. pādalekhaḥ (impression of the feet): Maṇḍala is the impression of the feet, that is, the firm contraction of the toes. malanād maṇḍalam ucyate (maṇḍala is so called because it bears): The root verb mal means to bear, to hold. Thus, Maṇḍala is so called because it bears Great Bliss. This is the instruction regarding the means to accomplish the Great Bliss.

lag pa bsgyur ba zhes bya ba ni mthe bo gnyis kyis ming med gnyis bsdams pa ni lag pa bsgyur ba'o/ /de nyid ni phyag rgyar 'gyur ba'o/ / sor mo nyed pa de bzhin no/ /zhes bya ba ni 'dir sor mo'i sgra ni ling+ga dang lce'o/ /de dag gis nyed pa ni gyen du sbyor ba'o/ / gang bsams pa de ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ de ni zhes bya ba ni de kho na nyid kyi le'u gang du bsams pa ma lus pa skye ba med pa'i mtshan nyid can bsgom par bya ba ste/ de lta bas na gang gi phyir mchog tu snying po 'gyur ba de rnam par bsam par bya'o/ /'od gsal ba'i mtshan nyid de nyid rnam par bsam par bya ba yin pas de'i phyir de nyid bsam par bya ba'o/ /

karasphoṭaḥ (hand gesture): It is the pressing of the ring finger with the thumb. That is Mudrā, the hand gesture. aṅgulyāmoṭanaṃ tathā (and the snapping of the fingers): Here ‘fingers’ refers to the tongue and male organ. ‘Snapping’ refers to the directing of these two upwards. tad dhyeyam ityādi (concentrate on that): Here ‘that’ refers to that which is thought of. According to this chapter on the True Principle all thoughts are characterised as non-arising. So concentrate upon that, for that which is thought of has the nature of the supreme essence. Therefore concentrate upon that, the thought which is characterised by the Innate Radiance.
pitari prāptaṃ yat saukhyaṃ tat sukhaṃ bhujyate svayaṃ || maraṇaṃ yena sukhena tat sukhaṃ dhyānam ucyate || (21)
ji ltar pha las bde thob pa/ / de yi bde ba Rang gis bza'/ / bde ba gang gis 'chi ba 'di/ / de yi bde ba bsam gtan brjod/ /
The bliss obtained in the Father is enjoyed by one’s own self. The bliss by which death is attained, that bliss is concentration.

pha ni rdo rje 'chang ste gsum pa'i don gyi bdun pa yin te/ rdo rje 'chang gis brnyes pa'i bde ba gang yin pa'i bde ba bskyed par bya'o/ / rang gis zhes bya ba ni phyi rol gyi phyag rgya la ltos pa med pa nyid du nye bar spyod par byed pa'o/ / de ni bsam gtan no zhes bya ba la sogs pas 'od gsal gyi bsam gtan gsungs pa der ni bsam gtan pa dang bsam gtan bya ba dang bsam gtan zhes bya ba gsum char yang yod pa ma yin na de ji ltar bsgom par bya zhe na/

pitari (in the Father): The Father is Vajradhara. Here, the locative ‘in’ the Father implies the instrumental ‘by’ the Father. That bliss which is attained by Vajradhara is enjoyed is the intent. svayam (by one’s own self): Firstly this means, one enjoys together with the external consort. Further, due to the greatness of this practice, one enjoys by one’s own self without depending on an external consort. The Concentration of the Innate Radiance has been expressed by “concentrate on that which is thought etc.” [1.5.20]. In this context, how can one concentrate since the three, the one who concentrates, the act of concentration and object of concentration, are all non-existent?

bde ba gang gis 'chi ba 'dir/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ 'chi ba ni thar pa'o/ / de nyid du sems dang sems las byung ba dang ma rig pa'i mtshan nyid rnams nub par gyur pa de ni 'chi ba zhes bya'o/ / bde ba gang gis zhes bya ba ni nyon mongs pa dang nye ba'i nyon mongs pa ma lus pa zad pa'i mtshan nyid can bde ba chen po zhes bya ba'o/ /

[To this it is said:] maraṇam ityādi (death etc.): Death is liberation since liberation is an end to the ignorance which characterises the mind and it’s thoughts. In this manner liberation is of the nature of death. yena sukhena (the bliss by which): Meaning, by the Great Bliss which is characterised as the destruction of all afflictions and distresses.
tattvapaṭalaḥ pañcamaḥ ||
de kho na nyid kyi le'u ste lnga pa'o// //
Thus the Fifth, the chapter regarding the True Principle.
dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i dka' 'grel rnal 'byor rin po che'i phreng ba las lnga pa de kho na nyid kyi le'u'i 'grel pa'o// //
Thus ends the fifth, the chapter on the True Principle, of the Hevajra Pañjikā known as Yogaratnamālā of Kṛṣṇācāryapāda.

d.crumb: spyod pa

f.d: spyod pa

d.crumb: CHAPTER 6. Application of the Vow

f.d: CHAPTER 6. Application of the Vow
da ni rnal 'byor pa rtag tu bsgom pa la dga' ba yin du zin kyang spyod pa med par myur du byang chub thob par mi 'gyur ro zhes bstan pa'i phyir/

Even for those yogis who are constantly devoted to the practice of emanation there is no quicker means to enlightenment than by the Application of the Vow (Caryā). Therefore the Application of the Vow is now revealed.
ataḥ paraṃ pravakṣyāmi caryāṃ pāraṃgatāṃ varāṃ || gamyate yena siddhāntaṃ Hevajre siddhihetunā || (1)
de nas gzhan yang rab bshad bya/ / spyod pa pha rol phyin mchog nyid/ / gang gis dngos grub mthar 'gro ba/ / kye yi rdo rjes dngos grub rgyus/ /
Now I shall explain the supreme and excellent Application of the Vow (Caryā) by means of which definitive clarity is attained for the accomplishment in the Hevajra tradition.

de nas gzhan yang rab bshad bya/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ bla ma sangs rgyas kyi bka' dang / dka' thub kyi sdug bsngal byed pa ni spyod pa ste bshad par bya ba'o/ / pha rol song zhes bya ba ni shin tu 'jig rten las 'das pa'o/ / mchog ni gtso bor gyur pa ste/ gang gis rtogs par 'gyur zhing rab tu go bar 'gyur ba'o/ / gang gis zhes bya ba ni gang gis so/ / ci zhig rab tu go bar 'gyur zhe na/ grub mtha' nges par zhes bya ba'o/ / dngos grub rgyu zhes bya ba ni dngos grub kyi don du tshe 'di nyid la dngos grub 'byung ngam mi 'byung ba mtshan ma thob pa la nges par 'gyur ba'o/ /

caryā (the Application of the Vow): Caryā is the strict application of vows according to the instructions of the gurus and Buddhas. Bhagavān said that he will explain that Caryā. pāraṃgatāṃ (supreme): Means beyond all things. varāṃ (excellent): Means superior. gamyate (is attained): Means is ascertained. yena (by means of which): Means that which ascertains. siddhāntaṃ (definitive clarity): [Here] means clarity which leaves no room for doubts. siddhihetunā (for the accomplishment): Whether there is accomplishment or not in this life, definitive clarity for the accomplishment is gained through the foundation of Caryā.

bhāvakena vidhartavyaṃ karṇayor divyakuṇḍalaṃ || śirasi cakrī dhartavyā hastayo rucakadvayaṃ || (2) kaṭyāṃ vā mekhalaṃ caiva pādayor nūpuran tathā || bāhumūle ca keyūraṃ grīvāyām asthimālikā || (3) paridhānaṃ vyāghracarma bhakṣaṇaṃ daśārdhāmṛtaṃ ||

sgom pa po yis rnam 'dzin pa/ / rna ba dag la rna cha bzas/ / spyi bor 'khor lo rnam par 'dzin/ / lag pa dag la lag gdub gnyis/ / rked pa la yang ska rags nyid/ / rkang par de bzhin rkang gdub bo/ / lag pa'i rtsa bar dpung rgyan nyid/ / mgrin par rus pa'i phreng ba ste/ / bgo ba stag gi pags pa nyid/ / bza' ba mi 'chi'i bcu phyed de/ /

The practitioner should wear divine ear-rings, a circlet around the head, upon each wrist a bracelet, a girdle around his waist, anklets around the ankles, arm ornaments around the upper arms and a garland of bones around the neck. His dress must be of tiger skin and his food the Five Nectars.
sgom pa po zhes bya ba ni rnal 'byor pa spyod pa po ste/ lha rdzas kyi rus pa'i rang bzhin nyid do/ / mi 'chi bcu phyed ni bdud rtsi lnga'o/ /
bhāvaka (the practitioner): Refers to the yogī who follows the strict Application of the Vow. divyaṃ (divine): Divine because the ear-rings are made of bone. daśārdhāmṛtaṃ: Means the Five Nectars.
herukayogasya puṃso vihāraḥ pañcavarṇeṣu || (4) pañcavarṇasamāyuktam ekavarṇan tu kalpitaṃ || anekenaikavarṇena yasmād bhedo na lakṣyate || (5)
he ru ka sbyor skyes bu ste/ / kha dog lnga la rnam par gnas/ / rigs lnga dag dang mnyam ldan pa/ / rigs ni gcig tu rnam par brtag / kha dog du ma nyid kyis ni/ / gang phyir dbye ba mtshon mi bya/ /
The one who performs the Heruka yoga interacts with all the five castes. He conceives of the five castes unified as one caste because he does not distinguish between one or many castes.

he ru ka sbyor zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ gnas zhes bya ba ni slong mo pa la sogs pa rgyu ba'o/ / rigs lnga ni shin tu dman par 'gyur ba'am/ rigs lnga zhes bya ba 'di bden pa la mngon par zhen pa'i byis pas rnam par brtags pa ste/ sdig pa la sogs pa'i skyon dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i phyir zhes byas nas so/ / rang gi ngo bos ni rigs gcig kho na yin te/ ji ltar byas nas she na/ rigs dag du ma nyid kyis ni/ / gang phyir dbye ba mtshon mi bya/ /zhes bya ba gsungs te/ skye ba tha dad pa'i srog chags rnams kyi rnam pa tha dad pa nyid yin no/ / 'di lta ste glang po rta dang phag dag gi rigs gcig pa rnams kyi rnam pa ni gcig pa nyid yin te/ ji ltar ba lang dag dang glang po ni glang po dag dang ngo / / de dag kyang kha dog tha dad kyang rigs tha dad du mi 'gyur te/ de ltar na 'jig rten gyi tha snyad du yang rigs gcig pa nyid du grub na/ rnal 'byor gyi kun rdzob tu lta smos kyang ci dgos te/ thog pa med pa dang ldan pa'i 'khor bar thams cad kyang rigs thams cad yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

vihāraḥ (interacts): Refers to the interacting with people, receiving alms and so on. pañcavarṇaḥ (five castes): Refers particularly to those of the lower castes. Or else ‘five castes’ refers to the aggregate of the five castes. In truth all are undifferentiated. In spite of the belief in the differentiated external world which is caused by the association with dullness and the other defilements, in truth, there is only one caste. How this is so is said by: “ ... because he does not distinguish between one or many castes.” Different species of living beings are of different shapes, that is, like elephants, horses and pigs etc. Members of the same species are of similar shape, like cows among cows and elephants among elephants. So they are not of different species, [that is] not different from one another because of the similarity in their shape. Like this, even by worldly conventions the oneness of castes is concluded. Then what to say regarding the convention among the yogis where within the infinite phenomenal universe all things are of the same nature!
spyod pa dang rjes su mthun pa'i gnas bstan pa'i phyir/
Now the locations appropriate for the Application of the Vow are mentioned:
ekavṛkṣe śmaśāne vā bhāvanā kathyate śubhā || mātṛgṛhe tathā ramye 'thavā vijane prāntare || (6)
shing gcig dang ni dur khrod dang / / ma mo'i khyim dang mtshan mo dang / / yang na dben pa'am bas mtha' ru/ / bsgom pa bzang por brjod par bya/ /
It is said to be auspicious to practise emanation in a deserted place [at the foot of] a ‘single tree’, in a crematory or else in the beautiful abode of the Mothers.

shing gcig gam zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ gang gi grib ma shing gzhan la mi 'phog cing gang gzhan gyi grib mas kyang mi 'phog pa de ni shing gcig go/ / gtsor rnal 'byor rgyun mi gcod pa 'di ni spyod pa ste/ shing gcig la sogs pa dben par rigs so zhes bya bar dgongs so/ /

ekavṛkṣa (a ‘single tree’): A tree whose shadow never falls on another tree and on which another tree’s shadow does not fall is called ‘single tree’. vijane (deserted place): The locations described as a deserted place, a ‘single tree’ and so on are appropriate for the uninterrupted practice of yoga which characterises this Application of the Vow.
'di ni ma brtags pa dang yid gnyis kyis bya ba ni ma yin no zhes bya ba bslab pa'i phyir/
In order to indicate that the Application of the Vow should not be performed rashly without the proper preparation it is said:
kiñcid uṣme tu saṃprāpte caryāṃ kartuṃ yadīṣyate || siddhiṃ gantuṃ yadīcchāsti caryayā tv anayā caret || (7)
cung zad drod ni thob pa na/ / gal te spyod pa byed 'dod pas/ / gal te 'grub 'gyur 'dod yod na/ / 'dis ni spyod pa spyad pa nyid/ /
After having gained some ‘heat’ if the yogī wishes to continue the Application of the Vow and desires accomplishment he should then continue with the following Application of the Vow.

cung zad drod ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ drod ni ting nge 'dzin dang sngags las byung ba'i mthu ste/ de thob par gyur nas bya'o zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ / sbrul dang stag dang mi dang mi ma yin pa la sogs pas ji ltar zil gyis mi non cing bsrung bar 'gyur la/ de dag gis mi 'jigs pa dang bkres pa dang skom pa la sogs pas kyang mi gnod pa ste/ gal te tshe 'di nyid la phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub thob par 'dod par gyur pa de'i tshe spyod pa 'di spyad par bya'o zhes bya bar dgongs so/ /

uṣma (‘heat’): Here heat refers to the energy produced from a stabilised meditative state and the practice of mantra. Gaining this heat perform the Application of the Vow is the meaning. [By following the Application of the Vow] he will neither be troubled by nor be afraid of snakes, wild animals, men and other beings and he will not be afflicted by hunger and thirst. anaya caret (apply this): If one has the desire to gain the Mahāmudrā Accomplishment in this lifetime, then apply the following Application of the Vow is the intent.

cāruvaktrāṃ viśālākṣīṃ rūpayauvanamaṇḍitāṃ || nīlotpalaśyāmāṅgīṃ ca svābhiṣiktāṃ kṛpāvatīṃ || vajrakanyām imāṃ gṛhya caryāṃ kartuṃ vibudhyate || (8) vajrakulābhāvāt sveṣṭadevakulena krīyate || athavānyakulodbhavā/ bodhibījanikṣepeṇa saṃskṛtām {imāṃ} gṛh{ṇīyāt} || (9)

shin tu bzhin bzangs mig yangs ma/ / rang gis dbang bskur snying rje can/ / rdo rje'i bu mo 'di khyer nas/ / spyod pa bya bar rtogs par bya/ / rdo rje rigs kyi dngos med na/ / rang 'dod lha yi rigs kyis bya/ / yang na gzhan gyi rigs byung ba/ / byang chub sa bon gdab pa dang / / sbyang ba yis ni gzung bar bya/ /

Take a Vajra girl who has a beautiful face, wide eyes, endowed with grace and youth, is of the colour of the blue lotus and is herself consecrated and merciful. Instruct her regarding the method for performing this Application of the Vow. If a virgin of the Vajra family is not available, then prepare to practise with a virgin belonging to the family of one’s own chosen deity. If not, practise with a virgin born of another family. Take such a virgin who has been refined by the dropping of the Seed of Enlightenment (bodhibīja).

rdo rje bu mo 'di khyer nas/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ rdo rje rigs kyi bu mo kho na'o/ / rtogs par bya ba ni rigs pa nyid yin pas te/ de ni rigs rnams kyi mchog nyid yin pa'i phyir dang / gzhan gyis mi 'phrogs pa nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ / byang chub sa bon nyams myong ba/ /zhes bya ba ni dbang bskur ba la sogs pas de 'dus byas pa'o/ /

vajrakanyāṃ (Vajra girl): Means a virgin girl of the Vajra family. vibudhyate (instruct): Means unite with her because of the eminence of her family and because she is not misguided by others. bodhibījanikṣepeṇa (by the dropping of the Seed of Enlightenment): Means refined by consecration and so on.
yadi [gītaṃ] gīyata ānandāt tarhi vajrānvitaṃ paraṃ || yady ānande samutpanne nṛtyate mokṣahetunā || tarhi vajrapade nāṭyaṃ kuryād yogī samāhitaḥ || (10)
gal te dga' bas glu blang ste/ / de tshe rdo rje mchog ldan no/ / gal te dga' ba skyes pa na/ / thar pa'i rgyur ni gar bya ste/ / de tshe rdo rje rkang pas gar/ / yo gis mnyam par bzhag pas byed/ /

If songs are sung from joy then let the supreme songs regarding the Vajra be sung. When joy arises, if the yogī dances for the sake of liberation, then let him dance the Vajra postures with full attention.

rdo rje mchog dang ldan pa ni bde ba chen po'i ye shes te de brjod pa'o/ / rdo rje rkang pas zhes bya ba la/ rdo rje ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje'o/ / de'i rkang pa ni go 'phang ste/ g.yas brkyang ba dang / g.yon brkyang ba dang / zlum po dang / sa ga dang / skyil krung phyed pa la sogs pa'o/ /

vajrānvitāṃ (regarding the Vajra): Refers to those songs which sing of the knowledge of the Great Bliss of the Vajra. vajrapada (the Vajra postures): Vajra here refers to Hevajra. Dance the postures of Hevajra, like those of grounded feet, raised feet, equipoised feet and half lying.

Akṣobhyaś cakrīrupeṇāmitābhaḥ kuṇḍalātmakaḥ || Ratneśaḥ kaṇṭhamālāyāṃ haste Vairocanaḥ smṛtaḥ || (11) mekhalāyāṃ sthito 'moghaḥ prajñā khaṭvāṅgarūpiṇī || ḍamarūpāyarūpeṇa yogī dveṣaviśuddhitaḥ || (12)

'khor lo'i gzugs kyis mi bskyod pa/ / rna cha'i bdag nyid 'od dpag med/ / mgul gyi phreng ba rin chen bdag / lag gdub rnam par snang mdzad brjod/ / ska rags la ni don yod gnas/ / kha T+wA~M ga gzugs shes rab ste/ / thabs kyi gzugs kyis cang te'u nyid/ / zhe sdang rnam dag rnal 'byor pa/ /

Akṣobhya is symbolised by the circlet, Amitābha by the ear-rings, Ratneśa by the necklace, Vairocana by the hand ornaments, Amogha by the girdle, Wisdom by the Khaṭvāṅga and Means by the hand-drum. The yogī symbolises the Wrathful One.
zhe sdang rnam dag ces bya ba ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i rnam par dag pa'o/ /
dveṣaviśuddhiḥ (symbolises the Wrathful One): Means the yogī symbolises Hevajra.
mantra[vi]śuddhyā sthitā gītā nartanā bhāvanā smṛtā || tasmād gītañ ca nāṭyañ ca kuryād yogī sadā sadā || (13)
glu ni rnam dag sdugs su gnas/ / gar ni bsgom pa byas pa nyid/ / de yi phyir na glu dang gar/ / yo gis rtag tu rtag tu byed/ /
The Vajra songs are considered as signifying mantra and the dance the emanation. So the yogī must always sing and dance.
rtag tu zhes bya ba ni rtag par rgyun du'o/ /
sadā sadā (always): Means at all times.
bhakṣitavyan tu bhaiṣajyaṃ pātavyaṃ vāri nityatām || jarāmṛtyur na bādheta rakṣābhūtaḥ sadā bhavet || (14)
sman ni rnam par bza' ba ste/ / chu ni rtag par btung ba nyid/ / rga shis zil gyis mi non cing / / rtag tu bsrung bar 'gyur ba yin/ /
Daily the yogī should eat Bhaiṣajyam and drink Vāri. Then he will not be affected by aging and death and will always be protected from malevolent spirits.

sman zhes bya ba ni bzhi mnyam pa'o/ / chu ni mi bskyod pa'o/ / rtag par zhes bya ba ni rtag pa nyid du'o/ / rgas pa ni gnyer ma dang skra dkar 'byung ba'o/ / bsrung bar gyur pa zhes bya ba ni 'byung po dang sha za la sogs pas gzung bar mi nus pa'o/ /

bhaiṣajyaṃ: Is the code word for catuḥsamaṃ. varī: Is the code word for Akṣobhya (semen). nityatāṃ (daily): Means everyday. rakṣābhūtaḥ (protected from malevolent spirits): Means invisible to hungry ghosts etc.
cauryakeśakṛtāṃ mukuṭīṃ tatra HŪṂ-bhavo yojayet || pañcabuddhakapālāni dhartavyaṃ yogacaryayā || (15)
rkun ma'i skra las cod pan byas/ / de la hU~M byung sbyar bar bya/ / sangs rgyas lnga yi thod pa rnams/ / rnal 'byor spyod pas rnam par 'dzin/ /

The yogī must coil his hair into a crown like knot on the top of his head and there unite with the one who manifests from hūṃ. For the yoga of this Application of the Vow, he must adorn [his head] with five skulls representing the Five Buddhas.

rkun ma'i skra zhes bya ba ni dpyangs pa'i skra'o/ / hU~M byung zhes bya ba ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i gzugs so/ / thod pa ni mi bskyod pa la sogs pa'i sangs rgyas lnga'i rang bzhin no/ / rnal 'byor ni thabs dang shes rab kyi rnal 'byor gyi snyoms par 'jug pa'o/ /

cauryakeśaḥ (coiled hair): Means hair coiled and knotted on top of the head. hūṃbhavaḥ (the one who manifests from hūṃ): Refers to the body of Hevajra. kapālāni (skulls): The skulls represent Akṣobhya and the other Buddhas. yogaḥ (yoga): Refers to the method for uniting Wisdom and Means.
pañcāṅgulakapālakhaṇḍaṃ [kṛtvā] mukuṭyāṃ dhriyate sadā || kacaḍorī dvivetā ca prajñopāyasvabhavātaḥ || bhasmakeśapavitrañ ca yogī vibharti caryayā || (16)

thod pa sor lnga pa yi tshad/ / byas pas cod pan 'dzin par byed/ / thabs dang shes rab rang bzhin las/ / skra yi ska rags nyis skor nyid/ / thal ba skra yi mchod phyir thogs/ / rnal 'byor pa yi spyod pas 'dzin/ /

He should attach carved pieces of skull five finger-widths long on the crown. The rope used to tie the hair has two strands which symbolise Wisdom and Means. In order to perform the Application of the Vow he smears ashes and wears a sacred thread made of hair.

de'i rol pa ni phyi dang nang gi bdag nyid can gyi mchod pa'o/ / de'i phyir thod pa'i dum bu sor lnga pa 'dzin par mdzad do zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ / skra'i ske rags ni skra'i tha gu'o/ / thal ba ni thal bas bskus pa'o/ / skra'i mchod phyir thogs zhes bya ba ni skra'i mchod phyir thogs pa nyid do/ /

pañcāṅgulakapālakhaṇḍaṃ ... dhriyate (he should attach carved pieces of skull five finger-widths long): This is said in order to display the internal and external play of worship. kacaḍorī (rope used to tie the hair): Refers to the thread for tying the hair. bhasmaṃ (ashes): Refers to the smearing of ashes on the body. keśapavitraṃ (sacred thread made of hair): Refers to the sacred thread made of hair worn at sacrifices.
jāpo ḍamarukaśabdaḥ prajñākhaṭvāṅgo bhāvanā || jāpyaṃ bhāvyaṃ bhaved etad vajrakapālacaryayā || (17)
cang te'u sgra ni bzlas pa ste/ / kha T+wA~M ga sgom shes rab nyid/ / rdo rje thod pa'i sbyor ba yis/ / 'di dag bzlas dang sgom pa yin/ /

The recitation of mantra is the sound of the hand-drum and the practice of emanation is [the holding of] the Khaṭvāṅga of Wisdom. This is the nature of that which is recited and that which is emanated in this Vajra-Kapāla Application of the Vow.
lobhaṃ mohaṃ bhayaṃ krodhaṃ vrīḍākāryañ ca varjayet || nidrām ātmānam utsṛjya caryāṃ kuryān na saṃśayaḥ || (18)
brkam dang rmongs dang 'jigs dang khro/ / ngo tsha'i 'bras bu rnam par spang / / bdag nyid kyis ni gnyid spangs nas/ / the tshom med par spyod pa bya/ /
He should avoid avarice, delusion, fear, anger and shame. He should abandon sleep and notions of a self and perform this Application of the Vow without having any doubts.

ngo tsha ba ni ngo tsha ba nyid do/ / gnyid ni rnal 'byor gyi bar chad chen po'o/ / lus dang srog la chags pa ni de bzhin nyid du spang bar bya ba'o/ / the tshom med par zhes bya ba ni the tshom dang bral bar gyur pas zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

vrīḍā (shame): Means shyness. nidrā (sleep): Sleep is a great obstacle to yoga. Although necessary for the existence of the body, abandon even that. na saṃśayaḥ (without doubts): Means being free from all doubts.

śarīraṃ dānaṃ datvā ca paścāc caryāṃ samārabhet || bhāgābhāgavicāreṇa tasmād dānaṃ na dīyate || (19) bhakṣyaṃ bhojyaṃ tathā pānaṃ yathāprāptaṃ tu bhakṣayet || grahaṇaṃ nātra kartavyaṃ iṣṭāniṣṭavikalpataḥ || (20) bhakṣyābhakṣyavicāran tu peyāpeyaṃ tathaiva ca || gamyāgamyan tathā mantrī vikalpan naiva kārayet || (21)

lus kyi sbyin pa byin nas ni/ / phyi nas spyod pa yang dag spyad/ / skal dang skal min rnam dpyad pas/ / de phyir sbyin pa sbyin mi bya/ / bza' bca' de bzhin btung ba nyid/ / ji ltar rnyed pa rab tu bza'/ / yid 'ong mi 'ong rnam rtog phyir/ / zhen pa tsam du mi bya'o/ / bza' dang bza' min spyod pa dang / / de bzhin btung dang btung min nyid/ / bgrod dang bgrod min sngags pa yis/ / rnam rtog nyid du mi bya'o/ /

After having given the body as an offering the practitioner should begin the Application of the Vow. He should not offer gifts with thoughts of worthiness or unworthiness. He must eat and drink whatever he obtains and he should not hold any notions regarding likes and dislikes. The practitioner should not have thoughts regarding what is edible and inedible; similarly, he should not differentiate between what can or cannot be drunk and what should or should not be done.

lus dag ces bya ba la sogs pa la/ dang por de sangs rgyas thams cad dang / sems can thams cad la dbul zhing sbyin pa'o/ / skal dang skal min zhes bya ba ni mkho 'am mi mkho dpyod pa rnam par spangs nas ltos pa med par sbyin pa'o/ /

śarīram ityādi (body etc.): At the outset, give the body as an offering to the Buddhas for the sake of living beings, that is, with the appropriate wish offer the body. bhāgābhāgaṃ (worthiness or unworthiness): Means giving without any reservations having neither the thought of worthiness nor of unworthiness.
siddhilabdho 'pi yaḥ śiṣyaḥ samyagjñānāvabhāsakaḥ || abhivandayati guruṃ siddho 'vīcyātyājyahetunā || (22)
dngos grub rnyed pa'i slob ma gang / / yang dag ye shes snang ba po/ / mnar med spang ba'i rgyu yi phyir/ / grub pas bla ma mngon phyag 'tshal/ /
Even when a disciple has attained the Accomplishment and is resplendent with complete knowledge, he respectfully greets his perfected guru in order to avoid the Avici hell.
mngon phyag 'tshal zhes bya ba ni phyag bya ba ste/ phyag ma byas na mnar med par ltung ba'o/ / spang ba'i rgyu'i phyir zhes bya ba ni yongs su spang ba'i ched du'o/ /

abhivandayati (he respectfully greets): Means he should respectfully greet [the guru]. If he fails to properly greet [the guru] then he will burn in the Avici hell. tyājyahetunā (in order to avoid): Means in order to ward off going to the Avīci hell.
śikṣādikṣāvinirmukto lajjakāryaṃ tathaiva ca || sarvabhāvasvabhāvena [vi]cared yogī mahākṛpaḥ || (23)
bslab dang dbang las rnam par grol/ / de bzhin ngo tsha'i 'bras bu nyid/ / dngos po kun gyi rang bzhin gyi/ / yo gis rnam dpyad snying rje che/ /
Such a yogī of great mercy, being one with the intrinsic nature of all things wanders the world free from the ties of social conventions, religious injunctions and inhibitions.
dus su za ba ni bslab pa'o/ / skra breg pa la sogs pa ni dbang ngo / / dngos po kun gyi rang bzhin gyis/ /zhes bya ba ni gnas skabs thams cad du kye'i rdo rje'i nga rgyal gyis gnas pa'o/ /

śikṣā (social conventions): Refers to the conventions regarding fixed times for meals etc. dīkṣā (religious injunctions): Refers to observances like the shaving of the head and so on. sarvabhāvasvabhāvena (being one with the intrinsic nature of all things): Means identifying with Hevajra in all states.
homatyāgatapo'tīto mantradhyānavivarjitaḥ || samayasamvaravinirmuktaś caryāṃ kurute suyogavān || (24)
sbyin sreg mchod sbyin dka' thub 'das/ / sngags dang bsam gtan rnam par spangs/ / dam tshig sdom las rnam par grol/ / rnal 'byor ldan pas spyod pa byed/ /

Abandoning fire-sacrifices, going beyond austerities, rid of mantra recitations and the practice of concentrations and freed from the Observance of the Vow and the Observance of the Concealed Essence, the excellent yogī performs the Application of the Vow.

sbyin sreg ces bya ba la sogs pa la/ dgyes pa'i rdo rjer lhag par mos pa nyid kyis 'di la lhag par rnal 'byor brtan par bya ba'i phyir phyi rol gyi sbyin sreg la sogs pa yongs su spang ba'o/ / ci'i phyir zhe na/ gang gi phyir dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i bdag nyid can 'dis gang cung zhig ci za ba de nyid sbyin sreg yin pa'i phyir ro/ / mchod sbyin ni phyag rgya la brten pa'o/ / lus kyi las thams cad ni dka' thub bo/ / cang te'u'i sgra dang kha T+wAM 'dzin pa ni sngags dang bsam gtan no/ / yang na rdo rje glu dang rdo rje gar ni sngags dang bsam gtan no/ / de'i phyir 'dis gang byed pa de ni dam tshig yin la/ gang mi byed pa de ni sdom pa yin no/ /

suyogavān (the excellent yogī): The ‘excellent yoga’ is the yogī’s actualization of Hevajra. This excellent yoga is now clearly defined. In this excellent yoga the whole gamut of external practices such as fire-sacrifices are observed. But in what manner are they observed? For the yogī who identifies with Hevajra, eating is fire-sacrifice, yoga is serving Wisdom and austerities are his physical activities. The sound of the hand-drum is the mantra and the holding of the Khaṭvāṅga is the concentration (dhyāna). Similarly, the Vajra dance is the concentration and the Vajra songs the mantra. Thus, whatever he does is the Observance of the Vow (samaya) and whatever he does not do is the Observance of the Concealed Essence (saṃvara).

rgyud 'dir dman pa dang bar ma dang mchog dang shin tu mchog tu gyur pa'i sems can gyi dbye bas phyag rgya rnam pa bzhi bstan pa yin no/ / de la shin tu mchog tu gyur pa'i sems can gyis ni brgya la dbang bzhi pa bskur ba dang dus mnyam du phyag rgya chen po mngon sum du byed pa yang srid pas logs shig tu spyod pa ma gsungs so/ / de'i phyir dbang po dman pa dang 'bring dang mchog tu gyur pa'i slob ma rnams la spyod pa med par myur du byang chub thob par mi 'gyur ro zhes bstan pa'i phyir spyod pa rnam pa gsum gsungs pa yin te/ spros bcas dang spros med dang shin tu spros pa med pa'o/ / 'di ni spros pa med pa'i spyod pa ste/ dbang po dman pa dang bar ma'i phyir gsungs pa yin no/ / dbang po mchog tu gyur pa rnams la ni le'u bcu bzhi pa las kye'i rdo rje'i rnal 'byor ma zhes bya ba la sogs pas shin tu spros pa med pa'i spyod pa ston par mdzad par 'gyur ro/ / dbang po dman pa rnams kyi spros pa dang bcas pa'i spyod pa yang brtag pa gnyis pa'i le'u bdun pa las mdor bstan pas ston par 'gyur ro/ /

It was previously mentioned that in this tantra there are four kinds of Seals for the four types of practitioners who are distinguished as being of weak, medium, strong and strongest sensibilities. In this context, no Application of the Vow is mentioned for a person of the strongest sensibility, for at the very time of his gaining the Fourth Consecration it is realised through the Mahāmudrā, the Great Seal. Since there is no quicker means to enlightenment than by the Application of the Vow, three different kinds of the Application of the Vow are given to the three types of disciples who are of weak, medium and strong sensibilities. The three are the Differentiated, the Undifferentiated and the Extremely Undifferentiated Application of the Vow. The Undifferentiated Application of the Vow [explained in this chapter] is given for those practitioners of the medium sensibility. For those of strong sensibility, the Extremely Undifferentiated Application of the Vow is explained later in the fourteenth chapter [third chapter of the second part] with such statements as: “Good, good, O Yoginīs etc.” For those of weak sensibility, the Differentiated Application of the Vow is hinted upon in the seventh chapter of the second part [of this tantra].
śakratulyo 'pi yo daityaḥ purato bhavati niścitaṃ || bhayaṃ tatra na kurvīta siṃharūpeṇa paryaṭet || (25)
nges par sngon du lha min gang / / brgya byin ltu bu yin na yang / / de la 'jigs par mi bya ste/ / seng ge'i gzugs kyis rnam par rgyu/ /
Even if a titan equal to Indra comes in front of such a yogī, he is not perturbed, for he wanders like a lion.
karuṇā pīyate nityaṃ sarvasattvārthahetunā || yogapānarato yogī nānyapānena majjanaṃ || (26)
sems can kun gyi don gyi phyir/ / rtag tu snying rjes btung bar bya/ / rnal 'byor btung dga' rnal 'byor ba/ / gzhan gyi btung bas bzi ba med/ /
He always drinks compassion for the benefit of all beings, for the yogī who is devoted to the drink of yoga does not get drunk by drinking anything else.

snying rje btung bar zhes bya ba la sogs pa la dmigs pa dang bcas pa'i bsgom pa ni snying rje ste/ de nyid kyis bde ba chen po'i ro myong bar byed pa ni btung ba'o/ / de ni dus thams cad du btung bar bya ba ste/ 'gro ba'i don bya ba'i ched du'o/ / de nyid kyi phyir rnal 'byor btung bas zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rnal 'byor ni ting nge 'dzin to/ / de nyid ni btung ba ste/ de la dga' ba ni 'dod pa'o/ / de'i phyir gzhan chang la sogs pa'i btung bas spyod pa byed pa'i rnal 'byor pas bzi bar mi bya ba ste/ rmongs pa gtsor gyur pas rnal 'byor gyi gegs chen por 'gyur ba'i phyir zhes de ltar bslab par bya'o/ /

karuṇā (compassion): Compassion is an emanation based upon a foundation. pīyate (drinks): The drinking is the relishing of the flavours of the Great Bliss by means of compassion. nityaṃ (always): Meaning, always, day and night, drink that alone, for the benefit of the world. yogaḥ (yoga): Yoga is a stabilised meditative state and that is the drinking. rataḥ (devoted): Here, being devoted to the union means being enamored. nānyapānena (by drinking anything else): Refers to drinking wine etc. majjanaṃ (drunk): Drinking must be in accordance with the practice of the Application of the Vow. This instruction is given because drinking wine etc., which are primarily characterised by delusion, is a great obstacle to yoga.
caryāpaṭalaḥ ṣaṣṭaḥ ||
spyod pa'i le'u ste drug pa'o// //
Thus the Sixth, the chapter regarding the Application of the Vow.
dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i dka' 'grel rnal 'byor rin po che'i phreng ba las drug pa spyod pa'i le'u'i 'grel pa'o// //
Thus ends the sixth, the chapter regarding the Application of the Vow, of the Hevajra Pañjikā known as the Yogaratnamālā.

d.crumb: CHAPTER 7. Secret Sign Language

f.d: CHAPTER 7. Secret Sign Language
atha chomāpaṭalaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ | yena vijñāyate bhrāta bhaginī ca na saṃśayaḥ || (1)
de nas ts+tsho m+mA'i le'u bshad par bya'o/ / gang gis spun dang sring mor yang / / the tshom med par shes par bya/ /
Now I shall expound the chapter regarding Chomā, the Secret Sign Language by which a ‘brother’ can without any doubt recognise a ‘sister’.

brda ni kla klo'i skad de/ rnal 'byor ma rnams kyis rtogs pa brda ston pa'o/ / de yang thabs kyi mchog tu gyur pa nyid yin pa nyid du shes par bya'o/ / de'i phyir de nas brda'i le'u zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ brda gsal bar byed pa'i le'u la yang 'di skad ces bya'o/ / spun ni rnal 'byor pa'o/ / sring mo ni rnal 'byor ma'o/ /

chomā (the Secret Sign Language): According to the convention of the yoginīs, Chomā, the Secret Sign Language, is the accepted mode of communication when meeting the yoginīs. This also must be known since it is a supreme Means. Therefore it is said: atha chomā ityādi (now the Secret Sign Language etc.): The chapter that expounds upon the Secret Sign Language is now discussed. bhrātā (‘brother’): Refers to a yogī. bhaginī (‘sister’): Refers to a yoginī.
aṅgulīṃ darśayed yas tu • āgatam ity uktaṃ bhavet || dvābhyāṃ susvāgato bhavet || kṣemamudrāṃ vijñānīyād vāmāṅguṣṭhanipīḍanāt || (2)
gang zhig sor mo gcig ston dang / / gnyis kyis legs par 'ongs pa yin/ / g.yon pa'i mthe bong bcangs pa las/ / bsnyun gyi phyag rgyar rnam par shes/ /
To the one who shows one finger, showing two fingers means ‘Most welcome’. Know that the Sign of Well-being is shown by pressing the left thumb.
sor mo gcig ces bya ba ni mdzub mo ste/ 'ongs sam zhes bya ba'i don to/ / gang zhig ces bya ba ni gang zhig gis blta bar bya'o/ / gnyis kyis zhes bya ba ni mdzub mo dang gung mo dag gis so/ /

aṅgulīṃ (one finger): Means the index finger, shown in order to be welcomed. yas tu (the one who): Meaning, the one who shows. dvābhyāṃ (with two fingers): Means with the index and the middle fingers.
anāmikāṃ tu yo dadyād dadyāt tasya kaniṣṭhikāṃ || madhyamān darśayed yas tu dadyāt tasya pradeṣikāṃ || (3)
gang zhig srin lag ston pa la/ / de yi mthe'u chung rnam par sbyin/ / gang zhig gung mo ston pa la/ / de yi mdzub mo rnam par sbyin/ /
To the one who offers the ring finger give the little finger [in reply]. To the one who shows the middle finger show the index finger.
anāmikān darśayed yas tu grīvāṃ tasya pradarśayet || paṭaṃ saṃdarśayed yas triśūlaṃ tasya darśayed || (4)
gang zhig srin lag ston pa la/ / de yi mgrin pa rab tu bstan/ / gang zhig gos ni ston pa la/ / de yi rtse gsum rab tu bstan/ /
To the one who shows the ring finger show the neck. To the one who shows the Sign of the Tiara show the Sign of the Trident.
dar dpyang ston pa zhes bya ba ni de gnyis kyis dar dpyang bcings pa'i tshul ston pa'o/ / rtse gsum zhes bya ba ni mthe'u chung mthe bos mnan nas lhag ma rtse gsum gyi tshul du brkyang pa'o/ /

paṭṭiṃ saṃdarśayed (shows the Sign of the Tiara): Means shows the gesture of tying a Tiara above the forehead with the index and middle fingers. triśūlaṃ (Sign of the Trident): This hand gesture is formed by pressing the little finger down with the thumb and making the remaining three fingers stand straight in the shape of a trident.
stanaṃ darśayed yas tu sīmān tasya pradarśayet || medinīṃ darśayed yas tu cakraṃ tasya pradarśayet || (5)
gang zhig nu ma ston pa la/ / de yi mtshams ni rab tu bstan/ / gang zhig so ni ston pa la/ / de yi kha ni rab tu bstan/ /
To the one who shows the breasts show the end of the parting of the hair. To the one who points to the earth show the Sign of the Circle.
mtshams ni zhes bya ba ni spyi gtsug gi mtshams so/ / 'khor lo ni 'khor lo'i tshul ston pa'o/ /
sīmantaṃ (the end of the parting of the hair): Refers to the place where the parting of the hair ends at the crown of the head. cakraṃ (Sign of the Circle): Refers to the gesture of showing a circle.
bhṛkuṭīṃ darśayed yas tu śikhāmokṣo vidhīyate || lalāṭaṃ darśayed yas tu pṛṣṭaṃ tasya pradarśayet || (6)
gang zhig khro gnyer ston pa la/ / gtsug phud dgrol bar brjod par bya/ / gang zhig dpral ba ston pa la/ / de yi rgyab ni rab tu bstan/ /
To the one who shows the eyebrows instruct by loosening the tuft of hair. To the one who shows the forehead show the back.
khro gnyer ni smin ma g.yo ba'o/ / gtsug phud dgrol ba zhes bya ba la sogs pa ni drang ba'i don gyi bshad pa'o/ /
bhṛkuṭīṃ (eyebrows): Refers to frowning eyebrows. śikhāmokṣa ityādi (loosening the tuft of hair etc.): Interpret this in a literal sense.
pādatalaṃ darśayed yas tu krīḍate kautukena tu || mudrāpratimudreṇa bhedayet samayena tu || (7)
gang zhig rkang mthil ston pa la/ / lto yis rnam par rtse bar bya/ / phyag rgya phyag rgya'i lan gyis ni/ / dam tshig gis ni rnam par bye/ /

To the one who shows the sole of the foot, in answer joyfully dance. Thus, with such signs and counter signs, in accordance with the Observance of the Vow, the yogī and the yoginī should reveal themselves.
[Now another interpretation of the signs mentioned in the previous verses:]

sor mo gcig ni ston pa dang / /zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ gang yang sor gcig ces bya ba mdzub mo'am/ gung mo dang mdzub mo dag gis shes rab kyi pad+mar ston pa ste bskul bar bya'o/ / de nyid ni legs par 'ongs pa yin zhes bya ba la/ legs par zhes bya ba ni khu ba ste sor mo sbyor bas phab ces bya ba'i don to/ / bsnyun gyi phyag rgyar zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ bsnyun gyi phyag rgya ni bde ba'i mthar thug pa'i chos kyi dbyings rab tu bsgrub pa ste/ de rnams shes pa'o/ / de ji lta bu zhig ce na/ g.yon gyi mthe bong bcangs pa las/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ g.yon zhes bya ba ni shes rab ste/ de'i pad+ma'i nang ngo / / mthe bong ni rdo rje ste des 'dzag pa'i gnas skabs thob par gyur pa ni btsir bar bya ba'o/ /

aṅgulīm ityādi (one finger etc.): To the one who shows one finger, that is, the index finger, show the index and middle fingers or the Lotus of the Wisdom. Showing this sign means ‘most welcome’ (susvāgata) where ‘most’ (the prefix su) implies semen (śukra). By utilising the fingers the semen is attracted is the meaning. kṣemamudrāṃ ityādi (Sign of Well-being etc.): [This] relates to the question ‘how are you?’ and is an acknowledgement of the Essence of Nature. Know this. How this sign is to be interpreted is said by: vāmāṅguṣṭhanipīḍanāt (pressing with the left thumb): Here, ‘left’ (vāmā) refers to the Wisdom and ‘thumb’ (aṅguṣṭḥa) refers to the Vajra. This sign indicates the pressing, with the Vajra, of the very core of the Wisdom’s Lotus in order to attain the state of flow.

srin lag ces bya ba la sogs pa la/ srin lag ni shes rab kyi ye shes kyi dbang bskur ba'o/ /gang zhig ces bya ba ni gang gi phyir rim pa 'di nyid kyis byin pa'o/ / de la mthe'u chung ni dbang tha ma ste bzhi pa zhes bya ba'i bar du'o/ / ji ltar sbyin par bya zhe na/ gung mo zhes bya ba gsungs te/ gung mo zhes bya ba a wa d+hU tI zhes bya ba bstan pa'o/ / gang zhig ces bya ba ni bla ma gang zhig gis slob ma la bzhi pa'i man ngag ces bya bar grags pa sdigs mdzub spangs la bstan par bya'o/ /

anāmikāṃ ityādi (ring finger etc.): The ring finger refers to the Wisdom consecration. To the one who further offers this, give the little finger. The little finger refers to the last consecration, the Fourth. How the Fourth is to be expressed is said by: madhyamāṃ darśayed yas tu (to the one who shows the middle finger): Refers to the guru showing the middle finger which symbolises the Avadhūtī. By showing the Avadhūtī to the disciple, the instruction on the Fourth is expressed.

de la mdzub mo dang srin lag ces bya ba ni la la nA dang ra sa nA'o/ / sbyin par bya zhes bya ba ni bstan par bya ba'o/ / ji lta bu la bstan par bya zhe na/ mgrin par rab tu ston pa la/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ gang zhig zhabs la gtugs pa la sogs pas bla ma yang dag par mnyes par byed pa'i slob ma la bstan par bya zhes bya bar dgongs so/ / dar dpyang zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ sor mo gnyis kyis dar dpyang bcings pa'i tshul du byed pa ste/ shes rab dang thabs mtshon pa'o/ / de 'dir ston cig ces dri ba la/ de la rtse gsum du ston zhes bya ba ste rtse gsum ni shes rab dang thabs dang gnyis su med pa'i mtshon par byed pa'i la la nA dang ra sa nA dang a wa d+hU tI'o/ / de la rab tu phye nas bstan par bya ba'o/ /

anāmikāṃ (ring finger): ‘Give the ring finger’ means together with the index finger give instructions regarding Lalanā and Rasanā [Nāḍīs]. How instruction may be given is said by: yas tu grīvāṃ pradarśayet (to that one show the neck): Instruction may be given to the pupil who fully pleases the guru with total surrender. This is the implication [of showing the neck]. paṭṭiṃ (Sign of the Tiara): The Sign of the Tiara is shown by two fingers tying a Tiara [in place]. Showing the Sign of the Tiara with two fingers, which symbolise Wisdom and Means, implies the asking for instruction. triśūlaṃ tasya darśayet (show him the Sign of the Trident): The Trident which symbolises the non-duality, Wisdom and Means is clearly shown to the disciple as signifying the Lalanā, Rasanā and Avadhūtī.

nu ma ston pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ slob ma gang zhig la nu ma ste shes rab dang thabs mtshon par byed pa ste/ de dag nyams su myong bas bstan cing smra bar bya ba'o/ / mtshams ni bde ba chen po'i 'khor lo ste/ de la rab tu bstan par bya'o/ / sa ni sprul pa'i 'khor lo ste de bstan par bya ba'o/ /gang zhig ces bya ba ni phyi na ste/ de la 'khor lo zhes bya ba chos kyi 'khor lo bstan par bya ba'o/ /

stanam ityādi (breasts etc.): The disciple who shows the breasts, which symbolise Wisdom and Means, is expressing his experience of Wisdom and Means. sīmantaṃ (end of the parting of the hair): Where the parting of the hair meets the crown of the head is the location of the Centre of Great Bliss. This should be shown to the disciple. medinī (earth): To the one who shows the earth, implying the Centre of Creation, show the: cakraṃ (Sign of the Circle): The Circle refers to the Centre of Essential Nature.

khro gnyer zhes bya ba ni longs spyod kyi 'khor lo bstan par bya ba'o/ / gang zhig ces bya ba ni yang ngo / / gtsug phud dgrol bar brjod par bya/ /zhes bya ba la thar pa'i don gyis bslab pa ste/ khyod kyis srog chags gsad par bya/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa brjod par bya ba'o/ / dpral ba ston pa la zhes bya ba ni ngag gis yang phyag bya ba'o/ / de la rgyab ni zhes bya ba ni lag pas de'i rgyab la reg par bya'o zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ /

bhṛkuṭīṃ (eyebrows): To the one who shows frowning eyebrows, implying the Centre of Enjoyment, further śikhāmokṣo vidhīyate (instruct by the loosening of the hair): ‘The loosening of the hair’ refers to the instructions for liberation [given in 2.3.29]: “You should slay all living beings ... etc.” lalāṭaṃ (forehead): To the one who shows the forehead out of respect, [in acknowledgement] show: pṛṣṭhaṃ (the back): Means show the back with the hand, not by touching but by pointing.

lag pas reg pa 'ba' zhig ma zad kyi/ rkang mthil zhes bya ba ni rkang pa'i mthil gyis sa'i dkyil 'khor bstan par bya ba ste/ rnal 'byor 'di dang ldan pas sa la ji ltar bde bar gnas par bya'o zhes brjod par bya'o/ / gang zhig bla mas rjes su gnang bar byas par 'gyur ba gnas pa des/ lto ba'i rnam par rtse bar bya/ /zhes bya ba la lto ba zhes bya ba ni rnal 'byor pa ste/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das so/ / rim gyis de dag lhan cig tu de lta bu'i yon tan gyi tshogs kyis brgyan par bya ba'o/ / 'di ni nges pa'i don gyi bshad pa'o/ /

pādatalaṃ (sole of the foot): Refers to the Earth maṇḍala. By showing the sole of the foot, the disciple is expressing the playful ease with which he steps upon such an earth. krīḍate (dance): In response to the disciple who walks on the earth following the guru’s instructions, the contented yogī [the guru] dances with the disciple. Being endowed with the Buddha’s qualities such a yogī is at one with the Bhagavān Buddha. Such is the esoteric meaning.
phyag rgya lan zhes bya ba la/ sor mo gnyis zhes bya ba la sogs pas dbye bar bya'o/ /
pradmudra (counter sign): Refers to ‘show two fingers’ and other [counter signs].

vadanti tatra yoginya aho putra mahākṛpa || yadi mālāhastan darśayanti tatra militavyam iti kathayanti || (8) mālā{m a}bhipreṣitāṃ kṛtvā samaye tiṣṭha suvratā || bhajeti tatra melāyāṃ divyagocaram āśritya || yad {dhi} vadanti yoginyas tat sarvam {eva} kartavyaṃ || (9)

de la rnal 'byor mas smras pa/ / e ma bu ni snying rje che/ / gal te phreng ba lag ston na/ / 'du bar bya zhes smra ba yin/ / phreng ba mngon par gtad byas na/ / dam tshig la mnos brtul zhugs bzang / / de la phyi rol zhes 'du ba/ / bzang po'i spyod yul la gnas pa/ / de la 'du bar rnal 'byor mas/ / gang smras de ltar thams cad bya/ /

There the yoginīs greet by saying: ‘Well done, O son of great mercy’. If the yoginīs show the Sign of the Garland-inhand, they are saying: ‘There we must meet.’ By the casting away of the garland they are indicating: ‘O disciplined one, abide within regulations of the Observance of the Vow.’ Worship there at the meeting place, abiding in the divine realm doing whatever the yoginīs command.

phreng ba ma'i lag ces bya ba ni skra bcing ba ltar bya ba'am/ phreng ba drang ba ltar bya ba'o/ / de la mngon du phyogs pa ltar ston pa ni/ phreng ba mngon par bstan byas na/ / zhes bya ba'o/ / 'di dag gnyi ga yang dngos su'am de lta bu'i tshul gyis rtogs par bya'o/ / 'di dag thams cad kyang lag pa g.yon pa bstan par bya'o/ / phreng ba mngon par gtad byas zhes bya ba'i don bstan par bya ba'i phyir/ dam tshig la gnas zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ lha rdzas zhes bya ba ni rnal 'byor ma'o/ / phyi rol zhes bya ba ni bstan par gyis shig ces bya ba'o/ /

mālāhastaṃ (Sign of the Garland-in-hand): The Sign of the Garland-in-hand is shown by removing a garland from the coils of the hair. Understand that both the removing of the garland from the hair and the casting away of the garland towards the yogī are acted out with the appropriate gestures of the hand. All these secret signs must be shown with the left hand. mālām abhipreṣitāṃ (casting away the garland): The intent of this gesture is said by: ‘O disciplined one, abide within the regulations of the Observance of the Vow.’ bhajet (worship): Means serve. divya (divine): Divine because of the yoginīs.

Vajragarbha uvāca / he bhagavan ke te melāpakasthānāḥ / bhagavān āha / {te} pīṭhañ copapīṭhañ ca kṣetropakṣetram eva ca || chandohañ copacchandohaṃ melāpakopamelāpakas tathā || pīlavaṃ copapīlavaṃ śmaśānopaśmaśānakaṃ || (10) etā dvādaśabhūmayaḥ | daśabhūmīśvaro nātha ebhir anyair na kathyate || (11)

kye bcom ldan 'das 'du ba'i gnas lags/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / gnas dang nye ba'i gnas dang ni/ / zhing dang nye ba'i zhing nyid dang / / ts+tshan do nye ba'i ts+tshan do dang / / de bzhin 'du ba nye 'du ba/ / 'thung gcod nye ba'i 'thung gcod nyid/ / dur khrod nye ba'i dur khrod nyid/ / 'di rnams sa ni bcu gnyis te/ / sa bcu'i dbang phyug mgon po nyid/ / 'dis ni gzhan gyis brjod mi bya/ /

Vajragarbha asked: O Bhagavān, what are these meeting places? Bhagavān replied: They are the Pīṭhas, Upapīṭhas, Kṣetras, Upakṣetras, Chandohas, Upachandohas, Melāpakas, Upamelāpakas, Pīlavas, Upapīlavas, Śmaśānas and Upaśmaśānas. These are the twelve Stages (bhūmī). It is with reference to these stages and for no other reason that the Lord is known as the Lord of the Ten Stages (daśabhūmīśvara).

kye bcom ldan 'das zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ 'di rnams sa ni bcu gnyis zhes bya ba ni gnas la sogs pa'o/ / 'di las 'byung bar 'gyur bas na sa zhes bya ste/ rab tu dga' ba dang / dri ma med pa dang / 'od byed pa dang / 'od 'phro ba dang / sbyang dka' ba dang / mngon du gyur pa dang / ring du 'gro ba dang / mi g.yo ba dang / legs pa'i blo gros dang / chos kyi sprin dang / kun du 'od dang / dpe med pa zhes bya ba rim bzhin no/ / ye shes ldan zhes bya ba bcu gsum pa rdo rje 'dzin pa'i sa ni shin tu mi gnas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa'i ngo bo nyid yin pas de ni ma brjod do/ /

eta (these are the twelve): The twelve are the Pīṭhas and the other meeting-place. When considered as the Stages, they are in order: Muditā, Vimalā, Arciṣmatī, Prabhākarī, Sudurjayā, Abhimukhī, Dūraṅgamā, Acalā, Sādhumatī, Dharmameghā, Samantabhadrā, Nirupamā and then the thirteenth, Jñānavatī, the stage of Vajradhara, which is not discussed here because it is of the nature of the Unanchored Essence of Release (apratiṣṭhitanirvāṇadhatu).
sa bcu'i dbang phyug gi byang chub sems dpa' dang / mgon po sangs rgyas kyis bstan pa yin no zhes sbyar bar bya'o/ / gang dag las zhes bya zhe na/
daśabhūmīśvaraḥ (the Lord of the Ten Stages): Refers to the Enlightened Being (bodhisattva). nāthaḥ (the Lord): Refers to the Enlightened One (Buddha). Of which stages is he the Lord?
gnas la sogs pa 'di dag nyid la zhes bya ba'i don te/
[This is answered by]: ebhiḥ (with reference to these): Here ‘these’ refers to the Pīṭhas and so on.

Vajragarbha uvāca / he bhagavan ke te pīṭhādayaḥ / bhagavān āha / pīṭhaṃ Jālandharaṃ khyātam Oḍḍiyānaṃ tathaiva ca || pīṭhaṃ Paurṇagiriś caiva Kāmarūpan tathaiva ca || (12) upapīṭha Mālavaṃ proktaṃ Sindhur Nagaram eva ca || kṣetraṃ Munmuni prakhyātaṃ kṣetraṃ Kāruṇyapāṭakaṃ || Devikoṭaṃ tathā kṣetraṃ kṣetraṃ Karmārapātakaṃ || (13) upakṣetraṃ Kulatā proktam Arbudaś ca tathaiva ca || Goḍāvarī hi Mādriś ca • upakṣetraṃ hi saṃkṣipet || (14) chandohaṃ Harikelañ ca lavaṇasāgaramadhyajaṃ || Lampākaṃ Kāñcikaṃ caiva Saurāṣṭraṃ ca tathaiva ca || (15) Kaliṅgam upacchandohaṃ dvīpaṃ cāmikarānvitaṃ || Kokaṇaṃ copacchandohaṃ samāsenābhidhīyate || (16) pīlavaṃ {ca} grāmantaṣṭhaṃ pīlavaṃ nagarasya ca || Caritraṃ Kośalaṃ caiva Vindhyākaumārapaurikā || upapīlavaṃ tatsanniveśaṃ Vajragarbha mahākṛpa || (17) śmaśānaṃ pretasaṃhātaṃ śmaśānaṃ codadhes taṭaṃ || udyānaṃ vāpikātīram upaśmaśānaṃ ucyate || (18)

kye bcom ldan 'das gnas la sogs pa gang lags/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / gnas ni dzA lan d+ha rar bshad/ / de bzhin du ni au T+yan nyid/ / gnas ni ko la la gi ri nyid/ / de bzhin du ni kA ma rU nyid/ / nye gnas mA la wa zhes brjod/ / si na d+hu na gar nyid do/ / zhing ni mum+mu nir bshad de/ / zhing ni byed pa'i brang nyid do/ / de wI ko Ti de bzhin zhing / / zhing ni lcags pa'i brang nyid do/ / nye zhing gu la ta zhes brjod/ / de bzhin a rbud nyid dang / / ba yi mchog sbyin kha ba'i ri/ / nye ba'i zhing ni mdor bsdus pa'o/ / ts+tshan do ha ri ke la dag / / lan tshwa rgya mtsho'i nang skyes dang / la ma ba kA dang kAny+tsi nyid/ / de bzhin saurASh+Sha nyid do/ / nye ba'i ts+tshan do ka ling ka / gser dang ldan pa'i gling dang ni/ / kong ka Na yang nye tsan dor/ / mdor bsdus pas ni brjod par bya/ / 'thung gcod grong khyer gyi dang yang / / 'thung gcod grong gi mthar gnas pa/ / tsa ri tra dang ko sa la/ / bin d+h+ya gzhon nu'i grong khyer ro/ / rdo rje snying po snying rje che/ / nye ba'i 'thung gcod de nye ba'o/ / dur khrod rab son dge 'dun dang / / dur khrod rgya mtsho'i 'gram nyid do/ / skyed tshal ra ba rdzing bu'i 'gram/ / nye ba'i dur khrod brjod par bya/ /

Vajragarbha asked: O Bhagavān, which are the Pīṭhas and the other meeting places? Bhagavān replied: The Pīṭhas are Jālandhara, Oḍḍiyāna, Pūrṇagiri and Kāmarūpa. The Upapīṭhas are Mālava, Sindhu and Nagara. The Kṣetras are Munmuṇi, Kāruṇyapāṭakaṃ, Devīkoṭa and Karmārapaṭakaṃ. The Upakṣetras are Kulatā, Arbuda, Godāvarī and Himādri. The Chandohas are Harikelaṃ which is located in the middle of the salty ocean, Lampāka, Kāñcika and Saurāṣṭra. The Upacchandohas are Kaliṅga, the Golden Island and Kokaṇa. The Pīlava is at the edge of a village and a city. The cities of Cāritra, Kośala and Kumārapura, which is in the Vindhya hills, are also Pīlavas. In close proximity to them are the Upapīlavas, O Vajragarbha of great mercy. Śmaśāna is a meeting place of hungry ghosts as well as the seashore. A garden or the edge of a pond are known as an Upaśmaśāna.

kye bcom ldan 'das zhes bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / ko la gi ri ni pu li ra ma la ya'o/ / na ga ra ni pa tA la pu tra'o/ / lan tshwa rgya mtsho nas skyes zhes bya ba ni ha li ke la'i khyad par ro/ / gser dang ldan pa'i gling zhes bya ba ni gser gling nyid do/ / de nye ba zhes bya ba ni u pa li la ste nye ba'o/ / rdzing bu zhes bya ba ni ring ba'o/ /

paurṇagiri: Refers to the place Pollagiri, which is also known as Pullīramalayaṃ. nagaraṃ: Refers to the city of Pāṭalīputra. lavaṇasāgaramadhyajaṃ (located in the middle of the salty ocean): This is a description of Harikela. cāmīkarānvitaṃ: Refers to Suvarṇadvīpa (lit. the Golden Island), tatsanniveśaṃ (in close proximity): Refers to the location of the Upapīlavas which are close to the Pīlavas. vāpikātīraṃ (edge of a pond): Means a lake.
divasaṃ caiva vakṣyāmi yoginīnāṃ sumelakaṃ || Hevajre Yoginītantre sarvasattvārthahetunā || (19)
sems can kun gyi don gyi phyir/ / rnal 'byor ma rgyud kye'i rdo rje/ / rnal 'byor ma yi legs 'du ba/ / nyin bar nyid kyang rab bshad bya/ /
Further, for the benefit of all beings I shall speak of the auspicious meeting days of the yoginīs in the tradition of this Yoginī tantra, the Hevajra Tantra.
Vajragarbha uvāca / he bhagavan ke te divasāḥ / bhagavān āha / pretapakṣe caturdaśyām aṣṭamyāñ ca tathaiva ca || (20)
kye bcom ldan 'das nyi ma gang lags/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / yi dgas zla phyed bcu bzhi dang / / de bzhin du yang brgyad pa nyid/ /
Vajragarbha asked: O Bhagavān, what are those days? Bhagavān replied: The Fourteenth and Eighth nights of the waning phase of the moon.
nyin mo nyid kyang zhes bya ba la sogs pa la [{]yi dgas [,]yi dwags [}]zla phyed ces bya ba ni mar ngo'i phyogs so/ / 'di ni phyi rol gyi bstan pa'o// //
Regarding the days etc.: pretapakṣaḥ (waning phase): Means the dark half of the lunar month. So far the external practice has been expressed.
da ni gdug pa can rnams gzhug par bya ba'i phyir dang slob ma'i rnal 'byor bstan pa'i phyir/
Now in order to subdue evil people, both the external and the internal practices are expressed through the following single statement:
dhvajaṃ śastrahataṃ caiva saptāvartañ ca bhakṣayet || kṛpām utpādya yatnena māraṇaṃ krīyate viduḥ || (21)
rgyal mtshan dang ni mtshon bsnun nyid/ / lan bdun pa yang bza' bar bya/ / 'bad pas snying rje bskyed pa yis/ / gsad par bya bar brjod pa nyid/ /

The yogī must eat the flesh of one killed at the gallows pole as well as one killed by a weapon and one who is a ‘seven times returned’. The wise yogī performs the rite of Killing after intently arousing mercy.

phyi dang nang gi bdag nyid can sgra gcig gis bstan par 'dod nas rgyal mtshan dang ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rgyal mtshan ni dpyangs pa'o/ / mtshon bsnun nyid ni g.yul ngo la sogs par gsad pa'o/ / lan bdun pa ni skye ba bdun pa'o/ / snying rjes zhes bya ba ni de'i 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal bsams nas so/ / mkhas pa zhes bya ba ni rnam par mkhas pa nyid de 'di ni bshad pa gcig go/ /

dhvajaḥ (gallows pole): This refers to one who has been hanged. śastrahataḥ (one killed by a weapon): Refers to one killed in a battle etc. saptāvartaṃ (‘seven times returned’): Refers to one who has been born seven times [consecutively as a human being]. kṛpā (mercy): Means reflecting on the sorrows of his existence. viduḥ (wise one): Means by the wise ones. This is one [the external] interpretation.
[Now another interpretation:]

rgyal mtshan ni dmigs pa dang bcas pa'i sems so/ / mtshon bsnun na ni shes rab kyi mtshon gyis bcad pa ste/ gcig dang du ma'i rang bzhin gyis bcad pas rang bzhin med par byas pa ni mtshon gyis bsnun pa'o/ / nyid ces bya ba ni gang gis gcod par byed pa'i sems nyid kyang bcad pas rang bzhin med par byed par bstan pa'o/ / lan bdun pa yang zhes bya ba ni lan bdun gyi bar du yang yang bltas nas bza' bar bya ba ste/ rang bzhin med par byas zhes bya ba'i don to/ / 'di ni gnas ji lta bur yang bdag dang gzhan mchog tu bsrung bar byas par 'gyur te/ bdud la sogs pas kyang nye bar 'tshe bar mi 'gyur ro/ / stong pa nyid kyi ting nge 'dzin la mngon du phyogs par 'gyur ro/ / snying rje bskyed ces bya ba la sogs pa la/ dang por tshangs pa'i gnas bzhi bsgom pa byas nas so/ / 'bad pas zhes bya ba ni nges pa kho nar ro/ / mkhas pas zhes bya ba ni rnam par mkhas pa'o/ /

dhvajaḥ (gallows pole): Symbolises the mind resting on a foundation. śastrahataḥ (one killed by a weapon): Killing with the weapon implies the severing with the weapon of Wisdom and the non-substantiation of the differentiated by reflecting upon the nature one and many. ca (as well as): Implies the non-substantiation of even any thought that comes to mind. saptāvartaṃ (‘seven times returned’): Means he eats seven times repeatedly, that is makes [all thoughts] non-existent In such a meeting place, the eating is the supreme protection for one’s own self and others and by this protection snakes and other troublesome beings cause no harm and the Stabilised Meditative State of the Voidness becomes apparent kṛpām utpādya (arousing mercy etc.): Means perform firstly the emanation of the Four Brahma Abodes, [ref. 1.3.1] yatnena (intently): Implies that it is imperative. viduḥ (the wise): Means by the wise.
kṛpāhīnā na sidhyanti tasmāt kṛpām utpādayet || duṣṭāvatāraṇe sarvaṃ vidhimukhyāt prasidhyati || (22)
snying rje med na mi 'grub pas/ / de phyir snying rje bskyed pa nyid/ / thams cad gdug pa gzhug pa ste/ / cho ga'i gtso bos dgag par bya/ /
Those who lack mercy cannot succeed, so arouse mercy. In overcoming evil people everything is accomplished by following the correct procedure.

gal te 'gro ba rnams gsad cing mi dmigs par bya ba yin na/ de lta na ci'i phyir tshangs pa'i gnas bzhi dang por bsgom par bya zhe na/ snying rje med na zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ gang gi tshe dang por tshangs pa'i gnas bzhi bsgom pa med na de'i tshe yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi ngo bo med par yang 'gyur te/ stong pa nyid 'ba' zhig bsgoms pas nyan thos la sogs pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa nyid du yang 'gyur ba srid do/ / de lta bas na de'i phyir snying rje bskyed pa nyid ces bya bas nye bar bsdus pa yin no/ / thams cad gdug pa zhes bya ba ni bde bar gshegs pa'i bstan pa la sdang ba ste rgyang 'phen pa la sogs pa'o/ / de dag gsang sngags kyi theg pa la sbyar bar bya ba'i phyir gsungs pa yin no/ / cho ga'i gtso bo zhes bya ba la sogs pa 'dir cho ga'i gtso bos dgag par bya ba yin no/ /

If killing of beings is to be performed, how so is it to be performed? The reason for initially performing the emanation of the Four Brahma Abodes is said by: kṛpāhīnā ityādi (those who lack mercy etc.): If the emanation of the Four Brahma Abodes is not always initially performed, the accomplishment of perfect Enlightenment will not be attained. By merely emanating Voidness the yogī at some time attains the release of the nirvana of the Śrāvakas and others. tasmāt ityādi (so etc.): Means to refute [that limited process]. duṣṭa (evil people): They are those who are opposed to the teachings of the Buddha. In order to draw evil people towards the Mantrayāna it is said: vidhimukhyāt (following the correct procedure): It is by following the correct procedures that this is attained.
gang dag gang du gsad pa la sogs pa'i sgra dang ldan pa mthong ba de dang der 'di bzhin du rig par bya'o/ /
Wherever words like ‘killing’ etc. are noticed, there consider them in the manner mentioned in the verses that follow.
tatraivaṃ mantavyaṃ / dinas tu bhagavān Vajrī naktaṃ prajñā ca bhaṇyate || (23)
de la 'di ltar blta ba nyid/ / nyin mo bcom ldan rdo rje can/ / mtshan mo shes rab brtag par bya/ / mi bya cung zad yod ma yin/ /
In that practice conceive as follows: The day is the Bhagavān Vajrī (Hevajra) and night is Prajñā (the Goddess Wisdom).
nākāryaṃ vidyate kiñcin nābhakṣyaṃ vidyate sadā || nācintyaṃ vidyate hy atra nāvācyaṃ yac chubhāśubhaṃ || (24)
rtag tu mi bza' yod ma yin/ / 'di la mi bsam yod ma yin/ / bzang ngan mi smra gang yang med/ /
The yogī should not think of anything as being prohibited and he should never think of anything as being inedible. There is not anything, good or bad, that he should not think or say.

nyin mo bcom ldan rdo rje can/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ rtag tu zhes bya ba ni dus thams cad du'o/ / 'jig rten pa la sogs pa'i drung du ni rgyal mtshan la sogs pa spang bar bya ba la tshogs kyi 'khor lo la sogs pa dben pa'i gnas su ni longs spyod par bya'o zhes bya ba yin no/ / mi bsam yod ma yin zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ mi bsam zhes bya ba ni bsam pa gzhan ci yang mi bsam pa ste/

sadā (always): Means at all times. In the presence of ordinary people abstain from exposing the eating of the flesh of a hanged man and the others and in the Assembly of the Circle of Initiates (gaṇacakra) and other rites, eat in a secret place is the intent. nācintyaṃ (anything he must not think): Means without thinking in terms of right and wrong thoughts.
yathātmani tathā sattve tathātmani {hy} ahaṃ paraṃ || iti saṃcintya yogātmā khānapānādim ārabhet || (25)
ji ltar bdag nyid de ltar gzhan/ / de bzhin bdag ni nga mchog nyid/ / 'di ltar sems pa'i rnal 'byor bdag / bza' dang btung ba la sogs spyad/ /
The yogī should commence eating and drinking etc. reflecting: ‘As in myself similarly in other beings and similarly in myself the supreme identity.’

ji ltar bdag nyid dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i nga rgyal byed pa de bzhin du sems can gzhan la yang bya ba'o/ / de bzhin bdag nyid ces bya ba ni kun bsdu ba ste/ de dag dang bdag gnyi ga dgyes pa'i rdo rjer blta bar bya'o/ /

yathātmani (‘as in myself... ’): Means as he identifies Hevajra with himself, similarly the yogī must realise this Hevajra identity with other beings as well. tathātmani (similarly in myself): As a unified whole I myself am this Hevajra who is the supreme identity present in all individuals.
yāvanto {hy} aṅgavikṣepā vacasaḥ prasarāṇi ca || tāvanto mantramudrāḥ syuḥ śrīherukapade sthite || (26)
yan lag ji snyed bsgyur ba dang / / tshig rnams rab tu rgyas pa nyid/ / he ru ka dpal gnas bzhugs pas/ / de snyed sngags dang phyag rgya yin/ /
For the yogī who abides in the state of the Divine Heruka, all movements of the body are the ritual hand gestures (mudrā) and the flow of speech Mantra.
śrīkāram advayaṃ jñānaṃ hekāraṃ hetvādiśūnyatā || rukārāpagatavyūhaṃ kakāraṃ na kvacit sthitaṃ || (27)
shrI ni gnyis med ye shes te/ / he ni rgyu sogs stong pa nyid/ / ru ni tshogs dang bral ba nyid/ / ka ni gang du'ang mi gnas pa'o/ /

[Regarding the composite word Śrīheruka:] Śrī symbolises non-dual knowledge. He symbolises the primordial voidness of causality. Ru symbolises the rejection of discriminating thought. Ka symbolises the fact of not being located anywhere.

bdag nyid gzhan zhes bya ba ni bdag nyid dang gzhan dag go/ / gnas bzhugs pas zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ gnyis med ces bya ba ni chos thams cad stong pa nyid do/ / de nyid shrI ste chos thams cad 'od gsal ba'i rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir ro/ / rgyu zhes bya ba ni byed rgyu'o/ / sogs pa zhes bya ba ni rang bzhin no/ / stong pa nyid ni de dag dang bral ba'o/ / tshogs ni rnam par rtog pa ste de dang bral ba ni yongs su spangs pa nyid do/ / ka zhes bya ba ni mi gnas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa'o/ / 'di dag gis ni stong pa nyid dang mtshan ma med pa dang mngon par 'du byas pa med pa dang / smon pa med pa'i don rnams ni he ru ka zhes bya ba'i sgras bstan pa yin no/ /

advayaṃ (non-dual knowledge): The non-dual knowledge is the Voidness of All Natures, which is śrī, because it is the Innate Radiance. hetu (causality): Means cause or source. ādiśūnyatā (primordial Voidness): Refers to the intrinsic nature, which is Voidness. vyūhaṃ (discriminating thought): Refers to any conjecture of thought. apagataṃ (rejection): Means abandoning. ka [referring to the last syllable of the composite name Śrīheruka]: Means released by the Unanchored Release. So far the meaning of the composite word Śrīheruka has been shown to indicate [the four Vimokṣas,] Voidness, the Unconditioned, Freedom from Desire and Freedom from the Accumulation of Karma.
yeṣāṃ yeṣāṃ ca jantūnāṃ piśitam aśnīyate budhaiḥ || te te sattvā vaśaṃ yānti vajrakapālayogataḥ || (28)
rdo rje thod pa'i sbyor ba yis/ / skye bo gang dang gang rnams kyi/ / sha ni mkhas pas bza' bar bya/ / sems can de de'i dbang du 'gyur/ /
All those living beings whose flesh the wise yogis eat are all subdued by means of this Vajra-Kapāśla Yoga.

'gro drug tu skye bar 'gyur bas na skye bo ste phung po lnga'o/ / sha zhes bya ba ni de'i rang bzhin no/ / bza' bya ba zhes bya ba ni snang ba med par bya ba'o/ / mkhas pa zhes bya ba ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i rnal 'byor dang ldan pa'o/ / sems can de de zhes bya ba ni dngos po de dang de'o/ / dbang du 'gyur zhes bya ba ni de dang de la dbang thob par 'gyur ba ste/ gzugs la sogs pa rnam pa sna tshogs pa sprul pas gdul bya sna tshogs 'dul bar 'gyur ro/ / rdo rje ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje'o/ / thod pa ni bde ba srung bar byed pa'i phyir bdag med pa ste/ stong pa nyid dang snying rje'o/ / de'i sbyor ba ni ting nge 'dzin te de yis so/ /
