sa dang chu dang rlung dang ni/ / me dang nam mkha' nyid dag ni/ / rang gzhan rig pa'i tshor ba yis/ / kun gyis skad cig mi gnod de/ / mtho ris mi yul rkang 'og gi/ / skad cig las ni gzugs gcig 'gyur/ / rang gzhan cha yi rnam rtog gis/ / gnod pa nyid ni nus pa min/ /

Instantaneously with the arising of this Knowledge earth, water, fire, air and space do not restrain the yogī and he knows his mind and the minds of others. At that moment his body is at one with the realms of heaven, men and hell. It is no longer possible for the yogis to be obstructed by the misconception that distinguishes himself from others.

ji ltar na sa la sogs pas mi gnod ce na/ gal te sgom pa po 'dod par gyur na sa la 'og tu 'dzul zhing steng du 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / thad kar yang ri dang rtsig pa la mi thogs par 'gro ba dang 'ong bar yang byed do/ / dug dang mtshon la sogs pas nyon mongs par yang mi 'gyur ro/ / chu'i steng du gnas shing nang du 'jug par yang 'gyur la/ nyal ba dang 'dug pa dang 'chag par yang byed do/ / rlung dang char 'bab pa la sogs pas kyang nyon mongs par mi 'gyur ro/ / de bzhin du gzhan dag la yang sbyar bar bya'o/ / rang gzhan rig pa'i tshor ba yis/ /zhes bya ba ni bdag dang gzhan gyi 'das pa dang ma 'ongs pa dang da ltar gyi sems shes pa'o/ / mtho ris mi yul zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ gzugs gcig ces bya ba ni rang bzhin gcig pa'o/ / rang gzhan cha'i zhes bya ba la sogs pa'i don bstan zin to/ /

How is it that the earth etc. do not obstruct? The unobstructed emanator can, as he desires, rise above the earth, go through a wall or a mountain and can come and go as he wishes. He is not afflicted by poisons, weapons etc. and he is not hindered above or below water whether he stays or moves. He is not afflicted by wind, rain etc. Similarly, he is unobstructed by the other elements. svaparasaṃvidvedanam (knows his mind and the mind of others): Means he knows the past, present and future of his own mind and that of others. ekamūrtiḥ (one body): Means one nature. svapara (himself and others): This has the same meaning as given above.
lung gzhan dag las dgyes pa'i rdo rje khyad par can rab tu bstan pa'i phyir
In order to demonstrate the greatness of the Hevajra Tantra in comparison with texts of other religious traditions it is said:
samastavedasiddhāntaiḥ karmaprasaraṇādibhiḥ || siddhir na syād bhavec chuddhyā punarjanma bhavāntare || (54)
thams cad rig byed grub mtha' dang / / de bzhin las rgyas la sogs pas/ / srid pa dag 'gyur dngos grub min/ / yang ni srid mthar skye bar 'gyur/ /
There is no accomplishment attained by following all the Vedas, Siddhāntas and traditions of ritual. By following their purifications, there is rebirth in another cycle of existence.

thams cad rig byed ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rig byed ni nges brjod dang srid srung dang snyan dngags dang mchod sbyin no/ / grub mtha' ni mu stegs kyi 'dod pa ste rnying ba la sogs pa dang / nyan thos kyi sde snod kyi mdo sde la sogs pa ste yang srid kyi mthar byed par 'dis 'gyur pas so/ / las rgyas ni bya ba'i rgyud la sogs pa'o/ / 'di dag la bshad pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi dngos grub yod pa ma yin no/ / pha rol tu phyin pa'i theg pa la yod dam 'on te med ce na/ srid pa dag 'gyur zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ dag pa ni 'dis nyon mongs pa dang shes bya'i sgrib pa zad par byed pas na dag pa ste/ pha rol tu phyin pa drug gi mtshan nyid can gyi lam mo/ / dag pa des byang chub thob par 'gyur te/ 'on kyang srid mthar zhes bya ba bskal pa grangs med pa gsum du skye ba gcig nas gcig tu brgyud par zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

vedaḥ (the Veda): The Vedas are the Ṛk, Yajur, Sāma and Atharva. siddhāntaḥ. ‘Siddhanta’ refers to the Purāṇas written by the non-Buddhists, to the Piṭakas and the Sūtrāntas of the Śrāvakas and to other traditions. Siddhāntas arc so called because their accomplishment (siddhi) is at the end (anta) of the next life. karmaprasaraṇa (traditions of ritual): This refers to the Kriyā Tantra etc. siddhir na syāt (there is no perfection): No perfection is attained by following these traditions. What docs and docs not happen in the Pāramitā tradition is said by: bhavet ityādi (there is etc.): ‘Purification’ refers to the cleansing of the veils of afflictions and the veils of the objects of experience. By means of the purification of the method of the Six Perfections there is enlightenment, but in another life. punarjanma (another birth): Means the repetition of countless births in the three eons.
gal te rnal 'byor gyi rgyud du yang tshe 'di la byang chub thob par gsungs na/ de las ci yis lhag par 'gyur zhe na/

It is also said in the Yoga tantras that there is Enlightenment in this very life. Then what is the pre-eminence of the perfection in this Hevajra tradition in contrast with the perfections of other traditions? This is answered by:
na ca tena vinā siddhir iha loke paratra ca || na jñātaṃ yena Hevajraṃ vyarthas tasya pariśramaḥ || (55)
'jig rten 'di dang pha rol du/ / de med pas kyang dngos grub med/ / gang gis mi shes kye'i rdo rje/ / de yi ngal ba don med 'gyur/ /
Without this Knowledge there is no accomplishment possible in this or any other world. The effort of the one who does not know Hevajra is all in vain.

de med pas kyang zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ de zhes bya ba rang rig pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi lhan cig skyes pa med na skye ba 'di 'am skye ba gzhan dag la yang dngos grub yod par ma gsungs so/ / de ltar na de dang 'di la khyad par ci yod ce na/ gang gis mi shes dgyes pa rdo rje zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rgyud gzhan las ni lhan cig skyes pa bstan pa tsam zhig tu zad la/ dgyes pa'i rdo rje 'di las ni yongs su gsal ba'i rnam pa gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir gang gis dgyes pa'i rdo rje mi shes pa de'i thos pa dang bsam pa dang bsgom pa'i ngal ba don med par 'gyur ro zhes shin tu gsal bar bstan pa yin no/ /

tena vinā (without it): Means that without the Innate which is characterised as being one of direct personal experience, there is no accomplishment in this or any other life. What makes this tradition special is said by: hevajram ityādi (Hevajra etc.): The Innate that is hinted at in other tantras is fully elaborated only in the Hevajra Tantra. Therefore, the listening, reflecting, meditation and other efforts of one who does not know Hevajra are all in vain is the intent.
gal te byang chub ni rnyed par dka' ba yin na/ skye ba 'di la ji ltar thob par 'gyur zhe na/
How it is possible to attain the hard to obtain enlightenment in this very life is said by:
nadīśrotaḥpravāhena dīpajyotiḥprabandhavat || satataṃ tattvayogena sthātavyam ahorātrataḥ || (56)
chu bo'i rgyun ni rab 'bab dang / / mar me'i rtse mo rab bcings ltar/ / rtag tu de nyid rnal 'byor gyis/ / nyin dang mtshan du rnam par gzhag /
Like the flow of the river ’ s current, like the rays of the light of a lamp, the yogī must always, day and night, remain at one with the True Principle.

chu bo'i rgyun zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ chu bo'i rgyun ni chu rgyun 'bab pa ste de bzhin du rgyun mi 'chad pa'o/ / mar me'i rtse mo ni mar me'i 'od kyi rtse mo ste de'i rgyun bzhin du'o/ / rtag tu ni rgyun mi 'chad par ro/ / de nyid rnal 'byor ni lhan cig skyes pa'i dga' ba'i rnal 'byor te/ des nyin mtshan du gnas par bya ba'o/ / nges par de ltar gnas par gyur na tshe 'di nyid la byang chub 'grub par 'gyur ro zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

nadīsrotaḥ (river’s current): Refers to the uninterrupted flow like that of a river. dīpajyotiḥ (light of a lamp): Refers to the rays of light from the flame of a lamp. satataṃ (always): Means uninterruptedly, as the flow of the river and the rays of light. tattvayogena (at one with the True Principle): Means at one with the Innate Joy. Remain at one with that, day and night. The intent is that by abiding in this manner, enlightenment is definitely attained in this very life.
yoginīcakro nāma mahāyoginīnāṃ melāpakapaṭalo 'ṣṭamaḥ
rnal 'byor ma'i 'khor lo zhes bya ba 'du ba'i le'u ste brgyad pa'o// //
Thus the Eighth, known as the Circle of the Yoginī, the chapter regarding the assembly of the great Yoginīs.
rnal 'byor ma ni bdag med ma la sogs pa'o/ / de dag dang 'du ba ni 'du ba ste gzhal yas khang dang lhan cig skyes pa'i dga' bar ro/ / de gsal bar byed pa'i le'u la yang de skad ces bya'o/ /

mahāyoginīnaṃ (of the great Yoginīs): The Yoginīs are Nairātmyā and the others. melāpakaḥ (assembly): Refers to meeting place, within the secret inner chamber and in the Innate Joy. This eighth chapter which explains that is thus known.
dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i dka' 'grel rnal 'byor rin po che'i phreng ba las le'u brgyad pa'i 'grel ba'o// //
Thus ends the eighth chapter of the Hevajra Pañjikā known as the Yogaratnamālā.

d.crumb: rnam par dag pa'i le'u

f.d: rnam par dag pa'i le'u

d.crumb: CHAPTER 9. Purification

f.d: CHAPTER 9. Purification
ataḥ paraṃ viśuddhipaṭalaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ /
de nas mchog tu rnam par dag pa'i le'u bshad par bya'o/ /
Now I shall expound the chapter regarding Purification.

rnam par dag pa'i le'u zhes bya ba la 'dis rnam par dag par byed pas na rnam par dag pa ste/ gang gis srid pa thams cad skyon dang bral bar 'gyur ba de ni rnam par dag pa'o/ / de gsal bar byed pa'i le'u la yang rnam par dag pa'i le'u zhes bya ba'o/ /

viśuddhipaṭalaṃ (chapter on Purification): Purification is so called because it purifies. The chapter on Purification is the chapter which deals with purification by which all phenomenal things become undefiled.
sarveṣāṃ khalu vastūnāṃ viśuddhis tathatā smṛtā || paścād ekaikabhedena devatānān tu kathyate || (1)
nges par dngos po thams cad kyi/ / dag pa de bzhin nyid du brjod/ / phyi nas re re'i dbye ba yis/ / lha rnams kyi ni brjod par bya/ /
Thusness is known as the purification of all things that exist. Further, the purification of each one of the deities is individually explained.

dngos po thams cad la khyab pa ni rnam par dag pa ste/ de bzhin nyid ces bya ba chos thams cad kyi stong pa nyid do/ / brjod ces bya ba ni le'u brgyad par bstan pa'o/ / phyi nas zhes bya ba ni da ltar ro/ / lha rnams zhes bya ba ni rdo rje'i gau rI la sogs pa'o/ /

sarveṣāṃ (of all): Refers to the purification of all phenomenal manifestations. tathatā (Thusness is known): Thusness is known as the Voidness of All Natures. smṛtā (is known): Refers to the explanation found in the eighth chapter (1.8). paścāt (further): Means now in this chapter. devatānāṃ (of the deities): Means of Vajra, Gaurī and the other yoginīs.
ji ltar ma dag pa ji lta bu zhig ji ltar rnam par dag par byed ce na/ skye mched drug ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
How are all things that exist impure and how are they to be purified?
ṣaḍindriyaṃ pañcaskandhaṃ ṣaḍāyatanaṃ pañcabhūtaṃ || svabhāvena viśuddham {apy} ajñānakleśair āvṛtaṃ || (2)
phung po lnga dang dbang po drug / skye mched drug dang 'byung chen lnga/ / rang bzhin gyis ni rnam par dag / nyon mongs shes bya'i sgrib sbyang bya/ /

Although the six sense organs, their six objects, the Aggregate of the Five Components of Phenomenal Awareness and the five elements are by their intrinsic nature pure, they are veiled by ignorance and afflictions.

rang bzhin gyis ni zhes bya ba ni de bzhin nyid kyi rang bzhin gyis so/ / gal te dag pa zhig yin na ci'i phyir dag ce na/ nyon mongs zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ shes bya'i sgrib pa ni rang bzhin yongs su mi shes pa ste/ mi shes pa'i sgrib pa zhes bya ba'o/ / nyon mongs pa ni 'dod chags la sogs pa ste/ nyon mongs pa'i sgrib pa'o/ / des bsgribs pa ni bkab pa'o/ / de'i phyir rnam par dag par byed do/ /

svabhāvena (by their intrinsic nature): Means by the very nature of Thusness. If all things are already pure, then what is the need for purifying? [In answer it is said:] ajñānaṃ (ignorance): Here ignorance means not knowing the intrinsic nature of things and refers to the veil that obscures the nature of the Objects experienced (jñeyāvaraṇa). kleśaḥ (afflictions): The veils of afflictions (kleśāvaraṇa) are passion and the other emotions. āvṛtaṃ (veiled): Veiled by ignorance and afflictions means obscured by them. It is for this reason that purification is necessary.
de bzhin nyid kyi bdag nyid can gyi dag pa de ji lta bu zhig ce na/ rang rig bdag nyid ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
The nature of the purification by Thusness is said by:
svasaṃvedyātmikā śuddhir nānaśuddhyā vimucyate || viṣayaśuddhabhāvatvāt svasaṃvedyaṃ paraṃ sukhaṃ || (3)
rang rig bdag nyid dag pa nyid/ / dag pa gzhan gyis rnam grol min/ / yul gyi dngos po dag pa'i phyir/ / rang gis rig pa'i bde ba mchog /

Only that purification which is essentially one Of direct personal experience and no other method of purification liberates. From the pure nature of the objects of experience arises this direct personal experience which is the highest bliss.

sngar ngas le'u brgyad par bstan pa yin te/ dag pa gzhan gyis rnam grol min/ / zhes bya bar dgongs so/ / yul gyi dngos po zhes bya ba la/ gzugs la sogs pa rnams kyi rang rig pa'i bde ba mchog tu khyad par can du 'gyur ba'i dag pa'o/ /

nānyaśuddhyā vimucyate (no other method of purification liberates): The purification by Thusness and the way it is to be performed have previously been explained in the Eighth chapter (1.8). The intent is that no other method of purification than this method of purification by direct personal experience can purify. viṣayāḥ (objects): Refers to form and the other [objects of the experience]. svasaṃvedyaṃ paraṃ sukham (direct personal experience is the highest bliss): Means the bliss of direct personal experience is the finest purification.
rūpaviṣayādi ye 'py anye pratibhāsante hi yoginaḥ || sarve te śuddhabhāvā hi yasmād budddhamayaṃ jagat || (4)
gzugs la sogs pa'i yul rnams dang / / gzhan yang rnal 'byor pas mthong ba/ / dngos po de kun dag pa ste/ / 'di ltar 'gro ba sangs rgyas bdag /
For the yogī, form and whatever other objects of experience that manifest, are all pure in nature, for the world is pervaded by the Enlightened Nature.

gzhan yang zhes bya ba ni phyi rol gyi gzugs la sogs pa'o/ / dngos po de kun dag pa ste/ /zhes bya ba ni dngos po rnams rang bzhin gyis dag pa'o/ / ji lta bu zhe na/ sangs rgyas bdag ces bya ba gsungs te/ lhan cig skyes pa'i bdag nyid can no/ / 'gro ba ni brtan pa dang g.yo ba'o/ /

ye ’py anye (whatever other): Refers to the external forms and other [objects of the experience]. śuddhabhāvā (pure in nature): Means pure by their intrinsic nature. How this is so is said by: yasmād buddhamayaṃ jagat (because the world is pervaded by the Enlightened Nature): Means the world of moving and motionless things is pervaded by the Innate.
he bhagavan ke te 'viśuddhāḥ / bhagavān āha / rūpādayaḥ / kasmāt / grāhyagrāhakabhāvāt / Vajragarbha āha / ke te grāhyagrāhakāś ceti / (5)

kye bcom ldan 'das rnam par ma dag pa gang lags/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ gzugs la sogs pa'o/ / de ci'i slad du zhe na/ gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i dngos po'i phyir ro/ / rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ kye bcom ldan 'das gzung ba dang 'dzin pa yang gang lags/

Vajragarbha asked: O Bhagavān, what are these unpurified things? Bhagavān replied: Form and the others. Vajragarbha asked: How so? Bhagavān answered: Because of the existence of the subject and object. Vajragarbha asked: What are the subjects and objects?
da ni kye bcom ldan 'das zhes bya ba la sogs pas lha'i rnam par dag pa zhus pa yin no/ /
Here with ‘O Bhagavān etc. Vajragarbha asks regarding the purification of the deities.

bhagavān āha / cakṣuṣā gṛhyate rūpaṃ śabdaḥ karṇena śrūyate || gandhaṃ nāsikayā veti jihvayā svādanaṃ viduḥ || (6) kāyena spṛśyate vastu manaḥ sukhādim āpnute || sevitavyā ime sevyā nirviṣīkṛtya śuddhitaḥ || (7)

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal ba/ / mig gis gzugs ni gzung bar bya/ / sgra ni rna bas mnyan par bya/ / dri ni sna yis tshor bar bya/ / lce yis ro ni myang bar bya/ / dngos po lus kyis reg par bya/ / yid kyis bde sogs thob pa ni/ / dag pas dug med byas nas ni/ / bsten bya 'di dag bsten pa nyid/ /

Bhagavān replied: Form is perceived by the eye; sound is heard by the ear; smell is experienced by the nose; taste is experienced by the tongue; objects are felt by the body and the mind experiences pleasure etc. These, which are worthy of adoration, should be served, rendering them non-substantial through purification.

mig ces bya ba la sogs pa la gzung bar bya zhes bya ba ni/ yongs su spyad par bya ba'o/ / myong bar bya zhes bya ba ni yongs su spyod pa'o/ / lce yis zhes bya ba ni ro'o/ / thob par zhes bya ba ni gzung bar bya ba'o/ / gal te dag pa ma yin na bsten par bya ba ma yin no zhe na/ de'i phyir bsten bya 'di dag ces bya ba gsungs te/ bsten bya ni bsten par bya ba'o/ /

cakṣuṣā gṛhyate (perceived by the eye): Perceived by the eye means distinguished, known or discriminated. svādanaṃ (taste): Means flavours. āpnute (experiences): Means feels. If the senses are not impure should not they be served? This is clarified by: sevitavyā ityādi (should be served etc.): They should be served because they are worthy of adoration.
'di dag dug med par ji ltar bya zhe na/
How they are to be rendered non-substantial is said by:

rūpaskandhe bhaved Vajrā Gaurī vedanāyāṃ smṛtā || saṃjñāyāṃ Vāriyoginī saṃskāre Vajraḍākinī || (8) vijñānaskandharūpeṇa sthitā Nairātmyayoginī || sadā tāsāṃ viśuddhyā vai sidhyanti tattvayoginaḥ || adhyātmapuṭaṃ / (9) paścād bāhyapuṭaṃ vakṣye • aparagauryādiyoginyaḥ / aiśānyāṃ Pukkasī khyātā • agnau Śavarī kīrtitā || nairṛtye sthāpya Caṇḍālīṃ vāyave Ḍombinī sthitā || (10) indre Gaurī yame Caurī Vetālī vāruṇadiśi || kauvere Ghasmarī caiva • adhastād Bhūcarī smṛtā || (11) ūrdhvaṃ ca Khecarī proktā • utpattikramapakṣataḥ || bhavanirvāṇasvabhāvena sthitāv etau dvidevate || (12)

gzugs phung rdo rje ma yin te/ / tshor ba la yang dkar mor brjod/ / 'du shes chu yi rnal 'byor ma/ / 'du byed rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma/ / rnam shes phung po'i tshul gyis ni/ / bdag med rnal 'byor ma gnas so/ / rtag tu 'di dag rnam dag pas/ / de nyid rnal 'byor pas 'grub 'gyur/ / nang gi 'phar ma la'o/ / de nas phyi yi 'phar ma bshad/ / dbang ldan du ni puk+ka sI/ / mer ni de bzhin ri khrod ma/ / bden bral gdol pa mo bzhag cing / / rlung du g.yung mo rnam par bzhag / phyi nas lha mo dkar mo sogs/ / dbang dkar gshin rjer chom rkun ma/ / chu bdag phyogs su ro langs ma/ / lus ngan por ni g+hasma rI/ / 'og tu sa spyod ma zhes brjod/ / steng du mkha' spyod ma zhes bshad/ / bskyed pa'i rim pa nyid kyi phyogs/ / srid dang zhi ba'i rang bzhin gyis/ / lha mo 'di gnyis rnam par gnas/ /

Vajrā is in the the Form component (rūpaskandha) of the Aggregate of the Five Components of Phenomenal Awareness; Gaurī is known to be in the the Sensation component (vedanāskandha); Vāriyoginī is in the Conceptualising component (saṃjñāskandha); Vajraḍākinī is in the component of the Imprint of Past Actions (saṃskāraskandha) and Nairātmyayoginī is in the component of the Awareness of Phenomena (vijñānaskandha). By the constant purification of these Yoginīs, the yogis devoted to the True Principle surely attain their goal. Such is the inner enclosure of the maṇḍala. Further, I shall explain the external enclosure consisting of the ‘other’ Gaurī and the remaining Yoginīs. Pukkasī is said to be in the north-east; Śavarī is famed to be in the south-east; Caṇḍālī is located in the south-west; Ḍombī is located in the north-west. Gaurī is in the east; Caurī in the south; Vetālī in the west and Ghasmarī in the north. Bhūcarī is below and Khecarī is above and these two deities are of the nature of the Bound Existence and the Release respectively. Such is the view according to the Process of Generation.

gzugs phung zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rdo rje ma ni gzugs kyi phung po rnam par dag pa'o zhes bya ba'i don to/ / de nyid kyi phyir de nyid rnal 'byor pas zhes gsungs pa yin no/ / dbang ldan du ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa ni phyi rol gyi rim pa nas brtsams pa'o/ / gal te nang gi rim par yang gau rI brjod pa ma yin nam/ phyi rol gyi rim par yang de brjod pa ni ji lta bu zhe na/ gzhan yang lha mo gau rI la sogs pa zhes bya ba gsungs te/ ming tsam 'dra ba'i gau rI gzhan zhig go/ / lha mo 'di gnyis zhes bya ba ni lha mo 'di gnyis zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

rūpaskandhe ityādi (Form component etc.): The intent is that the Form component must be understood as purified by the Yoginī Vajrā. Therefore it is said: tattvayoginaḥ (the yogis devoted to the True Principle). aiśānyāṃ ityādi (north-east etc.): Beginning with north-east the outer enclosure is described. In the inner enclosure the name of the Yoginī Gaurī is mentioned. How is it that the same name is also mentioned in the context of the outer enclosure? This is clarified by: apara (other): This ‘other’ Gaurī is only similar in name to the Gaurī of the inner enclosure. dvidevate (the two deities): Refers to the two goddesses Khecarī and Bhūcarī.
gnas kyi dbye ba ni lha mo rnams kyi dbye ba shes par bya ba'i phyir bstan to/ / yang 'di dag gi rnam par dag pa ni ma bstan pa de bstan pa'i phyir/
In order to understand the different functions of the goddesses their respective locations have been mentioned. Now, the purified nature of these goddesses is explained by:

rūpe Gaurī samākhyātā śabde Caurī prakīrtitā || Vetālī gandhabhāge ca rase Ghasmarī kīrtitā || (13) sparśe ca Bhūcarī khyātā Khecarī dharmadhātutaḥ || sadā hy āsāṃ viśuddhyā tu sidhyanti tattvayoginaḥ || (14)

gzugs la dkar mo rtag tu bshad/ / sgra la chom rkun ma rab grags/ / dri yi cha la ro langs ma/ / ro la g+hasma rI rab grags/ / reg la sa spyod ma zhes bshad/ / chos kyi dbyings la mkha' spyod ma/ / rtag tu 'di dag rnam dag pas/ / de nyid rnal 'byor pas 'grub 'gyur/ /

Gaurī is said to be located in form; Caurī is proclaimed to be in sound; Vetālī is in smell; Ghasmarī is famed to be in flavour, Bhūcarī is said to be in touch and Khecarī in the Essence of Nature which is the mind. By the constant purification of these Yoginīs, the yogis devoted to the True Principle will attain their goal.
gzugs la gau rI zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ de nyid rnal 'byor pas zhes bya ba lha'i de kho na nyid kyi rnal 'byor pa'o/ /
tattvayoginaḥ (yogis devoted to the True Principle): Refers to the yogīs devoted to the essential principle of these deities.
bhujānāṃ śūnyatā śuddhiś caraṇā māraśuddhitaḥ || mukhāny aṣṭavimokṣeṇa netraśuddhis trivajriṇāṃ || (15)
phyag gi dag pa stong pa nyid/ / bdud dag pa las zhabs rnams nyid/ / rnam thar brgyad kyis zhal rnams nyid/ / rdo rje gsum gyis dag pa'i spyan/ /

The arms symbolise the purification of Voidness; the feet the purification of the Māras; the faces the purification of the Eight Releases (aṣṭavimokṣāḥ) and the eyes the purification of the three Vajrīs.

phyag gi zhes bya ba la sogs pa ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje phyag bcu drug pa'i phyag rnams kyi rnam par dag pa gsungs pa yin te/ phyag bcu drug po rnams kyi de kho na nyid ni stong pa nyid bcu drug ste/ 'di lta ste nang stong pa nyid dang / phyi stong pa nyid dang / phyi nang stong pa nyid dang / chen po stong pa nyid dang / stong pa nyid stong pa nyid dang / don dam pa stong pa nyid dang / 'dus byas stong pa nyid dang / 'dus ma byas stong pa nyid dang / mtha' las 'das pa stong pa nyid dang / thog ma dang tha ma med pa stong pa nyid dang / dor ba med pa stong pa nyid dang / rang bzhin stong pa nyid dang / rang gi mtshan nyid stong pa nyid dang / chos thams cad stong pa nyid dang / dngos po med pa stong pa nyid dang / dngos po med pa'i ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid de 'di dag kho na phyag tu byas pa'o/ / zhabs rnams ni bdud rnams bcom pa'i rnam par dag pa ste/ phung po'i bdud dang / nyon mongs pa'i bdud dang / 'chi bdag gi bdud dang / lha'i bu'i bdud ces bya ba'o/ / zhal rnams zhes bya ba ni zhal rnams so/ / rdo rje gsum zhes bya ba ni sku dang gsung dang thugs rdo rje'o/ /

bhujānāṃ (the arms): The essential principle of the sixteen arms are the sixteen Voids. These sixteen Voids are: Inner. Voidness, External Voidness, Internal and External Voidness, Great Voidness, Voidness of Voidness, Supreme Voidness, Refined Voidness, Unrefined Voidness, Extreme Voidness, Supreme Voidness without precedent, Undispersed Voidness, Self-characterised Voidness, Primordial Voidness, Voidness of all natures, Voidness of non-existence and Voidness of essential nonexistence. The arms signify these Voids is the intent. caraṇā māraviśudditaḥ (the feet the purification of the Māras): The four feet signify the destruction which is the purification of the four Māras. The four Māras are the Māra of the Aggregate of Personality, the Māra of Afflictions, the Māra of Death and the Māra of the Son of the Deity. mukhāni (the faces): Means by the eight faces. trivajriṇām (of the three Vajrīs): Means by the Body, Speech and Mind.
pṛthivī Pukkasī khyātā • abdhātuḥ Śavarī smṛtā || tejaś Caṇḍāliṇī jñeyā vāyur Ḍombī prakīrtitā || (16)
sa ni buk+ka sI zhes bshad/ / chu khams rngon pa mo zhes brjod/ / me ni gtum mor shes par bya/ / rlung ni g.yung mor rab tu grags/ /
Pukkasī is said to be the Earth element; Śavarī is known to be the Water element; Caṇḍālī is known to be the Fire element and Ḍombī is proclaimed to be the Air element.
sa ni zhes bya ba la sogs pas ni sa la sogs pa rnams kyi rnam par dag pa bstan te/ puk+ka sI la sogs pa'o zhes bya ba'i don to/ /
pṛthivī ityādi (Earth element etc.): The purification of Earth and the other elements is by means of Pukkasī and others is the intent.

dveṣākhyāpitā Nairātmyā rāga- ca Vāriyoginī || īrṣyā ca Vajraḍākinī paiśunyaṃ Guptagaurikā || (17) mogho Vajrā tathā khyātā dveṣādīnāṃ tu śodhanaṃ || etena śodhyate skandham utpattikramapakṣataḥ || (18)

zhe sdang zhes bshad rdo rje ma/ / 'dod chags chu yi rnal 'byor ma/ / phrag dog rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma/ / ser sna gsang ba'i dkar mo nyid/ / gti mug de bzhin rdo rjer bshad/ / zhe sdang la sogs rnam spyod pa/ / bskyed pa'i rim pa'i phyogs las ni/ / 'dis ni phung po sbyang bar bya/ /

Nairātmyā is proclaimed to be Wrath; Vāriyoginī to be Passion; Vajraḍākinī to be Envy; Gaurī of the inner enclosure to be Malignancy and Vajrā to be Delusion. Such is the purification of Wrath and so on. In the Process of Generation the Aggregate is purified by these five goddesses.

'dis ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ phung po zhes bya ba ni phung po la sogs pa'o/ / de ltar re zhig bskyed pa'i rim pa'i phyogs kyi rnam par dag pa bstan nas/ yang rdzogs pa'i rim pa'i phyogs la de nyid ro gcig pa'i rnam par dag pa bstan pa'i phyir/

skandhaṃ (the Aggregate): Here ‘Aggregate’ refers to the Aggregate of the Five Components of Phenomenal Awareness and other aggregates. So far the purification according to the view of the Process of Generation has been explained. Now the one essential purification according to the Process of Completion is expressed by:
yena tu yena badhyate lokas tena tu tena tu bandhanaṃ muñcet || loko muhyati vetti na tattvaṃ tattvavivarjitaḥ siddhiṃ na lapsyet ||
gang dang gang gis 'jig rten 'ching 'gyur ba/ / de dang des ni 'ching ba las grol te/ / de nyid mi shes 'jig rten mi grol zhing / / de nyid rnam spangs dngos grub rnyed mi 'gyur/ /

It is by those very things which bind mankind that their bondage is released. Men are deluded by not knowing the True Principle, and those who are devoid of the True Principle cannot achieve the accomplishment.

gang dang gang gis zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ gzugs la sogs pa gang gis 'jig rten 'ching bar 'gyur ba de nyid kyis bdag nyid grol bar bya'o/ / lha'i rnam pa'i bsgom pa yang mi bya'o/ / gal te de dang des grol bar 'gyur ba nyid yin na 'jig rten na bcings pa nyid du 'gyur ba ji lta bu zhe na/ 'jig rten rnams rmongs par gyur pas de nyid las 'di bden pa la mngon par zhen pa nyid kyis de nyid mi shes pa ste/ de rnams kyi ma skyes pa'i de kho na nyid de ma rtogs pa'o/ / de nyid rnam spangs zhes bya ba ni skye ba med pa'i bsgom pa dang bral ba zhes so/ / dngos grub ni rdo rje 'chang gi go 'phang ste/ rnyed par mi 'gyur ro zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ /

yena tu yena (by those very things): Things refers to forms and so on by which all men are bound. It is by those very things and not by the emanation of the forms of the deities etc. that I [Vajradhara] liberate myself. If all men are liberated by those very things which bind, then how is it that men are bound? This is answered by: loko muhyati vetti na tattvaṃ (men are deluded by not knowing the True Principle): Because of their firm belief in the reality of the external forms and so on they do not know the True Principle of the non-arising nature of the external forms etc. tattvavivarjitaḥ (devoid of the True Principle): Refers to those who do not know this principle. siddhiṃ (accomplishment): Refers to the state of Vajradhara which is not attainable by those who lack the conception of this principle of nonarising.
tasmāt / (19) gandha na śabda na rūpaṃ naiva rasa na ca cittaviśuddhiḥ || sparśa na dharma na sarvaviśuddhyā śuddhasahāva jago jaga manye || (20)
de phyir dri med sgra med gzugs nyid med/ / ro dang sems kyi rnam par dag pa med/ / reg med chos med thams cad rnam par dag / rang bzhin dag pa'i 'gro la 'gro bar shes/ /
Thus, no smell, no sound, no form, no taste, no purification of mind, no touch and no nature, for by the purification of all things I experience an intrinsically pure world.

gang gi phyir de de ltar na de'i phyir zhes bya ba rgyu des dri la sogs pa don dam pa nyid du yod par mi 'gyur ro zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ / sems kyi rnam par dag pa yang tha dad du bya ba ma yin te/ de'i skye ba med pa'i ngo bo nyid kyi phyir ro/ / thams cad rnam par dag ces pa ni 'gro ba thams cad rnam par dag pa'o/ / gang gis 'gro ba rnam par dag ce na/ rnam par dag ces bya ba gsungs te/ chos thams cad kyi stong pa nyid kyi rnam par dag pa'o/ / de'i phyir rang bzhin dag pa'i 'gro la zhes so/ / yang de lta bu sus shes she na/ 'gro bar zhes bya ba gsungs te/ shes par gyur na zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

tasmāt (thus): By the reasoning of the previous verse smell and so on in terms of the supreme truth do not exist is the intent. na cittaviśuddhiḥ (no purification of mind): There is no necessity even to separately perform the purification of the mind because of it’s non-arising nature. sarvaviśuddhyā (by the purification of all things): By this purification the world is essentially pure. By means of what is this purification of all things achieved? It is by means of the purification by the Voidness of All Natures that was previously mentioned. The knower of such a pure world says: jaga manye (I experience ... the world): Means I know such a pure world.
viśuddhipaṭalo navamaḥ ||
rnam par dag pa'i le'u ste dgu ba'o// //
Thus the Ninth, the chapter regarding Purification.
dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i dka' 'grel rnal 'byor rin po che'i phreng ba las rnam par dag pa'i le'u'i 'grel pa ste dgu pa'o// //
Thus ends the Ninth, the chapter regarding Purification, of the Hevajra Pañjikā known as the Yogaratnamālā.

d.crumb: dbang bskur ba gsal bar byed pa'i le'u

f.d: dbang bskur ba gsal bar byed pa'i le'u

d.crumb: CHAPTER 10. Consecration

f.d: CHAPTER 10. Consecration
da ni slob ma mngon par dbang bskur ba sbyin par bya ba yin la/ de yang bris pa'i dkyil 'khor nyid du sbyin pa yin pas/ de'i phyir
athātaḥ saṃpravakṣyāmi maṇḍalasya yathākramaṃ || śiṣyo 'bhiṣicyate yena vidhiś cāpi pravakṣyate || (1)
de nas ji ltar dkyil 'khor gyi/ / rim pa yang dag rab tu bshad/ / gang gis slob ma dbang bskur ba'i/ / cho ga'ang rab tu bshad par bya/ /
Now I shall explain the correct anrangement of the maṇḍala by which the disciple is consecrated and shall also explain the rules for the performance of consecration.

de nas ji ltar zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rim pa yang dag ces bya ba ni phyin ci ma log pa yin pa'i cho ga ste/ cho ga gang gis slob ma dbang bskur bar byed pa de'i cho ga yang dag par rab tu bshad do zhes bya bar sbyar ro/ /

yathākramam (correct arrangement): Means the precise arrangement which leaves no room for doubt. vidhiś cāpi pravakṣyate (and shall also explain the rules for the performance): The rules which are explained here are the correct rules for the consecration of the disciple.
vasudhāṃ śodhayed yogī prathamaṃ devatātmakaḥ || HŪṂ-vajrīkṛtya yatnena paścān maṇḍalam ālikhet || (2)
dang por lha yi bdag nyid kyi/ / rnal 'byor pas ni nor 'dzin sbyang / / 'bad pas hU~M las rdo rje can/ / byas te phyi nas dkyil 'khor pri/ /
The yogī, who in essence is the deity, should first purify the site of the consecration. After attentively performing the Hūṃvajrī rite, he should then draw the maṇḍala.

nor 'dzin zhes bya ba ni sa gzhi'o/ / lha'i bdag nyid kyi zhes bya ba ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje phyag gnyis pa'i rnal 'byor dang ldan pas so/ / hU~M las rdo rje can zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ stong pa nyid kyi rnam par bsgoms nas ra~M las nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor/ de'i steng du hU~M las sna tshogs rdo rje'o/ / de las rdo rje'i rang bzhin gyi sa gzhi dang / rdo rje ra ba dang / gur dang de'i phyi rol du rdo rje me 'bar bar bsams nas/ oM rak+Sha rak+Sha hU~M hU~M hU~M phaT ces bya bas byin gyis brlabs nas dkyil 'khor bri bar bya'o/ /

vasudhāṃ (site): Refers to the ground at the consecration site. devatātmakaḥ (in essence is the deity): Refers to the yogī who identifies himself as being the two-armed Hevajra. hūṃvajrīkṛtya (after ... performing the Hūṃvajrī rite): This is performed by first conceiving Voidness; then the Solar Maṇḍala is visualised manifesting from the seed-syllable raṃ; above that, from the seed-syllable hūṃ emanate a crossed vajra. Utilising this crossed vajra emanate the vajra floor, the vajra balustrade and the vajra canopy. Then emanate a circle of vajra fire surrounding this chamber. Empower this vajra chamber with oṃ rakṣa rakṣa hum hum hum phaṭ svāhā. Let the maṇḍala be drawn after that.
udyāne vijane deśe bodhisattvagṛheṣu ca || maṇḍalāgāramadhye ca vartayen maṇḍalaṃ varaṃ || (3)
tshal dang skye bo med gnas dang / / byang chub sems dpa'i khyim dang ni/ / dkyil 'khor khang pa'i nang du yang / / dkyil 'khor dam pa rab tu bzhengs/ /
The excellent maṇḍala should be constructed in a garden or an isolated place or the abodes of the Bodhisattvas or within the inner sanctum of a temple.
byang chub sems dpa' ni phyag na rdo rje la sogs pa'o/ /
bodhisattvagṛheṣu (abodes of Bodhisattvas): The Bodhisattvas are Vajrapāṇi and others.
divyena rajolekhena • athavā madhyamena tu || pañcaratnamayaiś cūrṇair athavā taṇḍulādibhiḥ || (4) trihastaṃ maṇḍalaṃ kāryaṃ trayāṅguṣṭhādhikan tataḥ ||

rdul tshon dam pa'i tshon dang ni/ / yang na 'bring po nyid kyis te/ / rin chen lnga yi phye ma'am/ / yang na 'bras la sogs pas so/ / de nas dkyil 'khor khru gsum dang / / mthe bong gsum ni lhag par bya/ /

The maṇḍala appropriate is three cubits and three thumb widths long and is drawn with divine powder or with the powder of medium quality made from the five gems or else with the powder made from rice grains etc.
khru gsum zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ mthe bo gsum gyis lhag pa zhes bya ba'i don te/ 'di ni dkyil 'khor mdor bstan pa'o/ / rgyas par ni 'og nas 'chad par 'gyur ro/ /

trihastam ityādi (three cubits etc.): Means it is three cubits plus three thumb widths in length. So far the simple description of the maṇḍala has been given. The instructions regarding the use of the maṇḍala will be elucidated later.
dbang bskur ba rab tu brjod par bya ba'i phyir/
In order to reveal the consecration it is said:
vidyā tatra praveṣṭavyā divyā pañcakulodbhavā || (5) athavā yā kāyathālabdhā ṣoḍaśābdā tathaiva ca ||
der ni rigs lnga las byung ba'i/ / rig ma bzang mo rnam par gzhug / yang na ji ltar gang rnyed de/ / de ltar bcu drug lon pa nyid/ /
A divine consort who originates from [one of] the Five Families must be introduced into this maṇḍala. Or else, any available sixteen year-old girl must be introduced.

rig ma zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ bzang mo zhes bya ba ni mchog tu gyur pa'o/ / yang na zhes bya ba ni nus pa med na'o/ / de'i tshe ni ji ltar rnyed pa'i lang tsho gtsor gyur pa gzhug par bya ba ste/ rnal 'byor ma'i tshul 'di ni 'dod chags chen po'i tshul yin pas so/ / 'dis ni slob ma'i mtshan nyid mdor bstan to/ /

divyā (divine): Means the best of consorts. athavā (or else): Means if it is not possible to find a divine consort then introduce any available youthful girl. Since this Yoginī system of practice is one which utilises great passion, the youthful characteristics of the female disciple are emphasised.
da ni gsang ba'i dbang bskur ba mdor bstan pa'i phyir/
Now the Secret Consecration is briefly described.

tāvad dhi sevyate mudrā yāvac chukravatī bhavet || (6) mudrāyāś ca mukhaṃ baddhvā upāyasya mukhaṃ tathā || sevayā tatra yad bhūtaṃ śiṣyavaktre nipātayet || (7) kāritavyaṃ ca tatraiva samarasaṃ śiṣyagocaraṃ ||

ji srid khu ba ldan gyur pa/ / de srid phyag rgya bsten par bya/ / phyag rgya'i gdong ni bcing ba dang / / thabs kyi gdong yang de bzhin no/ / bsten pa de las gang byung ba/ / slob ma'i khar ni btung bar bya/ / ro mnyam slob ma'i spyod yul nyid/ / de nyid la yang bya bar bya/ /

The consort is served until her sexual fluids flow. Then covering the face of the consort as well as that of the ‘Means’, drop the fluid which has arisen from the service into the mouth of the disciple. There, with that dropping the Flavour of Essential Similarity should be activated within the view of the disciple.

ji srid ces bya ba la sogs pa ste/ phyag rgya'i gdong yang zhes bya ba ni slob ma'i gdong ngo / / thabs kyi zhes bya ba ni slob ma'i'o/ / bya bar bya zhes bya ba la sogs pa de nyid la yang zhes bya ba ni shes rab la'o/ / ro mnyam zhes bya ba ni shes rab kyi dbang bskur ba'o/ / slob ma'i spyod yul zhes bya ba ni slob ma'i gdong g.yogs dgrol ba'o/ /

mudrāyāḥ (of the consort): Means of the female disciple. upāyasya (of the ‘Means’): Means of the male disciple. kāritavyam ityādi (should be activated etc.): In this context ‘there’ means in the Wisdom consort. samarasaṃ (the Flavour of Essential Similarity): Points towards the Wisdom consecration. śiṣyagocaraṃ (within the view of the disciple): Means this is performed after uncovering the disciple’s face.
de dag gis cir 'gyur zhe na/
What occurs by this is said by:
svasaṃvedyād bhaved jñānaṃ svaparavittivarjitaṃ || (8) khasamaṃ virajaṃ śūnyaṃ bhāvābhāvātmakaṃ paraṃ || prajñopāyavyatimiśraṃ rāgārāgavimiśritaṃ || (9)

rang rig ye shes nyid du 'gyur/ / rang gzhan yang dag rig pa spangs/ / mkha' mnyam rdul bral stong pa nyid/ / dngos dang dngos med bdag nyid mchog / thabs dang shes rab shin tu 'dres/ / chags dang chags bral rnam par 'dres/ /

From direct personal experience arises this Knowledge, free of notions of self and other, space-like, undefiled, void, the essence of existence and non-existence and the supreme. This Knowledge is a blending of Wisdom and Means and a fusion of passion and the absence of passion.

rang rig ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ de lta bu nyid kyi ro mnyam pas rang rig ye shes nyid du 'gyur zhes bya'o/ / de khyad par ji lta bu can zhig ce na/ rang gzhan zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ bdag dang gzhan gyi char rnam par 'byed pa dang bral ba'o/ / mkha' mnyam zhes bya ba ni snang ba med pa nyid kyi phyir nam mkha' dang mnyam pa'o/ / nyon mongs pa med pa nyid kyi phyir rdul bral lo/ / spros pa las shin tu 'das pa'i phyir stong pa'o/ / dngos po ni 'byung ba'o/ / dngos po med pa ni 'gag pa'o/ / de dag gi bdag nyid can de skad ces bya'o/ /

svasaṃvedyāt (from direct personal experience): From the Flavour of Essential Similarity arises the Knowledge which is one of direct personal experience. The unique quality of this Knowledge is said by: svapara ityādi (self and other etc.): Means this Knowledge is devoid of the distinction between oneself and others. khasamaṃ (space-like): This Knowledge is space-like because it is devoid of appearances. virajaṃ (undefiled): This Knowledge is undefiled because it is free from afflictions. śūnya (Void): This Knowledge is characterised as voidness because it is beyond the differentiated world. bhāva (existence): Means the arisings or what is produced. abhāva (non-existence): Means destruction. ātmakaḥ (of the essence): Means this Knowledge is of the nature of both existence and non-existence.

mchog ces bya ba ni don dam pa'i shes rab bo/ / thabs kyi stong pa nyid ni shes rab bo/ / thabs ni snying rje chen po ste/ sems can thams cad la bdag nyid dang mnyam pa yongs su myong ba'o/ / de dag 'dres pa ni de dag gzugs gcig tu snang bar 'gyur ba'o/ / chags pa ni mchog tu dga' ba'o/ / chags pa dang bral ba ni dga' bral gyi dga' ba ste/ de dag 'dres par 'gyur ba'i rang bzhin no/ /

paraṃ (supreme): Means this Knowledge is of the nature of the supreme truth. prajñā (Wisdom): Refers to the Voidness of All Things (sarvadharmaśūnyatā). upāya (Means): Refers to Great Compassion which is the experience of being at one with all beings. vyatimiśraṃ (blending): Wisdom and Means are blended because they are experienced as one. rāga (passion): Here refers to the Refined Joy. arāga (absence of passion): Refers to the Joy of Cessation. vimiśritaṃ (fusion): This Knowledge is characterised as a fusion of passion and the absence of passion.
sa eva prāṇināṃ prāṇaḥ sa eva paramākṣaraḥ || sarvavyāpī sa evāsau sarvadehavyavasthitaḥ || (10) sa evāsau mahāprāṇaḥ sa evāsau jaganmayaḥ || bhāvābhāvau tadubhūtau anyāni yāni tāni ca || (11)

de nyid srog chags rnams kyi srog / de nyid yi ge dam pa nyid/ / de nyid 'gro ba'i bdag nyid de/ / de nyid thams cad khyab pa po/ / thams cad lus la rnam par gnas/ / dngos dang dngos med de las byung / / gzhan rnams gang rnams de rnams dang / /

This Knowledge is the very life-breath of living things and is the imperishable supreme. It is all-pervading and abides in all living bodies. It is truly the Great Life-breath and the World-pervader. Existence, non-existence and anything else whatsoever originate from it.

srog chags ni sems can no/ / de dag nyid ni srog ste de dag med na srog med pa'i phyir ro/ / yi ge mchog ni thog ma dang tha ma med pa chos kyi dbyings kyi gzugs can nyid kyi phyir ro/ / khyab pa po ni chos thams cad de'i rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir ro/ / thams cad lus la rnam par gnas/ /zhes bya ba ni srog chags rnams kyi lus la rnam par shes pa gnas pa'i phyir ro/ / de nyid las 'gro ba rnams 'byung bar 'gyur te/ de'i bdag nyid can gyi las dang nyon mongs pa las 'byung ba'i phyir zhes bstan pa'i phyir ro/ / dngos dang dngos med ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ dngos po ni lus so/ / dngos po med pa ni tshor ba la sogs pa'o/ / gzhan dang zhes bya ba ni dbang po drug go/ / gang rnams de rnams zhes bya ba ni phyi rol gyi dngos po brtan pa dang g.yo ba la sogs pa'o/ /

prāṇināṃ (of living beings): Means of living beings. prāṇa (life-breath): This life-breath is their very life because without it there is no life. paramākṣara (imperishable supreme): This Knowledge is eternal because it is of the nature of the Essence of Nature. sarvavyāpī (all-pervading): This Knowledge is all-pervading because it is at one with all things. sarvadehevyavasthitaḥ (abides in all living bodies): It abides in all living beings because beings are regulated. In this manner the phenomenal world itself arises from this consciousness. Since the body arises from one’s own karmic afflictions, it is said: bhāva (existence): Refers to the physical body. abhāva (non-existence): Refers to sensation and the other components of phenomenal awareness. anyāni (anything else): Refers to the six sense organs. yāni tāni (whatsoever): Refers to external objects, whether moving, motionless etc.
mu stegs pa rnams kyis kyang de nyid la bdag la sogs pa nyid du yongs su brtags pa yin zhes rab tu bsgrub pa'i phyir/
In order to show that it is this Knowledge that the non-Buddhists conceived of as soul and other such concepts, it is said:
sarvaṃ vijñānarūpaṃ ca puruṣaḥ purāṇa īśvaro || ātmā jīvaṃ ca sattvaṃ ca kālaḥ puḍgala eva ca || sarvabhāvasvabhāvo 'sau māyārūpī ca saṃsthitaḥ || (12)

rnam par shes pa kun gyi tshul/ / skyes bu sngon rabs dbang phyug dang / / bdag dang gso ba sems can dang / / dus dang gang zag nyid dang ni/ / dngos po kun gyi rang bzhin 'di/ / sgyu ma'i gzugs kyis yang dag gnas/ /

The concepts of other traditions such as ‘everything is consciousness in essence’, ‘primordial man’, ‘supreme being’, ‘soul’, ‘individual self’, ‘pure essence’, ‘time’ and ‘atomic entity’, all originate from this Knowledge. This Knowledge is the intrinsic nature of all there is and it also exists as illusory forms.

rnam par shes pa kun gyi gzugs/ /zhes bya ba gsungs so/ / rnam par shes pa'i gzugs ni rig byed kyi mtha' smra ba rnams kyi'o/ / sems kyi gzugs can gyi skyes bu zhes bya ba ni grangs can gyi'o/ / gang zag ces bya ba ni gang zag tu smra ba rnams kyi'o/ / 'gro ba'i byed pa po rtag pa'i dbang phyug ces bya ba ni zhi ba'i grub pa'i mtha' smra ba rnams kyi'o/ / bdag nyid nye bar skye bar 'gyur/ 'tsho bar 'gyur/ 'chi bar 'gyur/ bcing bar 'gyur/ 'gro bar 'gyur zhes bya ba ni bdag tu smra ba rnams kyi'o/ / srog ces bya ba ni phyogs kyi gos can rnams kyi'o/ / sems can zhes bya ba ni sems can du smra ba rnams kyi'o/ / dus zhes bya ba la/ dus kyis 'byung ba smin par byed/ / dus kyis skye dgu sdud par 'gyur/ / dus kyis logs shig sad par byed/ / dus las shin tu 'da' bar dka'/ / zhes bya ba ni dus rgyur smra ba rnams kyi'o/ / las kyis 'gengs par byed cing de dag yongs su smin pa na 'dzag par yang 'gyur ro zhes bya ba de lta bu ni gang zag tu smra ba rnams kyi'o/ / dngos po kun zhes bya ba ni 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'o/ / sgyu ma'i gzugs zhes bya ba ni sna tshogs pa'i sprul pa'i sprul pa po nyid do/ /

sarvaṃ vijñānarūpaṃ (‘everything is consciousness in essence’): Refers to the Vedanta view that everything is of the nature of consciousness. puruṣaḥ (‘primordial man’): Refers to the view of the Sāṃkhya tradition. īśvaraḥ (‘supreme being’): The ‘supreme being’ is the eternal creator of the world and here refers to the view of the Siddhānta tradition. ātmā (‘soul’): This refers to the view of the tradition where it is that soul (ātman) that is born, lives, dies, binds and liberates. jīvaḥ (‘individual self): Refers to the view of the Digaṃbara Jaina tradition. sattva (‘pure essence’): Refers to the those who argue that the supreme is Sattva. kālaḥ (‘time’): Refers to those who base their view on time. They say: “Time ripens all elements, time destroys all mankind, it is time that dreams and awakens and lime is the insurmountable.” pudgala (‘atomic entity’): The view of the followers of the Pudgala tradition is that the atomic entity accumulates karma and then passes away by the gradual destruction of all karma. sarvabhāvā (all there is): Means all that exists in this world and beyond. māyārūpī (as illusory forms): This means that this Knowledge is the source for the creation of the myriad variety of forms.
yang de lta bu'i ro mnyam par 'gyur ba de ji ltar slob ma rnams kyi spyod yul du 'gyur bar bya zhe na/
Now, how this Flavour of Essential Similarity must be placed within the view of the disciples is said by:
prathamānandamātran tu paramānandaṃ dvisaṃkhyataḥ || tṛtīyaṃ viramākhyaṃ ca caturthaṃ sahajaṃ smṛtaṃ || (13)
dang po dga' ba tsam nyid de/ / gnyis pa'i grangs las mchog dga' nyid/ / gsum pa las ni dga' bral bshad/ / bzhi pa lhan cig skyes par brjod/ /
The first Joy is merely pleasure; the Refined Joy is reckoned as the second; the third is known as Cessation and the fourth is known as the Innate.

dang por zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ dga' ba tsam zhes bya ba ni thun mong du 'gyur ba'i bde ba tsam zhes bya ba'i don to/ / gnyis pa'i grangs las zhes bya ba gnyis pa'o/ / gsum pa zhes bya ba ni tha dad du sbyar bar bya'o/ / dga' bral zhes bya ba ni dga' bral gyi dga' ba'o/ / lhan cig skyes pa zhes bya ba ni lhan cig skyes pa'i dga' ba'i rang bzhin no/ / 'di ni bshad pa gcig yin no/ /

prathamānandamātran tu (the first Joy is merely pleasure): Here merely pleasure means it is the ordinary sexual pleasure. dvisaṃkhyataḥ (reckoned as the second): Means is the second. tṛtīyaṃ (the third): This implies that a different yoga is necessary for the third. viramākhyaṃ (known as Cessation): Refers to the Joy of Cessation. sahajaṃ (Innate): Means the fourth is of the nature of the Innate Joy. This is one interpretation [of 1.10.12]
[Now another interpretation of the same verse:]

dang por zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ dang por zhes bya ba ni thog ma ste/ phyi rol gyi pad+ma dang rdo rje rnal 'byor gyis slob dpon gyi dbang bskur bas dga' ba tsam 'byung ba'o/ / ci phyir dga' ba tsam yin zhe na/ thun mong gi ngo bo nyid yin pa'i phyir te gzhan dag gis kyang rdo rje dang pad+ma'i sbyor ba de lta bu dang mthun pa'i bde ba nyams su myong bar 'gyur ro zhes byas nas dga' ba tsam zhes brjod do/ / mchog dga' nyid ces bya ba la sogs pa la mchog ni khyad par can du gyur pa ste/ man ngag nyid las gsang ba'i nor bur yang dag par myong bar 'gyur ba nyid do/ / gnyis pa'i grangs las zhes bya ba ni dbang bskur ba'i grangs gnyis pa'o/ / gsum pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa la khyad par can gyi dga' ba ni dga' bral te shes rab kyi dbang bskur ba'i mtshan nyid can te/ de las gzhan pa'i nor bu bde ba chen po yang dag par rig pa nyid do/ / bzhi pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ bzhi pa ni dbang bskur ba bzhi pa'o/ / lhan cig skyes pa zhes bya ba ni mi gnas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa'i dbyings kyi ngo bo nyid yang dag par rtogs pa'o/ /

prathamaṃ (the first): First, at the beginning, meaning, in the Master Consecration, by the union of the external Lotus and Vajra, mere pleasure is made to arise. Why is it just merely pleasure? It is said to be merely pleasure because of its ordinary nature, for people in general experience a similar pleasure from the union of the Lotus and Vajra. paramānandaṃ (Refined Joy): The second Joy is called Refined Joy because it is an excellent extraction which is experienced by means of the Secret Gem by following the guru’s instructions. dvisaṃkhyataḥ (counted as the second): Refers to the second consecration. virama (Cessation): Refers to the most excellent of joys and it characterises the Wisdom Consecration because Great Bliss is experienced by the Gem which has entered into Wisdom. caturthaṃ (fourth): Refers to the fourth consecration. sahaja (Innate): It is Innate because it is experienced as the Unanchored Essence of Release.

de lta bu'i lhan cig skyes pa nyid ro mnyam zhes bya ba'i sgra dang skad cig ma'i dbye bas slob ma'i spyod yul du nges par bstan pa na/ de'i tshe bcom ldan 'das 'khor gang dag gis yongs su bskor ba brjod par 'dod nas/ sdud pa pos de skad ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/

Thus far, the Bhagavān explained the Innate Joy which is to be placed within the view of the disciple as the Flavour of Essential Similarity and other such characteristics. Now the writer of this tantra describes what further occurred in the Bhagavān’s assembly.

evaṃ śrutvā tu vai sarve Vajragarbhādayo budhāḥ || paramavismayāpannā mūrchitāḥ patitāvanau || (14) prathamānandaṃ jagadrūpaṃ paramānandaṃ jagat tathā || viramānandaṃ jagac caiva na vidyate sahajaṃ triṣu || (15) iti /

de bzhin gshegs pa rnams dang ni/ / rdo rje snying po la sogs kun/ / mkhas pas de skad nges thos nas/ / mchog tu ngo mtshar gyur nas ni/ / brgyal zhing sa la 'gyel bar 'gyur/ / dang po dga' ba 'gro ba'i gzugs/ / de bzhin mchog dga' 'gro ba nyid/ / dga' bral dga' ba'ang 'gro ba nyid/ / gsum pa lhan cig skyes pa med/ /

“The first Joy is of this world, similarly, the Refined Joy is of this world and the Joy of Cessation is also of this world. The Innate does not exist in these three.” Hearing this all the wise ones, Vajragarbha and others, were overcome by great astonishment and fell senseless onto the ground.

ngo mtshar zhes bya ba ni rmad du byung ba rtogs par 'gyur ba'o/ / sa zhes bya ba ni sa'o/ / ci'i phyir 'gyel bar 'gyur zhe na/ dang por zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ 'gro ba'i gzugs zhes bya ba ni 'gro ba rnams kyi rigs pa nyid kyi phyir ro/ / mchog dga' 'gro ba nyid ces bya ba ni lam gyi ngo bo nyid kyis kun rdzob kyi bden pa'i ngo bo nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de bzhin zhes bya ba ni de bzhin du zhes bya ba'i don to/ / gang yang dga' bral gyi dga' ba'i ngo bo zhes grags pa de yang shin tu phra ba rang gi sems kyis so sor rig par bya ba'i ngo bo 'o/ / de yang 'gro ba nyid yin te/ kun rdzob kyi bden pa'i rang bzhin nyid kyis te de yang sems tsam nyid yin pas kun rdzob kyi bden par bsdus pa'i phyir ro/ / nyid ces bya ba ni nges par gzung bar bya bar blta'o/ / gsum char yang 'jig rten pa'i 'gro bas rig par 'gyur ba yin pas 'gro ba zhes bya bar brjod do/ / gsum la lhan cig skyes pa med/ /ces bya ba ni gsum po 'di dag la lhan cig skyes pa yod pa ma yin zhing / yang dag par rigs pa yang med pa nyid de/ mtshan nyid dang bral ba'i phyir zhes bya ba'i don to zhes bya ba ni sdud pa po'i tshig yin te/ yongs su rdzogs zhes bya ba'i don to/ / de lta bur gyur pas ngo mtshar skyes par 'gyur ro zhes bya'o/ /

vismayaṃ (astonishment): This implies that they were stunned. avanau (onto the ground): Means, they fell on the floor. The reason why they fell down is said by: prathamānandaṃ jagadrūpam ityādi (the first Joy is of this world etc.): The first Joy is of this world because it is experienced by every one in the world. paramānandaṃ jagat tathā (similarly, the Refined Joy is of the world): Just like the first Joy, the Refined Joy is of this world because in it’s method it utilises principles of the world. viramānandaṃ (Joy of Cessation): The Joy of Cessation is experienced by the subtle mind and so is of this world because even the mind, the nature of which is of the relative world, can only be known in terms of relative principles. Therefore, when accurately determining these three Joys the relative aspect is to be noted. The worldly Joy is of these three kinds; it is said to be of the world because it is experienced in terms of the relative, phenomenal world. na vidyate sahajaṃ triṣu (the Innate does not exist in these three): The Innate neither exists nor is experienced in these three Joys, for the Innate is characterised by the Signless. This is the intent. iti (this): Refers to the end of the statement made by the writer of this tantra [that the assembly of listeners were overcome by astonishment].
bhagavān āha Hevajraḥ sarvabuddhaikavigrahaḥ / saṃśayāpanayaṃ divyaṃ Vajragarbhasya bodhaye || (16)
bcom ldan bka' stsal kye'i rdo rje/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi sku gcig pa/ / rdo rje snying pos rtogs bya'i phyir/ / the tshom legs par sel ba ni/ /
Bhagavān who is Hevajra, the one form epitomising all the Buddhas, in order to awaken Vajragarbha spoke the divine antidote for their astonishment.

bcom ldan bka' stsal zhes bya ba ni sdud pa po'i tshig go/ / sangs rgyas kun dang lhan cig gnyis su med par gyur pa'i sku ni sku gcig pu'o/ / 'dis the tshom nges par sel bar byed pas na the tshom legs par sel ba'o/ / bzang po zhes bya ba ni gtso bo'o/ / rtogs pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni rab tu bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir ro/ /

bhagavān aha (the Bhagavān ... spoke): These are the words of the writer of this tantra. sarvabuddhaikavigrahaḥ (the one form epitomising all the Buddhas): Means the one whose form is not different from all the Buddhas. samsayapanayaṃ (antidote for their astonishment): Means that which removes astonishment. divyaṃ (divine): Means the excellent. bodhaye (in order to awaken): Means in order to bestow knowledge.

na rāgo na virāgaś ca madhyamaṃ nopalabhyate || trayāṇāṃ varjanād eva sahajaṃ bodhir ucyate || (17) athavā sarvātmakaḥ saivāthavā sarvair vivarjitaḥ || viramādau sa lakṣyata ānandatrayavarjitaḥ || (18)

'dod chags med cing chags bral med/ / dbu mar dmigs par mi 'gyur ro/ / gsum po spangs pa nyid kyi phyir/ / lhan cig skyes pa byang chub brjod/ / yang na de nyid thams cad bdag / yang na kun gyis rnam par spangs/ / de yang dga' bral dang por mtshon/ / dga' ba gsum po rnam par spangs/ /

Neither passion nor the absence of passion is found there and no middle; it is because of being free of these three that the Innate is called Enlightenment. The Innate is contained in all as well as free of all. It is to be marked at the beginning of the Cessation, free of these three Joys.

'dod chags med cing zhes bya ba la sogs pa la 'dod chags ni mchog tu dga' ba'o/ / chags bral ni dga' bral gyi dga' ba'o/ / dbu ma zhes bya ba ni dang po'i dga' ba'o/ / gsum po 'di dag ni yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi ngo bor dmigs par mi 'gyur ro/ / gsum po zhes bya ba ni gsum po de dag go/ / spangs pa ni tha dad du byas pa'o/ / lhan cig skyes pa zhes bya ba ni lhan cig skyes pa'i dga' ba'o/ / byang chub ces bya ba ni rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi rgyu yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

rāga (passion): Refers to the Refined Joy. virāga (absence of passion): Refers to the Joy of Cessation. madhyamaṃ (middle state): Refers to the first Joy. These first three Joys cannot be experienced as being the complete enlightenment. trayāṇāṃ vaijanāt (because of being free of these three): Means by the abandoning of these three, that is, excluding them. sahaja (Innate): Refers to the Innate Joy which is Enlightenment because it is the cause of complete enlightenment.
[Another interpretation of 1.10.16]

'dod chags zhes bya ba ni 'dod chags la dmigs pa'i phyir 'dod chags te/ dbang bskur dang po'o/ / chags bral ni khyad par can gyi bde ba la dmigs pa'i phyir dbang bskur ba gsum mo/ / dbu ma ni de dag gi bar na gnas par gyur pa ste/ gnyis gsang ba'i dbang bskur ba'o/ / dmigs par mi 'gyur ro zhes bya ba ni yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi de ma thag pa'i rkyen gyi ngo bo nyid ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir/ gsum po spangs pa nyid kyi phyir/ / zhes bya ba gsungs pa yin no/ / lhan cig skyes pa zhes bya ba lhan cig skyes pa'i don gyi dbang bskur ba la lhan cig skyes pa zhes bya ste/ bzhi pa zhes bya ba'i don to/ / byang chub brjod ces bya ba ni rgyu la 'bras bu btags pa'o/ / gal te dbang bskur ba'i khyad par gzhan la yang ci'i phyir brjod par mi bya zhe na/ rgyu yi rgyu nyid yin pa'i phyir/ /zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ /

rāga (passion): Here ‘passion’ refers to the first consecration, because it is based upon passion. virāga (absence of passion): Here ‘absence of passion’ refers to the third consecration, because it is based upon a special facet of bliss. madhyamaṃ (middle): Refers to the second consecration which is between the first and the third. nopalabhyate (is not found): These three are not found to be constituents of the cause for complete enlightenment. Therefore it is said: trayāṇāṃ vaijanāt (because of being free of these three). sahaja (Innate): Refers to the fourth consecration which bestows the Innate nature. bodhir ucyate (is called Enlightenment): The Innate is known as complete enlightenment, it being the cause that produces the effect which is complete enlightenment. Why is it not mentioned in the other consecrations? It is not mentioned because the Innate is the supreme cause of enlightenment. Such is the intent.

de nyid kyi phyir/ dga' ba gsum po rnam par spangs/ /zhes gsungs pa yin no/ / gal te gzhan dag la thams cad du de yod pa ma yin na lhan cig skyes pa zhes bya ba khyab pa po nyid du mi 'gyur ro zhe na/ de'i phyir rgyu'i gtso bo nyid yin pa'i phyir/ lhan cig skyes pa la rdzogs pa'i byang chub ces brjod do/ / da ni yang bstan par gyur pa'i lhan cig skyes pa nyid gsal por bstan pa'i phyir/ de yang dga' bral dang por mtshon/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ dga' bral gyi dang po zhes bya ba de mchog tu dga' ba yin nam zhe na/ de ma yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir/ dga' ba gsum po rnam par spangs/ /zhes gsungs te/ shugs kyis na mchog tu dga' ba'i phyi ma zhes bya bar bstan par 'gyur ro/ / de yang le'u gsum pa las/ / lhan cig skyes dga'i rang bzhin bdag / mchog mtha' dga' bral dang por ni/ /zhes bya ba gsungs pa yin no/ / bshad pa gcig yin no/ /

Therefore it is said: ānandatrayavaijitaḥ (free of the three Joys): If the Innate is not found at all in the other consecrations then the all-pervasive nature of the Innate moment is not attained. The Innate is called enlightenment because it is the principal cause. Now how the Innate is to be revealed is said by: viramādau ityādi (at the beginning of Cessation): Does this mean that the Innate is attained prior to the Joy of Cessation, in the Refined Joy itself? This is answered in the negative by: ānandatrayavaijitaḥ (free from the three joys): Meaning that the Innate is after the Refined Joy. This is further explained in the thirteenth chapter (2.2.40) by: “... my nature is that of Innate Joy which is at the end of the Refined Joy and at the beginning of the Joy of Cessation.” This is one interpretation.
[Now another interpretation]

dga' bral dang po mtshon zhes bya ba ni dbang bskur ba gsum pa la sogs pa'o/ / mtshon zhes bya ba ni ji ltar rigs par bya'o/ / khyad par ji lta bu zhig ce na/ dga' ba gsum po rnam par spangs/ /zhes bya ba gsungs te/ dga' ba dang mchog dga' dang dga' bral spangs pa ste/ 'di ni mtshan nyid dang bral ba'i ngo bo nyid yin pas ngo bo nyid gzhan yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

viramādau (at the beginning of cessation): Means that the Innate must be marked, that is, the appropriate observation should be made at the beginning of the third consecration. The uniqueness of this observation is said by: ānandatrayavaijitaḥ (free from the three joys): Means without the Ordinary Joy, the Refined Joy and the Joy of Cessation. The Innate, because of it’s Signless characteristic, is different from these three Joys.
prathamaṃ meghavad bhāti siddhe tu māyāvad bhavet || sahasā svapnavad bhāti svapijāgradabhedavat || (19)
dang po sprin dang 'dra ba yin/ / grub pa sgyu ma lta bur 'gyur/ / gnyid log sad par mi byed par/ / nyal dang log pa'i khyad par las/ / rtag tu rmi lam 'dra bar 'gyur/ /
At first the Innate manifests like a cloud; by further perfection it appears as an illusion. Then suddenly it manifests like sleep and then as having no distinction between sleep and waking.

de ltar yang dag par mtshon nas man ngag gis lhan cig skyes pa bsgom pa'i ting nge 'dzin las skyes pa gang yin pa de bstan pa ni sprin lta bu dang / sgyu ma lta bu dang / rmi lam lta bu dang / rmi lam sad pa'o zhes gsungs te/ dang por zhes bya ba ni goms par byed pa'i dus su'o/ / ji ltar sprin dang 'dra zhe na/ sprin srab mos g.yogs pa'i zla ba nya ba ltar mi gsal ba'i phyir ro/ / ji ltar sgyu ma lta bu zhe na/ gang gi tshe mngon sum du gyur pa'i tshe grub pa zhes bya ba bde ba chen po'i ros nges par bsgos pas 'gro ba rnams sgyu ma bzhin du mthong ngo / / phyi nas zhes bya ba ni de'i rjes la rmi lam dang 'dra ba'o/ / ji ltar rmi lam dang 'dra zhe na/ bdag dang gzhan du mi dmigs pa'i phyir ro/ / de nas ni rmi lam dang sad pa lta bu ste/ sad pa dang rmi lam gyi gnas skabs la dbye ba med par rtag tu mnyam par gzhag pa'i phyir ro/ /

In this Innate which has been clearly characterised, when emanating in accordance with the instructions, stabilised meditative states arise. They arc described by ‘like a cloud’, ‘as an illusion’, ‘like sleep’ and ‘as sleep and waking’ prathamaṃ (first): Here ‘first’ means at the time of commencing the practice. meghavat (like a cloud): Why like a cloud? In the first stabilised meditative state the Innate is not clearly manifested, as is the full moon when covered by clouds. māyāvat (as an illusion): Why as an illusion? The one who is immersed in the flavour of the great bliss of this stabilised meditative state perceives the world as an illusion. When the illusory nature is truly realised then this stabilised meditative state is accomplished. sahasa (then suddenly): Means suddenly after the previous stabilised meditative state. svapnavat (like sleep): Why like sleep? Because of the nonexistence of notions distinguishing oneself from others. Further: svapijāgradabhedavat (like having no distinction between sleep and waking): Why like sleep and waking? Because the sleep and waking states are indivisibly united.
de ltar ting nge 'dzin bzhi yongs su rdzogs par 'gyur ba'i rnal 'byor pa ci ltar 'grub par 'gyur zhe na/
How the yogī accomplishes the perfection of these four stabilised meditative states is expressed by:
abhedalakṣaṇāsiddhau mudrāyogī tu sidhyati ||
dngos grub mtshan nyid mi phyed pa'i/ / phyag rgya rnal 'byor pa yis 'grub/ /
By achieving this state of no distinction which is in fact no accomplishment, the Mudrāyogī accomplishes.

mi phyed mtshan nyid ma grub pa/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ gzugs la sogs pa'i dbye ba med pas mi phyed pa'o/ / dbye ba med pa ji lta bu zhe na/ mtshan nyid ma grub pa'i phyir dbye ba med pa'o/ / 'dis mtshon par byed pas na mtshan nyid de rang bzhin no/ / de ma grub pa ni dngos po thams cad bde ba chen po'i rang bzhin nyid kyis rang bzhin med par byas pa'o/ / phyag rgya rnal 'byor zhes bya ba/ / phyag rgya chen po'i rnal 'byor te/ / 'grub par 'gyur ba'i zhes bya ba'i don to/ / nyid ces bya ba ni de lta bu'i phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub ni dbang bskur ba med na 'byung bar mi 'gyur bas dbang bskur ba sbyin par bya'o/ /

abheda (no distinction): Means the non-existence of the distinctions of form and so on. How is it that there are no distinctions? lakṣaṇāsiddhau (state ... which is in fact no accomplishment): In truth, there are no distinctions. Here ‘state’ means characteristic and refers to the intrinsic nature. By this non-accomplishment which is a state where there are no distinctions all phenomenal manifestations are rendered non-substantial by the Great Bliss. mudrāyogī (Mudrāyogī accomplishes): The Mudrāyogī, that is, the practitioner of Mahāmudrā, accomplishes in this manner is the intent.

ity āha maṇḍalaṃ śāstā catuṣkoṇaṃ samujjvalaṃ || (20) caturdvāraṃ mahādīptaṃ hārārdhahārabhūṣitaṃ || śrakcitracāmarair yuktaṃ aṣṭastambhopaśobhitaṃ || (21) vajrasūtrair samāyuktaṃ nānāpuṣpopaśobhitaṃ || dhūpaṃ dīpaṃ tathā gandham aṣṭakalaśādibhir yutaṃ || (22) te ca sapallavāgrāḥ syur vastrācchāditakandharāḥ || pañcaratnaparikṣiptaṃ dadyād vijayaṃ pūrvataḥ || (23) navena suniyuktena supramāṇena cāruṇā || sūtreṇa sūtrayet prājñaḥ sveṣṭadevatārūpataḥ || (24)

ston pas dkyil 'khor 'di skad gsungs/ / gru bzhi yang dag 'bar ba nyid/ / sgo bzhi gzi brjid chen po ste/ / do shal do shal phyed pas brgyan/ / phreng ba sna tshogs rnga yab ldan/ / ka ba brgyad kyis nye bar brgyan/ / rdo rje srad bu mnyam par ldan/ / me tog sna tshogs nye bar brgyan/ / bdug pa mar me de bzhin dri/ / bum pa brgyad la sogs pa ldan/ / de yang yal ga la sogs brgyan/ / mgrin pa gos kyis dgab pa dang / / rin chen lnga ni yongs su gzhug / rnam par rgyal ba shar du sbyin/ / rang 'dod lha yi gzugs kyis ni/ / sar pa legs par bkal ba dang / / shin tu tshad ma mdzes pa yi/ / sra dbus shes rab can gyis gdab/ /

Thus the Lord said: The maṇḍala comprises of a blazing square with four brilliant doors. It is adorned with garlands and chains and has flowing plumes of many colours. It is resplendent with eight pillars, has vajra threads and is decorated with flowers of many kinds. Incense, lamps and perfumes are there. In the maṇḍala there are eight jars which have branches in them and a piece of cloth is tied around each of their necks. The Victory Jar containing the five precious objects should be offered in the east. Assuming the nature of one’s own chosen deity draw the maṇḍala with a beautiful, new thread that is well made and of the right length.

de'i phyir ston pa zhes bya ba rdo rje 'chang gis de'i ched du dkyil 'khor gsungs pa yin no/ / yang dag 'bar ba zhes bya ba ni rin po che sna tshogs kyis brgyan pa'o/ / sna tshogs rnga yab ces bya ba ni rgyan sna tshogs can gyi rnga yab dang ldan pa'o/ / mgrin pa gos kyis bkab pa dang / /zhes bya ba ni gos sar pas mgul pa bcings pa'o/ / rin chen lnga ni byi ru dang mu tig dang mu men dang gser dang dngul lo/ / gzhag ces bya ba ni gzhag par bya ba'o/ /

iti (thus): Since consecration must be given because this kind of Mahāmudrā accomplishment does not occur without consecration, the Lord, that is, Vajradhara, spoke thus of the maṇḍala. samujjvalaṃ (blazing): Means decorated with various kinds of gems. srakcitracāmaraiḥ (with flowing plumes of many colours): Means with animal tails of many colours. vastrācchāditakandharāḥ (a piece of cloth is tied around each of their necks): Means that the neck of each pot is encircled with a clean piece of cloth. pañcaratnāni (five precious objects): The five are coral, pearl, diamond, gold and silver. dadyāt (should be offered): Means should be placed.
dkyil 'khor bdag po zhes bya ba la sogs pa ni sngon gyi bsnyen pa gsungs pa yin no/ /
The preliminary propitiation is described by:

cakreśasya japel lakṣaṃ māṇḍaleyasya cāyutaṃ || pūrvoktenaiva mantreṇa śodhayed dharaṇīṃ budhaḥ || (25) baliṃ ca dāpayet tatra prāg A-kārādimantrataḥ || rakṣāṃ caiva yathādiṣṭāṃ yathā dhyāne tathātra ca || (26)

'khor lo'i bdag po'i bzlas pa 'bum/ / dkyil 'khor can gyi de bzhin khri/ / gong du gsungs pa'i sngags nyid kyis/ / mkhas pas nor 'dzin rnam par sbyang / / gong gi a sogs sngags kyis ni/ / de la gtor ma rnam par sbyin/ / ji ltar bsam gtan de bzhin 'dir/ / bsrung ba ji ltar gsungs pa nyid/ /

Recite the mantra of the principal deity of the circle one hundred thousand times and the mantra of each of the retinue deities ten thousand times. Using the previously mentioned mantra the wise yogī must purify the ground. Firstly, at the site of consecration, place the sacrificial offering using the mantra which begins with akāra. Perform the protection rite here in the same way as mentioned in the context of the practice of concentration.
gang du zhes bya ba ni sa sbyang ba'i yang sngon du'o/ / a sogs sngags kyis zhes bya ba ni a kA ro mu khaM sarba d+harmA NAM Ad+ya nut+pan na twAta oM AHhU~M phaT swA hA zhes bya ba'o/ /

prāg (firstly): Means prior to the purification of the ground. akārādimantra (mantra which begins with akāra): This mantra which is for the sacrificial offering is akāro mukhaṃ sarvadharmāṇāṃ ādyanutpannatvāt oṃ āḥ hūṃ phaṭ svāhā.
prakāśitās tu ye sekā vidhivad dadyāt svamaṇḍale || pūjā cābhyarcanā caiva yathākhyātā tathātra ca || (27)
gang zhig dbang ni rab phye ba/ / rang gi dkyil 'khor cho gas sbyin/ / mchod dang gsol ba gdab pa nyid/ / ji ltar bshad pa de bzhin 'dir/ /
In accordance with the injunctions bestow the consecrations previously revealed in the appropriate maṇḍala. The worship and the supplication should be performed there as prescribed.
mchod dang gsol ba gdab pa zhes bya ba ni bla ma la'o/ / ji ltar bshad pa de bzhin zhes bya ba ni de kho na nyid bsdus pa la sogs par ro/ /
pūjā cābhyarcanā (worship and supplication): Refers to the worship and supplication of the guru. yathakhyātā (as prescribed): Means as prescribed in the Tattvasaṃgraha and other works.

śuddhaṃ dvipuṭam ālikhya cakraṃ Gauryādīnāṃ tathā || pūrveṇa likhet kartṛkāṃ dakṣiṇe paścime tathā || (28) uttare cāgnikoṇe ca nairṛtye vāyave tathā || aiśāne ca yathākhyātam adhaś cordhvaṃ tathā tathā || (29)

'phar ma gnyis bzang rnam bris nas/ / myur du dkar mo la sogs bri/ / shar du gri gug rnam par bri/ / lho dang nub tu'ang de bzhin no/ / byang dang me yi mtshams dang ni/ / bden bral rlung du'ang de bzhin no/ / dbang ldan du ni ci gsungs pa/ / da lta de ltar 'og dang steng / /

Draw a clean double enclosure which is the Circle of Gaurī and the other Yoginīs. In the east he should draw a knife, and likewise he should draw a knife in the south, west, north, south-east, south-west, north-west, north-east, below and above.
Vajrasattvakṛtāṭopaḥ kṛtālīḍhaś ca pādayoḥ || praviśen maṇḍalācāryo dvibhujahevajrayogataḥ || (30) snātaḥ śuciḥ sugandhāṅgo citrābharaṇabhūṣitaḥ || HŪṂ-HŪṂ-kārakṛtāṭopo HĪ-HĪ-kārabhayānakaḥ || (31)

rdo rje sems dpa'i snyems byas nas/ / rkang pa g.yas pa brkyang byas te/ / phyag gnyis kye rdo rje sbyor bas/ / slob dpon dkyil 'khor 'jug pa nyid/ / khrus dang gtsang sbra dri zhim lus/ / sna tshogs rgyan gyis rnam par brgyan/ / hU~M hU~M snyems pa byas nas ni/ / hI hI rnam pas 'jigs byed bdag /

The Master of the Maṇḍala assuming the form of the two-armed Hevajra should enter the maṇḍala dancing the majestic postures of Vajrasattva. He must have bathed, be clean, have a fresh-smelling body and be adorned with many ornaments. He majestically utters hūṃ hūṃ and the terrifying hī hī.
rdo rje sems dpa' zhes bya ba ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje'o/ /
vajrasattva: Means Hevajra.
paścāt tattvaṃ samākhyātaṃ viśuddhaṃ jñānarūpiṇaṃ || saṃsāravyavadānena nāsti bhedo manāg api || (32)
phyi nas de nyid yang dag bshad/ / rnam dag ye shes gzugs can dang / / 'khor ba dang ni mya ngan 'das/ / khyad par cung zad yod ma yin/ /
Then explain the True Principle which is pure and is in essence the Knowledge. By the purification of the phenomenal there exists not even the slightest perceivable distinction.

phyi nas zhes bya ba ni dbang bskur ba'i rjes thogs su'o/ / rnam dag ni 'khor ba pa'i skyon dag pa'o/ / ye shes gzugs can ni thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes dang mnyam pa'o/ / 'khor ba dang ni rnam byang dag / ces bya ba ni ye shes gang la srid pa dang mya ngan las 'das pa dag khyad par cung zad kyang med pa zhes bya ba ni lhag pa ste/ spros pa thams cad las shin tu 'das pa'i phyir zhes bya bar dgongs so/ /

paścāt (then): Means after bestowing the consecration. visuddhaṃ (pure): Means cleansed of the defilements of the phenomenal world. jñānarūpiṇaṃ (in essence the Knowledge): Means equal to the knowledge of the Omniscient One. saṃsāravyavadānena (by the purification of the phenomenal world): Refers to the knowledge wherein there is no distinction between the bound and the released existences. manāg api (even the slightest perceivable): There is not even the slightest perceivable distinction because the True Principle is beyond the realm of phenomenal distinctions.
'di nyid ni mchog dgar zhes bya ba la sogs pa'i tshigs su bcad pa gnyis kyis gsal bar ston par 'gyur ro/ /
This True Principle is clearly defined in the two verses that follow.

paramaratau na ca bhāva na bhāvaka || na ca vigraha na ca grāhya na grāhaka || māṃsa na śonita viṣṭa na mūtraṃ || na charda na moha na śaucapavitraṃ || (33) rāga na dveṣa na moha na īrṣyā || na ca paiśunya na ca māna na dṛśyaṃ || bhāva na bhāvaka mitra na śatru || nistaraṅga sahajākhyavicitraṃ || (34)

mchog dgar bsgom pa med cing sgom pa po yang med/ / lus kyang med cing gzung ba med dang 'dzin pa'ang med/ / sha dang khrag kyang med cing bshang dang gci ba'ang med/ / skyug bro rmongs med gtsang sbra mchod phyir thogs med dang / / chags med sdang ba med dang rmongs med phrag dog med/ / ser sna med dang nga rgyal med cing mthong bya med/ / bsgom dang sgom pa po med bshes dang dgra med cing / / rlom sems med pa'i lhan cig skyes pa'i sna tshogs nyid/ /

In the supreme delight there is neither the emanated nor the emanator. There is no form and neither is there object nor is their the perceiver. There is no flesh, no blood, no excrement, no urine, no sickness, no delusion, no envy, no malignity, no pride, no visible object, no emanated object, ho emanator, no friend and no enemy. The Innate is calm and undifferentiated.

mchog dga' ni mchog tu gyur pa'i shes rab ste 'od gsal ba'i mtshan nyid can gyi ye shes so/ / der ni sgom pa med ces bya ba bsgom par bya ba cung zhig kyang med pa'o/ / sgom pa po ni sems te de yang med pa'o/ / lus ni lus so/ / gzung ba ni snang bar 'gyur ba'i dngos po'o/ / 'dzin pa ni mig la sogs pa'o/ / de bzhin du sha dang khrag la sogs pa yang med pa'o/ / de ltar nyon mongs pa'i sgrib pa yod pa ma yin no zhes bya bar bsgrubs nas/ / shes bya'i sgrib pa yang yod pa ma yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir mthong ba med ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ mthong bar bya ba la sogs pa'i phyi rol gyi dngos po yang yod pa ma yin no zhes bya ba'i don to/ / rlabs med pa'i zhes bya ba la sogs pa la rlabs ni rnam par rtog pa'o/ / de zad par gyur pa ni rlabs med pa'o/ / sna tshogs ni rnam pa sna tshogs su snang ba'o/ / de med pa ni sna tshogs med pa'o/ /

paramaratau (in the supreme delight): The supreme delight is the Supreme Wisdom which is the knowledge characterised by the Innate Radiance. na bhāvo (neither the emanated): In that supreme delight nothing at all is emanated. bhāvakaḥ (the emanator): Refers to the mind, which also does not exist. vigraho (form): Refers to the body. grāhyo (object): Refers to the manifested objects. grāhakaḥ (perceiver): Refers to the eyes and the other faculties of perception. māṃsaṃ ityādi (flesh etc.): Similarly there is no flesh, blood etc. After explaining the non-origination of the Veils of Affliction (kleśāvaraṇa), in order to explain the non-origination of the Veils of the Objects of Experience (jñeyāvaraṇa), it is said: na dṛśyaṃ (no visible object): Means that the visual and other external emanations do not exist. nistaraṅga (calm): Here taraṅga (which means waves) refers to the various modes of the mind. The destruction of the various modes of the mind is expressed by ‘calm’. avicitraṃ (undifferentiated): The differentiated are the various kinds of experiences. ‘Undifferentiated’ is used in order to indicate that the differentiated appearances are non-existent.

'di skad ces bya ba ni 'di skad bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa'o/ / gsol zhes bya ba ni rdo rje snying pos zhus par 'gyur ba'o/ / don ci zhig zhus she na/ ci slad ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /
Bhagavān who had spoken thus was asked by Vajragarbha:
ity āha Vajragarbhākhyaḥ [he bhagavan] kasmād bhūtātmakaṃ bhavet || dehaṃ svabhāvataḥ śuddham ādāv evāsvabhāvakaṃ || (35)
rdo rje snying pos 'di skad gsol/ / gzod nas rang bzhin med pa yi/ / lus kyi rang bzhin dag pa ni/ / ci slad 'byung ba'i bdag nyid lags/ /
Vajragarbha asked thus: How does the body become composed of the elements when it is by its nature pure and primordially without any characteristics?

dgongs pa ni 'di yin te/ lhan cig skyes pa'i ngo bo nyid kyi rang bzhin gyis rnam par dag pa'i lus 'di ci'i slad du zag pa dang bcas pa'i 'byung ba lnga'i bdag nyid can du 'gyur ba'i rgyu las 'dra bar gyur pa'i 'bras bu 'byung bar 'gyur ro zhes bya ba'i rigs pas 'od gsal ba las bzhengs pa'i rdo rje 'chang gi sku bzhin du lus can thams cad kyang 'gyur te/ lhan cig skyes pas bskyed pa'i phyir/ /zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ /

The intent of his question is said by: kasmāt ityādi (how etc.): The intent of the question is: The body is primordially pure in terms of the Innate nature. How is the body impure? The body is impure because it is composed of the elements. By the reasoning of similarity, from one kind of cause a similar effect arises. Since they originate from the Innate are not all bodies similar to the body of Vajradhara who arises from the Innate Radiance? Such is the question.
tatrāha bhagavān Vajrī ḍākinīnāṃ sukhaṃdadaḥ || nistaraṅgaḥ svarūpātmā sarve dehe vyavasthitaḥ || (36)
de nas bcom ldan rdo rje can/ / mkha' 'gro bde ba sbyin pas gsungs/ / rlom sems med pa'i rang bzhin bdag / thams cad lus la rnam par gnas/ /
To that question Bhagavān who is the granter of bliss to the Ḍākinīs answered: Calm is the true nature and it abides in all bodies.
Vajragarbha āha / he bhagavan kasmān mahābhautikaskandhaḥ /
kye bcom ldan 'das ci'i slad du 'byung ba chen po las gyur pa'i phung po lags/
Vajragarbha asked: O Bhagavān, whence the aggregate of the great elements?

{tatra} bhagavān āha / (37) bolakakkolayogena kunduruṃ kurute vratī || sparśāt kāṭhinyadharmeṇa pṛthivī tatra jāyate || (38) bodhicittadravākārād abdhātoś caiva saṃbhavaḥ || gharṣaṇād jāyate tejo gamanād vāyuḥ prakīrtitaḥ || (39) saukhyam ākāśadhātus ca pañcabhiḥ pariveṣṭitaḥ || tasmāt saukhyaṃ na tattvākhyaṃ mahābhūtaṃ yataḥ sukhaṃ || (40)

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / po la kak+kol sbyor bas/ / reg pa sra ba'i chos kyis ni/ / sa ni de las skye bar 'gyur/ / byang sems khu ba'i rnam pa las/ / chu yi khams ni 'byung bar 'gyur/ / bskyod pa las ni drod skye ste/ / 'gro bas rlung du rab tu grags/ / bde ba nam mkha' nyid kyi khams/ / lnga bo rnams kyis yongs su bskor/ / gang phyir 'byung ba che bde ba/ / de phyir bde ba de nyid min/ /

Bhagavān replied: By uniting the male and female sexual organs the holder of the Vow performs the erotic union. From contact in the erotic union, as the quality of hardness, Earth arises; Water arises from the fluidity of the semen (bodhi-citta); Fire arises from the friction of pounding; Air is famed to be the movement and the Space element is the erotic pleasure.
