The Innate is covered by these five elements and so the erotic pleasure is not the real bliss, for this pleasure arises from the five great elements.

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ /zhes bya ba la 'jig rten pa'i 'di ni bde ba tsam yin na ji ltar lhan cig skyes pa zhes brjod par bya/ 'dra ba dang rgyu'i ngo bo yang yod pa de'i phyir rdo rje'i pad+ma zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te reg par gyur pa na sra ba nyid ni chos so/ / chos ni sa'o/ / byang chub sems ni khu ba ste/ rlan pa'i ngo bo nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ / bskyod pa las ni me'o/ / khu ba 'gro bar 'gyur ba ni rlung ngo / / de'i bde ba ni nam mkha'i khams te/ snang ba med pa'i ngo bo nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te phung po lnga'i bdag nyid ni yin du zad na bde ba chen pos bskyed pa nyid yin pas zag pa med pa'i ngo bo nyid du ci'i phyir mi 'gyur zhe na/ de'i phyir bde ba de nyid ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ kun rdzob tu rdo rje dang pad+mas bskyed pa de ni de kho na nyid ces bya ba yang ma yin la don dam pa'i lhan cig skyes pa yang ma yin no/ / ci'i phyir zhe na/ gang phyir 'byung ba che bde ba/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ 'byung ba chen po bskyed pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te 'byung ba chen po skyed par byed pa yin pas 'byung ba chen po zhes brjod pa yin no/ /

How is this mere worldly pleasure to be equated with the Innate? It is to be equated with the Innate by the reasoning of similarity. The worldly pleasure is equated with the Innate because of it’s similarity with the Means, Compassion. Therefore it is said: sparśāt kāṭhinyadharmeṇa (from contact... as the quality of hardness): The quality is the hardness from the contact. pṛthivī (Earth): Earth refers to that which possesses the quality of hardness. bodhicitta (Enlightened Consciousness): Here refers to semen because of its fluidity. gharṣaṇāt (from the friction): Fire arises from the friction of pounding. gamanāt (movement): Air arises from the movement of semen. saukhyaṃ (pleasure): The pleasure arising from this movement of semen is the Space element because pleasure is devoid of the projection of any form. If the nature of this elemental five-fold aggregate is pure because of arising from the Great Bliss, why is this pleasure not pure? This is answered by: tasmāt ityādi (and so etc.): The pleasure arising from the relative, that is, the phenomenal female and male sexual organs is not the real bliss, the supreme Innate. Why this is so is said by: mahābhūtam ityādi (great elements etc.): Since the origination of this pleasure depends upon the elements it is not the real bliss.
de ltar na sngar ci'i phyir bsngags par byed ce na/ lhan cig skyes par gang skyes pa/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
In that case how the true bliss is to be ascertained is said by:
sahajātyāṃ yad utpannaṃ sahajaṃ tat prakīrtitaṃ || svabhāvaṃ sahajaṃ proktaṃ sarvākāraikasaṃvaraṃ || (41)
lhan cig skyes pas gang skyes pa/ / lhan cig skyes par de brjod bya/ / rang bzhin lhan cig skyes zhes brjod/ / rnam pa thams cad sdom pa gcig /
The Innate is known as that which is manifested by a simultaneous arising. The intrinsic nature is known as the Innate which is the one Concealed Essence of all things.

nang gi bdag nyid can gyi thabs dang shes rab dag las gang byung ba'i lhan cig skyes pa zag pa med pa'i mtshan nyid can de ni don dam par lhan cig skyes par zhes bya ba'i sgras brjod par bya ba yin no/ / 'di nyid gsal bar bstan par bya ba'i phyir rang bzhin zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin dang / de bzhin nyid dang / yang dag pa'i mtha' dang / ngo bo nyid ces bya ba ni rnam grangs so/ / de nyid lhan cig skyes pa nyid/ /ces bya ba'i sgras sngar brjod pa yin gyi bde ba tsam ni ma yin no/ / de khyad par ci lta bu can zhig ce na/ rnam pa thams cad ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rnam pa thams cad ni sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad do/ / de dag mdor bsdus pa ni sdom pa ste/ sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad de la brten pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar nang gi bdag nyid can gyi thabs dang shes rab kyi ting nge 'dzin las skyes pa'i lhan cig bskyed pa brjod pa yin no/ /

That undefiled nature which is produced from the simultaneous coarising of the internal Wisdom and Means is the Innate which is known as the Supreme. In order to clarify this it is said: svabhāvam ityādi (intrinsic nature etc.): Here ‘intrinsic nature’ is synonymous with the primordial state of all things, Thusness and the Absolute Void. This has been called the Innate. If it is not merely pleasure what is it’s uniqueness? This is said by: sarvākāra ityādi (all things etc.): ‘All things’ refers to the nature of all the Buddhas. saṃvaraṃ (the Concealed Essence): Means the quintessence, because all things have their basis in the Innate. Thus the Innate arising from the internal Wisdom and Means is explained.
da ni dmigs pa med pa'i ngo bo nyid kyi thabs dang shes rab kyis bskyed pa'i lhan cig skyes pa bstan pa'i phyir/ rnal 'byor snying rje thabs su 'gyur/ /zhes bya ba gsungs te/
Now in order to reveal the Innate which arises from Wisdom and Means and relies upon no support it is said:
kṛpopāyo bhaved yogī mudrā hetuviyogataḥ || śūnyatākaruṇābhinnaṃ bodhicittaṃ iti smṛtaṃ || (42)
phyag rgya rgyu dang bral ba las/ / yo gi snying rje thabs su 'gyur/ / stong nyid snying rje dbyer med pa/ / byang chub sems zhes rab tu brjod/ /
The Yogi is the Means, mercy and the Consort is the freedom from causality. The absence of distinction between Voidness and Compassion is known as the Enlightened Consciousness.

sems can thams cad la mnyam pa nyid kyi sems ni snying rje'o/ / de nyid ni thabs kyi mchog yin te de yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub sgrub pa'i thabs kyi gtso bo'i ngo bo yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de nyid rnal 'byor pa rnams kyi gtso bo yin pa'i phyir ro/ / phyag rgya ni shes rab bo/ / de gang zhig ce na/ stong pa nyid de chos thams cad kyis ma skyes pa'o/ / ma skyes pa nyid ci ltar yin zhe na/ rgyu dang bral ba las zhes bya ba gsungs te/ bdag dang gzhan dang gnyis las chos thams cad ma skyes pa nyid do/ / ma skyes pa'i mtshan nyid can ni stong pa nyid de mchog tu gyur pa'i shes rab bo/ / de dag dbyer med pa 'od gsal ba'i mtshan nyid can don dam pa'i lhan cig skyes pa zhes bya ba de byang chub sems zhes bya ba'i sgras bstan pa yin gyi/ yang phyi rol gyi phyag rgya las nyams su myong ba'i bde ba tsam ni ma yin no zhes bya bar dgongs so/ /

kṛpā (Mercy): Mercy is the experiencing of oneself as being of the same nature as all livings beings. upāya (Means): Mercy is the supreme Means because it is the method by which complete Enlightenment is accomplished. yogī (male practitioner): The male practitioner is Means because it is the essential quality of yogis. mudrā (consort): Consort refers to Wisdom. What is that? Wisdom is Voidness, the non-arising of all things. How is this non-arising the Voidness? This is said by: hetuviyogataḥ (from freedom from causality): ‘From freedom from causality’ because of the non-arising of all phenomenal things either from self, from another, from both or in the absence of any kind of cause. Therefore the non-arising characteristic is Voidness and is that supreme Wisdom. abhinnaṃ (absence of distinction): Means the absence of distinction between Wisdom and Means. bodhicitta (Enlightened Consciousness): The absence of distinction between Wisdom and Means is the characteristic of the Innate Radiance (prabhāsvara), the supreme perfectly Enlightened Consciousness. The intent is that this Innate is not merely the ordinary pleasure experienced with the external consort.
gal te 'di dag rdzogs pa'i rim pa'i rnal 'byor pas sgom par byed pas na gsang sngags bzlas pa la sogs pa bya'am 'on te mi bya zhe na/ sngags kyi bzlas med ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
Should the yogī just conceive the Process of Completion and should he do or not do the recitation of mantras and other rituals? This is clarified by:
na mantrajāpo na tapo na homo na maṇḍaleyaṃ na ca maṇḍalañ ca || sa mantrajāpaḥ sa tapaḥ sa homas tan maṇḍaleyaṃ tan maṇḍalañ ca || samāsataś cittasamājarūpī || (43)

sngags kyi bzlas med dka' thub med dang sbyin sreg med/ / dkyil 'khor can yang med cing dkyil 'khor yang ni med/ / de ni sngags bzlas de dka' thub dang de sbyin sreg / de ni dkyil 'khor can dang de ni dkyil 'khor nyid/ / mdor bsdus nas ni sems ni 'dus pa'i gzugs can no/ /

No recitation of mantra, no austerity, no fire-sacrifice, no retinue of the maṇḍala and no maṇḍala. The Enlightened Consciousness is the recitation of mantra, the austerity, the fire-sacrifice, the retinue of the maṇḍala and the maṇḍala. All these are aspects of the totality of Consciousness.

sngags ni yi ge oM la sogs pa'o/ / me la mar la sogs pa blugs pa ni sbyin sreg go/ / dkyil 'khor pa'i dbus su gnas pa ni dkyil 'khor can no/ / dkyil 'khor ni gzhal yas khang ngo / / gal te de lta na bsngags bzlas pa la sogs pa'i 'bras bu rnal 'byor ba de la yod par mi 'gyur ro zhe na/ de'i phyir de ni sngags bzlas zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rdzogs pa'i rim pa'i lhan cig skyes pa bsgom pa'i ting nge 'dzin de nyid bsngags pa'i de kho na nyid yin no/ / sems ni ji skad bstan pa'i byang chub kyi sems so/ / de nyid ni bsdus pa ste chos thams cad ro gcig par bsdus pas rnal 'byor pa de'i gzugs can du gyur pa'o/ / de lta bu ni 'dir bzhi pa'i dbang bskur ba zhes bya ba ste/ rnam par rtog pa'i dri ma thams cad 'dis mngon sum du dag par byed pa'i phyir ro/ / dbang bskur ba gsal bar byed pa'i le'u la yang de skad ces bya'o/ /

na mantra (no mantra): Mantra refers to oṃ and so on. tapas (austerity): Refers to the observance of the three daily rituals etc. homa (fire-sacrifice): Refers to the offering of clarified butter and other oblations into the fire. maṇḍaleyaṃ (retinue of the maṇḍala): Refers to those deities located in the maṇḍala. maṇḍalaṃ (maṇḍala): Refers to the inner chamber. In that case is there any benefit for the yogī from mantra recitation etc.! To make this clear it is said: sa ityādi (That etc.): ‘That’ refers to Enlightened Consciousness which is the principle of mantras, the stabilised meditative states and the emanation of the Innate in the Process of Completion. cittaṃ (Consciousness): Therefore the True Principle is the Enlightened Consciousness which is: samāja (the totality): Means the convergence of all natures into one essence. rūpī (aspects): The yogī becomes the meeting place of all these aspects. This is that very Fourth, the Mahāmudrā Consecration. Through the cleansing of all notions and defilements by means of this consecration the True Principle becomes apparent.
abhiṣekapaṭalo daśamaḥ ||
dbang gi le'u zhes bya ba ste bcu pa'o// //
Thus the Tenth, the chapter regarding Consecration.
dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i dka' 'grel rnal 'byor rin po che'i phreng ba zhes bya ba las le'u bcu pa'i 'grel pa'o// //
Thus the chapter regarding consecration has been explained. Thus the tenth chapter of the Hevajra Pañjikā known as the Yogaratnamālā.

d.crumb: CHAPTER 11. Various Rites

f.d: CHAPTER 11. Various Rites

gsang sngags kyi gzhung lugs la sems can rnams gzhug pa'i phyir/ lta stangs bzhi po ltung bar byed pa dang / dbang du bya ba dang dgug pa dang rengs par bya ba rnams mnyam par zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
In the application of mantra, for control of beings, there are four kinds of Gazes. They are Overthrowing (pātanā), Subduing (vasya), Attracting (ākṛṣṭi) and Paralysing (stambhanā).
samākrūrā lalāṭī ca pātanā kathitā sadā || vaśyā vāmāśritā dṛṣṭiḥ puttalī dvau ca vāmataḥ || (1)
mnyam par ma rangs dbral ba can/ / rtag tu ltung bar byed par brjod/ / dbang gi lta stangs g.yon na gnas/ / g.yon pa nas ni gzugs brnyan gnyis/ /
It is said that for the rite of Overthrowing the gaze is straight ahead, cruel and on the forehead. For the rite of Subduing the eyes are focused towards the left with the image on the left.

mnyam pa ni mi g.yo ba'o/ / ma rungs pa ni khro ba dang bcas pa'o/ / dpral ba can ni mig 'bras gnyis dpral ba la brten pa ste/ des ni ltung bar byed do/ / gang g.yon phyogs su brten pa ni g.yon na gnas pa ste des dbang du bya'o/ /

samā (straight ahead): Means not to any side. krūrā (cruel): Means with an angry look. lalāṭī (on the forehead): Means the eyes are focused on the forehead of the symbolic image of the victim. This is the gaze for Overthrowing. vaśyā vāmāśritā (Subduing: the eyes are focused towards the left): In the rite of Subduing the gaze is directed towards the left.
ākṛṣṭir dakṣiṇe bhāge puttalī dvau (hi) cordhvataḥ || madhyamā stambhanādṛṣṭir dvau ca nāsājaḍāntare || (2)
g.yas pa'i cha la dgug pa nyid/ / steng nas kyang ni gzugs brnyan gnyis/ / dbu ma rengs pa'i lta stangs nyid/ / sna yi rtse mo'i dbus su gnyis/ /

For the rite of Attracting the gaze is focused upwards towards the right side and the image is on the right. For the rite of Paralysing the gaze is towards the middle, the eyes focused on the the root of the nostril.
gang steng du brten pa dag gis g.yas logs su blta ba des ni dgug par bya bas so/ / sna gong du drang por blta ba gang yin pa des ni rengs par bya ba'o/ /

ākṛṣṭi (Attracting): In the rite of Attracting the gaze is focused upwards and towards the right. stambhana (Paralysing): In the rite of Paralysing the gaze is focused on the root of the nostril, that is, directed towards one’s own mouth.
pātanā recakenaiva kuṃbhakena vaśīkaret || pūrakeṇaiva tv ākṛṣṭiḥ praśāntakena stambhanā || (3)
'byung ba nyid kyis ltung bar byed/ / rngub pa yis ni dbang du byed/ / dgang ba yis ni dgug pa nyid/ / gzhil ba yis ni rengs par byed/ /
Overthrowing is performed by means of exhalation; Subduing by breath retention; Attracting is by inhalation and Paralysing by the tranquilly-held breath.
sna'i rtse mo nas 'byung ba nyid kyi rlung ni 'byung ba nyid do/ / 'jug pa ni 'gengs byed do/ / nang gang bar gyur pa ni bum pa'o/ / zhugs nas mi g.yo bar gyur pa ni zhi ba'o/ /

recaka (exhalation): ‘Exhalation’ is the attentive releasing of the breath through the nostrils. pūraka (inhalation): ‘Inhalation’ is the attentive entering in of the breath through the nostrils. kumbhaka (breath retention): ‘Breath retention’ is the full breath held within. praśānta (tranquilly-held breath): ‘The tranquilly-held breath’ is the inhaled breath made motionless.
'di dag goms par bya ba'i gnas bstan pa'i phyir rlon pa'i shing zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
The locations appropriate for the diligent application of these four rites are mentioned by:
pātanā snigdhavṛkṣeṣu vaśyā puṣpaprakīrtitā || ākṛṣṭir vajravṛkṣeṣu staṃbhanā sacare tṛṇe || (4)
rlon pa'i shing la ltung byed nyid/ / dbang ni me tog rab tu grags/ / rdo rje'i shing la dkug pa nyid/ / g.yo bcas rtsa la rengs byed nyid/ /
The rite of Overthrowing must be performed among succulent trees; Subduing among flowering trees; Attracting among vajra trees and Paralysing amongst moving grass.
khu ba dang bcas pa'i shing dang / me tog dmar po dang / rdo rje shing dang / g.yo ba dang bcas pa'i rtswa rnams la'o/ /
snigdhavṛkṣeṣu ityādi (succulent trees etc.): For Overthrowing and the other rites the ‘trees’ are juicy trees, red-flowered trees, plants with milky sap and moving grass, respectively.
ṣaṇmāsābhyāsayogena siddhyati nātra saṃśayaḥ || bhrāntir atra na kartavyā • ācintyā {hi} buddharddhayaḥ || (5)
zla drug goms pa'i sbyor ba yis/ / 'grub 'gyur 'dri la the tshom med/ / 'di la 'khrul ba mi bya ste/ / sangs rgyas rdzu 'phrul bsam mi khyab/ /
The yogī will definitely accomplish his goal by practising these gazes for six months. In this regard have no confusions for the powers of the Buddha are unimaginable.
'khrul pa ni the tshom dang bcas pa'o/ / gsang ba'i lta stangs ci'i phyir ma gsungs she na/ 'dir dgongs pa ma yin te/
bhrānti (confusion): Means doubts. The gaze for the rite of Killing has not been mentioned. Why it has not been mentioned is said by:
sādhayitvā caturdṛṣṭiṃ sattvāni tārayed budhaḥ || māraṇaṃ nātra kāryaṃ syāt samayabhedaḥ paraṃ bhavet || (6)
lta stangs bzhi po bsgrubs nas ni/ / mkhas pas sems can gzhug par bya/ / gsad par 'di la bya ma yin/ / dam tshig nges par nyams par 'gyur/ /
Having mastered the four Gazes the wise one must save all beings. Here actual killing should not be performed. If killing is performed it becomes a breakage of the Observance of the Vow.
lta stangs bzhi po bsgrubs nas ni/ / mkhas pas sems can gzhug par bya/ /zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /
The Gazes have been mentioned in order to overcome beings and not for killing beings.
sarvākāryaṃ tu kartavyaṃ hitvā sattvasya vañcanāṃ || sattvāpakāramātreṇa mudrāsiddhir na labhyate || (7)
sems can slu ba spangs nas ni/ / bya ba ma yin thams cad bya/ / sems can gnod pa tsam gyis ni/ / phyag rgya'i dngos grub rnyed mi 'gyur/ /
In this practice anything may be performed, except deceiving other beings, for the Mudrā Accomplishment is not attained by harming living beings.
samayaṃ bhakṣayet tatra pradīpyantaṃ samāhitaḥ || nādiṃ gādiṃ tathā hādim antaśvam ādiśvaṃ ca vā || (8) pañcāmṛtaṃ tathā bhakṣyaṃ Hevajre siddhihetunā ||

de la dam tshig bza' bya ba/ / na dang ga ha dang po dang / / mtha' yi shwa dang dang po'i shwa/ / kye'i rdo rje yi dngos grub phyir/ / bdud rtsi lnga yang de bzhin bza'/ / kye yi rdo rjes gsungs mtshan nyid/ /

During the rite attentively eat the sacramental food which includes excrements, and the meat of human beings, cows, elephants, horses and dogs. The Five Nectars must be consumed for the sake of accomplishment in the Hevajra.

saptāvartan tato lakṣet Hevajroktais tu lakṣaṇaiḥ || (9) saptāvarte bhavet siddhir viramānandadūṣakī || susvarañ cakṣuṣmac caiva gandhakāyaṃ mahāvapuḥ || (10) saptacchāyā bhavet tasya dṛṣṭvā yogī tu lakṣayet || tasya prāśitamātreṇa khecaratvaṃ bhavet kṣaṇāt || (11)

skye ba bdun pa'ang de nas mtshon/ / dga' bral dga' ba la smod pa/ / lan bdun pas ni 'grub par 'gyur/ / skad snyan mig dang ldan pa dang / / dri lus gzi brjid chen po dang / / de yi grib ma bdun du 'gyur/ / mthong nas rnal 'byor pa yis mtshon/ / de ni zos pa tsam gyis ni/ / skad cig las ni mkha' spyod 'gyur/ /

Then the yogī should mark out a Seven-times-retumed who possesses the characteristics mentioned in the Hevajra tradition. Through the Seven-times-retumed comes the accomplishment which is the destroyer of the Joy of Cessation. The Seven-times-retumed has a fine voice, beautiful eyes, a well proportioned and sweet-smelling body and has seven shadows. When such a man is sighted the yogī should mark him out. Just by eating his flesh the power to move in space is instantaneously attained.
skye ba bdun pa ni len bdun skyes pa'o/ / dga' bral dga' ba smod pa la/ /zhes bya ba ni lhan cig skyes pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi dngos grub bo/ /
saptāvartan (Seven-times returned): ‘Seven-times’ means seven births. virāmānandadūṣakī (destroyer of the Joy of Cessation): Refers to the accomplishment of the Innate Joy.

atha Kurukullāyāḥ sādhanaṃ vakṣye yena sarvasattvāni vaśaṃ yānti / saṃkṣiptaṃ pūrvam uddiṣṭaṃ vistareṇa kalpadvādaśaiḥ || (12) HRĪḤ-kārasambhavā devī raktavarṇā caturbhujā || iṣukārmukahastā ca • utpalāṅkuṣadharaṇā || (13) asyā bhāvanāmātreṇa trailokyaṃ vaśam ānayet || lakṣeṇaikena rājānaḥ prajāloko 'yutena ca || (14) paśuyakṣādayaḥ koṭyā saptalakṣeṇa cāsurāḥ || lakṣadvayena devāś ca śatenaikena mantriṇaḥ || (15)

ku ru kul+le'i sgrub thabs bshad par bya ste/ gong du brtag pa bcu gnyis par/ / rgyas par gsungs pa mdo ru bsdu/ / hrIHlas byung ba'i lha mo ni/ / kha dog dmar zhing phyag bzhi ma/ / mda' dang gzhu yi lag pa ma/ / ut+pa la dang lcags kyu 'dzin/ / 'di ni bsgoms pa tsam gyis ni/ / 'jig rten gsum po dbang du byed/ / 'bum phrag gcig gis rgyal po rnams/ / khri yis 'jig rten phal ba nyid/ / bye bas phyugs dang gnod sbyin sogs/ / 'bum phrag bdun gyis lha ma yin/ / 'bum phrag gnyis kyis lha rnams nyid/ / brgya phrag gcig gis sngags pa nyid/ /

Now I shall explain the propitiation of Kurukullā, by means of which all beings are subdued. It has previously been mentioned briefly and is fully described in the tantra consisting of twelve parts. The Goddess Kurukullā originates from the seed-syllable hrīḥ, is red in colour, four-armed and holds arrows, a bow, a lotus and a goad in her hands. The three worlds are subdued by merely emanating her. By one hundred thousand repetitions of her mantra kings are subdued; by ten thousand, ordinary people; by ten million, animals, Yakṣa etc.; by seven hundred thousand, titans; by two hundred thousand, the gods and by one hundred, other mantra-practitioners.

dbang gi las la ni ku ru kul+le khyad par du bsngags te/ de'i sgrub thabs mdor bsdus pa'o/ / gang sngon du bstan pa der ni rgyas par bshad pa ste/ dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i rgyud brtag pa bcu gnyis par ro/ / mda' ni mda'o/ / gzhu ni gzhu'o/ / ut+pa la ni ut+palo/ / lcags kyu ni lcags kyu'o/ / thams cad kyang dmar po'o/ /

kurukullā: The rite of subduing is a speciality of the goddess Kurukullā. saṃkṣiptaṃ (briefly): Refers to that which has previously been mentioned [1.2.19]. vistareṇa (fully described): Her propitiation is explained in detail in the larger Hevajra Tantra consisting of twelve parts. iṣu ityādi (arrows etc.): The arrows, bow, lotus and goad are all red in colour.
Śrīhevajraḍākinījālasamvara-Vajragarbhābhisaṃbodhi-nāma prathamaḥ kalparājā samāptaḥ ||
kye'i rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dra ba'i sdom pa las rdo rje snying po mngon par byang chub pa zhes bya ba brtag pa'i rgyal po rdzogs so// //
Thus ends the first regal part, called the Awakening of Vajragarbha [in the Great Regal Tantra known as] the Concealed Essence of the Ḍākinīs of the Divine Hevajra.

rdo rje ni rdo rje 'chang ngo / / de'i snying po ni thugs te dgyes pa'i rdo rje'o/ / de'i mngon par zhes bya ba ma lus par rtogs pa gang yang yod pa de ni rdo rje snying po mngon par byang chub pa'o/ / de gsal bar byed pa'i rtog pa la yang de skad ces bya'o/ /

[Vajragarbhābhisaṃbodhi is analysed:] Vajra refers to Vajradhara and garbha refers to Vajradhara’s essence. From the awakening of the essence of Vajradhara bodhi, enlightenment, comes about. Thus: Vajragarbhābhisaṃbodhi: Means the awakening of the essence of Vajradhara. The first section of this tantra which explains this awakening is so called.
dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i dka' 'grel rnal 'byor rin po che'i phreng ba zhes bya ba las brtag pa dang po'i 'grel ba'o// //
Thus ends the Second Chapter of the Second Part of the Hevajra Pañjikā known as the Yogaratnamālā.

d.crumb: CHAPTER 1. Rite of Establishing Sanctity

f.d: CHAPTER 1. Rite of Establishing Sanctity
atha Vajragarbha āha / deśayantu yathānyāyaṃ pratiṣṭhālakṣaṇaṃ śubhaṃ || bhagavān vajrasārātmā sarvabuddhaikasaṃgrahaḥ || (1)
rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ bcom ldan rdo rje snying po bdag / sangs rgyas thams cad gcig bsdus pa/ / rab gnas mtshan nyid bzang po nyid/ / rim pa ji bzhin bshad du gsol/ /
Then Vajragarbha spoke: May Bhagavān, the one who is the essence of the Vajras and the epitome of all the Buddhas, instruct upon the auspicious characteristics of the Rite for Establishing Sanctity.

ras ris la sogs pa la lha rnams nges par gnas pa ni rab gnas so/ / 'dir ni de'i cho ga la rab gnas zhes bya'o/ / de'i mtshan nyid ni rang gi ngo bo'o/ / rdo rje ni phyag na rdo rje ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi sku dang gsung dang thugs so/ / de nyid ni snying po ste de'i bdag nyid gang la yod pa de la de skad ces bya'o/ /

pratiṣṭhā (Rite of Establishing Sanctity): The Rite of Establishing Sanctity is the ritual for making deities abide in pictures and so on, and here refers to the procedural rules for making the deities abide. lakṣaṇaṃ (characteristic): Refers to the nature of the Rite of Establishing Sanctity. vajrasārātmā (the one who is the essence of the Vajras): Here Vajras refer to the Body, Speech and Mind of all the Buddhas. Therefore, the one who is the essence of the Body, Speech and Mind of all the Buddhas is known as the one who is the essence of the Vajras.
bhagavān āha / homaṃ kṛtvā yathāproktaṃ vartayitvā tu maṇḍalaṃ || pradoṣe saṃskaret pratimāṃ kṛtvādhivāsanādikaṃ || (2)
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / ci gsungs sbyin sreg byas nas ni/ / dkyil 'khor dam pa bzhengs pa dang / / snga bar sku gzugs sbyang ba dang / / sta gon la sogs byas nas ni/ /
Bhagavān spoke: After having performed the fire sacrifice as prescribed and constructing the maṇḍala, at dusk sanctify the image performing the preliminary rituals of purification and so on.

sbyin sreg ces bya ba ni bgegs gzhig par bya ba'i phyir ro/ / srod la zhes bya ba ni mtshan mo rtsom pa'i dus su'o/ / sta gon la sogs byas nas ni/ /zhes bya ba ni cho ga ji lta ba bzhin du sta gon byas nas zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

homaṃ (fire sacrifice): The fire sacrifice is performed in order to remove obstacles. pradoṣe (at dusk): Means at night-fall. kṛtvādhivāsanādikam (performing the preliminary ritual of purification and so on): Means performing the preliminary ritual of purification according to the rules.
gaganasthān sarvabuddhān pratimāhṛdi veṣayet || sveṣṭadevatāsaṃyogī pratyakṣamantrapāragaḥ || (3)
nam mkhar bzhugs pa'i sangs rgyas kun/ / sku gzugs snying gar rab tu gzhug / rang 'dod lha mnyam rnal 'byor pa/ / rab mthong sngags kyi pha rol son/ /
The yogī, at one with his chosen deity and full of the knowledge of mantras, should make all the Buddhas residing in all the directions enter into the heart of the image.
sangs rgyas kun zhes bya ba ni rab tu gnas par bya ba'o/ /
veṣayet (make ... enter): Means all the Buddhas must be made to abide in the image.
OṂ vajrapuṣpe ĀḤ HŪṂ SVĀHĀ / OṂ vajradhūpe ĀḤ HŪṂ SVĀHĀ / OṂ vajradīpe ĀḤ HŪṂ SVĀHĀ / OṂ vajragandhe ĀḤ HŪṂ SVĀHĀ / OṂ vajranaivedye ĀḤ HŪṂ SVĀHĀ /
oM badzra puSh+pe AHhUM swA hA/ oM badzra d+hu pe AHhUM swA hA/ oM badzra dI pe AHhUM swA hA/ oM badzra gan+d+he AHhUM swA hA/ / oM badzra nai we d+ye AHhUM swA hA/
[These are the mantras for the five ritual offerings of flowers, incense, lamp, perfume and food respectively.]
oM zhes bya ba la sogs pa ni mchod pa'i sngags bstan pa'o/ /
oṃ ityādi (om etc.): These are the mantras for the ritual offerings.
nāna-HŪṂ-kāranniṣpannān puṣpādyāṃs tu praḍhaukayet || arghapādyādikaṃ prāgvat pūrvatantravidhikramaiḥ || (5)
sna tshogs hUM ni rdzogs pa dang / / me tog la sogs dbul ba nyid/ / gong ma'i rgyud kyi chog rim pas/ / mchod yon zhabs bsil gong ma bzhin/ /

Various kinds of flowers along with the uttering of the seed-syllable hum should be offered. The water for the libation, the water for washing the feet and so on should be offered, as before, in accordance with the rules prescribed in the earlier tantra.

sna tshogs zhes bya ba'i rnam pa sna tshogs pa'o/ / gong ma'i rgyud kyi lugs rim pa'i dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i rgyud rgyas pa'i cho ga'i rim pas so/ / skabs la bab pa'i sbyin sreg thams cad bstan pa'i phyir zhi ba'i thab khung zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/

nānā (various): Means different kinds. pūrvatantraṃ (the earlier tantra): Refers to the larger version of the Heruka Tantra. vidhikramaiḥ (in accordance with the rules prescribed): Refers to the rules prescribed in the Heruka Tantra. Now the rules for the different fire sacrifices are mentioned.
śāntike vartulaṃ kuṇḍaṃ caturasvaṃ tu pauṣṭike || trikoṇaṃ māraṇe proktaṃ śeṣān atraiva sādhayet || (6)
zhi ba'i thab khung zlum po nyid/ / rgyas pa nyid kyi gru bzhi pa/ / gsad pa la ni gru gsum brjod/ / 'di nyid la ni lhag ma bsgrub/ /
The sacrificial fire-pit used for the rite of Pacifying is circular, for the rite of Abundance is square-shaped and for Killing as well as for the remaining rites is triangular.
ekahastārdhahastaṃ vā 'dhordhve tu śāntikaṃ bhavet || dvihastam ekahastañ ca • adhordhve pauṣṭikaṃ mataṃ || (7) viṃśatyaṅgulam ardhaṃ ca • adhordhve māraṇaṃ bhavet ||

khru gang dang ni khru phyed nyid/ / zhi ba'i steng dang 'og tu yin/ / khru do dang ni khru gang nyid/ / rgyas pa'i steng dang 'og tu brjod/ / sor mo nyi shu'am de yi phyed/ / gsad pa'i steng dang 'og tu yang / /

The dimensions of the sacrificial fire-pit for the rite of Pacifying is one cubit in depth [from the surface] and half a cubit above the surface; for the rite of Abundance it is two cubits in depth and one cubit in height and for the rite of Killing it is twenty fingers in depth and ten fingers in height.
śukravarṇaṃ bhavec chāntau pītan tu pauṣṭike tathā || (8) māraṇe kṛṣṇavarṇañ ca vaśye raktaṃ prakīrtitaṃ || yathā vaśye tathākṛṣṭau dveṣādau yathā māraṇe || (9)
zhi bar kha dog dkar por 'gyur/ / rgyas par ser po de bzhin no/ / gsad pa la ni kha dog gnag / dbang la dmar por rab tu grags/ / dbang la ji bzhin de ltar dgug / gsad la ji ltar zhe sdang sogs/ /

For Pacifying the colour is white, for Abundance yellow, for Killing black and for Attracting red. The colour for Subduing is the same as that for Attracting and the colours for Causing hatred and the rest are the same as that for Killing.
de nyid la ni zhes bya ba ni gsum po 'di nyid la ci ltar rigs par til la sogs pas sbyin sreg bya ba'o/ /
The ingredients that should be offered in the three kinds of rites are mentioned now.
tīlaṃ śāntau dadhi puṣṭau māraṇe kaṇṭhakaṃ tathā || dveṣādau kaṇṭhakaṃ proktaṃ vaśya ākṛṣṭau cotpalaṃ || (10)
zhi la til dang rgyas la zho/ / gsad la tsher ma de bzhin no/ / sdang la sogs pa'ang tsher mar brjod/ / dbang dang dgug la ut+pa la/
For Pacifying offer sesame seeds, for Abundance clarified butter and for Killing thorns; for Causing hatred etc. also thorns and for Subduing and Attracting lotus flowers.
OṂ agnaye mahātejaḥ sarvakāmaprasādhaka || kāruṇyakṛtasatvārtha • asmin sannihito bhava || agnyāvāhanamantraḥ / (11)
oM a sne ma hA te dzA/ sar+b+ba karma pa sA d+hu kaH kA ru N+yA kr-i ta sa twa ar+tha a smin san+ni hi to b+ha ba/ me dgug pa'o/ /
The mantra for invoking the Fire deity is: Oṃ! O Fire of great brilliance, granter of all desires, compassionate for the benefit of all beings! Be present here.
tvaṃ devi sākṣībhūtāsi hevajrakrodhapūjite || nānāratnadhari dhātry amuko 'haṃ maṇḍalaṃ likhe || (12)
ma ma rin chen sna tshogs 'dzin/ / kye yi rdo rje khros mchod pa'i/ / lha mo khyod ni dbang du gyur/ / che ge bdag ni dkyil 'khor 'dri/ /
I, so and so, draw this maṇḍala with you as witness, O Goddess who is the bearer of many jewels and worshipped by the wrath of Hevajra.
lha mo khyed ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa ni sa gzung ba'i skabs su ste/ 'di ni sngags brjod pa'i skabs yin par bstan to/ /
tvaṃ devi ityādi (you ... O’ Goddess etc.): This is the mantra for invoking the Earth goddess.
svārthañ caiva parārthañ ca sādhituṃ gaccha havyabhuk || āgamiṣyasi yathākāle sarvasiddhiṃ kuruṣva me || agnisantoṣaṇamantraḥ / (13)
swAr+thany+tsai ba ba rAr+thany+tsa sA d+hi taM gats+tsha ha bya b+hu ka / A ga mi Sh+ya si ya thA kA le sar+b+ba sid+d+hiM ku ru Sh+wa me/ me dga' ba'i sngags so/ /

The mantra for propitiating the Fire deity is: O Consumer of the sacrificial offerings, go in order to accomplish your desires as well as those of others, and return in time of need. Accomplish everything for me.
OṂ JAḤ HŪṂ VAṂ HĀḤ KHAṂ RAṂ / arghamantraḥ / OṂ NĪ RĪ HŪṂ KHAḤ / pādyamantraḥ / OṂ DHVAṂ DHVAṂ DHVAṂ / naivedyamantraḥ / (14)
oM dzaHhUM baM hoH khaM raM mchod yon gyi sngags so/ / oM ni ri ti hUM khaMHzhabs bsil gyi sngags so/ / oM d+h+wa~M d+h+wa~M lha bshos kyi sngags so/ /
The mantra for the libation is: oṃ jaḥ hūṃ vaṃ hāḥ khaṃ raṃ. The mantra for washing the feet is: oṃ nī rī hūṃ khaḥ. The mantra for the food offering is: oṃ dhvaṃ dhvaṃ dhvaṃ.
mthar ni ar+g+haM la sogs pa'i sngags te me la dbul ba'o/ /
The mantras for the libation and the other offerings are for use in the fire sacrifice.
homanirṇayapratiṣṭhāpaṭalaḥ prathamaḥ ||
kye'i rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dra ba'i sdom pa las brtag pa gnyis pa rab gnas kyi le'u ste dang po'o// //
Thus ends the First, the chapter regarding the Rules for the Fire-sacrifice and the Rite of Establishing Sanctity.
dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i dka' 'grel rnal 'byor rin po che'i phreng ba zhes bya ba las dang po rab gnas kyi le'u'i 'grel pa'o// //
Thus ends the first chapter of the second part of the Hevajra Pañjikā known as the Yogaratnamālā.

d.crumb: CHAPTER 2. Definition of the Accomplishment

f.d: CHAPTER 2. Definition of the Accomplishment
Vajragarbha āha / gaganavatsarvadharmeṣu sāgare tumbikā yathā || sattvāḥ kathaṃ prasidhyanti sveṣṭadevatārūpataḥ || (1)
rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ nam mkha' lta bu'i chos kun la/ / rgya mtshor ku ba ji lta bar/ / rang 'dod lha yi gzugs las ni/ / sems can ji ltar 'grub par 'gyur/ /
Vajragarbha asked: How is it possible for beings to attain perfection by means of their chosen deity who is like a gourd floating in the ocean of existence which is extensive as space?

rdo rje snying pos gsol pa zhes bya ba ni zhus pa'o/ / nam mkha' lta bu zhes bya ba la sogs pa la sems can rnams kyi dge ba ma yin pa'i chos thog ma med pa'i dus nas brtsams pa ni nam mkha' lta bu'o/ / de dag gi gnyen po'i phyogs su gyur pa ni rang 'dod pa'i lha bsgom pa'o/ / de lta bas na mi mthun pa'i phyogs kyi phung po ni rgya mtsho lta bu yin la/ gnyen po'i phyogs ni ku ba lta bur gnas pas/ mi dge ba'i rgya mtsho las rgal bar nus pa ma yin no snyam du dgongs pa'o/ / de ltar na sems can rnams de bsgoms pas grol bar ci ltar 'gyur zhes bya ba ni zhus pa'i don to/ /

vajragarbha āha (Vajragarbha said): Means he questioned. gaganavat ityādi (as space etc.): The adverse natures of living beings, accumulated from beginningless time, are vast like space. The antidote for the misfortune of beings is the emanation of their chosen deity. How can beings attain perfection by means of the emanation of the deity’s form because such an antidote, which is like a gourd in the ocean of adversities, is not fully capable of overcoming the adversities? Such is the intent of his question.
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/
To this Bhagavān replied:
bhagavān āha / nairātmyāyogayuktātmā 'thavā herukayogataḥ || kṣaṇam apy anyacittaḥ san na tiṣṭhet siddhikāṅkṣakaḥ || (2)
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / bdag med rnal 'byor ldan pa'am/ / yang na he ru ka dpal brtson/ / gzhan pa'i sems kyis skad cig kyang / / dngos grub 'dod pas mi gnas so/ /
Bhagavān replied: One who wishes to attain the Accomplishment should remain at one in union with Nairātmyā or Heruka and should not even for a moment rest in any other thought.

bdag med rnal 'byor zhes bya ba la sogs pa ste/ rnal 'byor ni ting nge 'dzin te de dang ldan pa'i bdag nyid dam/ / yang na dpal he ru ka'i rnal 'byor dang ldan pa'i bdag nyid ni rnal 'byor gyi mi mthun pa'i phyogs kyi phung po ma lus par spongs nas nges par 'grub par 'gyur ro zhes bya ba'o/ / gal te rgya mtsho lta bu'i mi mthun pa'i phyogs kyi phung po las lha'i rnal 'byor tsam gyis ji ltar rgal bar 'gyur zhe na/ rgal bar 'gyur ba nyid yin te/ ji ltar ri'i phug gi nang gi mun pa'i phung po yun ring por bsags pa ni 'bar ma thag pa'i me sgron gyis skad cig gis mi snang bar byed do/ / de bzhin du 'dir yang bdag med ma dang dgyes pa'i rdo rje bsgom pa'i khyad par gyis 'gyur ro zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ /

nairātmyāyogayuktātmā (at one in union with Nairātmyā): ‘Union’ refers to a stabilised meditative state. The yogī who is at one in union with Nairātmyā or Hevajra certainly accomplishes by eliminating all adversities. How is it possible to overcome the ocean-like adversities merely by means of the union with the deity? The intent is that just as a fire in a mountain cave burns once and destroys the long standing accumulation of darkness, so is the benefit of emanating Nairātmyā and Hevajra.

gal te de ltar na yang gnyen po'i phyogs skad cig tsam bsgoms pas mi mthun pa nyams par 'gyur ba zhig yin na/ de lta na ni ci'i phyir dngos grub 'grub par mi 'gyur zhe na/ de ni bden ni de lta na mi mthun pa'i phyogs nyams pa tsam gyis phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub 'thob pa ni ma yin no/ / 'on kyang tshogs gnyis rdzogs pa des ni 'thob par 'gyur ro/ / de nyid kyi phyir/ gzhan pa'i sems kyis skad cig kyang / /zhes bya ba gsungs te/ gzhan pa'i sems zhes bya ba ni zhi gnas kyi mtshan nyid can gyi bsgom pa'i khyad par las so/ / de yang rim gyis goms pas 'thob par bya ba yin pas na/ de'i phyir/ dang por goms par byed dus kyis/ /zhes bya ba la sogs gsungs te/

In that case, if adversities are destroyed by performing the emanation of this antidote once, why is it that there is no accomplishment? A yogī does not attain the Mahāmudrā Accomplishment by merely destroying the adversities once unless the yogī is fully resplendent in union with these two deities. In order to indicate this it is said: kṣaṇam apy anyacittaḥ san (even for a moment... any ether thought); ‘One-pointed mind’, a sign of the tranquil state of mind (śamatā), is a special characteristic of the practice of emanation. It is attained gradually by means of persevering in the practice. Now that practice is described.

prathamābhyāsakālasya sthānaṃ vai kalpitaṃ śubhaṃ || yatrasthaḥ siddhyate mantrī ekacittaḥ samāhitaḥ || (3) svagṛheṣu niśākāle siddho 'ham it cetasā || bhāvayed yoginīṃ prājño 'thavā śrīherukākṛtiṃ || (4)

dang po goms par byed dus kyi/ / gnas ni gang du bsngags pa'i sems/ / gcig tu mnyam gzhag 'grub 'gyur ba'i/ / gnas ni bzang po nges par brtag / rang gi khyim du mtshan dus su/ / bdag nyid 'grub pa'i sems kyis ni/ / rnal 'byor ma bsgom shes rab can/ / yang na he ru ka dpal gzugs/ /

At the initial stage of the practice an auspicious location is chosen where the practitioner, who is single-minded and well composed, can accomplish. At night in his own house, with the attitude ‘I am the accomplished one’, the wise one should emanate the form of the Yoginī or the divine Heruka.

mtshan dus su zhes bya ba ni mtshan mo nyid kyi dus su ste/ dus gzhan na mi mthun pa'i sa phyogs 'byung bar 'gyur bas so/ / bdag nyid 'grub pa'i zhes pa ni mos pa'i khyad par te/ mtshan mo mnyam par gzhag pa'i rnal 'byor bya'o zhes bya ba gsungs pa'o/ / de las gzhan pa'i dus su rgyun mi 'chad par bya ba'i phyir/ rkang pa 'khrud dang zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs pa la/

niśakāle (at night): Since there are adverse conditions at other times this practice should be performed at night. siddho ’ham (‘I am the accomplished one’): This is an attitude assumed in order to lead to the actual accomplishment. The Regulated Practice (samāhitayoga) for the night has been mentioned. The Continuous Practice (nirantarayoga) to be followed at other times is mentioned by:

aṅghriṃ prakṣālayan bhuñjan ācamapūgaṃ bhakṣayan || candanair hastaṃ mardayan kaupinaiś chādayan kaṭiṃ || (5) niḥsaraṃ bhāṣayan bhāṣāṃ gacchan tiṣṭhan ruṣan hasan || bhagavatīṃ sevayet prājño yoginīṃ bhāvayed vratī || (6)

rkang pa 'khrud dang za ba dang / / 'thor 'thung so rtsi za ba dang / / tsan+dan gyis ni lag nyed dang / / smad g.yogs kyis ni rkang 'gebs dang / / 'byung dang smra dang 'gro ba dang / / 'dug dang khro dang rgod pa dang / / bcom ldan 'das ma bsten pa dang / / shes rab brtul zhugs can nyid kyis/ / rnal 'byor ma ni rnam par bsgom/ /

At all times whether washing the feet, rinsing the mouth, chewing betel-nut, anointing the hands with sandal-wood paste, tying the loin cloth around the waist, going out, conversing, walking, standing, angry or laughing, the wise holder of the Vow should serve the Goddess and emanate the Yoginī.
bsten pa dang zhes bya ba ni bsnyen par bya ba'o/ / gang la bsnyen par bya zhe na/ rnal 'byor ma ste bdag med ma la'o/ /
sevayet (serve): Means worship. Who is to be worshipped? The Yoginī Nairātmyā.
kṣaṇam apy anyarūpeṇa • avidyāduṣṭacetasā || na sthātavyaṃ buddhair yatnāt siddhyarthaṃ siddhikāṅkṣibhiḥ || (7)
gzhan gyi tshul gyis skad cig kyang / / gdug pa'i sems ni mi rigs pas/ / dngos grub 'dod pas dngos grub phyir/ / mkhas pas 'bad pas mi gnas so/ /
Those desiring the accomplishment of the Enlightened Ones, with perfection as their goal, should not even for one moment with their mind afflicted by ignorance identify with any other form.
gzhan gyi gzugs kyis zhes bya ba ni bdag med ma ma yin pa'i gzugs kyis so/ /
anyarūpa (any other form): Means forms other than that of Nairātmyā.

Vajragarbha mayākhyātaṃ dhyānaṃ kilbiṣanāśanaṃ || siddhyarthaṃ kautukenāpi pakṣam ekaṃ parikṣethāḥ || (8) sarvacintāṃ parityajya devatāmurticetasā || dinam ekam avicchinnaṃ bhāvayitvā parikṣethāḥ || (9)

bsam gtan nyon mongs 'jig byed pa/ / rdo rje snying po nga yis bshad/ / brtse bas dngos grub don du yang / / zla ba phyed du yongs su rtogs/ / bsam pa thams cad yongs spangs nas/ / lha yi gzugs su sems pa yis/ / nyi ma gcig tu ma chad par/ / bsgom pas yongs su brtag par gyis/ /

O Vajragarbha, I proclaim that this practice of concentration is the destroyer of all evils. In order to become accomplished, test the practice zealously for fifteen days. Discarding all other thoughts, with the mind identified with the form of the deity, perform the emanation for one day and test the practice.

rdo rje snying po zhes bya ba ni nye bar sdud pa'o/ / nyon mongs pa zhes bya ba ni skyon no/ / brtan pa nyid bskyed par bya ba'i phyir ro/ / brtse bas zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ zla phyed ces bya ba ni zla ba phyed do/ / nyi ma gcig tu zhes bya ba ni shin tu mnyam par gzhag pa'i tshul gyis so/ /

vajragarbha ityādi (O Vajragarbha etc.): This is the summing up of the previous verses. kilbiṣaṃ (evils): Refers to adverse influences. In order to produce a firm determination it is said: kautukenāpi (zealously). pakṣam (fifteen days): Means half a month. avicchinnaṃ (uninterruptedly): Means with intense attention for a whole day.

nānyopāyo 'sti saṃsāre svaparārthaprasiddhaye || sakṛd abhyāsitā vidyā sadyaḥ pratyayakāriṇī || (10) bhayonmādais tathā duḥkhaiḥ śokapīḍādyupadravaiḥ || rāgadveṣamahāmohaiḥ sādhako naiva kliśyate || (11)

rang gzhan don ni rab bsgrub phyir/ / 'khor bar thabs gzhan yod ma yin/ / rig ma lhan cig goms byas pas/ / 'phral du mngon du byed pa nyid/ 'jigs smyo de bzhin sdug bsngal dang / / mya ngan gdung ba 'tshe ba dang / / 'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug ches/ / sgrub pa po ni nyon mi mongs/ /

There is no other means than this in the whole of existence for accomplishing goals of oneself and others. Once this technique is perseveringly practised its benefit is immediately demonstrated. The practitioner is then not afflicted by fears, madness, miseries, sorrows, molestations and other troubles, passion, anger and great delusions.
lan cig ces bya ba ni rtag tu thun re goms par byed pa'o/ / 'jig zhes bya ba la sogs pa ni yid ches pa ston par byed do/ /
sakṛt (once): Means every day, at one juncture, perseveringly practise. bhaya ityādi (fears etc.): This statement demonstrates the value of the practice.
evaṃ vimṛṣyamāṇā vai hitāhitaphalodayaṃ || kathaṃ te kṣaṇam apy ekaṃ yoginaḥ santi raurave || (12)
phan dang gnod pa'i 'bras 'byung bar/ / de ltar nges par shes nas ni/ / ji ltar de ni skad cig kyang / / rnal 'byor ma rnams du 'bod gnas/ /
Deliberating in this manner on the arising of favourable and unfavourable fruits, how can yogis exist even for one moment in the fearful fiery hell!

de ltar zhes bya ba la sogs pa la nges par shes nas zhes bya ba ni nges par spyod pa'i ngang tshul can no/ / phan pa'i 'bras bu 'byung bar 'gyur zhing mi phan pa ste dge ba ma yin pa ni zad par 'gyur ba'o/ / ngu 'bod ces bya ba la 'jig rten gyi spyod pa ni dmyal ba'i rgyu yin no/ /

evaṃ vimṛsyamāṇā (deliberating in this manner): Means constantly deliberating. hitāhitaphalodayaṃ (arising of favourable and unfavourable fruits): The ‘arising of favourable’ refers to the arising of the benefits when deeds are performed in the world. The ‘arising of unfavourable’ refers to the arising of adversities. raurave (in the fearful fiery hell): Means in the cause for hell which are the deeds performed in the phenomenal world.

gal te de lta bur gnas par gyur kyang sdig pa can la sogs pa rnams kyis phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub 'thob pa'i skabs ga la yod ce na/ mtshams med lnga ni byed pa dang / /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
What right do sinful people have to the Mahāmudrā Accomplishment? This is answered by:
pañcānantaryakāriṇaḥ prāṇivadharatāś ca ye || api tu ye janmahīnā ye mūrkhāḥ krūrakarmiṇaḥ || (13) kurūpā vikalagātrāś ca siddhyante te 'pi cintayā ||

mtshams med lnga ni byed pa dang / / srog chags gsod la dga' ba dang / / gzhan yang skye ba dman gang dang / / rmongs dang ma rungs las byed dang / / gzugs ngan yan lag mtshang ba'ang / / bsams pas de rnams 'grub par 'gyur/ /

By such a deliberation even those who have committed the five ignoble deeds, those who delight in killing living beings, those who are of low birth, those who are stupid, those who perform cruel deeds and those who are deformed and lacking limbs accomplish.
yan lag ma tshang ba ni yan lag nyams pa'o/ / bsams pas zhes bya ba ni bdag med ma bsgoms pas so/ /
vikalagātrāḥ (those... lacking limbs): Means those with deformities. cintayā (by such a thought): Means by the emanation of Nairātmyā.
gal te de ltar na chos dang ldan pa rnams kyis ni de 'grub par mi 'gyur zhe na/ dge ba bcu la goms pa dang / /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
Then do not the virtuous accomplish! This is clarified by:
daśakuśalābhyāsī ca gurubhakto jitendriyaḥ || (14) mānakrodhavinirmuktaḥ • sa tāvat siddhyate dhruvaṃ ||
dge ba bcu la goms pa dang / / bla ma la gus dbang po dul/ / nga rgyal khro las rnam par gol/ / des ni re zhig nges 'grub 'gyur/ /
The one who perseveringly practises the ten virtues, is devoted to the guru, has conquered his senses and is free from pride and anger definitely accomplishes.
sātatyābhyāsayogena siddhilabdhaḥ samāhitaḥ || (15) māsam ekaṃ cared guptaṃ yāvat mudrā na labhyate ||
rtag tu goms pa'i rnal 'byor gyis/ / mnyam par bzhag pas dngos grub 'thob/ / zla ba gcig tu gsang la spyad/ / ji srid phyag rgya ma rnyed par/ /
One who has gained proficiency by means of constant practice and is well composed should continue with the practice secretly for one month, so long as a consort is not found.

rtag tu goms pa'i zhes bya ba la sogs pa la dngos grub thob ces bya ba ni ting nge 'dzin thob pa'o/ / de nyid kyi phyir mnyam par gzhag pas zhes bya ba gsungs pa yin no/ / zla ba gcig tu zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ gsang la zhes bya ba ni sbas pa'i brtul zhugs las te phyag rgya chen po thob par bya ba'i phyir ro/ /

siddhi (proficiency): Refers to the gaining of a stabilised meditative state. samāhitaḥ (well composed): He is also self-composed. māsam ityādi (month etc.): Here ‘secretly’ refers to the Secret Observance (guhyavrata).
ādeśaṃ labhate mantrī yoginībhir ādiśyate || (16) gṛhītvā amukīṃ mudrāṃ sattvārthaṃ kuru vajradhṛk ||
gnang ba rnyed gyur sngags pa la/ / rnal 'byor ma yis bstan par bya/ / phyag rgya che ge mo khyer la/ / sems can don gyis rdo rje 'dzin/ /
The practitioner then receives an indication and will be instructed by the Yoginīs as follows: “O bearer of the Vajra, take this consort and act for the benefit of all beings”.
de nas rnal 'byor ma rnams gnang ba nye bar ston par 'gyur ro/ /
Then, for obtaining a consort he will be given instructions by the yoginīs.
tāñ ca prāpya viśālākṣīṃ rūpayauvanamaṇḍitāṃ || (17) sihlakarpūrasaṃyuktāṃ bodhicittena saṃskaret ||
rnyed pa de yang mig yangs ma/ / gzugs dang lang tshos rnam par brgyan/ / si h+la ga bur yang dag ldan/ / byang chub sems kyis rnam par sbyang / /
Obtaining such a consort, who has large eyes, is resplendent with grace and youth and who is born from the union of the female and male sexual fluids, refine her with the Enlightened Consciousness.
byang chub sems kyis zhes bya ba ni gsum la skyabs su 'gro ba la sogs pa'o/ /
bodhicittena (with the Enlightened Consciousness): Refers to the refining with the Triple Refuge and other initial practices.
daśakuśalād ārabhya tasyām dharmaṃ prakāśayet || (18) devatārūpacittañ ca samayañ caikacittatāṃ || māsam ekena bhavyā sā bhaven naivātra saṃśayaḥ || (19)
dge ba bcu las brtsams nas ni/ / de la chos ni rab tu dbye/ / lha yi gzugs kyi sems dang ni/ / dam tshig sems dang gcig pa nyid/ / zla ba gcig gis skal ldan par/ / 'gyur bar 'di la the tshom med/ /

Beginning with the ten virtuous observances, reveal to her the doctrine. Instruct regarding the mind identified with the form of the deity, the Observance of the Vow and the state of one-pointedness of mind. She will without any doubt become suitable in one month.

lha'i gzugs kyis sems ni lha'i rnal 'byor nyid do/ / dam tshig ni bsrung bar bya ba dang bza' bar bya ba la sogs pa'o/ / sems kyang gcig pa zhes bya ba ni lhan cig skyes pa'i rnal 'byor ro/ / skal ldan par zhes bya ba ni dngos grub kyi skal ba dang ldan par ro/ /

devatārūpacittaṃ (the mind identified with the form of the deity): Refers to the identification with the deity. samayaṃ (Observance of the Vow): Refers to keeping the observances and so. ekacittatā (the state of one-pointedness of mind): Refers to the Innate yoga (sahajayoga). bhāvyā (suitable): Means suitable for accomplishment.

varalabdhā yato nārī sarvasaṃkalpavarjitā || athavā cātmanaḥ śaktyā kṛṣṭvā mudrāṃ prakalpayet || (20) devāsuramanuṣyebhyo yakṣebhyaḥ kinnarād api || tāñ ca gṛhya carec caryām ātmano dhairyapratyayāt || (21) na caryā bhogataḥ proktā yā khyātā bhīmarūpiṇī || svacittapratyavekṣāya sthiraṃ kiṃ vācalaṃ manaḥ || (22) [satataṃ devatāmūrtyā sthātavyaṃ yoginā yataḥ]

mchog thob pa yi bud med gang / / rtog pa thams cad yang dag spangs/ / yang na bdag gi nus pa yis/ / lha dang lha min mi rnams dang / / gnod sbyin mi'am ci las kyang / / phyag rgya bkug la rab tu brtag / de yang khyer la spyod pa spyad/ / bdag nyid la ba mngon du'i phyir/ / gang bshad 'jigs pa'i gzugs can gyi/ / spyod pa longs spyod phyir ma gsungs/ / yid ni brtan nam g.yo'am ci/ / rang gi sems ni so sor brtag /

Take as one’s consort such a woman who is free from all misconceptions and has been received as a boon. Or else select a consort, by attracting with one’s own power, from among the gods, titans, men, or even from the wood-spirits or the celestial musicians. Having firm confidence in himself, taking such a consort, the yogī should perform the Application of the Vow. This Application of the Vow which is said to be of a terrifying nature is not instructed for the sake of enjoyment, but for the examination of one’s thoughts, as to whether one’s mind is steady or wavering.

rtog pa ni rnam par rtog pa'o/ / bkug la zhes bya ba ni kun dgug pa'o/ / de yang zhes bya ba ni mchog thob pa'am dgug pa de'o/ / brtan pa bstan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni brtan par rab tu bsgrub pa'i phyir ro/ / de nas longs spyod phyir ni spyad ma gsungs/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ spyad par bshad ces bya ba sngar brtul zhugs kyi le'u'i nang du'o/ / 'jigs pa'i tshul gyis zhes bya ba ni dka' ba dang bcas pas 'jug pa nyid do/ /

saṃkalpa (misconceptions): Refers to all false or imaginary thoughts. kṛṣṭvā (attracting): Means enticing. tāṃ (such a consort): Means either the consort received as a boon or the consort who has been attracted. dhairyapratyayāt (with firm confidence): Means assuming a courageous attitude. Why so is answered by: na caryā ityādi (this Application of the Vow ... is not etc.): This Application of the Vow is what has been previously mentioned in the chapter regarding the Application of the Vow (1.6). bhīmarūpiṇī (of a terrifying nature): ‘Terrifying nature’ because it is very dangerous.
Vajragarbha āha || Nairātmyāyogayuktena mudrārthaṃ viśiṣyate kathaṃ || mudrayā mudrayā dhvābhyāṃ mudrāsiddhiḥ kathaṃ bhavet || (23)
rdo rje snying pos gsol ba/ / bdag med rnal 'byor ldan pa yis/ / phyag rgya nyid ces ji ltar brjod/ / phyag rgya phyag rgya nyid dag gis/ / phyag rgya'i dngos grub ji ltar 'gyur/ /

Vajragarbha said: How can the yogī who is one in union with Nairātmyā clearly understand the meaning of ‘mudrā’, for with mudrā and mudrā, that is, two mudrās, how can the Mudrā Accomplishment come about?

rdo rje snying pos gsol zhes bya ba la don ci zhig zhus she na/ bdag med rnal 'byor zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ phyag rgya zhes bya ba ni phyi rol gyi phyag rgya ste/ ci'i phyir tshol bar byed ces bya bar dgongs pa'o/ / phyag rgya phyag rgya gnyis dag gis/ /zhes bya ba la gnyi ga phyag rgyar gyur pas phyag rgya'i dngos grub ces bya ba'o/ /

What did Vajragarbha ask about? [He asked regarding:] mudrārthaṃ (the meaning of ‘mudrā’): Here ‘mudrā’ refers to the external consort as well. He asked regarding the meaning of ‘mudrā’ in order to understand how the Mudrā Accomplishment can be attained with two mudrās, that is, the external consort and the internal consort [who is the goddess Nairātmyā with whom the yogī identifies].

bhagavān āha || strīrūpaṃ vihāyānyad rūpaṃ kuryād bhagavataḥ || stanaṃ hitvā bhaved bolaṃ kakkolamadhyasaṃsthitaṃ || (24) tīradvayaṃ bhavet ghaṇṭhā kiñjalkaṃ bolakaṃ bhavet || śeṣaṃ rūpaṃ mahātmano Herukasya mahārateḥ || (25) Herukayogasya punsaḥ puṃstvam āyāty ayatnataḥ || mudrāsiddhir bhaved yasmād vyaktaśaktasya yoginaḥ || (26)

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / bud med gzugs ni spangs nas ni/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi gzugs su bya/ / nu ma spangs pa po lar 'gyur/ / kak+ko la dbus yang dag gnas/ / 'gram gnyis dril bu nyid du 'gyur/ / ze'u 'bru bo la can du 'gyur/ / lhag ma bdag nyid chen po nyid/ / dpa' chen he ru ka yi gzugs/ / he ru ka sbyor skyes bu nyid/ / 'bad pa med par skyes bur 'gyur/ / gsal bar nus pa'i rnal 'byor pas/ / de phyir phyag rgya'i dngos grub 'gyur/ /

Bhagavān replied: [The yogī who has identified with the goddess Nairātmyā] should, abandoning the feminine form, assume the form of the Bhagavān. After relinquishing the breasts, the Vajra arises in the middle of the Lotus, the two sides become the Bell and the Kiñjalka becomes the Vajra. The other forms assumed are those of Heruka, the great being of great erotic delight. The man who is at one with Heruka attains the masculine form without any difficulty and by this the yogī whose powers are fully manifest attains the Mudrā Accomplishment.

bud med gzugs zhes bya ba ni bdag med ma'i gzugs so/ / bcom ldan 'das zhes bya ba ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje'o/ / nu ma spangs pa zhes bya ba ni nu ma gnyis spangs par 'gyur bas rdo rjer 'gyur bar bya'o zhes bya ba'i don to/ / 'gram gnyis zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ 'gram gnyis po nyid dril bu zhes bya ba 'bras bur ro/ / ze'u 'bru zhes bya ba ni sna ste rdo rjer bya'o/ / dga' chen zhes bya ba ni 'dod chags chen po'i rang bzhin no/ /

strīrūpaṃ (the feminine form): Refers to the form of Nairātmyā. bhagavataḥ (of the Bhagavān): Means of Hevajra. stanaṃ hitvā (relinquishing the breasts): Means removing the two breasts. The intent is to then create the penis. tīradvayam ityādi (the two sides etc.): The two sides become the ‘bell’, that is, the testicles. With the Kiñjalka, the central part of the vagina, create the penis. mahārateḥ (of great erotic delight): Refers to the one full of the Great Passion.

phyag rgya'i dngos grub 'gyur zhes bya ba ni phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub tu 'gyur ba'o/ / de'i phyir zhes bya ba ni rim pa de gnyis kyis so/ / gsal dang mi gsal zhes bya ba ni bskyed pa'i rim pa sgom pa dang ldan pa'i'o/ / gal te phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub thob pas lha'i gzugs gnyis thob par gyur pa de'i phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub de yang ji ltar gzhal yas khang na spyod pa'i tshangs pa la sogs pa'i lus 'chags pa dang 'jig pa dag gis bskyed cing 'jig par 'gyur ba bzhin du yin nam zhe na/ 'byung dang 'jig pa dag gis kyang / /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/

mudrāsiddhiḥ (the Mudrā Accomplishment): Refers to the Mahamudrā Accomplishment. yasmād (by this): Means by the process mentioned here. vyaktaśaktasya (whose powers are fully manifested): Refers to those who are accomplished in the emanation practices of the Process of Generation. In this context the Mahāmudrā Accomplishment is the accomplishment of the non-duality of the bodies of both the deities. By this the celestial body of Brahma and others is attained. Whether even such an accomplisher of the Mahāmudrā is subject to creation and dissolution in terms of the relative and the absolute is said by:

utpattipralayābhyāṃ ca prajñopāyo na bādhyate || upāyaḥ saṃbhavo yasmāl layaṃ prajñā bhavāntakī || (27) tena pralayan nāsyāsti • utpādo naiva tatvataḥ || pralayāntīyate kaścil layābhāvān na ca kṣayaḥ || (28)

chags dang 'jig pa dag gis kyang / / thabs dang shes rab gnod mi 'gyur/ / gang phyir thabs ni 'byung ba nyid/ / 'jig pa shes rab srid mthar byed/ / des na rab 'jig yod ma yin/ / de nyid la ni chags pa med/ / la la 'jig pas 'jig par 'gyur/ / 'jig pa'i dngos med zad pa med/ /

Wisdom and Means are not obstructed by creation and dissolution, for Means is origination and Wisdom, the destroyer of the existent, is dissolution. Therefore, in truth there is neither destruction nor origination. The destruction causes the end, and since there is no dissolution of anything there is no termination.

'byung ba dang 'jig pa dag gis kyang gnod par mi 'gyur ro/ / ci'i phyir gnod par mi 'gyur zhe na/ thabs ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ 'byung ba nyid ces bya ba ni rtag tu 'byung bar 'gyur te/ ji srid nam mkha' gnas kyi bar du rtag pas rtag par gyur pa zhes bya ba'i don to/ / 'di nyid thabs te de'i 'bras bu bsgom pa rdzogs par 'gyur ba nyid ji ltar 'jig par 'gyur/ 'jig pa zhes bya ba ni dngos po thams cad mi dmigs pa'o/ / de nyid ni shes rab ste 'di nyid kyis srid mthar byed ces bya ba lus la mngon par zhen pa mthar byed pa'o/ / de dag ro gcig par 'gyur ba rmi lam dang mig 'phrul dang sgyu ma dang smig rgyu lta bu nam mkha' ji srid kyi bar du gnas pa'i sku gnyis ni phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub bo/ / gang gi phyir de lta bu'i rnam pas 'byung ba dang 'jig pa yod pa ma yin te/ gzhan yang de kho na nyid du gang yang 'jig pa yod pa ma yin no/ / gal te la la dngos po'i ngo bo zhig tu gyur na ni skye zhing 'jig par yang 'gyur na/ ji srid mi gnas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa'i ngo bo nyid 'dus ma byas kyi mtshan nyid can yin pa de'i phyir gang zhig 'jig par 'gyur ba de med pas zad pa yang med do/ / de lta bas na de ltar phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub thob pa la 'byung ba dang 'jig pa yod par mi 'gyur ro zhes bya bar gnas pa yin no/ / de yang bsgoms pas thob par bya ba nyid yin pas ci lta bu zhig bsgom par bya zhe na/ bskyed pa'i rim pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/

utpatti ityādi (creation etc.): He is not affected by creation and dissolution. Why he is not affected is said by: upāyaḥ saṃbhavo (Means is origination): Origination is constant so long as the arisings are continually active in space. This is the Means. It’s fruit is in the perfection of emanation. layaṃ (dissolution): Destruction is dissolution, that is, the non-substantiality of all existent things. That is Wisdom. Therefore Wisdom is: bhavāntakī (the destroyer of the existent): Means the destroyer of the belief in the body. So long as these two bodies of Wisdom and Means are in space the Mahāmudrā Accomplishment, by these two becoming one, is similar to a dream, magic, illusion or mirage. By such a reasoning destruction is non-arising. But even though in truth there is nothing that is dissolved, there is creation and destruction so long as the existent being is unrefined in terms of the Unanchored Essence of Release. Then what is destroyed when destruction does not exist! kṣayaḥ (termination): Refers to the termination of destruction. In this manner it is demonstrated that the one who accomplishes the Mahāmudrā is not subject to creation and destruction. The Mahāmudrā Accomplishment is attained only by means of the practice of emanation. The nature of that emanation is said by:
utpattikramayogena prapañcaṃ bhāvayed vratī || prapañcaṃ svapnavat kṛtvā prapañcair niḥprapañcayet || (29)
bskyed pa'i rim pa'i rnal 'byor gyis/ / brtul zhugs can gyis spros pa bsgom/ / spros pa rmi lam ltar byas nas/ / spros pa nyid ni spros med byed/ /

The holder of the Vow must conceive the differentiated world by means of the method of the Process of Generation. Making the differentiated dream-like, utilising the differentiated, transform it into the undifferentiated.

spros pa zhes bya ba ni rten dang brten pa'i mtshan nyid can de rnam pa sna tshogs pa'o/ / rmi lam ltar byas na zhes bya ba ni ji ltar rmi lam na sems nyid rnam pa sna tshogs par snang ba de ltar byas pa nyid do/ / spros pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa la dag gi rnam par rtog pas spros par mi byed cing rnam par rtog par mi byed pa'o/ / rim pa 'di ltar goms par byas pas cir 'gyur zhe na/ ji ltar sgyu ma zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/

prapañcaṃ (differentiated): The differentiated is characterised as having a supporting foundation and a supported object. It is of various kinds. svapnavat kṛtvā (making ... dream-like): Means making the differentiated similar to the dreaming mind which creates a variety of forms. prapañcaiḥ (utilising the differentiated): Means using the notions of existence and transforming the differentiated into the undifferentiated. What occurs when this process is perseveringly practised is said by:
yathā māyā yathā svapnaṃ yathā syād antarābhavaṃ || tathaiva maṇḍalaṃ bhāti sātatyābhyāsayogataḥ || (30)
ji ltar sgyu ma rmi lam dang / / ji ltar bar ma'i srid yin pa/ / rtag tu goms par sbyor ba las/ / dkyil 'khor nyid ni de bzhin 'dod/ /
As an illusion, as a dream, as the intermediate state, so does the maṇḍala shine forth through constant persevering practice.

dri za'i grong khyer zhes bya ba ni seng ge'i zla ba'i grong khyer ro/ / de bzhin 'dod ces bya ba ni de lta bur gsal po nyid du gyur pa zhes bya ba'i don to/ / da ni rim pa'i bdag nyid can gyi bde ba chen po de nyid ngo bo nyid kyi dkyil 'khor gyi 'khor lor bsgom par bya'o zhes rab tu bsgrub pa'i phyir

antarābhavaṃ (intermediate stage): The ‘intermediate state’ is similar to the city of the celestial musicians (gandharvanagara) or the mythical city of Hariścandra [which arc said to be located in the space, between heaven and earth]. tathaiva maodalaṃ bhāti (so does the maṇḍala shine forth): Means that the maṇḍala clearly manifests as an illusion and so on. Now, in order to reveal that this emanation of the Maṇḍala Circle has indeed the intrinsic nature of the Great Bliss which characterises the Process of Perfection, it is said:
mahāmudrābhiṣekeṣu yathājñātaṃ mahat sukhaṃ || tasyaiva tatprabhāvaḥ syān maṇḍalaṃ nānyasaṃbhavaṃ || (31)
phyag rgya chen po'i dbang bskur ba/ / ji ltar shes pa'i bde chen po/ / 'di ni de yi byin brlabs yin/ / gzhan las dkyil 'khor 'byung ba med/ /
The maṇḍala is indeed the manifestation of the great bliss that is known in the Mahāmudrā consecration, for nowhere else than from this great bliss does the maṇḍala originate.

phyag rgya chen pos zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ phyag rgya'i dbang bskur ba ni shes rab kyi dbang bskur ba ste bzhi po de dag go/ / ci ltar shes pa'i zhes bya ba'i bla ma'i man ngag nyid las ji ltar rig pa'o/ / de ci zhig ce na/ bde ba chen po zhes bya ba ni bsgrub bya sgrub byed kyi mtshan nyid can te/ de nyid las byung bar gyur pa ni dkyil 'khor 'di nyid yin no zhes bya ba'i don to/ / byin rlabs zhes bya ba ni de'i rang bzhin no zhes bya ba'i don to/ / dkyil 'khor zhes bya ba ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje dang bdag med ma'i dkyil 'khor ro/ / gzhan las 'byung ba med ces bya ba ni gzhan las 'byung bar 'gyur ba ma yin pa'o/ /

mahāmudrābhiṣekeṣu (in the Mahāmudrā consecrations): Here Mahāmudrā consecration refers to the Wisdom consecration. yathājñātaṃ (that is known): Refers to what is known during the four consecrations in accordance with the instructions. What is clearly known from the guru’s instructions is: mahat sukhaṃ (the great bliss): This is the goal to be achieved. maṇḍalaṃ: The intent is that the maṇḍala is the manifestation of this great bliss. prabhāvaḥ (manifestation): Here it means that this great bliss is one and the same as the maṇḍala. maṇḍalaṃ: Refers to the maṇḍala of Hevajra and Nairātmyā. nānyasaṃbhavaṃ (for nowhere else than from ... originate): The maṇḍala does not originate from any other source is the intent.

gal te shes rab kyi ye shes kyi dbang bskur ba ni spros pa med pa'i mtshan nyid kyi bde ba tsam nye bar dmigs pa yin na/ des ji ltar rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldan pa'i dkyil 'khor 'byung bar 'gyur/ 'dra bar 'gyur ba las 'dra bar 'byung bar 'gyur ro zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro zhe na/ de ltar ni ma yin te/ / 'dra ba las 'dra bar 'byung bar 'gyur ro zhes bya ba ni 'jig rten gyi tha snyad tsam du yin te/ ji ltar kun gzhi rnam par shes pa smra ba rnams kun gzhi rnam par shes pa ni 'gro ba rnams kyi sa bon 'dzin pa yin no zhes smra ba ltar/ de bzhin du shes rab ye shes kyi dbang bskur bas rtogs par byas pa bde ba chen po'o/ / mtshan nyid can chos thams cad kyi stong pa nyid ces bya ba yang chos thams cad kyi rten du gyur pa nyid yin no zhes theg pa chen po'i gsang sngags las sngags par byed do/ / de nyid bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir/ bde ba gnag ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/

Since the undifferentiated nature is experienced as just bliss in the consecration of the Knowledge of Wisdom, how does the Maṇḍala Circle endowed with all its different aspects arise? I will explain. From one kind of cause a similar kind of effect arises, would normally be the appropriate reasoning; but here it is not so because such a reasoning is only a worldly convention of reasoning. Like those who hold the view of a Store-house of Consciousness and describe the Store-house of Consciousness as the receptacle of the seed of the universe, in a similar manner the Mantra-mahāyāna tradition describes the Great Bliss attained in the Wisdom consecration to be the Voidness of All Natures which is described as the receptacle of the nature of all the Buddhas. In order to reveal this it is said:

sukhaṃ kṛṣṇaṃ sukhaṃ pītaṃ sukhaṃ raktaṃ sukhaṃ sitaṃ || sukhaṃ śyāmaṃ sukhaṃ nīlaṃ sukhaṃ kṛtsnaṃ carācaraṃ || (32) sukhaṃ prajñā sukhopāyaḥ sukhaṃ kundurujaṃ tathā || sukhaṃ bhāvaḥ sukhābhāvo Vajrasattvaḥ sukhasmṛtaḥ || (33)

bde ba gnag cing bde bser/ / bde ba dmar po bde ba dkar/ / bde ba ljang gu bde ba sngo/ / bde ba rgyu dang mi rgyu kun/ / bde ba shes rab bde ba thabs/ / de bzhin kun tu ru skyes bde/ / bde ba dngos dang dngos med bde/ / rdo rje sems dpa' bde bar brjod/ /
Bliss is black, yellow, red, white, green, blue and all things moving and fixed. Bliss is the Wisdom, the Means, the erotic union, existence and non-existence. Vajrasattva is known as Bliss.

gnyis sbyor zhes bya ba ni thabs dang shes rab kyis snyoms par 'jug pa'o/ / dngos ni sangs rgyas lnga'i rang bzhin no/ / dngos med ni de dag nyid kyis spros pa med pa nyid do/ / thabs dang shes rab kyi rang bzhin nyid kyi dpal dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i dkyil 'khor du ni ji ltar bde ba'i ngo bor 'gyur zhe na/ rdo rje sems dpa' zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ thabs dang shes rab kyi rang bzhin dag nyi ma dang zla ba yang dag par 'byor pa las 'byung ba'i sa bon las 'byung ba'i phyag mtshan gyi rdo rje dang / de'i dkyil na gnas pa'i sa bon ni sems dpa' ste/ rdo rje dang bcas pa'i sems dpa' ni rdo rje sems dpa'o/ / de nyid bde ba zhes bya bar brjod do/ /

kundurujaṃ (the erotic union): Refers to the unified state of Wisdom and Means. bhāva (existence): Refers to the nature of the Five Buddhas. abhāva (non-existence): Refers to the undifferentiated state of the Five Buddhas. Granted the blissful nature of the maṇḍala of Hevajra because of it being composed of Wisdom and Means, how is Nairātmyā’s maṇḍala of a blissful nature? This is explained by: vajrasattvaḥ sukhasmṛtaḥ (Vajrasattva is known as Bliss): Vajra is the symbol arising from the seed-syllable which has arisen from the union of the Moon and Sun, which are of the nature of Wisdom and Means respectively. Sattva is the Being, the Seed is the core of the Vajra. Therefore, Vajrasattva is the Being with the Vajra. He is also known as Bliss.
Vajragarbha āha || utpannakramayogo 'yaṃ [sat]sukhaṃ mahāsukhaṃ mataṃ || utpannabhāvanāhīno utpattyā kiṃ prayojanaṃ || (34)
rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ rdzogs pa'i rim pa'i rnal 'byor 'di/ / de yi bde ba bde chen brjod/ / rdzogs pa bsgom pa med pa ste/ / bskyed pa yis ni ci zhig 'tshal/ /
Vajragarbha said: This is the method of the Process of Completion and it’s bliss is known as the Great Bliss. What is the use of generating other than for the conceiving of the completion?

rdo rje snying pos gsol pa zhes bya ba la don ci zhig gis gsol zhe na/ bskyed pa'i rim pa'i de nyid bcom ldan 'das kyis bde ba'i ngo bo nyid du bsngags pa'i phyir/ rdzogs pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ bsgom pa zhes bya ba ni lha nyid bsgom pa'o/ / med pa'i bskyed pa yis ni ci zhig dgos/ /zhes bya ba ni dgos pa med do zhes bya ba'i don to/ / dgongs pa ni 'di yin te/ bde ba chen por mos pa'i dkyil 'khor gyi 'khor lo bsgom pa'i 'bad pa 'dis ci zhig dgos/ / bde ba chen po 'ba' zhig kho nas mngon par 'dod pa'i don 'grub par 'gyur ro zhe na/ gus pa bstan pa'i phyir/

vajragarbha aha (Vajragarbha said): What was the intent of Vajragarbha’s question? His intention was to make the Bhagavān describe the Process of Generation in terms of bliss. bhāvanā (conceiving): Means conceiving of the body of the deity. hīna (other than): Means other than for conceiving the completion of the body of the deity. utpattyā kiṃ prayojanaṃ (what is the use of generating): This means that Vajragarbha is implying that the Process of Generation is of no use. The import is: What is the purpose of actualising the Great Bliss through long drawn-out emanations of Maṇḍala Circles when one who directs all his attention through the Great Bliss accomplishes? Vajragarbha is exposing the difficulty in understanding the utility of the Process of Generation.
bhagavān āha / aho śraddhāvegena naṣṭo 'yaṃ mahābodhisatva iti ||
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / e ma'o byang chub sems dpa' che/ / dad pa'i shugs kyis rab tu nyams/ /
Bhagavān said: O Great Bodhisattva, it is said that this difficulty is removed by the strength of conviction.
dad pa'i shugs kyis rab tu nyams/ /zhes bya ba la/ bskyed pa'i rim pa la gus pa dang ldan pa nyams pa zhes bya ba bskyed pa'i rim pa spong bar byed pa nyid do/ /
naṣṭaḥ (removed): The difficulty in understanding the utility of the Process of Generation is removed by the strength of conviction.
dehābhāve kutaḥ saukhyaṃ saukhyaṃ vaktum na śakyate || vyāpyavyāpakarūpeṇa sukhena vyāpitaṃ jagat || (35)
lus kyi dngos med gang las bde/ / bde ba smra bar mi nus so/ / khyab dang khyab byed tshul gyis ni/ / bde bas 'gro ba khyab pa nyid/ /
In the absence of the body where is there bliss, for without the body it is not possible to speak about bliss. The world is pervaded by bliss, the world and bliss being mutually dependent.

lus kyi dngos med ces bya ba ni bskyed pa'i rim pa de nyid la stong par byed pa'o/ / ci ltar zhe na/ gang las bde zhes bya ba de gzhan las bde ba nye bar bstan par nus pa ma yin no/ / de lta bas na bde bas nye bar khyab pa de nyid 'gro ba zhes bya bar brjod do/ / khyab par byed pa'i ngo bo 'ba' zhig gis ni ma yin gyi/ khyab par bya ba'i ngo bos kyang yin no/ / gnyi ga yang khyab par bya ba dang khyab par byed pa'i ngo bo nyid yin te/ ji ltar bde ba med par yang lus la sogs pa yod pa ma yin la/ lus de med par yang bde ba yod pa ma yin no zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

deha ityādi (body etc.): With this verse the Process of Generation is praised since Vajragarbha raised an objection regarding the utility of this process. kutaḥ saukhyaṃ (where is there bliss): This implies that it is not possible to instruct about bliss anywhere else other than in the body. Thus it is said: sukhena vyāpitaṃ jagat (the world is pervaded by bliss): The body and bliss exist not merely as the pervaded and that which pervades, because they are mutually interdependent. Just as there is no body and other objects without bliss, so also without the body there is no bliss.
ji ltar me tog bya ba la sogs pas ni dpe gsungs pa yin no/ /
This view is exemplified through the following analogy.
yathā puṣpāśritaṃ gandhaṃ puṣpābhāvān na gamyate || tathā rūpādyabhāvena saukhyaṃ naivopalabhyate || (36)
ji ltar me tog la gnas dri/ / me tog dngos med shes mi 'gyur/ / de bzhin gzugs sogs dngos med pas/ / bde ba nyid kyang dmigs med 'gyur/ /
Just as smell in the flower does not occur in the absence of the flower, similarly bliss is not experienced in the absence of form and other qualities.
gal te de ltar na dkyil 'khor gyi 'khor lo bsgom pa kho nas chog mod/ bde ba chen po bsgom pas ci zhig bya zhe na/ dngos bdag ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs so/ /
If such is the nature of the emanation of the Maṇḍala Circle, what about the nature of the emanation of just Great Bliss alone? Regarding this it is said:
bhāvo 'haṃ naiva bhāvo 'haṃ buddho 'haṃ vastubodhanāt || māṃ na jānanti ye mugdhāḥ kausīdyopahatāś ca ye || (37)
dngos nga dngos po med pa nga / / dngos po rtogs phyir sangs rgyas nga / / gang zhig le los bsnun pa dang / / rmongs pa gang gis nga mi shes/ /
I am existence as well as not existence; I am the Enlightened One for I am enlightened regarding the true nature of things. But those fools who are afflicted by dullness do not know me.

dngos bdag ces bya ba ni longs spyod rdzogs pa dang sprul pa'i sku'i ngo bo nyid kyi dkyil 'khor gyi 'khor lo'i gzugs nyid do/ / dngos po bdag ma yin zhes bya ba la sogs pa ni chos kyi sku'i ngo bo nyid dang bde ba chen po'i rang bzhin gyis so/ / gal te khyod nyid dkyil 'khor gyi 'khor lo'i rnam pa nyid kyi ngo bo nyid zhig yin na ni de lta na dkyil 'khor ni gcig dang du ma'i rang bzhin dang bral ba'i phyir/ khyod nyid 'khrul pa'i ngo bo yin pas de lta bas na sangs rgyas ma yin no snyam du bsams pa'o/ / de lta bas na sangs rgyas bdag ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ sangs rgyas bdag ces bya ba la dngos po ni chos thams cad do/ / de dag rtogs pa ni rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'o/ / ye shes de dang ldan pas sangs rgyas bdag med ces bya'o/ / de lta bas na bdag ni mchog tu zab pa'i sku gnyis kyi ngo bo nyid yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir/ rmongs pa gang gis nga mi shes/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rmongs pa zhes bya ba ni thos pa dang mi ldan pa dge ba'i bshes gnyen la bsnyen bkur bya ba dang bral ba'o/ /

bhāvo ’haṃ (I am existence): In terms of the Maṇḍala Circle and so on which are of the nature of the Bodies of Enjoyment and Creation I am of the nature of phenomenal things. naiva bhāvo ’haṃ (I am... not existence): I am not existence in terms of being the Great Bliss which is of the nature of the Body of Essential Nature. If the phenomenal nature is understood as being the attributes of the Maṇḍala Circle, then is not the Maṇḍala Circle misconceived, because it does not possess the quality of one and many? Then, is there no enlightenment because of this misconception? To this it is said: buddho ’haṃ vastubodhanāt (I am the Enlightened One for I am enlightened regarding the true nature of things): ‘Things’ refer to all phenomenal things. ‘I am the Enlightened One’ because of being aware, that is, having complete knowledge regarding all things. This is said in order to show that I, the Bhagavān, am of the nature of the two profound supreme bodies. māṃ ityādi (me etc.): ‘Fools’ refer to those who do not pay attention and are lacking in auspicious friendship.
de lta bu'i zab mo'i ngo bo nyid kyi sku gnyis gsal bar bstan pa'i phyir/ bde chen gnas der rtag tu bzhugs/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
In order to demonstrate the nature of those two profound bodies it is said:
vihare 'haṃ sukhāvatyāṃ sadvajrayoṣito bhage || E-kārākṛtirūpe tu buddharatnakaraṇḍake || (38)
rdo rje btsun mo'i b+ha ga ni/ / e yi rnam pa'i cha byad gzugs/ / sangs rgyas rin chen za ma tog / bde ba can du rtag tu bzhugs/ /
I dwell in Sukhāvatī, the Citadel of Bliss, in the womb of the Vajra Lady which has the shape of the letter e (a triangle pointing downwards) and is the receptacle of the jewels of the Buddha.

de bzhin gshegs pa 'od dpag med kyi sangs rgyas kyi zhing la bde ba can zhes brjod do/ / 'dir ni bdag med ma la sogs pa'i b+ha ga la bde ba can zhes bya ste/ mdor bsdus pa'i rang bzhin gyi bla na med pa'i bde ba srung bar byed pa'i phyir te/ der bdag gnas pa'o/ / bde ba chen po'i gzugs su gcig par chos thams cad mtshon par bya ba'i phyir/ e yi rnam pa'i cha byad gzugs/ / zhes pa'o/ / sangs rgyas nyid ni rin po che'o/ / de'i za ma tog ni gzhag pa'i gnas so/ /

sukhāvatyām (in the Citadel of Bliss): The Buddha Field of the Tathāgata Amitābha is known as Sukhāvatī. But here in this Yoginī tantra the wombs of Nairātmyā and the other Yoginīs are referred to as Sukhāvatī, because their wombs are the protectors (āvati) of the highest bliss (sukha). vihare ’haṃ (I dwell): Means that I dwell there. In order to indicate the one Great Blissful nature of all things it is said: ekārākṛtirūpe (in ... the shape of the letter e). buddharatnakaraṇḍake (the receptacle of the jewels of the Buddhas): The ‘receptacle’ of the jewels of the Buddhas refers to the location of the treasury of their jewels.
da ni de lta bu'i bdag nyid kyi che ba'i bdag nyid bstan pa'i phyir/ 'chad pa po bdag ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
Now, in order to express the greatness of such a Being it is said:
vyākhyātāham ahaṃ dharmaḥ śrotāhaṃ sugaṇair yutaḥ || sādhyo 'haṃ jagataḥ śāstā loko 'haṃ laukiko 'py ahaṃ || (39)
'chad pa po nga chos kyang nga / / rang gi tshogs ldan nyan pa nga / / 'jig rten ston pa bsgrub bya nga / / 'jig rten 'jig rten 'das pa nga / /
I am the revealer, I am the revealed doctrine and I am the disciple endowed with good qualities. I am the goal, I am the master of the world and I am the world as well as the worldly things.

'di lta bu'i chos dgyes pa'i rdo rje la sogs pa 'chad par byed pa'o/ / nyan pa zhes bya ba ni yon tan dang ldan pa'i slob ma'o/ / bsgrub bya bdag ces bya ba ni gang sngar bstan pa'o/ / de'i sgrub pa po yang bdag nyid yin pa'o/ / 'gro ba'i ston pa ni longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sku dag ste bdag nyid yin pa'o/ / 'jig rten 'jig rten 'das pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa la gnyi ga spros pa las byung ba ni 'jig rten no/ / 'jig rten las 'das pa ni de dag nyid rgyur gyur pa'i byang chub sems khu ba ste/ 'di 'jig rten la dgos pa'i phyir dang / longs spyod rdzogs sku'i ngo bo nyid yin pas bdag nyid yin no/ / gal te khyod gtsor bde ba chen po'i ngo bo nyid yin na de ji lta bu zhig ce na/ lhan cig skyes dga'i zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/

dharma (doctrine): Refers to the doctrine revealed in the Hevajra Tantra and other similar tantras. śrotā (disciple): Refers to the disciple who is endowed with those good qualities a disciple should possess. sādhyo ’haṃ (I am the goal): Means I am that which has previously been described as the goal. jagataḥ śāstā (I am the master of the world): Being the Bodies of Enjoyment and Creation I am the master of the world. This is elaborated by: loko ’haṃ (I am the world): The world of living beings arises out of sexual union. [In this sense] the cause of living beings is the flow of Bodhicitta, which is semen and Enlightened Consciousness. laukiko ’py ahaṃ (I am ... worldly things): The worldly things refer to those things which are utilised in the world. The intent is that I am also of the nature of the Body of Enjoyment. Surely the principal quality of this Being is Great Bliss. How this is so is said by:
sahajānandasvabhāvo 'haṃ paramāntaṃ viramādikaṃ || tathā ca pratyayaṃ putra • andhakāre pradīpavat || (40)
lhan cig skyes dga'i rang bzhin nga / / mchog mtha' dga' bral dang por ni/ / mun pa la ni mar me ltar/ / de bzhin bus kyang yid ches kyis/ /
My intrinsic nature is the Innate Joy experienced at the end of the Refined Joy and at the beginning of the Joy of Cessation. And so have confidence, O son, for it is like a lamp in darkness.

lhan cig skyes pa'i dga' ba de khyad par ji lta bu can zhig ce na/ mchog mtha' zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ mchog tu dga' ba'i mtha' dga' bral gyi dang po gang yin pa de de nyid yin no zhes bya ba'i don to/ / gal te bsgrub par bya ba bde ba chen po kun gyi bdag nyid gang yin pa de nyid khyod yin zhes sngar gsungs pas 'khor ba pa'i lhan cig skyes pa'i bde ba de ni bsgrub bya ma yin na'ang / de ji ltar khyod nyid yin par 'gyur zhe na/ de bzhin bus kyang zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ kyang zhes bya ba'i sgra ni gtan tshigs so/ / gang gi phyir de nyid gtsor dpes bstan par bya ba yin pas 'dra bar 'gyur ba'i dpe nyid gyis rab tu bsgrub par bya ba yin pas de nyid ni gtsor bstan pa yin la/ 'di ni nye bar btags pa yin no/ /
