The unique quality of the Innate Joy is said by: paramāntaṃ ityādi (at the end of the Refined Joy etc.): Means I am that which manifests at the end of the Refined Joy and at the beginning of the Joy of Cessation. tathā ca pratyayaṃ (and so have confidence): The goal is, indeed, the all-pervasive Great Bliss which is the Bhagavān. Is it that the previously mentioned worldly relative Innate bliss is not the goal? The intent is that it is also the Bhagavān, Here ‘and’ is used in a causal sense. The absolute Innate Bliss is the cause of the relative bliss, the relative bliss being a limited aspect of the absolute Innate Bliss. Therefore confidence is attained by means of the relative bliss which is a limited aspect, similar in nature to the primary cause, the absolute Innate Bliss. Thus, Great Bliss is the principal bliss is the intent.

de nyid bstan pa'i phyir/ mun pa la ni mar me bzhin/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ 'ga' zhig ji ltar mun pa'i yul na gnas pa'i bum pa dang / snam bu la sogs pa rnams me sgron gyis gsal bar byed par bsgrub pa ltar/ de bzhin du dper gyur pa 'jig rten pa'i lhan cig skyes pa'i bde bas bsgrub bya'i mtshan nyid bde ba chen po sgrub par byed pa yin par blta bar bya'o/ /

This is mentioned by: andhakāre pradīpavat (like a light in darkness): Its something like this. The lamp is the cause for illuminating pots and other objects which are in darkness. Similarly, it is shown through this analogy that the worldly Innate Joy is the very means which makes the achievement of the goal, the Great Bliss, possible.
bde gnas su zhes bya ba la sogs pa la sngar gsungs pa de nyid gsal bar bstan pa'i phyir/
In order to further clarify ‘I dwell etc.’ which was previously mentioned [2.2.38] it is said:

dvātriṃśallakṣaṇī śāstā • aśītivyañjanī prabhuḥ || yoṣidbhage sukhāvatyāṃ śukranāmna vyavasthitaḥ || (41) vinā tena na saukhyaṃ syāt sukhaṃ hitvā bhaven na saḥ || sāpekṣam asamarthatvād devatāyogataḥ sukhaṃ || (42)

btsun mo'i b+ha ga bde chen du/ / ston pa sum cu rtsa gnyis mtshan/ / gtso bo dpe byad brgyad cur ldan/ / khu ba zhes bya'i rnam par gnas/ / de med pas ni bde med 'gyur/ / bde ba med na de med 'gyur/ / nus pa med phyir ltos dang bcas/ / lha yi rnal 'byor las bde ba/ /

The Lord and Master with the thirty-two auspicious characteristics and the eighty auspicious marks dwells as semen in the Citadel of Bliss (sukhāvatī) which is the womb of the Lady. Without semen there would be no bliss and without bliss semen would not exist. Since semen and bliss are ineffective on their own they are mutually dependent and bliss arises from the union with the deity.

sum cu rtsa gnyis zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ mtshan dang dpe byad kyis 'bar ba'i sku'o/ / gtso bo zhes bya ba ni sangs rgyas kyi chos kyi bdag po'o/ / btsun mo zhes bya ba ni dpe ste rdo rje'i btsun mo'o/ / de'i b+ha gar khu ba zhes bya ba ni bdag nyid gnas pa'o/ / khu ba ni bde ba ste phyi rol gyi khu ba'o/ / de med ces bya ba ni khu ba de med na'o/ / gang gi phyir bde ba ni khu ba ltos pa dang bcas nas 'byung ba'i phyir te/ khu ba med na rgyu gzhan gyis de lta bu'i bde ba 'byung bar nus pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ / des na lha'i rnal 'byor las kyang bde ba 'byung bar 'gyur zhes brjod pa yin te/ de dang 'dra bar bde ba chen po 'dod pas lha'i rnal 'byor nges pa kho nar bya ba yin no/ /

dvātriṃśat ityādi (thirty-two etc.): The intent is that his body is resplendent with the auspicious characteristics and marks. prabhuḥ (Lord): Refers to the one who possesses the qualities of the Enlightened One. yoṣit (Lady): Refers to the one who exemplifies the Vajra Lady. śukranāmnā vyavasthitaḥ (dwell as semen): Means that I, the Bhagavān, dwell in the womb of the Vajra Lady as semen. Semen here refers to both the bliss and the external semen. vinā tena (without semen): The bliss which is experienced is dependent upon semen. Without this, that is, in the absence of semen, there is no possibility of any other causes generating the same kind of bliss. devatāyogataḥ sukhaṃ (bliss arises from the union with the deity): It is said that the true bliss is generated only from the union with the deity. Therefore, the union with the deity must be conceived by the one who desires the Great Bliss.
tasmād buddho na bhāvaḥ syād abhāvarūpo 'pi naiva saḥ || bhujamukhākārarūpī cārūpī paramasaukhyataḥ || (43)
de phyir sangs rgyas dngos po min/ / de nyid dngos med tshul yang min/ / zhal phyag rnam pa'i gzugs can nyid/ / mchog tu bde bas gzugs med pa/ /
Thus, the Enlightened One is neither existence nor nonexistence. He is endowed with a form having arms and face and in terms of the highest bliss he is also formless.

de'i lam ni dngos po yang ma yin dngos po med pa yang ma yin te/ khu ba dang bde ba'i ngo bo nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i 'bras bur gyur pa sangs rgyas kyang dngos po yang ma yin dngos po med pa yang ma yin no/ / ji lta zhe na/ zhal phyag rnam pa zhes pa la sogs pa gsungs te/ longs spyod rdzogs pa'i sku'i ngo bo nyid ni gzugs can no/ / mchog tu bde ba'i chos kyi sku nyid kyis ni gzugs med pa'o/ / de'i phyir mi gnas pa'i gzugs can nyid yin pas na/ gzugs can ma yin gzugs med min/ /zhes bya bar gnas pa ma yin no/ /

For the same reason that the method towards enlightenment, because it is of the nature of semen and bliss, is neither existence nor non-existence, the fruit of the method, the Enlightened One, is also neither existence nor non-existence. How this is so is said by: bhujamukha ityādi (arms and face etc.): In terms of the Body of Enjoyment there is form. In terms of the highest bliss, that is, as the Body of Essential Nature, it is formless. Since the Enlightened One is undefinable it is concluded that he is neither existence nor non-existence.
gang gi phyir de ltar na/ de'i phyir
This being so [it is said]:
tasmāt sahajaṃ jagat sarvaṃ sahajaṃ svarūpam ucyate || svarūpam eva nirvāṇaṃ viśuddhyākāracetasā || (44)
de phyir 'gro kun lhan cig skyes/ / rang bzhin lhan cig skyes par brjod/ / rnam dag rnam pa'i sems kyis ni/ / rang bzhin mya ngan 'das pa nyid/ /
And so the Innate is the whole universe and this Innate, we say, is the intrinsic nature. This intrinsic nature is itself experienced as the release when the consciousness is purified.

'gro kun lhan cig skyes/ /zhes bya ba ste sems can thams cad do/ /lhan cig skyes pa zhes bya ba'i don ci zhig ce na/ rang bzhin lhan cig skyes par brjod/ / ces bya ba ste/ chos rnams kyi rang bzhin dang lhan cig skyes pa zhes bya ba ste rnam grangs so/ / de nyid ni mya ngan las 'das pa ste/ ji ltar byas nas she na/ rnam dag rnam pa'i sems kyis ni/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rnam par dag pa ni dri ma med pa ste/ 'od gsal ba'i ngo bo nyid do/ / de'i rnam pa can gyi sems su gang gi tshe mya ngan las 'das par gyur pa yin no zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

sahajaṃ jagat (the Innate is the whole universe): Here universe refers to all beings. What is the meaning of Innate? [This is said:] sahajaṃ svarūpam ucyate (the Innate is the intrinsic nature): The intrinsic nature refers to the primordial nature of all things and is synonymous with the Innate. How this Innate is the release is said by: viśuddhi ityādi (purified etc.): Purification is the attainment of the intrinsic nature which is the Innate Radiance. When such a consciousness is attained then there is release is the intent.

gal te dngos po dang dngos po med pa'i ngo bo nyid yin pa'i phyir 'gro ba sangs rgyas kyi rang bzhin nyid yin na/ de lta na ni ci'i phyir lha'i rnam par sgom par byed ce na/ de ni bden na lha'i rnam pa'i zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
If the universe is pervaded by the enlightened nature which is both existence and non-existence, then why perform the emanation of the deity’s form? This is a valid doubt. [To this it is said:]
devatāyogarūpaṃ tu jātamātre vyavasthitaḥ || bhujamukhavarṇasthānāt kiṃ tu prākṛtavāsanā || (45)
lha yi rnam pa'i gzugs kyis ni/ / bzhin lag kha dog gnas pa ni/ / skyes pa tsam gyis rnam par gnas/ / 'on kyang bag chags phal pas so/ /

The form of the Deity with which the yogī identifies exists only as something which is born, being a repository of the arms, faces and colours which moreover arise in accordance with unrefined past tendencies.

bzhin lag kha dog ces bya ba la sogs pa ni tha mal pa'i lus kyi ni zhes bya ba'i don to/ / de ltar na yang bsgom pa don med do zhe na/ 'on kyang zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te lus phal pa'i khyad par gyi de'i bag chags zhes bya ba ni lhag ma'o/ / de spang ba'i phyir zag pa med pa'i phung po'i bag chags rgyas par bya ba'i don du lha'i sku bsgom par bya ba yin no snyam du dgongs pa'o/ /

bhujamukha ityādi (arms, face etc.): The form of the deity is a repository of arms, face etc. since it is similar to a human body is the intent. Then is the emanation of the deity useless? [This is answered by:] kin tu ityādi (moreover etc.): Here ‘unrefined’ refers to that which comes from within the yogī’s body. ‘Tendencies’ refer to the tendencies that come from the yogī’s body. The emanation of the deity’s body is performed in order to eliminate the impure tendencies and in order to nourish the tendencies of the purified aggregates [of personality, elements and so on].

da ni lus kyi bsgom pa yang mi gnas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa'i rgyu nyid yin no zhes bya ba 'di bsgrub par bya ba yin pas/ de'i phyir 'di nyid dpe du mas bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir/ dug de nyid shes pa des zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/

Now, it is shown that the emanation of the body [of the deity] is the cause for the attainment of the Unanchored Release which is the goal. The possibility of attaining this goal is expressed through various analogies.
yenaiva viṣakhaṇḍena mriyante sarvajantavaḥ || tenaiva viṣatattvajño viṣeṇa sphoṭayed viṣaṃ || (46)
dug gi dum bu gang nyid kyis/ / skye bo thams cad 'chi bar 'gyur/ / dug gi de nyid shes pa des/ / dug gis dug ni 'bigs par byed/ /
By using that very poison, a tiny amount of which would kill any living being, the one who knows the nature of poisons dispels the poison utilising that very poison.
'byin par byed ces bya ba ni 'jil bar byed pa'o/ /
sphoṭayet (dispels): Means destroys.
yathā vātagṛhītasya māṣabhakṣyaṃ pradīyate || vātena hanyate vātaṃ viparītauṣadhikalpanāt || bhavaḥ śuddho bhavenaiva vikalpapratikalpataḥ || (47)

ji ltar rlung gis zin pa la/ / mon sran sde'u yi bza' ba sbyin/ / bzlog pa'i sman ni brtags pa yis/ / rlung gis rlung la snun par byed/ / rnam rtog las ni rnam rtog dang / / srid pa nyid kyis srid pa dag /

Just as the one who is afflicted by flatulence is given beans to eat, for afflictions caused by wind are destroyed by wind according to the rule of counteracting medicine, similarly phenomenal existence is purified by utilising phenomenal existence itself, utilising notions to counter notions.

ji ltar snga ma la rlung zhes bya zhe na/ dbugs kyi rgyu yin pa'i phyir ro/ / ji ltar zlog pa yin zhe na/ rigs gcig pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i brtags pa ni de nyid phan par ro/ / srid pa ni 'khor ba'o/ / dag pa ni yongs su zad pa'o/ / srid pa nyid kyis zhes bya ba ni nyi ma dang zla ba dang phyag mtshan dang sa bon yongs su gyur pas ni srid pa ste/ lha'i rnam pa nyid kyis de dag zad par 'gyur ro zhes bya ba'i don to/ / rnam rtog ni 'khor ba'o/ / kun rtog ni lha'i rnam pa'i kun rtog pas zad par 'gyur ro zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

viparītauṣadhi (counteracting medicine): How does counteracting medicine destroy? The downward flowing wind in the body (apānavāyu) is the cause for flatulence. How then is wind the counteracting medicine? Wind itself is beneficial because it is of the same nature as the cause of flatulence. kalpana (rule): Means the rule of prescription. bhava (existence): Means phenomenal existence. śuddha (purified): Means destroyed. bhavenaiva (by existence itself): Here ‘existence’ refers to that which arises by the transformation of the Moon, Sun and Symbol, and it is the form of the deity. By means of such an emanation of ‘existence’ the destruction of phenomenal existence occurs is the intent. vikalpa (notions): ‘Notions’ refers to the notions of phenomenal existence. parikalpana (utilising ... to counter): Means the countering by utilising the deity’s form. This destroys false notions is the intent. Another analogy is given by:
karṇe toyaṃ yathā viṣṭaṃ prati toyena kṛṣyate || tathā bhavavikalpo 'pi ākāraiḥ śodhyate khalu || (48)
ji ltar rna bar chu zhugs pa/ / chu gzhan dag gis 'gugs par byed/ / de bzhin dngos po'i rnam rtog kyang / / rnam par nges pas sbyang bar bya/ /
Just as water that has entered in the ear is drawn out by using water, similarly false notions regarding existence are indeed also purified by using phenomenal forms.

ji ltar rna bar chu zhugs pa/ /zhes bya ba ni dpe bstan pa'o/ / de bzhin zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ dngos po ni rnam par rtog pa'i ngo bo ste 'khor ba'o/ / rnam par zhes bya ba ni lha'i rnam pa'o/ / nges par zhes bya ba ni the tshom med par zhes bya ba'i don to/ /
bhava (existence): Refers to the phenomenal existence comprising notions. ākāraiḥ (by using phenomenal forms): Means by using the forms of the deity. khalu (indeed): Means without doubt.
yathā pāvakadagdhāś ca svidyante vahninā punaḥ || tathā rāgāgnidagdhāś ca svidyante rāgavahninā || (49)
ji ltar 'tshed pas tshig pa yang / / me yis kyang ni gdung bar bya/ / de bzhin 'dod chags mes tshig pa/ / 'dod chags me yis gdung bar bya/ /
Just as those who are burnt by fire treat the burn with fire, similarly those who are burnt by the fire of passion cure themselves by utilising the fire of passion.

ji ltar zhes bya ba la sogs pa la 'dod chags ni nyon mongs pa'o/ / de nyid ni me'o/ / des tshig pa ni yongs su gdungs pa'o/ / 'dod chags kyi mes bsregs shing yongs su btsos pa la/ 'dod chags chen po bsgom pa nyid thabs dang shes rab gnyis su med pa'i sku'i mtshan nyid can bstan pa'o/ /

rāga (passion): Passions are the afflictions (kleśāḥ) and are themselves the fire. dagdhā (those who are burnt): Refers to those consumed by passion. svidyante (cure themselves): Means mature themselves. ragavahninā (by utilising the fire of passion): Means by utilising the emanation of Great Passion which is characterised as the non-duality of the two, the bodies of Wisdom and Means.

yena yena hi badhyante jantavo raudrakarmaṇā || sopāyena tu tenaiva mucyante bhavabandhanāt || (50) rāgena badhyate loko rāgenaiva vimucyate || viparītabhāvanā hy eṣā na jñātā buddhatīrthikaiḥ || (51)

skye bo mi bzad pa yi las/ / gang dang gang gis 'ching 'gyur ba/ / thabs dang bcas na de nyid kyis/ / srid pa'i 'ching ba las grol 'gyur/ / chags pas 'jig rten 'ching 'gyur ba/ / 'dod chags nyid kyis rnam grol 'gyur/ / bzlog pa'i bsgom pa 'di nyid ni/ / sangs rgyas mu stegs kyis mi shes/ /

Beings are released from the bondage of existence utilising as Means those very things by which beings, because of their wicked deeds, are bound. Beings are bound by passion and are released by utilising passion. Such a conception of counteraction is not known to the followers of other Buddhist and non-Buddhist schools.

gang dang gang gis zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ 'ching 'gyur zhes bya ba ni bcings par gyur pa'o/ / mi zad pa'i las zhes bya ba ni srog gcod pa la sogs pa'o/ / thabs ni snying rje chen po'o/ / chags pas zhes bya ba ni 'jig rten pa'i chags pa'o/ / rnam grol 'gyur zhes bya ba ni lhan cig skyes pa'i chags pas so/ / bzlog pa'i zhes bya ba ni rang gi phyogs nyid yin na yang mi mthun pa'i phyogs ltar gyur pa'o/ / yang dag par ni 'dod chags gcig pur ma zad kyi 'jig rten pa'i chos thams cad kyi yang ngo / / mi shes zhes bya ba ni de lta bu'i bde ba chen po bsgom pa mi rtog pa'o/ / sangs rgyas zhes bya ba ni nyan thos la sogs pa'o/ / ji ltar na de dag sangs rgyas zhes bya zhe na/ sangs rgyas nyid ston par khas len pa'i phyir ro/ / ci'i phyir mu stegs zhes bya zhe na/ bcom ldan 'das kyi bstan pa'i snying por gyur pa rdo rje theg pa nyid la rab tu sdang ba'i phyir ro/ / de dag gis ni dkyil 'khor gyi 'khor lo bsgoms pas phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub 'grub par 'gyur ro zhes rab tu bsgrub pa yin no/ /

yena yena ityādi (those very things by which etc.): ‘Things’ which bind refer to those things which cause bondage. raudrakarma (wicked deeds): Refers to killing beings and other such deeds. upāya (Means): Refers to Great Compassion. rāgeṇa (by passion): Refers to the worldly passion. vimucyate (released): Means they are released by the Innate Passion. viparīta (counteraction): Here the antidote is the very same as the cause for the adversity. This in truth is not relevant only to passion but also relevant to all other kinds of human emotions. na jñātā (not known): This conception, that of Great Bliss, is not known, that is, not practised by other Buddhist and non-Buddhist schools. buddhatīrthakaiḥ (Buddhist and non-Buddhist schools): Refers to the Śrāvakas and others. They are called heretics because they are in conflict with the essence of the Vajrayāna teachings of the Enlightened One. So far it has been demonstrated that the Mahāmudrā Accomplishment is attained by the emanation of the Maṇḍala Circle.
da ni bde ba chen po'i mchog de nyid dpag tu med pa'i rigs su 'gyur ro zhes rab tu bsgrub pa'i phyir dbang po gnyis sbyor bas zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
Now in order to show that the supreme Great Bliss itself has innumerable families it is said:
kundureṣu bhavet pañca pañcabhūtasvarūpataḥ || eka eva mahānandaḥ pañcatāṃ yānti bhedanaiḥ || (52)
'byung ba lnga yi rang bzhin la/ / kun tu ru las lnga ru 'gyur/ / dga' ba chen po gcig nyid las/ / dbye bas lnga ru 'gro bar 'gyur/ /
In sexual union arise five having the nature of the five elements. The Great Joy, which is essentially one, becomes five by this differentiation.

dbang po gnyis sbyor ba zhes pa ni shin tu dga' ba'i sbyor ba'o/ / 'gyur zhes bya ba ni 'byung bar 'gyur ba'o/ / lnga zhes bya ba ni longs spyod rnam pa lnga'o/ / 'byung ba'i rang bzhin zhes bya ba ni sa la sogs pa 'byung ba chen po lnga'i ngo bo nyid do/ / yang de ci zhig ce na/ gcig nyid las zhes bya ba'o/ / lnga ru zhes bya ba ni rnam pa lngar ro/ / dbye bas zhes bya ba ni 'byung ba chen po lnga'i dbye bas so/ /

kundureṣu (in sexual union): Refers to the erotic play. bhavet (arise): Means there are. pañca (five): Refers to the five facets of sexual enjoyment. pañcabhūtasvarūpataḥ (having the nature of the five elements): Means as the nature of the Earth and the other elements. And further regarding them it is said by: eka eva (essentially one): As the Great Bliss they are essentially one. pañcatāṃ (five): Means five aspects. bhedanaiḥ (by this differentiation): Means by the differentiation into the five elements.
bolakakkolayogena sparśāt kāṭhinyavāsanā || kaṭhinasya mohadharmatvān moho Vairocano mataḥ || (53)
bo la kak+ko la sbyor bas/ / reg pa sra ba'i bag chags kyis/ / sra ba gti mug chos kyi phyir/ / gti mug rnam par snang mdzad brjod/ /
From the contact of the male and female sexual organs there is the experience of hardness. The nature of hardness is Delusion and Delusion is known as Vairocana.
rdo rje pad+mas zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ sra bar zhes bya ba ni sra bar shes pa ste sa'i khams so/ / de nyid ni gti mug gi chos te sra ba'i phyir ro/ /
kāṭhinyavāsanā (experience of hardness): Means the knowledge of hardness. Hardness refers to the Earth element whose nature is Delusion, it being firmly fixed.
bodhicittaṃ dravaṃ yasmād dravaṃ abdhātukaṃ mataṃ || apām Akṣobhyarūpatvād dveṣo {hy} Akṣobhyanāyakaḥ || (54)
gang phyir byang sems gsher ba nyid/ / gsher ba chu yi khams su brjod/ / chu ni mi bskyod gzugs kyi phyir/ / zhe sdang 'dren pa mi bskyod pa/ /
Bodhicitta, semen, is a fluid and so fluidity is known as the Water element. Since Water is of the nature of semen (akṣobhya) and Lord Akṣobhya is Wrath, the Water element is Wrath.
dvayor gharṣaṇasaṃyogāt tejo {hi} jāyate sadā || rāgo 'mitavajraḥ syād rāgas tejasi saṃbhavet || (55)
gnyis kyis bskyod pa'i sbyor ba las/ / drod ni rtag tu skye bar 'gyur/ / 'dod chags dpag med rdo rje yin/ / 'dod chags drod las 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
From the friction of the two sexual organs Fire always arises. From Fire arises Passion and Passion is Amitābha.
drod ces bya ba ni dro ba'o/ / 'dod chags drod las zhes bya ba ni chags pa nyid do/ /
tejas (Fire): Fire refers to heat. rāgas tejasi (from Fire ... passion): This implies the impassioned nature of passion.
kakkolakeṣu yac cittaṃ tat samīraṇarūpakaṃ || īrṣyā {hy} Amoghasiddhiḥ syād Amogho vāyusaṃbhavaḥ || (56)
kak+ko lar ni gang zhig sems/ / de ni rlung gi rang bzhin can/ / phrag dog don yod grub pa yin/ / don yod rlung las 'byung ba nyid/ /
The Consciousness [semen] which is placed within the female organ is of the nature of movement. Amogha arises from Air and Amoghasiddhi is Envy.
rlung gi rang bzhin gyis 'jug par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / de nyid kyi phyir phrag dog ste/ i ra ga ta pi ti zhes bya ba'i skad kyi dbyings so/ /
samīnaṇarūpakam (of the nature of movement): Means it is of the nature of Air because movement is the nature of Air. īrṣyā (Envy): Means jealousy.
sukhaṃ rāgaṃ bhaved raktaṃ raktir ākāśalakṣaṇaṃ || akāśaḥ Piśunavajraḥ piśunam ākāśasaṃbhavaṃ || (57)
bde ba 'dod chags khrag tu 'gyur/ / dga' ba nam mkha'i mtshan nyid de/ / nam mkha' ser sna rdo rjer 'gyur/ / ser sna nam mkha' las byung nyid/ /
The pleasure of passion becomes the impassioned state and this impassioned state is the characteristic of Space. Space is Piśunavajra, for Malignity (piśunam) is Space.

bde ba ni snyoms par 'jug pa'i chags pa ste/ chags pa med pa'i mtshan nyid can yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de nyid ni 'dod chags te 'gro ba thams cad kha dog bsgyur ba'i phyir ro/ / de ni nam mkha'i mtshan nyid de/ rang bzhin med pa'i phyir ro/ / phra ma rdo rje ni rin chen 'chang ngo / / don dam par rab tu ston par byed pas na phra ma'o/ /

sukhaṃ (bliss): Refers to the erotic joy. rāgaṃ (passion): This pleasure is the unrestrained passion. raktaṃ (impassioned state): This pleasure is the impassioned state because it delights the world. ākāśalakṣaṇaṃ (characterised by Space): Bliss is characterised by Space because it has no properties that can be described. piśunavajraḥ (Piśunavajra): Refers to Ratneśa. piśunaṃ (Malignity [also means displaying]): The displayer is so-called because of revealing the supreme truth.
ekam eva mahac cittaṃ pañcarūpeṇa saṃsthitaṃ || pañcakuleṣu saṃbhavās tatrānekasahasraśaḥ || (58)
sems ni chen po gcig nyid la/ / lnga yi gzugs kyis rnam par mtshon/ / rigs ni lnga po de nyid las/ / stong phrag du ma skyes pa nyid/ /
The great Consciousness, which is in fact one, exists in five forms. From within the Five Families there manifest thousands of families.
sems ni rin po che zhes bya ba ni bde ba chen po'i rang bzhin gyi sems so/ / rang bzhin lnga zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ de nyid las zhes bya ba ni de dag nyid las so/ /
mahac cittaṃ (great Consciousness): This refers to the consciousness characterised by Great Bliss. tatra (there): Means from within the five forms.
tasmād ekasvabhāvo 'sau mahāsukhaṃ śaśvatparaṃ || pañcatāṃ yāti bhedena rāgādipañcacetasā || (59)
de phyir 'di dag rang bzhin gcig / bde chen mchog tu rtag pa nyid/ / 'dod chags la sogs sems lnga yi/ / dbye bas lnga ru 'gro bar 'gyur/ /
Thus, this Great Bliss which is essentially one and the supreme, becomes five by differentiation into the five emotional states of passion and so on.

daśagaṅgānadīvālukātulyā ekakuleṣu tathāgathasaṅghāḥ || saṅghakuleṣu {hy} anekakulāni teṣu kuleṣu kulāni śatāni || (60) tāni ca lakṣakulāni mahānti koṭikulāni bahūni bhavanti || tatra kuleṣu cāsaṅkhyakulāni paramānandakulodbhavāni || (61)

gang gA'i klung ni bcu yi bye snyed kyis/ / rigs gcig la ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i tshogs/ / rigs kyi tshogs la rigs ni du ma rnams/ / de rnams rigs ni rnam pa brgya/ / de rnams la yang 'bum phrag rigs chen rnams/ / bye ba'i rigs la grangs ni med par 'gyur/ / de la rigs la grangs med rigs rnams ni/ / mchog tu dga' ba'i rigs las byung ba rnams/ /

Within each one of the families there are the assemblies of the Tathāgatas equal to the sands on the banks of ten Ganges rivers. Within the families of the assemblies there are many families. Within those families there are one hundred families. They further manifest into one hundred thousand families, ten million families and these families become innumerable. Within those there are innumerable families, all of which originate from the Family of Supreme Joy.

gang gA'i klung bcu'i zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ rigs gcig ni zhes bya ba ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs gcig nyid la'o/ / rigs kyi tshogs la zhes bya ba ni de bzhin gshegs kyi rigs kyi tshogs la ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i rigs kyi tshogs can gyi rigs te/ rigs de las rigs 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / rigs 'bum so so las kyang rigs bye ba 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / de dag las kyang rigs gzhan grangs med pa 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / de dag thams cad kyang mchog tu dga' ba'i rigs las 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ /

ekakuleṣu (within each one of the families): Means within each one of the families of the Tathāgatas. saṅghakuleṣu (within the families of the assemblies): Means within the families of the assemblies of the Tathāgatas. teṣu kuleṣu ityādi (within those families etc.): Means within the families of the families of the assemblies of the Tathāgatas are one hundred families. Each becomes one hundred thousand and ten million. And they further become innumerable families. All of these families originate from the Family of Supreme Joy.
Hevajre ḍākinījālāsaṃvare siddhinirṇayo nāma dvitīyaḥ paṭalaḥ /
kye'i rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma dra ba'i sdom pa las dngos grub gtan la phab pa zhes bya ba'i le'u ste gnyis pa'o// //
Thus ends the second chapter known as the Definition of the Accomplishment, in the Hevajra Tantra, the Concealed Essence of the Net of the Ḍākinīs.
mkha' 'gro ma ni rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma'o/ / de'i dra ba ni tshogs te dkyil 'khor gyi 'khor lo'o/ / de'i sdom pa ni bde ba'i mchog go/ / de'i phyir dngos grub ces bya ste de gtan la dbab pa'o/ /

ḍākinī (Ḍākinī): The Ḍākinīs are the Vajra Ḍākinīs. jālaṃ (Net): The Net of the Ḍākinīs means the assembly of the Ḍākinīs and is the Maṇḍala Circle. samvaraṃ (Concealed Essence): The Concealed Essence in the Maṇḍala Circle is the excellent bliss. siddhinirṇayaḥ (the Definition of the Accomplishment): The Accomplishment is attained by means of this excellent bliss. The ‘definition’ is of this Accomplishment.
dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i dka' 'grel rnal 'byor rin po che'i phreng ba las le'u gnyis pa'i 'grel pa'o// //
Thus the second chapter [of the second part] of the Hevajra Pañjikā known as the Yogaratnamālā.

d.crumb: gleng gzhi dang gsang ba'i skad ces bya ba'i le'u

f.d: gleng gzhi dang gsang ba'i skad ces bya ba'i le'u

d.crumb: CHAPTER 3. Fundamentals of All Tantras

f.d: CHAPTER 3. Fundamentals of All Tantras
atha vajrī sarvatantranidānaṃ nāmopayaṃ yoginīnāṃ kathayām āsa /
de nas rdo rje can gyi rnal 'byor ma rnams la rgyud thams cad kyi gleng gzhi zhes bya ba'i thabs bka' stsal pa/
Then the Adamantine One spoke to the Yoginīs regarding the Means which are known as the Fundamentals of All Tantras.

de nas zhes bya ba la sogs pa la rdo rje can zhes bya ba ni rdo rje 'chang ngo / / rgyud thams cad kyi gleng gzhi ni dgyes pa rdo rje'i rgyud kyi dbang du byas pa ste/ de'i ched du byas pa'i dang por bstan pa'i rgyud do/ /zhes bya ba ni ming de skad ces bya bar rab tu grags pa'o/ / thabs zhes bya ba ni yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub sgrub pa'i thabs so/ /

vajrī (the Adamantine One): Refers to Vajradhara. sarvatantranidānaṃ (the Fundamentals of All Tantras): ‘Fundamentals’ refers to the basic themes of the whole of the Hevajra Tantra cycle. These are the themes upon which the tantras instruct. nāma (known as): Means famed as. upāya (Means): Refers to the instructions upon the methods of practice which accomplish the complete awakening.
de nyid mdor bstan pa'i phyir sdom pa dang ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
These basic themes are named:
saṃvaraṃ cābhiṣekañ ca saṃdhyābhāṣaṃ tathaiva ca || ānandakṣaṇabhedañ ca tathānyaṃ bhojanādikaṃ || (1)
sdom pa dang ni dbang dang yang / / de bzhin dgongs pa'i skad nyid dang / / dga' dang skad cig dbye ba dang / / gzhan yang bza' ba la sogs pa/ /
The Concealed Essence (saṃvara), Consecration (abhiṣeka), the Tantric Code Language (sandhyābhāṣa), the different Joys (ānanda) and Moments (kṣaṇa) and others as well as Feasting (bhojana) and so on.

sdom pa ni bde ba chen po'i ye shes so/ / dbang ni dbang rnam pa bzhi'o/ / dgongs pa'i skad ni mngon par dgongs pa'i skad nyid do/ / dga' ba dang zhes bya ba ni dga' ba rnam pa bzhi'o/ / skad cig dbye ba zhes bya ba ni skad cig ma rnam pa bzhi'o/ / gzhan yang zhes bya ba ni spros pa med pa nyid kyi spyod pa'o/ / yang zhes bya ba ni mig la sogs pa dag pa'o/ / bza' ba ni slob dpon gyis so/ / sogs pa zhes bya ba'i sgras ni nges par bya ba'i tshigs bcad bsdu ba'o/ /

saṃvaraṃ (the Concealed Essence): The Concealed Essences are the components of the knowledge of Great Bliss. abhiṣekaṃ (Consecration): Refers to the four consecrations. sandhyābhāṣa (the Tantric Code Language): Refers to the communication regarding the enlightened state. ānandā (Joys): Refers to the four Joys. kṣaṇabhedaṃ (different... Moments): Refers to the four Moments. anyaṃ (others): Refers to the Undifferentiated and the other Applications of the Vow. ca (and): Here ‘and’ implies the purification of the eye and the other sense organs. bhojanādi (Feasting and so on): ‘And so on’ refers to the songs in praise of the master.
tatra saṃvaram āha / saṃvaraṃ sarvabuddhānām EVAṂ-kāre pratiṣṭhitaṃ || abhiṣekāj jñāyate samyag EVAṂ-kāraṃ mahat sukhaṃ || (2)
de la sdom pa bka' stsal pa/ / sangs rgyas kun gyi sdom pa ni/ / e ba~M rnam par reb tu gnas/ / e ba~M rnam pa'i bde chen po/ / dbang las yang dag shes par bya/ /
There Vajradhara spoke regarding the Concealed Essence: The Concealed Essence of the all the Buddhas abides in evaṃ. Evaṃ, the great bliss, is fully known through consecration.

sdom pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ gang gis sdom pa zhe na/ sangs rgyas kun gyi zhes bya ba ste/ bde ba chen po'i ngo bo nyid kyis sangs rgyas kun la tha dad pa mi mnga' ba'i phyir ro/ / e waM rnam par zhes bya ba ni chos 'byung gi phyag rgya la gnas pa'o/ / de ji ltar shes par bya zhe na/ dbang las yang dag ces bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ bla ma'i man ngag las shes par bya zhing rab tu bsgrub par bya'o/ /

saṃvaraṃ ityādi (the Concealed Essence): Whose Concealed Essence? It is the Concealed Essence of all the Buddhas. As the Great Bliss evaṃ is the Concealed Essence of all the Enlightened Ones because differentiated notions are non-existent in the Great Bliss. evaṃkāre (in evaṃ): Means located in the symbol of the Source of Nature (dharmodayamudrā). How it is known is said by: abhiṣekāj jñāyate ityādi (known through Consecration etc.): ‘Known through consecration’ means accomplished by following the guru’s instructions.
atha bhagavantaṃ Vajrasattvaṃ yoginya evam āhuḥ / EVAṂ-kāraṃ kim ucyate ḍākinīnān tu saṃvaraṃ || deśayantu yathānyāyaṃ bh[aga]vān śāstā jagadguruḥ || (3)

de nas rnal 'byor ma rnams kyis bcom ldan 'das rdo rje sems dpa' la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan ston pa 'gro ba'i bla/ / mkha' 'gro ma yi sdom pa nyid/ / e ba~M rnam pas ci zhes brjod/ / rim pa ji bzhin bshad du gsol/ /

Then the Yoginīs said to Bhagavān Vajrasattva thus: Why is evaṃ called the Concealed Essence of the Ḍākinīs? May the Bhagavān, the Master and Guru of the Universe, instruct by giving the appropriate reason.

mkha' 'gro ma'i zhes bya ba ni DA DA ni mkha' la 'gro bar byed pa zhes bya ba'i skad kyi dbyings kyis 'dir brtags nas/ nam mkha' la 'gro ba 'grub pa thams cad la mkha' 'gro zhes kla klo'i skad kyis bcom ldan 'das kyis bstan pa yin pas/ mkha' 'gro ma ni rdo rje rnal 'byor ma'o/ / de dag sdom pa ni mchog tu mdor bsdus pa'i phyir ro/ / de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi sku dang gsung dang thugs ngo bo nyid gcig par bstan pa'i phyir/

ḍākinīnaṃ (of the Ḍākinīs): The word ‘ḍākinī’ is derived from the root verb ḍai, meaning, moving in space, indicating the power of moving anywhere in space. Bhagavān has defined the origin of the word ‘ḍākinī’ in this manner. evaṃ: Bhagavān has previously instructed that evaṃ is the Concealed Essence of the Ḍākinīs who are the Vajra Yoginīs for evaṃ is the best of essences. In order to indicate the unity of the Body, Speech and Mind of all the Buddhas it is said:
bhagavān āha / E-kārākṛti yad divyaṃ madhye VAṂ-kārabhūṣitaṃ || ālayaḥ sarvasaukhyānāṃ buddharatnakaraṇḍakaṃ || (4)
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / e yi cha byad bzang po gang / / dbus su ba~M gyis rnam par brgyan/ / bde ba thams cad kyi ni gnas/ / sangs rgyas rin chen za ma tog /
Bhagvān replied: The divine letter e, adorned with the syllable vaṃ placed within it, is the abode of all bliss and the receptacle of the jewels of the Buddhas.

e'i rnam pa'i cha byad do/ / 'di la bzang po yod pas na bzang po ste/ baM gyi rnam pa'o/ / brgyan pa ni des pad+ma'i ze'u 'bru mdzes par byas pa'o/ / gnas zhes bya ba ni rten no/ / sangs rgyas rin chen zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ de bzhin gshegs pa lnga ni snod du gyur pa la de skad ces bya ste/ de dag gi rten gyi ngo bo nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ / dga' ba de las skye bar 'gyur/ /

divyaṃ (divine): It is said to be divine because it is brilliant. vaṃkāraṃ (the syllable vaṃ): Vaṃ is in the core. bhūṣitaṃ (adorned): Means resplendent. ālayaḥ (abode): Means the basic resting place. buddharatnakaraṇḍakaṃ (receptacle of the jewels of the Buddhas): ‘Buddhas’ refers to the Five Tathāgatas. It is said to be the receptacle because it bears the jewels of the Buddhas.
ānandās tatra jāyante kṣaṇabhedena bheditāḥ || kṣaṇajñānāt sukhajñānam EVAṂ-kāre pratiṣṭhitaṃ || (5)
skad cig dbye bas phye ba nyid/ / dga' ba de las skye bar 'gyur/ / skad cig shes nas bde shes pa/ / e ba~M rnam par rab tu gnas/ /
It is there in evaṃ that the Joys arise, distinguished by the different Moments. From the experience of these Moments the knowledge of the bliss located in evaṃ is known.

skad cig dbye bas phye ba yi/ /zhes bya ba ni rnam pa sna tshogs la sogs pa'i dbye bas phye ba'o/ / gal te dga' ba nyid yod par gyur na skad cig ma'i dbye bas ci zhig bya zhe na/ skad cig shes nas zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ skad cig ma rnams kyis rang gi ngo bo shes na ni dga' ba rnams kyis bde ba'i byed pa yongs su shes par 'gyur gyi/ gzhan du ni ma yin no zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ /

kṣaṇa (Moments): Moments refers to the four Moments distinguished as Diverse and so on. If the Joys are so distinguished, what regarding this distinction of the Moments? This is answered by: kṣaṇajñānāt ityādi (from the experience of these Moments etc.): It is only by knowing the nature of the Moments that the understanding of Bliss, that is, the distinctions regarding the Joys, is possible. Bliss arises only from the knowledge of the Moments and not by any other way is the intent.
skad cig ma'i dbye ba de dag nyid bstan pa'i phyir/
In order to show the nature of the different Moments it is said:

vicitraṃ ca vipākaṃ ca vimardo vilakṣaṇaṃ tathā || catuḥkṣaṇasamāgamyam EVAṂ jānanti yoginaḥ || (6) vicitraṃ vividhaṃ khyātam āliṅgacuṃbanādikaṃ || vipākaṃ tadviparyāsaṃ sukhajñānasya bhuñjanaṃ || (7) vimardam ālocanaṃ proktaṃ sukhaṃ bhuktaṃ mayeti ca || vilakṣaṇaṃ tribhyo 'nyatra rāgārāgavivarjitaṃ || (8)

sna tshogs dang ni rnam smin dang / / rnam nyed de bzhin mtshan nyid bral/ / skad cig bzhi ni rab shes pa/ / de ltar rnal 'byor pas shes 'gyur/ / 'khyud dang 'o byed la sogs pa/ / sna tshogs rnam pa sna tshogs bshad/ / rnam par smin pa de las bzlog / bde ba'i ye shes za ba nyid/ / bdag gis bde ba zos pa yi/ / gros ni rnam par nyed par brjod/ / mtshan nyid bral ba gsum las gzhan/ / chags dang chags bral rnam par spangs/ /

The yogis know that evaṃ is attainable through the four Moments which are Diverse, Ripening, Dissolving and Signless. The Diverse Moment is so called because it consists of a variety, embracing, kissing and so on. The Ripening Moment is the reverse of the Diverse Moment, it being the enjoyment of the blissful knowledge. The Dissolving Moment is said to be the reflective thought ‘I have experienced bliss’. The Signless is other than these three and is free from both passion and absence of passion.

sna tshogs dang ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ sna tshogs zhes bya ba sna tshogs pa la mkhas pa ste slob dpon gyi las so/ / rnam smin zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ de las zlog ces bya ba ni de dang mi 'dra bar gyur pa'o/ / ye shes zhes bya ba ni bde ba chen po'i ye shes so/ / de za ba ni de nyams su myong ba'o/ / rnam par nyed pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ zos zhes bya ba ni 'das ma thag pa zhig pa dran pa'o/ / yang na shes pa so sor rtogs pa ni zos zhes bya ste/ bdag gis bde ba spyad par gyur to zhes sngar gyi nges par 'dzin pa'o/ / mtshan nyid bral ba zhes bya ba ni sngar bstan pa gsum po'i'o/ / chags dang chags bral zhes bya ba ni srid pa dang mya ngan las 'das pa dang bral ba'o/ /

vividhaṃ (variety): Refers to the various skills and activities of the master when performing the ritual. viparyāsaṃ (reverse): Reverse here means the opposite of the Diverse. jñānasya (of ... knowledge): Refers to the knowledge of Great Bliss. bhuñjanaṃ (enjoyment): Means experiencing. ālocanaṃ (reflective thought): Means the recollection of bliss. Or else, it means the actualising of this experience. sukhaṃ bhuktaṃ mayeti (‘I have experienced bliss’): This is the affirmation of the [experience of the] previous Moment. vilakṣaṇaṃ ityādi (the Signless etc.): Here ‘three’ refers to the three Moments previously mentioned. rāgārāga (passion and absence of passion): Means that the Signless is devoid of the Phenomenal Existence and the Release.

vicitre prathamānandaḥ paramānando vipākake || viramānando vimarde ca sahajānando vilakṣaṇe || (9) ācarya guhya prajñā ca caturthan tat punas tathā || ānandāḥ kramaśo jñeyāś catuḥsecanasaṃkhyayā || (10)

sna tshogs dang po'i dga' ba nyid/ / rnam smin la ni mchog dga' nyid/ / rnam nyed dga' bral dga' ba nyid/ / mtshan bral lhan cig skyes dga' nyid/ / slob dpon gsang ba shes rab dang / / bzhi bde yang de bzhin no/ / dbang ni bzhi yi grangs kyis ni/ / dga' ba la sogs rim zhes bya/ /

In the Diverse is the First Joy; in Ripening is the Refined Joy; in the Dissolving is the Joy of Cessation; and in the Signless is the Innate Joy. In the order of the four consecrations, Master, Secret, Wisdom and after that the Fourth thus, the Joys are to be experienced.

sna tshogs dang ni zhes bya ba la sogs pas ni dga' ba rnam pa bzhi dbang bskur ba rnam pa bzhi rnam par gzhag par byed de/ dga' ba so sos kyang slob dpon dang gsang ba dang shes rab dang bzhi pa zhes bya bar thob par 'gyur ro zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ / de nyid kyi phyir dga' ba sogs pas bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ rim zhes bya zhes bya ba ni dga' ba ni slob dpon gyi dbang bskur ba'o/ / mchog tu dga' ba ni gsang ba'i dbang ngo / / dga' bral ni shes rab kyi dbang ngo / / lhan cig skyes pa ni dbang bskur ba bzhi pa'o/ / de ltar dbang bskur ba bzhi so so dang skad cig ma bzhi dang dga' ba bzhi bla ma'i man ngag las sbyar ba shes par bya ste/ de ltar na dbang bzhi'i rnam grangs shes par bya'o/ /

Here, the Joys appropriate to the four consecrations are mentioned. Each one of the Joys is related to one of the consecrations, Master, Secret, Wisdom and the Fourth. This is the intent. This is said by: ānandāḥ kramaśo (in the order ... the Joys): The order is: in the Master Consecration the Ordinary Joy, in the Secret Consecration the Refined Joy, in the Wisdom Consecration the Joy of Cessation and in the Fourth Consecration the Innate Joy. Thus, in each consecration one of the four Joys and one of the four Moments must be experienced. The Joy and the Moment appropriate to a particular consecration is to be understood as the conclusive proof of the accomplishment of that consecration. Understand the four-fold order in this manner.
hasitaśuddhyā tv ācārya • īkṣaṇe guhyakas tathā || prajñā {hi} pāṇyāvāptau ca tat punar dvandvatantrake || (11)
dgod pa dag pa slob dpon nyid/ / lta ba gsang ba de bzhin no/ / lag bcangs las ni shes rab nyid/ / gnyis gnyis 'khyud pa de yang nyid/ /
The Master Consecration is by the purification by the Smile, the Secret Consecration by the Gaze, the Wisdom Consecration by the Embrace and the Fourth Consecration by the Two in Sexual Union.

rgod pa'i dag pas zhes bya ba la sogs ni dbang gi rnam par dag pa gsungs pa yin te/ bya ba'i rgyud la sogs pa kha cig tu ni lha rnams thabs dang shes rab kyi rjes su chags pas dgod pa bstan te/ de rnam par dag pa ni slob dpon zhes bya ba slob dpon gyi dbang bskur ba'o/ / spyod pa'i rgyud la sogs pa kha cig tu ni thabs dang shes rab rjes su chags pa ston par byed phan tshun lta ba 'byung ba ste de'i rnam par dag pa ni gsang ba'i dbang bskur ba'o/ / rnal 'byor gyi rgyud la sogs pa kha cig tu thabs dang shes rab phan tshun 'khyud pa 'byung ste/ de'i rnam par dag pa ni shes rab kyi dbang bskur ba'o/ / rnal 'byor bla na med ces bya ba la sogs pa kha cig tu thabs dang shes rab gnyis kyis snyoms par 'jug pa 'byung bas de'i rnam par dag pa ni dbang bskur ba rnam pa bzhi'o/ /

By this verse the purifications appropriate to the consecrations are explained. hasitaśuddhyā (by the purification by the Smile): In certain Kriyā tantras, the smile indicates the affection between the deities of Wisdom and Means. ācārya (Master): Master refers to the Master Consecration and it is depicted by the purification by the smile. īkṣaṇe (by the Gaze): In certain Caryā tantras, the affection between Wisdom and Means is indicated by their gazing at each other. The Secret Consecration is depicted by the purification by the gaze. prajñā (Wisdom): In certain Yoga tantras the embrace of Wisdom and Means is depicted. The Wisdom Consecration is depicted by the embrace. dvandvatantrake (the Two in Sexual Union): In certain Anuttara tantras there is the complete sexual union, that is, the attainment of unity of the two, Wisdom and Means. The Fourth Consecration is depicted by the Two in Sexual Union.
de'i phyir/ dbang ni rnam pa bzhi ru bshad/ /ces gsungs te/
As a consequence of the above statements it is said:
sekaṃ caturvidhaṃ khyātaṃ sattvānāṃ siddhihetave || sicyate snāpyate 'neneti sekas tenābhidhīyate || (12)
sems can rnams kyi dngos grub phyir/ / dbang ni rnam pa bzhi ru bshad/ / gtoRa dang blugs pa zhes bya 'dis/ / des na dbang zhes brjod par bya/ /
In order that beings may attain the Accomplishment consecration is proclaimed to be four-fold. Consecration is so called because one is sprinkled and cleansed.

bzhi ni rnam pa bzhi'o/ /bshad ces bya ba ni dgyes pa'i rdo rje'i rgyud 'dir te rnal 'byor ma bla na med pa'i rgyud 'dir skal pa dang ldan par byas na thams cad la dbang ba'i phyir ro/ / de nyid kyi phyir sems can thams cad la phan par bya ba'i phyir zhes bya ba'o/ / dbang bskur zhes bya ba ni sgra'i don bstan pa'i phyir/ des na dbang zhes brjod par bya/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ blugs shing bkrus te dri ma med par byas/ /zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

caturvidhaṃ khyātaṃ (proclaimed to be four-fold): Means known to be of four kinds. Since this Hevajra Tantra is classified as a supreme Yoginī tantra it has complete authority over other tantras. So it is said: sattvānāṃ siddhihetave (for the benefit of living beings attaining the Accomplishment): Means for the welfare of beings. In order to show the meaning of the word ‘consecration’ it is said: snāpyate ’neneti (because ... cleansed): Consecration is so called because it washes, that is, removes the defilements, is the intent.
pāṇibhyāṃ tu samāliṅgya prajñāṃ vai ṣoḍaśābdikāṃ || ghaṇṭhāvajrasamāyogād ācāryasecanaṃ mataṃ || (13)
shes rab bcu drug lon pa la/ / lag pa dag gis yang dag 'khyud/ / rdo rje dril bu mnyam sbyor bas/ / slob dpon dbang du rab tu brjod/ /
Embracing a sixteen year old Wisdom consort with the hands and by uniting the Bell and Vajra is the Master Consecration.

lag pa dag gis zhes bya ba la sogs pas ni slob dpon gyi dbang bskur ba gsungs pa ste/ rdo rje dril bus mnyam par sbyor ba'i lag pas sam/ pad+ma dang rdo rje dag gis te man ngag ji lta ba bzhin du slob dpon gyi dbang bskur ba yin no/ /

This verse shows the characteristic of the Master Consecration. ghaṇṭavajrasamāyogāt (by uniting the Bell and Vajra): Refers to the holding of the [ceremonial] Bell and Vajra in the hands or to the uniting of the female and male sexual organs, as instructed by the guru. This is the characteristic of the Master Consecration.
cāruvaktrā viśālākṣī rūpayauvanamaṇḍitā || jyeṣṭhānāmikābhyañ ca śiṣyavaktre nipātayet || (14) kāritavyan tu tatraiva samarasaṃ śiṣyagocaraṃ ||

shin tu bzhin bzang mig yangs ma/ / gzugs dang lang tshos rnam par brgyan/ / mthe bong srin lag dag gis ni/ / slob ma'i kha ru ltung bar bya/ / de nyid du ni mnyam pa'i ro/ / slob ma'i spyod yul dag tu bya/ /

The consort has a beautiful face, wide eyes and is endowed with grace and youth. With the thumb and ring finger the Master must drop into the disciple’s mouth. There, with that dropping, the Flavour of Essential Similarity should be activated within the view of the disciple.

shin tu bzhin [{]bzangs [,]bzang [}]zhes bya ba la sogs pas ni shes rab kyi dbang bskur ba'i phyir shes rab kyi ngo bo gsungs pa yin te/ lag pa g.yon pa'i mthe bo dang srin lag dag gis snyoms par 'jug pa'i ro slob ma'i khar 'dzud cing gsang ba'i dbang bskur ba'i tshigs bcad brjod pa ste bshad pa gcig yin no/ / yang na mthe bo zhes bya ba ni la la nA'o/ / srin lag ces bya ba ni ra sa nA'o/ / de gnyis nas slob ma'i rdo rje nor bu'i sgor shes rab kyi byang chub kyi sems rab tu 'bab pa de'i man ngag bstan pa'o/ / de nyid du ni bya ba ste/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ de nyid du ni zhes bya ba ni shes rab gang la man ngag bstan pa nyid la'o/ / ro mnyam zhes bya ba ni thabs dang shes rab dag gi byang chub kyi sems yang dag par 'byor pa'o/ / slob ma'i spyod yul zhes bya ba ni so sor rtog pa'i yul du bya'o zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

cāruvaktrā ityādi (beautiful face etc.): With this description the qualities of the Wisdom consort for the Secret Consecration are described. jyeṣṭhānāmikābhyāñ ityādi (with the thumb and ring finger etc.): With the thumb and ring finger of the left hand, along with the songs and praises appropriate for the Secret Consecration, the juice of the sexual union must be dropped into the mouth of the disciple. This is one interpretation. Another interpretation: ‘Thumb’ refers to Lalanā nāḍī. ‘Ring finger’ refers to Rasanā nāḍī. The ‘disciple’ refers to the Vajra gem, the ‘mouth’ refers to the opening of the Lotus of Wisdom. What is dropped is Bodhicitta [which here refers to semen, the relative aspect of Bodhicitta, the Enlightened Consciousness]. The instruction to be given is said by: kāritavyaṅ ca tatraiva samarasaṃ ityādi (there... activate the Flavour of Essential Similarity etc.): ‘There’ means in the Wisdom herself the instruction is given. ‘Essential Similarity’ refers to the essential similarity of Wisdom and Means. śiṣyagocaraṃ (within the view of the disciple): The Flavour of Essential Similarity which is indicated by the union of the Bodhicitta [the sexual fluids] of Wisdom and Means should be made apparent to the disciple.
'di lta bu ni gsang ba'i dbang bskur ba'o/ /
Such is the Secret Consecration.
prajñāṃ pūjayec chāstā arcayitvā samarpayet || (15) śāstā brūyāt mahāsattva gṛhna mudrāṃ sukhāvahāṃ ||
ston pas shes rab rab tu mchod/ / rjed par byas nas gtad par bya/ / ston pas smras pa sems dpa' che/ / phyag rgya bde ba ldan pa khyer/ /
The Wisdom consort must be worshipped by the Master and having honoured her he must offer her to the disciple saying: ‘O great Being, take this consort who will give you bliss’.

ston pas shes rab ces gsungs pa ni rgyud nas gsungs pa'i mtshan dang ldan pa'o/ / mchod ces bya ba ni dang por ro/ / ston pa zhes bya ba ni bla ma ste/ dka' bar gyur pa'i las rnams kyi khur bzod dam mi bzod ces brtag pa'i phyir ro/ / de nas rgyud nas gsungs pa'i 'chad par 'gyur ba'i tshigs bcad brjod nas gtad par bya'o/ / phyag rgya bde ba ldan pa khyer/ /zhes bya ba ni chos kyi phyag rgya'o/ /

prajñāṃ ityādi (Wisdom etc.): First the master, that is, the guru, should worship the Wisdom consort who is endowed with the auspicious qualities prescribed in the tantras. This is in order to test whether or not the consort has the patience to bear the difficulties [of the practice]. samarpayet (offer): Offer her with the songs that are mentioned in this tantra. gṛhṇa mudrāṃ (take this consort): Here ‘consort’ (mudrā) is to be understood in the context of the Seal of Essential Nature (dharmamudrā).
'di lta bu ni shes rab kyi dbang bskur ba'o/ /
Such is the Wisdom Consecration.
jñātvā śiṣyaṃ mahadbhūtaṃ nirīrṣyaṃ krodhavarjitaṁ || (16) śāstā tam ājñāpayati kunduraṃ kuru vajradhṛk ||
phrag dog khro ba rnam spangs pa'i/ / slob ma cher gyur shes nas ni/ / ston pas de la gnang ba sbyin/ / kun tu ru gyis rdo rje 'dzin/ /
Knowing the disciple to be worthy and free of envy and wrath, the master then commands him: ‘O bearer of the Vajra, perform the Union’.

slob ma che 'gyur shes nas ni/ /zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ che 'gyur zhes bya ba ni phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub kyi snod du gyur pa'o/ / phrag dog spangs zhes bya ba ni ser sna dang bral ba'o/ / khro ba rnam spangs zhes bya ba ni snying rje chen po dang ldan pa'o/ / de la zhes bya ba ni slob ma la'o/ / snang ba sbyin zhes bya ba ni man ngag bstan par bya'o zhes bya ba'i don to/ / 'di skad kyang brjod par bya ste dbang po gnyis sbyor zhes kyang ngo / / sbyor zhes bya ba ni phyag rgya chen po'i snyoms par 'jug pa ste gyis shig ces bya ba'o/ / rdo rje 'dzin zhes bya ba ni rdo rje 'chang zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

mahadbhūtaṃ (worthy): Means worthy of the Mahāmudrā Accomplishment. nirīrṣyaṃ (free of envy): Means not competitive. krodhavarjitaṃ (free of ... wrath): Refers to the disciple who has Great Compassion. ājñāpayati (commands): Means gives instruction. The master says: kunduruṃ kuru (perform the Union): Means perform the erotic union, that is, the Attainment of the State of Unity of the Mahāmudrā (mahāmudrāsamāpatti). vajradhṛk (O bearer of the Vajra): Means Vajradhara, the bearer of the Vajra.
dbang bskur ba bzhi pa'o/ /
This is the Fourth Consecration.
da ni dbang gi don du slob mas ji ltar mnyes par bya ba bstan pa'i phyir/ slob ma'i bya ba zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/
Now the way the disciple honours the master in order to obtain the consecrations is said by:

śiṣyakṛtyaṃ pravakṣyāmy abhiṣekam anunāyayed || (17) mudrāyuktaṃ guruṃ dṛṣṭvā stutipūjāṃ karet yathā || he bhagavan mahāśānta vajrayogaikatatpara || (18) mudrāprasādhakābhedyavajrayogasamudbhava || yathā yūyaṃ mahātmano mamāpi kuru tad vibho || (19) saṃsārapaṅkasaṃghāṭe magno 'haṃ trāhy aśaraṇaṃ ||

ji ltar dbang bskur gsol btab pa'i/ / slob ma'i bya ba bshad par bya/ / bla ma phyag rgya ldan mthong nas/ / bstod dang mchod pa ji bzhin bya/ / bcom ldan zhi ba chen po kye/ / rdo rje rnal 'byor gcig bzhed pa/ / mi phyed phyag rgya sgrub pa po/ / rdo rje rnal 'byor las byung ba/ / ji ltar khyod ni bdag nyid che/ / mnga' bdag bdag la'ang de ltar mdzod/ / 'khor ba 'dam gyi tshogs nad du/ / bying ba skyabs med bdag la skyobs/ /

Now I shall tell you the role of the disciple, how he requests for the consecration and how he praises and honours when beholding the guru in union with the consort. [He should request by saying:] ‘O Lord, Great Tranquil Being who is intent only on the Vajra union, perfecter of the Seals and one who originates from the union of the indivisible Vajras! O great Being, as you do for yourself, O Lord, may you also do the same for me. I am sunk in the thick mud of phenomenal existence; save me who has no other resort.’

gsol ba gdab ces bya ba ni don du gnyer bar bya'o/ / bcom ldan zhi ba chen po kye/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pa ni bla ma la bstod pa'o/ / gnyis su med pa'i rnal 'byor la nges par gnas pa'i phyir zhi ba chen po'o/ / rdo rje ni rdo rje'o/ / rnal 'byor ni snyoms par 'jug pa'i khyad par ro/ / der gcig tu gtad pa gcig bzhed pa'o/ / phyag rgya sgrub pa po zhes bya ba la phyag rgya ni phyag rgya bzhi'o/ / sgrub pa po ni yongs su mnyes par byed pa po'o/ / stong pa nyid kyi rang bzhin gyi phyir mi phyed pa'o/ / rdo rje ni de bzhin gshegs pa rnams so/ / de dag gi rnal 'byor ni ting nge 'dzin te/ de las yang dag par byung ba'o/ / ji ltar zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ ji ltar khyod 'gro ba la phan pa'i rgyu yin pa ltar ro/ / de ltar zhes bya ba ni de bzhin du'o/ / mnga' bdag ces bya ba ni gtso bo'o/ /

anunāyayet (he requests): The request begins with the praise of the guru beginning with the words ‘O Lord etc.’: mahāśānta (the Great Tranquil Being): He is so called because of dwelling in the non-dual union. vajrayoga (the Vajra union): ‘Vajra’ is the male sexual organ. ‘Union’ refers to the Attainment of the State of Unity. tatpara (intent): Means being intent only on the principle of that union. mudrāprasādhakaḥ (the perfecter of the Seals): There are four Seals. The perfecter of the four Seals means the one who has completely purified by attaining the nature of Voidness. abhedyavajra (the indivisible Vajras): The indivisible Vajras are the Tathāgatas. yoga (union): The union of the Vajras refers to a stabilised meditative state. samudbhava (originates): Means originating in that stabilised meditative state. yathā (as): Means as you do for the benefit of the world. tat (the same): Means in a similar manner. vibho (O Lord): Means O ruler.
'dam dang 'dra ba ni 'dam ste 'khor ba'o/ / tshogs zhes bya ba ni spungs pa'o/ / der bying ba bdag la skyobs zhes bya ba skyabs mdzod cig pa ste/ skyabs med bdag la zhes bya bar sbyar ro/ /

saṃsārapaṅkasaṃghāte (in the thick mud of phenomenal existence): Means in the midst of phenomenal existence. magno ’haṃ (I am sunk in): Means I am sunk in the midst of phenomenal existence. trāhi (save): Means save me. aśaraṇaṃ (no resort): Here the implication is that I have no other resort.
miṣṭānnapānakhādyañ ca madanaṃ balaṃ mahattaraṃ || (20) dhūpan naivedyaṃ mālyañ ca ghanṭhādhvajavilepanaiḥ || ābhiḥ pūjādibhiḥ śiṣyaḥ pūjayed vajradhāriṇaṃ || (21)

zhim pa'i bza' ba btung ba dag / pa la che mchog ma da na/ / bdug pa lha bshos phreng ba dang / / dril bu rgyal mtshan byug pa yis/ / 'di rnams mchod pa rnams kyis ni/ / slob mas rdo rje 'dzin pa mchod/ /
The disciple should honour the bearer of the Vajra with pleasing food and drink, wine and meat of fine quality, incense, sacrificial oblations, garlands, bells, banners and anointments.

zhim pa'i zhes bya ba ni shin tu zhim par sems pa'o/ / bza' ba btung ba dang zhes bya ba ni mdor bstan pa'o/ / chang dang sha chen zhes bya ba ni rgyas par bshad pa'o/ / rdo rje 'dzin pa zhes bya ba ni gnyis su med pa'i ye shes 'dzin pa ste bla ma'o/ /

miṣṭa (pleasing): Means tasty and refers to both food and drink. mahattaraṃ (fine quality): Wine and meat of a fine quality are recommended. vajradhāriṇaṃ (the bearer of the Vajra): Refers to the guru who bears the non-dual knowledge.

paramānande tu saṃprāpte nānātvavarjite kṣaṇe || śāstā brūyāt mahāsattva dhāraṇīyaṃ mahat sukhaṃ || (22) yāvad ā bodhiparyantaṃ sattvārthaṃ kuru vajradhṛk || ity evaṃ vadate vajrī śiṣyaṃ vīkṣyā kṛpācayaṃ || (23) etad eva mahājñānaṃ sarvadehe vyavasthitaṃ || advayaṃ dvayarūpañ ca bhāvābhāvātmakaṃ prabhuṃ || (24) sthiracalaṃ vyāpya saṃtiṣṭhet māyārūpi ca bhāti ca || maṇḍalacakrādyupāyena sātatyaṃ yāti niścayaṃ || (25)

mchog tu dga' ba yang dag thob/ / sna tshogs spangs pa'i skad cig la/ / ston pas smras pa sems dpa' che/ / bde ba chen po rnam par gzung / / ji srid byang chub bar du ni/ / sems can don gyis rdo rje 'dzin/ / slob ma snying rje can mthong nas/ / rdo rje can gyis 'di skad smras/ / 'di ni ye shes chen po nyid/ / thams cad lus la rnam par gnas/ / gnyis dang gnyis su med pa'i tshul/ / dngos dang dngos med bdag nyid gtso/ / brtan dang g.yo ba khyab nas gnas/ / sgyu ma'i gzugs can nyid du 'dod/ / dkyil 'khor 'khor lo'i thabs kyis ni/ / rtag tu nges par 'gro bar 'gyur/ /

When the disciple has fully attained the Moment of the Refined Joy which is devoid of all notions of diversity, the Master should say: ‘O great Being, hold the Great Bliss. Until the attainment of Enlightenment, O bearer of the Vajra, act for the benefit of beings.’ In this manner, the Adamantine One, full of mercy, should command the disciple. ‘This is in fact the Great Knowledge located in all bodies which is non-dual as well as of dual nature and is the Lord whose essence is both existence and non-existence. It dwells pervading both fixed and moving things, and manifests as illusory forms. By utilising the Maṇḍala Circle and so on the eternal state is attained without doubt.’

mchog tu dga' ba zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ thob ces bya ba ni shin tu gnas pa'o/ / sna tshogs spangs pa zhes bya ba ni lhan cig skyes pa zhes bya ba ste bzhi pa'o/ / sems dpa' che zhes bya ba ni slob mas rtogs par bya ba'i phyir bde ba ste/ ye shes 'di ni ches phra zhing / / zhes bya ba la sogs pa'i tshigs su bcad pas so/ / bde ba chen po'i rnam par zung / / zhes bya ba ni man ngag ji lta ba bzhin du rjes su gnang ba sbyin pa'o/ / ji srid ces bya ba la sogs pas ni 'chad par 'gyur ba'i mtshan nyid can gyi rjes su gnang ba mdor bstan to/ / dbang bskur zhes bya ba ni dbang bskur bas dbang bskur ba'o/ / bya ba kun zhes bya ba ni bya ba'i tshogs so/ / rdo rje can zhes bya ba ni bla ma'o/ /

saṃprāpte (has fully attained): Means has generated, that is, has gone beyond. nānātvavaijite (devoid of all notions of diversity): Refers to the Innate, that is, the fourth Moment. mahāsattva dhāraṇiyaṃ mahat sukhaṃ (great Being, hold the great bliss): After calling the disciple and instructing him with ‘this knowledge is very subtle’ and so on [2.12.4], the disciple is commanded to hold the Great Bliss. Give this instruction as is appropriate. yāvad ityādi (until etc.): With this statement the characteristic of the knowledge which will be discussed next is indicated. śiṣyaṃ vīkṣya ityādi (looking at the disciple etc.): Disciple here refers to the one who has been consecrated by the first three consecrations in accordance with the appropriate rites. vajrī (the Adamantine One): Refers to the guru who should speak in this manner.

'di skad smra zhes bya ba ni ci zhig smra zhe na/ 'di nyid ces bya ba la sogs pa ste 'di nyid ces bya ba ni dbang bskur ba thob pa'i lhan cig skyes pa'i ye shes chen po nyid do/ / thams cad la zhes bya ba ni phyag rgya bzhi lus la gnas pa'o/ / gnyis su med pa ni thabs dang shes rab gnyis su snang ba dang bral ba nyid do/ / gnyis ni de dag nyid kyi ngo bo'o/ / dngos dang dngos med bdag nyid ces bya ba ni mchog tu dga' ba dang / / dga' ba dang dga' bral gyi ngo bo'o/ / gtso bo zhes bya ba ni dga' ba gsum pos las mchog tu gyur pa'o/ / brtan ni chos dang dam tshig phyag rgya bsgoms pa'o/ / g.yo ba ni phyi rol gyi phyag rgya dang snyoms par 'jug pa'o/ / de dag thams cad la khyab nas gnas pa yang 'di nyid do/ / sgyu ma'i gzugs can zhes bya ba ni sprul pa sna tshogs lta bu'o/ / de lta na 'di thabs gang gis 'grub par 'gyur zhe na/ dkyil 'khor 'khor lo'i zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ sogs zhes bya ba'i sgras ni phyag rgya gnyis kyi man ngag dang / dpa' bo gcig pu la sogs pa la mos pa yang bsdu'o/ /

What is it that he has to further say? This is said by: etad eva (this is in fact): Refers to the knowledge obtained from the consecration. mahājñānaṃ (the Great Knowledge): It is said to be ‘Great Knowledge’ because it is the Innate. sarvadehe vyavasthitaṃ (located in all bodies): Means located in the corpus of the four Seals. advayaṃ (non-dual): Means devoid of the manifestation of the duality of Wisdom and Means. dvayarūpaṃ (dual nature): Means of the nature of the two, Wisdom and Means. bhāvābhāvātmakaṃ (essence is both existence and non-existence): Means the nature of Refined Joy and the Joy of Cessation respectively. prabhu (Lord): ‘Lord’ because of being the prime cause of the [first] three Joys. sthiraṃ (fixed): Refers to the emanation of the Seal of Essential Nature (dharmamudrā) and the Seal of the Sacrament (samayamudrā). calaṃ (moving): Refers to the Attainment of the State of Unity with an external consort. vyāpya saṃtiṣṭhet (it dwells pervading): Means it abides by pervading all things. māyārūpī (illusory forms): This is because this Knowledge creates manifold forms. In that case, how the eternal is attained is said by: maṇḍala ityādi (Maṇḍala etc.): In this context ‘and so on’ refers to the collection of instructions regarding the two consorts, the actualization of the Sole Hero and other practices.
atha sarvayoginīnāṃ bhaginīnāṃ mṛṣitvā Vajragarbho bhagavantaṃ evaṃ āha || maṇḍalacakraṃ kim ucyeta sarvabuddhātmakaṃ puraṃ || deśayantu yathānyāyaṃ bhagavanto bhrāntir me 'bhūt || (26)

de nas rdo rje snying pos rnal 'byor ma rnams la bzod par gsol nas/ bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / dkyil 'khor 'khor lo ci zhes brjod/ / sangs rgyas kun bdag grong khyer la/ / bcom ldan bdag ni 'khrul gyur pas/ / rim pa ji ltar bshad du gsol/ /

Then Vajragarbha, requesting all the sister Yoginīs to be patient, spoke to the Bhagavān thus: Why is the Maṇḍala Circle known as the abode of the essence of all the Buddhas? May the Bhagavān correctly instruct, for I have misconceptions.

yang na zhes bya ba ni dkyil 'khor gyi 'khor lo'i sgras phyag rgya chen po'i man ngag gzung ngo / / bzod pa gsol nas zhes bya ba ni bzod par gyis shig ces byas nas/ gsol to zhes bya ba ni zhus par gyur pa'o/ / sangs rgyas thams cad kyis gang bar gyur pas na grong khyer ro/ / ci zhes bya ba ni gang gi phyir zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

atha (then): Then Vajragarbha, saying ‘Maṇḍala Circle’ etc., begging pardon, asked for instructions on the Mahāmudrā. puraṃ (abode): It is known as the abode because it is filled with all the Buddhas. kiṃ (why): Means for what reason.
'khrul gyur pas zhes bya ba ni bdag the tshom dang ldan par gyur ces bya ba'i don to/ /
bhagavān āha || maṇḍalaṃ sāram ity uktaṃ bodhicittaṃ mahat sukhaṃ || ādānan tat karotīti maṇḍalaṃ malanaṃ mataṃ || (27)
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / dkyil ni snying po zhes brjod de/ / byang chub sems ni bde chen po/ / len par byed pas dkyil 'khor nyid/ / 'dus pa dkyil 'khor nyid du brjod/ /
Bhagavān said: Maṇḍala is said to be the essence, the Enlightened Consciousness and the great bliss. Maṇḍala is so called because it holds the Great Bliss, that is, bears it.

dkyil 'khor zhes bya ba la sogs pa la dkyil zhes bya ba ni snying po zhes bya ba'i rnam grangs so/ / snying po de ci zhig ce na/ byang chub sems ni bde chen po/ /zhes bya ba gsungs te/ nyon mongs pa dang nye ba'i nyon mongs pa ma lus pas bskyed pa'i sdug bsngal dang bral ba'i mtshan nyid can no/ / de len pa ni bdag gir byed pa'o/ / de yis zhes bya ba ni bde ba chen po'i ye shes so/ / 'dus pa ni sangs rgyas thams cad dang mnyam par sbyor ba ste/ 'di lta bu ni don dam pa'i dkyil 'khor zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

maṇḍalaṃ ityādi (Maṇḍala etc.): The word ‘Maṇḍala’ is synonymous with essence. The nature of this essence is expressed by: bodhicittaṃ mahat sukham (the Enlightened Consciousness which is the great bliss): Great Bliss is the characteristic of the erotic play which destroys the sorrows arising from all the afflictions and molestations. ādānan (holds): Means gives possession of. tat (it): Refers to the knowledge of Great Bliss. malanaṃ (bears): Means is the meeting place of all the Buddhas. This is the supreme maṇḍala.
cakraṃ nivahaṃ khadhātvākhyaṃ viṣayādīnāṃ viśodhaṇaṃ || bolakakkolayogena tasya saukhyaṃ pratīyate || (28)
'khor lo zhes bya nam mkha'i khams/ / yul la sogs pa rnam par sbyang / / bo la kak+ko la sbyor bas/ / de yi bde ba shes par 'gyur/ /

The Circle is an assembly and having the nature of the Space element, it is that which purifies the sense objects and other aggregates. By the union of the male and female sexual organs the bliss of the Circle is experienced.

'khor lo ltar zhes bya ba ni bde ba chen po'i mtshan nyid can no/ / gnas zhes pa ni snying rje chen po'o/ / nam mkha'i khams ni chos thams cad kyi stong pa nyid do/ / yul la sogs pa rnam par sbyong zhes bya ba ni de dag ro gcig par gyur pa'i 'od gsal ba'i mtshan nyid do/ / rdo rje ni snying rje chen po'i rang bzhin gyi sems rdo rje'o/ / pad+ma ni chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin no/ / de dag man ngag ji lta ba bzhin du yang dag par sbyor ba ni sbyor ba'o/ / de'i zhes bya ba ni phyag rgya chen po'i de'o/ / bde ba ni 'od gsal ba'i mtshan nyid can no/ / shes par gyur ces bya ba ni rtogs par gyur nas zhes bya ba'i don to/ /

cakraṃ (the Circle): The Circle is characterised by the Great Bliss. nivahaṃ (assembly): Refers to Compassion. khadhātu (Space element): Refers to the Voidness of All Things which is the purification of the sense objects and other aggregates. The unified essence of Compassion and Voidness is the Innate Radiance (prabhāsvara). bola (the male sexual organ): Here refers to the Adamantine Mind which is full of Great Compassion. kakkola (female sexual organ): Refers to the primordial state of all things, Voidness. yogena (by the union): ‘Union’ refers to the uniting of the two, male and female sexual organs, according to instructions. tasya saukhyaṃ pratīyate (the bliss of the Circle is experienced): Means that by the union the bliss of the Mahāmudrā, which is characterised as Innate Radiance, is generated. This is the intent.
gsol ba zhes bya ba ni rdo rje snying po mgu bar gyur nas so/ /
Being satisfied with the Bhagavān’s reply, Vajragarbha further asked:
Vajragarbha āha || kena samayena sthātavyaṃ kena saṃvareṇeti ||
rdo rje snying pos gsol pa/ sdom pa zhes bya gang gis dang / / dam tshig gang gis gnas par bgyi/ /
Vajragarbha asked: By what Observance of the Vow and by what Observance of the Concealed Essence should the yogī abide?
ci'i phyir gsol zhe na/ rnal 'byor bla na med pa 'dir dam tshig dang sdom pa ma gsungs pas de'i phyir gsol ba'o/ /

What was the purpose of this question? He asked regarding the Observance of the Vow (samaya) and the Observance of the Concealed Essence (saṃvara) in the highest stage of the practice since they have so far not been mentioned.
In order to explain that Bhagavān replied:

bhagavān āha || prāṇinaś ca tvayā ghātyā vaktavyaṃ ca mṛṣāvacaḥ || adattañ ca tvayā grāhyaṃ sevanaṃ parayoṣitaḥ || (29) ekacittaṃ prāṇivadhaṃ [proktaṃ] prāṇa cittaṃ yato mataṃ || lokañ uttārayiṣyāmi mṛṣāvādañ ca śabditaṃ || yoṣicchukraṃ adattañ ca paradārāḥ svābhasundarī || (30)

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ / khyod kyis srog chags bsad pa dang / / brdzun gyi tshig kyang smra ba dang / / khyod kyis ma byin par yang long / / pha rol bud med bsten par gyis/ / sems gcig srog chags gsod pa nyid/ / gang phyir srog ni sems su brjod/ / 'jig rten bsgral ba zhes bya ba/ / brdzun gyi tshig tu rab tu bsgrags/ / btsun mo'i khu ba ma byin par/ / gzhan gyi bud med rang mtshungs mdzes/ /

Bhagavān replied: [As the Observance of the Vow] you should kill living beings, speak lies, take what is not given and service others’ wives. [As the Observance of the Concealed Essence] one-pointedness of thought is the killing of living beings, for the thought is the very life breath; to vow to save all beings is the speaking of lies; the sexual fluid of the woman is that which is not given and others’ wives are the beautiful ones who are one’s own.

khyod kyis srog chags gsad pa dang / /zhes bya ba ni mdor bstan pa'o/ / 'di dag nyid kyi bshad pa ni sems gcig ces bya ba la sogs pa ste/ sems kyi rang bzhin 'od gsal ba'i ngo bo nyid thob par 'gyur ba ni sems gcig pa nyid de/ de ni srog chags gsod pa'o/ / de ji ltar yin zhe na/ gang phyir srog ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa gsungs te/ gang gi phyir srog chags rnams kyi srog tu gyur pa ni sems nyid do/ / 'di skye ba med nyid ni gcod pa'o/ / 'jig rten zhes bya ba la sogs pa la/ bsgral ba zhes bya ba nyid [{]brdzun [,]rdzun [}]gyi tshig ste/ don dam par sems can gyi 'jig rten mi dmigs pa'i phyir ro zhes bya bar dgongs pa'o/ / btsun mo zhes bya ba ni rdo rje'i btsun mo'o/ / de'i khu ba ni gnyis su med pa'i ye shes te/ de yang 'phags pa'i lam bsgom pas thob pa yin pas de'i phyir ma byin par len pa'o/ / rang mtshungs mdzes zhes bya ba ni bdag med ma la sogs pa'o/ / de ji ltar gzhan gyi bud med yin zhe na/ mchog tu phul du byung ba nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

prāṇinaś ca ityādi (living beings etc.): This is the brief and simple description [and the Observance of the Vow]. It’s concealed meaning is elucidated by: ekacittaṃ ityādi (one-pointedness of thought etc.): The one-pointedness of thought is the attainment of the Innate Radiance and this is the killing of living beings. Why this is so is said by: prāṇa ityādi (life breath etc.): Since thought arises from the life breath, the very non-arising of thought is the killing. lokān ityādi (all beings etc.): To vow to save is the lie, because the world of living beings is not real in terms of the absolute truth. This is the intent. yoṣit (woman): Refers to the Vajra lady. sukraṃ (sexual fluid): The sexual fluid of the Vajra lady refers to the non-dual knowledge. adattaṃ (not given): The sexual fluid is what is not given because it is attained by means of a non-dual emanation. svābhasundarī (the beautiful ones who are one’s own): Refers to Nairātmyā and the other Yoginīs. How are they the wife of others (para)? Because of their most (parama) excellent nature.
atha sarvayoginyo bhagavantaṃ evam āhuḥ || ke punas te viṣayāḥ kānīndriyāṇi kim āyatanaṃ kathame skandhāḥ || ke punas te dhātavaḥ || eṣāṃ kiṃ svabhāvaṃ || (31)

de nas rnal 'byor ma thams cad kyis bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / yul de rnams kyang ci lags/ dbang po rnams ni gang lags/ skye mchid ni ci lags/ phung po rnams ni gang lags/ khams rnams de yang ci lags/ 'di rnams kyi rang bzhin ni ci lags/

Then all the Yoginīs asked the Bhagavān: What are the objects of sensory experience? What are the sensory organs? What are the faculties? How many aggregates are there? What are the essential aspects [of experience]? What is their intrinsic nature?
'di rnams kyi rang bzhin ci lags zhes bya ba ni yul la sogs pa rnams kyi'o/ /
eṣaṃ (their): Refers to the objects of sensory experience and the other aggregates.
bhagavān āha || ṣaḍ viṣayāḥ / rūpa śabdas tathā gandho rasa sparśas tathaiva ca || dharmadhātusvabhāvaś ca ṣaḍ ete viṣayā matāḥ || (32)
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ yul drug ni/ gzugs sgra de bzhin dri dang ni/ / ro dang de bzhin reg bya dang / / chos kyi khams kyi rang bzhin nyid/ / 'di rnams yul ni drug tu brjod/
Bhagavān replied: There are six objects of sensory experience. They are form, sound, smell, taste, touch and the sixth, thought, which is characterised by the Source of Nature.
indriyāṇi ca ṣaṭ || cakṣuḥ śrotraṃ ca ghrāṇañ ca jihvā kāyo manas tathā || mohavajrādibhir yuktāḥ ṣaḍ etānīndriyāṇi ca || (33)
dbang po rnams ni drug ste/ mig dang rna ba sna dang ni/ / lce dang lus dang de bzhin yid/ / 'di rnams dbang po drug po ni/ / gti mug rdo rje la sogs ldan/ /
There are six sensory organs. They are the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, skin and the mind. These six are associated with the adamantine goddess of Delusion (mohavajrā) and other goddesses.
gti mug rdo rje la sogs ldan/ /zhes bya ba ni ji ltar 'chad par 'gyur ba'o/ / dbang po drug ces bya ba ni mig la sogs pa'o/ /
mohavajrādibhiḥ (with the adamantine goddess of Delusion and the other goddesses): Refers to the appropriate allocations which will be mentioned later. ṣaḍ etāni (these six): Refer to the eyes etc.
viṣayavaiṣayikābhyāṃ ca dvādaśāyatanaṃ bhavet || pañcaskandhāś ca rūpādyā vijñānāntā mahākṛpa || (34)
yul dang yul can dag gis ni/ / skye mched pa nu gnyis dag tu 'gyur/ / phung po lnga ni gzugs la sogs/ / mthar ni rnam shes snying rje che/ /

The six qualities and the six organs of sensory experience comprise the twelve faculties. There are five components to the aggregate of phenomenal awareness, beginning with the Form component and ending with the component of the Awareness of Phenomena. O Being of great mercy.
yul dang yul can zhes bya ba ni mig la sogs pa'o/ / 'du byed tha ma zhes bya ba ni rnam par shes pa bar du ston pa'o/ /

viṣayavaiṣayikābhyāṃ (the six qualities and the six organs of sensory experience): These are the eyes and so on. pañcaskandhāḥ (five components to the aggregate of phenomenal awareness): The first is the Form component, then there are the components of Sensation, Conceptualisation and Imprints of Past Actions, and then the last which is the component of the Awareness of Phenomena.
indriyaṃ viṣayaṃ caiva indriyavijñānam eva ca || dhātavo 'ṣṭādaśākhyātā yoginīnāṃ tu bodhaye || (35)
dbang po dang ni yul nyid dang / / dbang po'i rnam par shes pa nyid/ / rnal 'byor ma rnams go bya'i phyir/ / khams ni bcwa brgyad rnams su bshad/ /
For the information of yoginīs there are eighteen essential aspects, comprising of six organs, the six objects and the six awarenesses of sensory experience.
rnal 'byor ma rnams zhes bya ba ni las dang po pa'i rnal 'byor ma rnams so/ / go bya'i phyir zhes bya ba ni rab tu rtogs par bya ba'i phyir ro/ /
yoginīnāṃ tu bodhaye (for information of the Yoginīs): Means for introducing to the novice Yoginīs. The nature of all these is said by:
svabhāvam ādyanutpannaṃ na satyaṃ na mṛṣā tathā || udakacandropamaṃ sarvaṃ yoginyo jānatecchayā || (36)
rang bzhin gdod nas ma skyes pa/ / brdzun min bden min de bzhin du/ / thams cad chu yi zla ba ltar/ / 'dod pas rnal 'byor mas shes kyis/ /
Their intrinsic nature is that of primordial non-arising and is neither true nor false. Their nature is like the reflection of the moon in water. Know this if you wish, O Yoginīs.

'di rnams kyi rang bzhin ci zhig ce na/ gdod nas ma skyes zhes bya ba gsungs te/ gdod ma nas skye ba med pa'i ngo bo nyid do/ / de ltar na snang bar ji ltar 'gyur zhe na/[ {]brdzun [,]rdzun [}]min bden min zhes bya ba gsungs te/ ji ltar snang bar 'gyur ba nyid ni [{]brdzun [,]rdzun [}]pa nyid yin pa'i phyir bden pa yang ma yin [{]brdzun [,]rdzun [}]pa yang ma yin pa'o/ / chu'i zla ba zhes bya ba la sogs pa ni rang bzhin yang gzhan yin la snang ba yang gzhan yin pa nyid do/ / shes gyis zhes bya ba ni shes par gyis shig pa'o/ / 'dod pas zhes bya ba ni ltar 'dod pa'i dbang gis so/ /

ādyanutpannaṃ (primordial non-arising): Means that from the very beginning itself they are of a non-arising nature. How do they manifest? na satyaṃ na ṃrṣā (neither true nor false): They are like a deceptive manifestation which is neither true nor false. udakacandropamaṃ (like the reflection of the moon in water): Their nature is like the reflection of the moon in water because a variety of natures are falsely manifested. jānata (know): Means understand. icchayā (if you wish): Means according to one’s desire.

tad yathā kāṇḍañ ca mathanīyaṃ ca puruṣahastavyāyāmañ ca pratītyākasmād agnir upajāyate || asāv agnir na kāṇḍe tiṣṭhati || na mathanīye na puruṣahastavyāyāme || sarvākārataḥ parigaveṣyamānaḥ || ekasminn api nāsti • sa cāgnir na satyaṃ na mṛṣā || evaṃ sarvadharmān yoginyo manasikuruta || (37)

'di lta ste/ gtsub shing dang gtsub stan dang skyes bu'i lag pa'i rtsol ba las glo bur du me skye bar 'gyur ro/ / me 'di ni gtsub shing la yang mi gnas/ gtsub stan la yang mi gnas/ skyes bu'i lag pa dag la yang ma yin te/ rnam pa thams cad du yongs su btsal na gcig na'ang yod pa ma yin pas me de yang bden pa yang ma yin zhing brdzun pa yang ma yin no/ /de ltar chos thams cad rnal 'byor mas yid la gyis shig /

It is like this: from a fire-drilling stick, a branch and the effort of a man’s hands, without any apparent connection fire suddenly from nowhere arises. This fire is not located in the fire-drilling stick and neither is it in the branch nor is it in the effort of a man’s hands. Even if carefully examined from all aspects it is not found in any one of these individually. This fire is neither true nor false. O Yoginīs, you should similarly conceive of all natures.

gtsub shing zhes bya ba ni gtsub par byed pa'o/ / gtsub stan zhes bya ba ni gtsub par bya ba'i gzhi'o/ / skyes bu'i lag pa'i rtsol ba zhes bya ba ni bya ba'o/ / glo bur du zhes bya ba ni de dag la yod pa ma yin na yang ngo / / yod pa ma yin pas zhes bya ba ni dmigs par ma gyur pa'o/ / bden pa ma yin zhing zhes bya ba ni gcig dang du ma'i rang bzhin dang bral ba'i phyir ro/ / [{]brdzun [,]rdzun [}]pa yang ma yin zhes bya ba ni de lta bur snang bar gyur pa nyid kyi phyir ro/ / yid la gyis shig ces bya ba ni yid la zungs shig pa'o/ /

kāṇḍaṃ (fire-drilling stick): Refers to the piece of wood kept vertically when rubbing for fire. mathanīyaṃ (a branch): Refers to the base upon which the rubbing for fire is performed. puruṣahastavyāyāmaṃ (the effort of a man’s hands): Refers to the action of kindling fire. akasmād (suddenly out of nowhere): Means even from examining these three it is not possible to know where the fire is located within them. na satyaṃ (not true): The fire is not true because it is devoid of the quality of one and many. na mṛṣā (not false): The fire is not false because it manifests. manasi kuruta (should conceive): Means should bear this in mind.
atha Nairātmyayoginīpramukhāḥ sarvavajraḍākinyaḥ pañcāmṛtaṃ gṛhītvā samayadravyañ ca bhagavantaṃ Vajrasattvaṃ pūjayanti || kunduruyogenānurāgayanti • pibayanti ca vajrāmṛtarasaṃ || (38)

de nas rnal 'byor ma bdag med ma la sogs pa rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma thams cad kyis bdud rtsi lnga thogs shing dam tshig gi rdzas thogs pas bcom ldan 'das rdo rje sems dpa' la mchod par byed/ kun tu ru'i sbyor bas rjes su chags par byed/ bdud rtsi lnga'i ro yang 'thung bar byed do/ /

Then all the Vajraḍākinīs with Nairātmyā in the forefront, partaking of the Five Nectars and the Sacrament of the Union, worshipped Bhagavān Vajrasattva. They amorously delight in the sexual union and drink the juicy nectar Of the Vajra.
'thung bar byed do zhes bya ba ni ngoms par 'thung ba'o/ / rdo rje bdud rtsi zhes bya ba ni byang chub kyi sems kyi ro'o/ /
pibayanti (drink): Means eagerly drank. vajrāmṛtarasaṃ (the juicy nectar of the Vajra): Means the Bodhicitta fluid (semen).
tataḥ paścād bhagavāṃs tuṣṭe sati adhiṣṭhānaṃ darśayanti || bho bho vajraḍākinyo mayā guptīkṛtaṃ tattvaṃ sarvair buddhair namaskṛtaṃ || vajrapūjāprabhāvena kathayāmi śṛṇutecchayā || (39)

de nas bcom ldan 'das dgyes nas rang byin gyis brlabs pa bstan pa/ kye kye rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma/ / sangs rgyas kun gyis phyag mdzad pa'i/ / de nyid bdag gis gsang mdzad pa/ / rdo rje mchod pa'i byin brlabs kyis/ / bshad kyis 'dod pas rab tu nyon/ /

After that, Bhagavān being satisfied, revealed the Empowerment to the Yoginīs. [Bhagavān said:] Well done, well done O Vajraḍākinīs! Compelled by the power of your worship of the Vajra I shall expound that principle which I have so far kept secret and which is respected by all the Buddhas. Listen if you so wish.

dgyes nas zhes bya ba ni dgyes par gyur nas so/ / shin tu spros pa med pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi spyod pa gang gis byin gyis brlabs pa'i phyir/ rdo rje sems dpar byin gyis brlab pa bstan pa zhes bya ba ste/ rab tu ston to zhes bya ba'i don to/ / de kho na nyid thob pa'i rgyu ni de nyid ces bya ba'o/ / mchod pa nyid ni rdo rje ste brtan par gyur pa'i phyir ro/ / 'dod pas zhes bya ba ni mgu bas so/ /

tuṣṭe sati (being satisfied): Means being in a satisfied state. adhiṣṭhānaṃ darśayanti (revealed the Empowerment): The Applica- tion of the Vow which is of an extremely undifferentiated nature, the diligent application of which is Vajrasattva is empowered, is highlighted. This is the intent. tattvaṃ (that principle): Refers to that principle which leads to the attainment of the truth. vajrapūjā (worship of the Vajra): Here, the making of the Vajra hard is the worship. It is called Vajra, the adamantine, because of it’s firmness. icchayā (if... so wish): Means respectfully attend.
atha utsāhaprāptāḥ sarvā devyo dakṣiṇaṃ jānumaṇḍalaṃ pṛthivyām pratiṣṭhāpya yena bhagavāṃs tenāñjaliṃ praṇamya bhagavato bhāṣitaṃ śṛṇvanti / (40)
lha mo thams cad dga' bar 'gyur/ / rangs par gyur te pus mo g.yas pa'i lha nga sa la btsugs nas/ bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der thal mo sbyar ba btud nas bcom ldan 'das kyi gsung nyan to/ /
